





BIBLIOTHECA
SCHOLASTICA. 
A DOVBLE DICTIONARIE, 
Penned for all those that would haue within short
space the vse of the Latin tongue, either to speake, or write. 
Verie profitable and necessarie for Scholers, Courtiers, Lawyers and their
Clarkes, Apprentices of London, Travellers, Factors for Marchants, 
and briefly for all Discontinuers within her Majesties Realmes
of England and Ireland. 
Compiled by Iohn Rider, Master of Artes, and preacher of Gods word. 

First reade me. 
With others conferre me.
Then censure me.
Read the Preface, Learne the vse. 

Printed by Ioseph Barnes, Printer to the Vniversitie of Oxford, and
are to be sold at the Tygers head in Paules Church-yarde. 1589. 
Cum privilegio Regiæ Majestatis. 










CLARISSIMO VIRO, AC BONARVM
LITERARVM SVMMO PATRONO, D. FRANCISCO
WALSINGHAMO, EQVITI AVRATO, DVCATVS
Lancastrensis Cancellario, & Regiæ Majestatis à sacris
Consilijs, et Secretario principali. I. R. Fælicitatem 
precatur perpetuam. 

SERIVS omnino quàm volebam, aliquando ta­
men novus hic partus in lucem prodijt, quod
flagitabam equidem quotidie: quippè in partu­
riendo, Ætnam humeris meis (donec prolem in
amplexu habuerim) mihi sustinere videbar. Sed
in orbis theatrum prodijt tandem, et tuis auspicijs
(Illustrissime Walsinghame) prodijt, quò me
summa de tua singulari humanitate concepta
spes, et magna quedam approbandæ tibi, si minus 
eruditionis, at certè voluntatis meæ, cupiditas impulit. Quem enim vs­
piam hominum mortalium hac doctorum tempestate melius compel­
larent literæ, quam illum ipsum, qui literas & literatos omnes incre­
dibili amore prosequitur, eosque apud sui similes, apud dissimiles, apud
vniversos, plurimi facit, et veneratur? Et (vt interim taceam de ceteris vir
tutibus tuis) vtráque te Accademia laudant, suspiciunt, et admirantur. 
Quippè a te lumen, a te subsidium habent, tuique ipsius magnificentia
adauctum sibi honorem sentiunt. Sed plura non addam, Amplitudo tua lau­
des istas, tametsi justas, et meritas, rarò et ægrè feret. Potuit quidem vir
summus, hoc quicquid est operæ & industriæ nostre, nobilisimus heros
COMES SVSSEXIÆ (cui privatim sum ex officio devotus)
jure quasi suo vendicare: potuit etiam vir ornatissimus, GVLI­
ELMVS WAADVS, (qui mihi et auctor in consilijs capiendis, et
adjutor in rebus ag&etilde;dis extitit) non repetere modò sed assumere etiam, 
et quodam modo postulare: vterque tamen mihi dij consulares, tibique
intimi, non solum suaserunt, sed etiam persuaserunt, vt te deum mortalem
et tutelarem mihi eligerem, tuamque amplitudinem enixè et vehemen­
ter rogarem, vt primum hunc meum infantulum, adhuc rudem et impo­
litum, honorificè adoptares. Pater sum, sed inops, non possum alere: pa­
ter sum, sed impotens, non possum adversus malarum bestiarum morsus
dentesque defendere. Nudus est adhuc infans, patre opulento: infirmus




est patrono forti & magnanimo opus habet. Te igitur (vir honoratissime)
obsecro & obtestor, vt ei pater & patronus fias; vtque; tuis foœlicibus auspicijs
è fascijs suis in lucem exeat, vagire desinat: Syllabas, voces, sensus articu­
latim enunciare discat, doceat tyrones & commilitones suos, Reipub, de­
corè et officiose inserviat. Dum tenerior est, quæso, sub scuto tuo se
totum tegat, ne Momus lingua, ne Zoilus vngue infantem vul­
neret. Te Deus opt. max. incolumem Reipub. Aca­
demiæ, mihique; diutissimè conservet. 
Oxoniæ Calend. Octob. 

Honori tuo devinctiss. 

Iohannes Riderus. 







Rideri gratitudinis carmen, ad suum
prænobilem Mecœnatem. 

Cura fuit patriæ prodesse, iuvare tenellos, 
Omnia quæ patitur studij nocumenta Iuventus
Mollis; seu cæcum vulgus dispellere: cura, 
Ingenium, votum, vires superasset, & illud
Triste fuisset opus, tua ni Comes inclyte cura
Ingenium, vires, votum relevasset. In illo

Subsidio superavit opus labor improvus: ecce
Vox, vires, vita, & votum prius excidet omne, 
Solus in extremas fugiam velut exul eremos: 
Signa dabit mortis fugiens calor, omnia mæsto
Eripiet sors sæva mihi: prius hauriet omnes
Xanthi Phœbus aquas; quam mens pro munere tanto
Ingratam, seu non memorem se præbeat. In te
Omnis fixa fuit spes, in te desinet omnis. 

Alteri Mecœnati. 

Virtutis comites te Comitem colunt, 
Virtutem Comitum tu sequeris comes: 
Illorum pietas te trahit, & tua
Lætos hos probitas efficit. Est pia
Illis Relligio, nec minor est tua. 
Ex illis patriæ gloria, de tuis
Lux crescit patriæ vera, laboribus. 
Monstrum terribilem vim Iovis exprimit, 
Ostendit fremitus Oceani truces

Vilis spuma: doeus solis amabile
Vincens vmbra docet: sic opus hoc rude
Ac monstrum genij Gorgoneum mei, 
Divinos animi vult radios tui
Donari solitis laudibus, et suis
Ostendi latebris vt speculo: vale. 

Tuæ salutis studiosissimus
Ioh. Riderus. 








Iohannes Casus adolescentibus linguæ Latinæ studiosis.

A Deste tyrunculi, ad Musas currite: nam molesta & longa via studendi (quæ vobis
in limine metum injecit) tollitur. Brevissimæ stadium, brevissimum artis stu­
dium postulat. Dignus ergò laude is est, qui Prisciani tædium, qui Pythagoræ silenti­
um sustulit. En Bibliothecam, & quasi gazam vobis offert Riderus Anglus. In qua, non
solum literas, syllabas, dictiones Anglolatinas, sed etiam classes, regulas, & syntaxeis
breviter & ingeniose docuit. Nam præter alphabetum, & sylvam verborum, florem il­
lum, Anglicanæ grammatices scriptorem, Lilium,  hic cortex, hic codex redolet. Non est
quod mireris (erudite lector) Auctorem multas in hac sylva spinas, id est, permulta in
hoc opusculo verborum monstra (quæ barbaras dictiones nominat) intrivisse: quippè
apud Oratores istiusmodi (lapide Philosophico, hoc est, ingenio &aamp; arte perpolita) aure­
am speciem, sonum & sensum habent: vt, Lentulitas & Appeitas apud Ciceronem.  Ad­
esdum ergo Papiri ingeniose puer, adeste tyrones, emite multos in hoc vno libello
libros: discite in eo rerum ac verborum pondera, authoris industriam approbate. Ab
edibus meis Oxonij, xxx. Septemb. 1589. 




Io. Vnderhil, S. Theologiæ Doctor. 

QVantum Thomasio Calepinus cedere debet, 
Tantum præclaro Thomasius ipse Ridero. 
Iho. Holland, S. Theologiæ professor Regius. 
Clarus honore Equitis Thomas Eliota, peritus
Iuris, & Angligenæ nobilitatis honos, 
Verba latina Anglo primùm sermone disertè
Reddidit; atque Anglis lexica prima dedit. 
Post ea Couperus librum congessit in vnum
Et Stephani gazas, atque Eliotis opes. 
Herculeus labor ille fuit, nec laurea laudi
Defuit: en volitat docta per ora virûm. 
Thomasius sequitur, quem Granta Academia laudat
Lexica Grammaticis quòd daret apta scholis. 
His Rider accedit, non re verum ἱππὀτα voce
Couperum, Thomam, teque Eliota sequens, 
Et nova verba docet, simul or dine cuncta novato
Digerit, vt nostræ consulat ille scholæ. 

Rob. Rolli. S. Theol. Doct. olim celeberrimæ scholæ
Westmonasterij Ludimagistri, carmen. 

Quædam mole placent, sic quædam mole laborant: 
Omnibus est brevitas grata, placensque locis. 
Sic tamen esse brevis voluit Riderus, vt idem
Lectori ex omni parte probaret opus. 
Vltra alios vocum est superaddita magna supellex, 
Quas operæpretium noscere grande foret. 
Quid multa? exquisitum opus est, vt dicere possis, 
Omnia verba dari, nec tibi verba dari. 

Johannes Estmond Ll: Doctor. 

Prisca licet commista novis sint plurima verba, 
Authorem laudant vtra&qacute;ue verba suum. 




Iohannes Purefey. 

O nimium nostræ ætatis (bona si sua nossent)
Fœlices pueros, qui tua scripta legant!
Siccine fœlices solos? Quin colligat istic
At&qacute;ue habeat magnam Musa senilis opem. 
Ergo tuus Ridere labor velut vtilis omnes
Ante alios, alijs gratior vnus erit. 
En tibi tot grates nostri, quot prodigus illis
Concita verborum flumina fundis, habent. 
Sic tamen esse cupis brevis, & sic multus, vt istud
Ex omni, Lector, parte probaret opus. 

Robertus Cranus Principalis 
Novi Hospitij. 

Arma, tubas, equites, sævi discrimina Martis, 
Et lætas segetes, hæc tibi sume Maro. 
Illa viros forsan delectant Martis alumnos, 
Musarum turbæ sunt ea grata minus. 
Tu pueris Ridere studes, puerilia tractas, 
Verba docere cupis, verbula nulla dare. 
Anglorum formare sonos sermone Latino, 
Mira tu teneros vtilitate doces. 
Parva licet prima videantur fronte, labore
Non parvo texis, nec minor vsus erit. 
Vno Riderus congessit verba libello
Exigui pretij, quæ liber vllus habet. 
Ergo favere viro fas est, qui talia vobis
Cudit, qui tantas accumulavit opes. 
Momus mordaci cesset corrodere dente, 
Iudicium poscit, perlege, lecta placent. 

Tho. Dochen ad lectorem. 

Perlege, sed prudens, cum&qacute;ue ijs qui talia scribunt
Confer, at vt justa, singula, lance probes. 
Post hæc si placeat, spes est, cum laude, volumen
Æternùm genio vivere posse suo. 

R. H. socius Novi Collegij. 

Si varij placeant vno de stemmate, fructus, 
Aut quæ transmutat commoda, læta ratis. 
Anglolatina vno placeant crescentia libro, 
Officiosa, fuit plena labore manus. 




Io. Williams Collegij omnium
animarum Socius. 
Ad librorum & bonarum artium Psyllos. 

Læditur gemma rutilante bufo, 
Læditur puro crocodilus auro, 
Ille fulgorem metuit, vigorem
Iste, nativum fugiens vter&qacute;ue
Evomit virus, fluitante tabo
Sternitur diro moriens vter&qacute;ue. 
Psylle serpentis soboles, avitum
Evomis virus, tua mens veneno
Mergitur, sanguis furijs tepescit, 
Nutriunt atrox aconita pectus, 
Et tibi præbet Crocodilus vber. 
Desinas gemmas hominum vel aurum
Splendidum sævis oculis videre, 
Ni velis gemmis perimi vel auro. 
Desinas duro metuendus ore, 
In pias artes solito furore
Invehi, ructans tua faux cruentam

Exocoquit tabem: soboli Tonantis
Desinas sacris malè velle Musis, 
Ni velis telis reprimi Tonantis. 
Arte deluso populo dolosa
Desinas artes violare, nostros
Desinas fuco iuvenes fovere, 
Ni velis Turcas imitari, & atram
De novo noctem revocare: parce
Quos vides Musis avidè dicatos. 
Byssus ex anguis trahit ore dentes, 
Dente si byssum terit anguis, euge
Psylle, cur byssum laceras Minervæ, 
Ni velis dentes tibi fauce demi. 
Non potes gemmas hominum, vel aurum
Impio flatu maculare. Virus
Effluens perdet tibi membra, noli
Hoc opus gemmis melius, paterno
Rodere morsu. 

Idem ad Lectorem. 

Mens vaga quæ nescit spernit, mens invida mordet
Optima, vult nævos mens inimica novos. 
Lectio censurâ prior est: lege & excute, cense: 
Tum liber, invidia iudice, liber erit. 
Est scelus in vitio virtutem ponere, crimen. 
fingere velle scelus, velle nocere scelus. 

CARMEN IOANNIS PELLING
ad Authorem. 

DOctos, indoctos, omnes, iuvat, edocet, ornat, 
Fida, sacra, eximium, dextra, camœna, decus: 
Hæc tria pol pr&zelig;stat pr&selig;stans opus, arte politum, 
Ordine concinnum, (chare Ridere) tuum. 
Est leve, si pondus pendas, si commoda, lance
Quis trutinet iustâ, grande sacoma librat. 

Ejusdem ad Lectorem. 

Si tibi non placeant, isto digesta libello, 
Si polles, nobis da meliora, precor. 
Si meliora nequis, quæso, da talia saltem, 
Talia si nequeas cur minus ista placent?

Richardus Harley. 

RIderum Coupere tibi non præfero, quamvis
Fœnora Thesauris addidit ampla tuis. 





Namque vocablorum numerosa prole beatus, 
Non genio, sed te fertilitate præit. 

Aliud. 

Anglo-latina cupis libare, Latino vel angla?
Istane, an Illa velis, en tibi malle tuum. 

In Rideri Bibliothecam scholasticam, L. Barfeldus. 

Qui ridere velit tua scripta Ridere, videtur
Rodere, non secus ac mus aliena, mihi. 
Nam quid habet proprium mus? num quid Zoilus offert
Dignum luce suum? carpit vterque tamen. 
Verùm hic ridiculus, dicetur, & invidus alter, 
Alterutrum simili spernere disce modo. 

Iohannes Doue. 

SI quis suggereret moribundi carmen oloris, 
Concinerem laudes (docte Ridere) tuas. 
Sed, quia sum dispar tua qui præconia narrem, 
Carmina vel tanto digna labore canam. 
Ergo posteritas hominum te concinet olim, 
Accedet laudi posthuma fama tuœ. 

Thomas Barsterdus Novi Collegij socius. 

VNo tot monumenta libro? tot condita verba, 
Miranda methodo, classe, tenore, nota?
Quid das Ridero, lector, pro munere tanto?
Grato gratari gratia grata iubet. 

Ioh. Hoskins ejusdem Collegij Socij
Prosopopœa ad Lectorem. 

Omnia vel Res sunt, vel Verba. Sit altera Rerum
Machina, verborum Mundus habebor ego. 
De me igitur lector quodcunque loquare, Latine
Si loqueris, verbis non potes absque meis. 

Laurentius Mychelbornus ex aula Glocestrensi. 

QVicquid posterius, perfectius. Ars iuvat Artem: 
Ætas ætatem, quæ latuere, docet. 
Nil simul, atque semel memorabile prodijt vnquam, 
Sunt incrementis omnia firma suis. 
At dices, Facile est inventis addere, quid si?
Ergo laude caret, qui meliora dedit?
Qui vero inventis plura addidit, addita complet, 
Abdita vestigat, verbaque scabra dolat, 





Indigesta locat, rudia ornat, sparsa reducit, 
Quæque notat, damnat spuria, casta probat, 
Qui nova ab Antiquis, translatis propria, vera
Distinguit falsis, & genuina Nothis, 
Qui leges, vsumque docet, diversaque sensa, 
Cuncta suo ponens ordine, classe, loco, 
Quique Latina Anglis coniungit, & Angla Latinis, 
Ad suadam & Veneres Linguæ vtriusque refert, 
Deinde premi pulchris qui characteribus vrget, 
Omnia in exigui corpus adacta libri: 
Hæc quicunque facit, punctum omne tulisse videtur, 
Et Patria vtiliter consuluisse su&aelig. 
Hæc Ridere nova Methodo dum Lexicon ornas
Fecisti, de te iudicet invidia. 

T. W. 

Publica donavit qui centum æraria libris, 
Annon hunc civem dixeris esse bonum?
Lexica verborum multis qui millibus auxit, 
Ille tibi merito non Philomusus erit?
Tu bonus hic Civis, Philomusus & ille vidêre
Ridere, in fiscum tam pretiosa ferens. 

E. M. ad Lectorem. 

Tradita qui facili Methodo dilucidat aptè, 
Non aliena rapit, sed facit esse sua. 
Ergo Libri nemo sibi vendicet huius ἱὰτα, 
Aut aliquam laudis particulam arripiat. 
Sunt sua de proprio quacunque adiunxerit Author, 
Cætera sed Methodo sunt sua facta sua. 

Aliud. 

Post Lilium nemo est ausus conponere nobis
Grammaticen, post te lexica nemo Rider. 
Fructu & doctrinâ pariter certare videntur, 
Lexica Rideri, Grammatice Lilij. 

P. M. ad lectorem. 

Continet multos liber iste libros, 
Cuilibet pomptus patet & paratus
Vtili fructu, queat ergo dici
Bibliotheca. 
Ambitu nullo miserè laborat
Laudis incertæ, nec inane captat
Nomen: a culpa procul absit Author
Bibliothecæ. 









To the Reader.

OVRTEOVS Reader, I may seeme to some over bold in setting forth a
newe treasure of wordes vnto the world, when the workes of so honorable
and learned men, who haue laboured in this kinde, are so learnedly penned, 
and higly esteemed. In truth I must, and doe most willingly confesse, that
neither in age, witte, learning, or experience, I am to be compared with the
least of them, may vnfit to carie the bookes, where some of the honorable
learned should read the lecture; whose learned labours haue yeelded these
manie years to England great profite. Yet notwithstanding, considering the great vtilitie of a 
Dictionarie, whose matter is manifold, and vse general, and also that no one Dictionarie, as yet
extant, hath the English before the Latine, with a ful Index of al such latine words as are in any
one common Dictionarie amongst vs: and also because the poore estate of most students is not
able to furnish themselues with al such Dictionaries, their several prices amounting to so much;
and also weighing the great want that poore scholers haue in not having most, or al of the com­
mon Dictionaries: I haue thought it good therefore for thy benefite, courteous Reader, to epito­
mize and contract the learned workes of al the learnedst and best Dictionaries in England, with
vs now extant, into a lesser roome, reducing al those learned Volumes into a portable Enchiri­
dion, & into so great treasures to cast, for thy vse, some smal mites of mine owne, which amount
to 4000 wordes more then any one Dictionarie nowe extant affoords. Which I haue done not
without great paines and charges: which heavie burden of charge, if it had not bene supported
by the Right honorable, my very good Lorde, the Earle of Sussex, and the Right worshipfull
Master William Waade Esquier, one of the Clarkes of her Majesties most honourable privie
Counsel, with other of my good loving Parishioners of Barmonsey neere London, & good friends
in and neare Banburie, it might haue bene said of me, as it was of the foolish builder, This man
began to build, but was not able to make an ende. But at last, though long, by Gods providence, 
it is come to this issue, that I must present it (howsoever it be finished) to thy courteous viewe
& friendly censure: requesting thee to reproue with judgement charitably, what I haue overpast, 
in haste: In recompence whereof, I wil be no lesse willing to reforme, then thy courtesie to admonish. 
Thus assuring my selfe, that thou, learned reader, wilt my faultes escaped, either with thy pen cor­
rect, or in courtesie conceale: Remembring that the first shadowes of young painters maie haue
some blemishes, & first editions of young writers, (yea & best works) some faults. I
commit thee, gentle Reader, to his tuition, that must present both thee
and me faultles, in his owne righteousnesse, before the great Iudge
at the comming of our Lord Jesus Christ.  From Oxon. 
this XXX. of September. 

Thine to his power, 
ION. RIDER. 







Directions for the Reader. 

IN the English of every word I obserue vsually this order. First I put the verbe (if it haue any) then
the participle, after the Nownes substantiues, and adjectiues , and lastly the Adverbs. 

In the Latine vnder the English I generally obserue this order. First I place the proper La­
tine word vnder the sigure of 1: then the figuratiue or translate vnder the figure of 2: and lastly
those that be obsolete, or words out of vse, vnder the figure of 3.
 
These words that be old and out of vse, I put them downe, not that in writing any Latine exer­
cise, having other choice, thou shouldst vse them: for to prevent that, I brand them in the forehead
with the figure of 3. But when thou readest them in their several authors, thou shouldest be
eased of a farther toile, in knowing here their significations. 

This note also, that when you see this v.  or this word vide, it sendes you to some such place there
named, where you may finde more concerning that title, or word which you looke for. 

Note where after any Latine nowne you finde m. it signifieth the masculine gender, f. the femi­
nine, n. the neuter, com. g. the common of two gender, and p. a participle, ad. for adjectiue, adu. for
adverbe.

Note also that when the verbe, noune, or participle, alphabetically followe not together in one
place, as buie and bought, sing and song,  &c. then if you finde not the Noune or participle in his place
Alphabetically, nor any reference from thence with this common note vide, looke then vnder the
verbe, as Buie, sung, &c. 

Also if you finde not the word you seeke for presently after one sorte of spelling, condemne mee
not forthwith, but consider how it is vsed to be spelled, whether with double or single letters, as
Chappell, or Chapell: and also when i, and y, are confounded, if you misse the word in the one place, 
take a little paines to turne to the other, as in this word boile, and boyle, for example. 

Also after my first Dictionarie, I haue added certayne generall heads Alphabetically placed: viz. 
of Birdes, Colours, Dogges, Fishes, Hawkes, which theire proper termes, Herbs, Nombers, Stones, Trees, 
Weightes. And also I haue added Calendarium Romanum,  wherein I haue for the benefitte, of
yong students, and scholers, shewed the vse of the Calends, Nones & Ides, by comparing our
Calender with it. Where they may plainely see how to date their Epistles by Calends, Nones, and
Ides, as it was vsed in Tullies time. 

Now therefore (gentle Reader) looke not to finde in this Booke every thing whatsoever thou
wouldest seeke for, as though all things were here so perfect, that nothing lacked, or were possi­
ble to be added herevnto. But if thow maiest onelie finde here the most wordes that thou nee­
dest, or at the least so many as no other Dictionarie nowe extant, hath the like: Take then, I say
in good part this my simple worke. 

For such wordes as you doubt to be false printed in the first, turne to the Second Dictionarie, and
there you shall finde them to be true: yet, I praie thee, amend these faults with thy penne in the
first Dict. Col. 1520, 3. for vntimely death, reade birth: and in the Second Insimulatio,  for Insinuatio. 

Directions for the Second Dictionarie. 

First you haue the word declined at large as far as it is needful, then the Quantities of Syllables accen­
ted, though not so plaine as I could haue wished: but the fault was not in the Printer, but in the
founder that Cast them. 

You haue also the Derivations, Etymologies, Affinities, and Differences of many hundred words, ga­
thered forthe of Martial, Isidor, Tardivus, and other good Authors. 

And also for the vse of Courtiers, Lawiers, Apprentices of London, Travailers, and al Discontinueres, 
whoe haue lost the vse of their Grammar rules by discontinuance, I haue for their sakes, put to
most verbes that be governors, such Case, or Cases, after them, as the verb governeth. As gen: for ge. 
nitivum. Acc.  for Accusativum. Dat. for Dativum. Abl.  for Ablativum. And if it governeth a doble Case
I giue it a doble example, to shewe the vse of it: which Examples you shall finde most of them in
the learned and laborious worke of the right reverend Father in God, my Lord Bishop of Winton.

Note also that wheresoever you find this Capital letter C, it standeth for Cicero. 

Also when you would know the Signification of any latine woorde that is in the Index, or second
Dictionarie, marke what figures be vnder that woord, for the First figures shew the Colume, & the
next the Line of the saide Colume, where you shall see that woorde you seeke for Englished. 

I pray thee (Courteous Reader) think not that I penne this for the learned, but for the vnlear­
ned: if otherwise thou takest mee, thou mistakest me. Yet if the learned will aford me as much fa­
voure, as the courteous Lion did the poore mouse, which was, to lye in his denne, so this my worke
in his studie: it may bee, that sometimes from a snare it may (to requite his courtesie) deliver him. 

Thus hoping that the learned will friendlye accept this woorke, in respect of my paines, and the
vnlearned in respect of their profitte, (not doubting of the friendly entertainement that my worke
shall haue with the Schole master & his scholers, because it will ease the one, and profit the other)
I end, committing thee to the tuition of the Almightie. 







ABA

To Abandon, put a­
way, or forsake. 
1 Amando, amoveo, abji­
cio, relinquo, desero, destituo.
2 Extermino.

destitutus. 2 Exterminatus. p.

destitutor. 2 Exterminator. m.

1 Amandatio, relictio, desertio,

missio, depressio. f.

Consternatio, demissio. f. In­
fractio animi. vid. astonishment.

this age.

Sicke of an Ague.
1 Febriens, febricitans. p.
An Ague or fever.
1 Febris, f.
A little fever or ague.
1 Febricula, f.
An ague whose heat beginneth in
the spirit of the heart, continuing 
commonly but one daie.
Ephemera febris, vel diaria.
An Ague, whose heat beginneth in
the bloode of the hart.
1 Synachus, m.
A consuming ague, whose heate be­
ginneth in the substance of the hart.
1 Hectica, f.
An ague comming by fittes.
1 Febris intermittens. 3 Inter­
vallata febris.
A quotidian ague that commeth 
once every day.
Amphemerina, quotidiana.
A tertian ague that commeth eve­
ry other daie.
1 Tritea, tertiana.
A quartan Ague that commeth
everie third day.
1 Tetartea, quartana.
That hath a quartane ague.
1 Quartanarius. ad.
A burning ague.
1 Causus, causon, pyretus, typhus,
An ague rising of fleame.
Epiala, epialos.
A vehemente ague causing an
inflammation in the mouth.
1 Emphysodes.
A fitt of an Ague.
1 Paxismus, paroxinium.

ague. 1 Horror febris.

ague. Apyrexia
One subiect to an ague.

Indoles, f.
Aptenes, vide fittenes.
Aptenes to learne.
1 Docilitas, f. 3. Ingeniositas, f.
Aptely, vide fitly.
Aptely, with sweete accente and
measure.
Modulatè. adu.

An argument that conuinceth e­
uerie way.
1 Dilemma, n.
A generall or indefinite argument 
to be disputed of.
1 Thesis, f. thema, n.
A particular or special argument.
1 Hypothesis, f.
A briefe argument, containing the 
summs of the whole matter or, dis­
course.
1 Periocha, f.
A forme of argument from parti­
culars to vniversals.
1 Inductio, f.
A forme of argument, having three
or more propositions in the antece­
dent, the attributum of the former, 
being alwaies the subiectum of the
latter.
1 Sorites.
The argument, or first entrie into a
Comedie.

The first parte of an argument, or 
reason.
1 Antecedens, p.
The latter part of an argument.
1 Consequens, p.
Ful of argumentes
1 Argumentosus, ad.

As. 
1 Vt, vti, sicut, sicuti, prout, ve­
lut, veluti, ceu.
As well as.
1 Tam quam, æque ac, pariter
ac, perinde atque, tanquam.
As soone as.
1 Vt primum, quam primum, si­
mul ac, simul atque, quam mox.
As it were, as if, or as though.
1 Tanquam, quasi, acsi.
As farre as.
1 Quatenus, quoad, quantum.
As concerning.
1 Quantum ad, quod attinet ad, de.
As for the residue of the time.
1 Cætero.
For as much as.
1 Cum, quando, quandoquidem.
As long as.
1 Donec, quamdiu, quoad.
As for example.
1 Puta, vtputa, vtpote, vt. 
Exempli Causa. 
Exempli Gratia.
Euen as.
1 Quemadmodum, ita vt.
As much as.
1 Quantum, quantumvis, quan­
tumlibet, quantumcumque, quoad.

thing.

scapus, canon, m.

even weight.

f. profugus, proscriptus, 2 able­

Abanniti,
A banisher. 1 Proscriptor, m.
A Banishing.

gatio, 2 Ejectio, expulsio, expor­
tatio, deportatio, f.
A Banishing for a yeare.
1 Abannitio, f.
A Banishing in the citie of Syracu­
sa, practised by writing the name of
the party in an Oliue leafe.
1 Petalismus, m.
Banishment, or exile.
1 Exilium, 2 exterminium, n fuga, 
f. 3 Liminium, n.
A Kinde of banishmente among
the Athenians, for 10 yeares space.
1 Ostracismus, m.
A maner of banishment, or con­
demnation, that whosoever findeth
the condemned man, may kill him.
1 Bannum, n.
Of, or belonging to banishmente.
1 Exularius, ad.

house, in which fire being inclosed ca­
steth forth heate.

A bathing place.

A Battell, or conflict. 
1 Prælium, n. pugna, dimicatio, f. 
congressus, m. congressio, f. con­
flictus, m. conflictio, polymachia. 
f. 2 Mars, m. arma, orum, discri­
men, n. Stratia, f. 
A battell betweene two, vi:  combat.
A little battell.
1 Præliolum, n.
A set battell.
1 Pugna stataria, bellum con­
stans.
A battell waged betweene light har­
nessed men.
1 Pugna velitaris.
A battell, wherein they that before
had gotten the victory, are nowe o­
uercome.
2 Osculana pugna.
A battell which Gyants prepared
against the Gods.
1 Gygantomachia, f.
A battell of mice and frogges.
1 Batrochomyomachia, f.
A battell before a citty or towne.
1 Bellum antarium.
The beginning of a battell.
1 Velitatio. f. 
2 Pugnæ Prælusio. 
Pugnæ Præludium.
An onset in battell.
1 Impressio, f.
The double warde of a battell, where
both noble and common Souldiers
are.
1 Principia, n.
The wing of a battell.
1 Cornu, indecl.
He that is sent out before the bat­
tell, to defie, or prouoke the enemy.

Bawdry.
1 Obscænitas, f.
The practise of bawdry.

A bawde, or Marchaunt of whores.
1 Leno, m. 3 Aquariolus, m.
A she bawde.
1 Lena, f. stuprisequestra.
An olde bawde.

A bawde that pampereth or trim­
meth women, that they may be sold 
the dearer.
1 Mango. m.
A bande bringing women against
their willes.
2 Perductor, m.

To Be. 
1 Sum, existo, sio. 3 Fuo. 
I haue Beene.
1 Fui.
I should or might be.
1 Forem verb. defect.
To be vnder, or in.
1 Subsum.
Be it so.
1 Fac, cum infinit. esto, licet.
A Beeing. 1 Essentia, existentia, f.
Beeing.
1 Existens, positus. 3 Ens.
That may Be, or not Be.
1 Contingens.

Preco, accensus, cærix, m.

names.

A Beadle to arrest, or doe execu­

pistrinalis, castifer.

strate.

peeces.

To turne Beastes into rancke
corne to feede. 
3 Impesco. 
Al kinde of beastes.
1 Pecus, oris, n. & vdis, f. 3 pecu, n
A beaste, 1 Bestia, f.
A great and terrible beaste.

A little beaste. 1 Bestiola, f.
A wilde beaste. 1 Fera, f.
A tame beast.
1 Domestica, f.
An hearde of beastes.

Beastly men. 1 Bilutes. m. pl.
Beastlynesse.

Beastly. 1 Beluinè, bestialiter.
A young beast. 2 Depubis, f.
A spotted beaste, quicke of sight, 
like a woolfe.
Lynx, m. & f.
Of the beaste Lynx.
1 Lynceus, ad.
A beast that liveth both on lande 
and water.
1 Amphibeum. n.
A beaste shining by night.
1 Noctiluca, f.
A beaste killed in sacrifice.
1 Victima, f.
A flying beaste. 1 Vapo.
Beastes having the crampe in
their feete, which causeth them to
go on the toppe of their hoofe only.
1 Orthocala.
Beastes yoked together. 1 Bijugi, o­
rum, m.
A beast living in the riuer Nilus, 
having feete like an Oxe, his backe
and mane like an horse neigheth
like an horse, a winding taile, and
tusked like a Bore.
Hyppotamus, m.
A beast in Scandinavia, like to Alce, 
very swifte, leaning to a tree when
it sleepeth, and being once fallen, 
cannot lifte it selfe vp againe.
Maclis.
A beast in India, which hath three
rewes of teeth, the face of a man, the
body of a Lion, and coueteth much
after mans flesh.
Manticora, æ. f.
 Beasts which haue no taile, or a mai­
med tail, and might not be offered vp
in Sacrifice.
Colura.
A Beast in Samos, whose bones are
so bigge, that they be kept for a mar­
veile, and whose voice is so strong, 
that is shaketh the earth.
Neades.
A beast like vnto an Ape, but ha­
ving the face of a Dogge.
Cynocephali.
A beast in Paonia, as big as a bull.
Monops.
Beasts like to sheep, but hauing hea­
rie wool like rams.
Musimones.
A little beast bred in wine.
Mustio.
A little beast devouring gnats.
Myrmecoleo.
A beast of Æthiopia.
Nabix.
A beast begotten betweene a Lio­
nesse, and the beast Hyena.
Crocuta, tæ. f.
A beast that striketh with his horne.
Cornupeta.
A beast in Hercinia, like a bull, but
bigger in bodie, and verie swift.
Vrus, ri, m.
A beast that trembleth at the Voice 
of a lion.
Leonthephonos.
A beast in Æthiope like a man.
Cephus, cepus.
Beasts that are armed with broade
armes.
Platucerotes.
A beast aboue the riuer Hippanis
which dieth the same day it is borne.
Ephemeron, vel Ephe­
merum.
A beast whose vpper part resembleth
a man, and the nether part an asse.
Onocentaurus m.
A Certaine wilde beast of the kind
of goates in Affrick.
Oryx, gis.
A beast in India, as big againe as
a horse, having a fair tail, and a ve­
ry fine heare.
Pæphagis.
A creeping, or ramping beast, such a
one as glideth like a Snake or Ad­




der.
Proserpens bestia.
A Beast like a fallow deere, or
roe bucke.
Pigargus, m.
A Beast in India, like a horse, 
fownd aboute great riuers.
Eale.
A Beast like a roe, wherof muske
doth come
Gazella, f.
A Beast bigger then a grashoper, 
destroing corne.
Grillus, m.
A Beastlesse then a foxe, in co­
lours dark and yelow, it may bee
taken for a black genette.
Genocha.
A Beast of al other the most sub­
till, like a wolfe, with a mane
like a horse.
Hyæna.
A Beast like vnto a Lizzarde, 
having spottes in his necke like
starres.
Stellio, m.
A Beast in shape like a wolfe, 
speckled like a Libberd.
Raphius, m.
A Beast, enemie to an elephant, 
having a horne in his snowt ben­
ding vpwardes.
Rhinoceros, m.
A Beast begotten betwixt a goate
and a Ramme.
Muscino.
A Beast like to be an hedge-hog, 
having the shape of a mouse, and 
a beare.
Arctomis, f.
A Beast which is both male, and
femal.
Arsenothelea.
A Venemous beast.
Ascalobotes.
Beastes being like to men, having
feete like goates.
Aegripanes.
A wilde beast, in fashion and
skinne like a fallow deere, but
greater, and hath no iointes in
the leggs, and therefore neuer
lieth, but leaneth to trees.
Alce, is vel es.
A Beaste having an heade like
a camell, and thighes like, an
Oxe.
Amalala, æ.
A wilde beast, having the head 
of a bull, the body and mane of a 
horse.
Bonasus.
A Beast like vnto a camell and
a panther.
Camelopardalis.
A Beast called a Civet, like a 
wolfe, and hath a mane like a
horse.
Civetta, f.
A Beast that fighteth against
Adders.
Offimacus, m.
A Beast called Hyena.
Belbus, m.
A Beast in the bankes of Ni­
lus, that killeth with the sight
whome he beholdeth.
Cacoblepa, f.
A Little Beast that doth easi­
lie change it selfe into all co­
loures that it sitteth vpon, be­
sides red and white, and is nouri­
shed onlie with the aire.
Chamœleon, m.
A Swift beast in Aethiopia, 
counterfaiting a mans voice.
1 Leucrocuta, f.
A beast that hath onlie the heade
of a dogge.
1 Caniceps, tis.
A Beast called a buffle, or wilde
Oxe, having but one horne, and
a very long mane.
1 Bison, f. Bubalus, m.


To Beat, or smite. 
1 Cædo, pulso, verbero, con­
verbero, diverbero, everbero, 
tundo, contundo, Subtundo, 
percutio, incutio, ferio, plan­
go, vt pectus plango. To knock, 
or beat the breast. 2 Castigo, 
multo, plecto, punio, obpunio, 
Lancino, occido, 3 plago, pla­
geo, Ico, occilo, exciso.
To beat much.
1 Compulso, admutilo, male­
facio.
To beate blacke and blew.
1 Sugillo.
To beat to the grownd.
1 Affligo.
To beat to death.
1 Oblido.
To beate with the fist.
1 Alapizo, collaphizo.
To beate with a staffe.
1 Fustigo.
To beate backe.
1 Repercutio, repello, refrin­
go, reverbero, 2 Revolvo.
To beate, or bruise any thing to 
make it thinner.
1 Procudo.

To beate out.
1 Extero, extendo, excudo.

ruo.

To beate out the braine.

3 Deparieto, exparieto.

1 Accudo.

1 Inculco.

1 Pulso.
To beate, or knocke often.
1 Pulto. 3 Verberito.

secundaria.


A Beere, whereon
dead bodies are caried. 
1 Sandapila, f. capulum, fere­
trum, n. orcomana, libitina, f
pollinctorium, n. glossaria, f. 
3 Bispulus, m. 
They which cary mens bodyes on
a beere.
1 Sandapilarij, polliones, m.


Beestinges, that is, 
The first milke that commeth in
teates, after the birth of any thing
be it in woman or beast. 
1 Colostra, f. colostrum, n. 
Of, or belonging to those beestings.
1 Colostratus, ad.

To be Before. 
1 Præsum. 
That is before. 1 Anterior.
Before, in time.
1 Ante, antea, pr: & adv. Prius
dudum, adu.
Before that.
1 Antequam, priusquam, ci­
tiusquam, adu.
Before in place.
Præ, pro, ante. præp.
Before, or in presence.
1 Coram. , pr. & adu. priorsum.  adu.
Before, or aboue.
1 Supra, superius. adu.
Before, or over against.
1 Adversus, adu.
Before and behind.
1 A fronte, & a tergo.
Before day light
1 Antelucanus, ad.
Before, or a little before day
light.
1 Anteluculo, antelucano. 
3 Anteluco, adu.
Before his eyes.
2 Vivus vidensque.
Before all men.
1 Palam, in propatulo, in pub­
lico, perpalam, adu.
Before all things, chiefly, or first
of all.
1 Inprimis.
Before this time.
1 Antehac.
A little before.
1 Paulo ante.
The day before, vide day.

To Beginne. 
1 Inchoo, ordior, exordior,

stituo, ineo, concipio, auspicor, 
proludo. 3 Ordio, cæpio, ador­
dior, proæmior, occæpto. 
To beginne, or growe by some oc­
casion.
2 Nascor, orior, exorior, coo­
rior, perorior, adorior.
To beginne first.
1 præpeto. 2 prægigno, vt ma­
lum morem prægignere. to begin
an euill custome. 
To haue his beginning in a 
place. 1 Orior.
To beginne well. 1 Auspicor.
To beginne a fresh, or againe.
1 Redintegro, remolior, reten­ 
to, resumo, itero, redauspicor, 
redordior. 2 repeto, retexo, re­ 
voco.
To beginne, or be begun.

nascor.
To beginne first with, or to pro­
voke. 1 Lacesso.
To beginne, as when one begin­
neth warre.
1 Capesso.
I shall beginne.
Occæpso.
To beginne to speake.
1 Præloquor.
To beginne, or come forth.
1 Aborior.
To beginne to arise as the sunne
dooth.
1 Suborior.
I haue begunne.
1 Cæpi, verb: defect.
He beganne.
1 Infit, verb: defect.

To Beseech, or desire. 
1 Obsecro, oro, precor, obte­
stor, peto, supplico, quæso, te­
stor, vide To aske, desire, and 
pray.

perrogo, ex obsecro, 2. con­
tendo.
To beseech, or craue with teares.
1 Imploro, invoco.

ring.

plicatio, f. vide desiring.

stomache, for defence of the
same.
1 Chondros xiphoides.
A bone in the lefte side of a
frog, whose vertue is great, as
Plinie writeth Lib. 32. Ca. 5.
1 Apocynon.
The Cuttle bone.
1 Testum, n.
The roundnes or knots of the
Bones in the knee, ankle, el­
bowe, or huckle.
1 Condylus, m.
Bones that fall from the table.
1 Analecta, orum, n.
An house wherein bones are
kept, vide charnell house.
When the ende of a bone is bro­
ken, where it ioyneth with an o­
ther.
1 Apagina.
The breaking of bones.
1 Ossifragium, n.
That hath the bones of his shoul­
der blades standing out like
wings.
1 Pterigodes.
That hath his bones pulled out, 
or broken. 1 Exossatus. p.
The gathering of bones.
1 Ossilegium, n.
He that gathereth bones.
1 Ossilegus, m.
Boneles, or without bones.
1 Exos, ad.
Bonie, or full of bones.
1 Ossatus, ossosus, ad.
Like a bone, or of a bone.
1 Osseus, ad.
One bone from an other.
1 Ossilatim, ad.

A Booke. 
1 Liber, codex, biblios, m. bi­
blion, n. 2 Scheda, f. scriptum, 
opus, opusculum, volumen, 
n. charta, f. 
A little booke.
1 Libellus, libellulus, codicu­
lus, codicellus, codicillus, 
commentariolus, m.
Bookes of divers arguments.
1 Pandectæ, arum, f.
Bookes, wherein lawes are writ­
ten concerning the nobilitie.
2 Elephantini libri.
A booke of medicines.
1 Antidotarius, m.
A booke, wherein olde customes
are written.
1 Annales.


 

The bookes of common customes.
1 Rituales libri.
Bookes of the holy scripture.
1 Hagiographa, biblia, n.
Bookes of Phisicke.
1 Iatronicæ, arum, f.
Bookes negligently written.
2 Oscitationes. f.
Reckoning bookes.
1 Adversaria, orum, n.
A reckoning booke, wherein ex­
pences are noted in iourneyes.
1 Itinerarium, n.
A booke of remembraunce.
1 Commentarius, m. comen­
tarium, n. tabula, f.
A booke containing things doon
in iourneyes. 1 Itinerarium. 
3 Hodæporicum, n.
A booke to instruct one.
1 Protrepticus, m.
Bookes containing and treating
of the properties, and nature of
fishes.
1 Halieutica, orum, n.
Bookes in treating of sinne.
1 Amaritgenati.
Bookes written on the back side.
1 Opisthograhi, m.
Bookes touching the gouerne­
ment of a cittie.
1 Politica, orum, n.
Bookes treating of morall Phi­
losophie.
1 Ethica, orum, n.
Bookes treating of naturall phi­
losophie.
1 Physica, orum, n.
A booke, wherein Mahumets
lawe, and religion is contained.
1 Alcoranum, n.
A Marchaunts booke.
1 Calendarius liber.
A booke of remembraunce, de­
claring what is done dailie.
1 Diarium, n.
A booke, containing the decla­
ration of notable sayings and
deedes.
1 Logistoricum, n.
Bookes of acts and statutes.
1 Capitularia. n.
A booke, wherein is contained
the knowledge of all offices and
dignities, for ciuill and martiall
affaires.
1 Laterculum, n.
A booke teaching the first pre­
cepts of arte.
1 Isagogicum, n.
Bookes containing the names
of such as are reckoned in the num­
ber of saintes, or such like, as is
the Popes rubricke.
1 Indigitamenta, orum, n.
A booke, whose Author is not
knowen.
1 Adespotus liter, m.
Bookes, which Cæsar wrote a­
gainst Cato.
1 Anticatones, m.
Bookes set foorth vnder false
names, and titles.
1 Libri subdititij.
A booke binder, or seller.
1 Librarius, bibliopola. 3 Bib­
liopegus, m.
A booke sellers shoppe.
1 Taberna libraria. 
1 Officina libraria.

To boyle againe. 1 Recoquo.
To boyle much, or throughly.
1 Percoquo, excoquo.
To boyle away.
1 Decoquo.
To boyle, or seeth togeather.
1 Concoquo, collixo.
To make to boyle.
1 Defervefacio, fervefacio, 
infervefacio.
To boyle new wine.
1 Defruto.
To boyle often.
1 Coctito, coquito.
To boyle, as a pot boyleth, or pas­
siuely. 1 Bullio, æstuo, inæs­
tuo, ferveo.
To boyle ouer.
1 Efferveo, ebullio, efferves­
co, adæstuo.
To boyle, and cast vppe great
waues, and surges.
1 Vndo, exæstuo.
To beginne to boyle.
1 Effervesco.
To be boyled.
1 Incoquor.
Boyled, or sodden.
1 Coctus, discoctus, fervefac­
tus, defervefactus, elixus, p.
Throughly boyled.
1 Excoctus, percoctus, p.
Often boyled.
1 Recoctus, p.
Boyled before, or perboyled.
1 Præcoctus, p.
A little boyled.
1 Subfervefactus, p.
Boyled meate.
1 Aulicoqua, orum, n.
A boyler.
1 Coctor, m.
The boyling of the Sea, in Bri­
tanie.
1 Clota, f.
A boyling, or seething.
1 Coctio, f. decoctus, m. coctu­
ra, decoctura. f.
A boyling vppe.
1 Ebullitio, f.
That is boyled in an earthen
pot.
1 Testuatius, ad.
Easie to be boyled.
1 Coctilis, coctivus, coctibilis, 
adu.


To be Boysterous. 
1 Perhorreo, perhorresco, 2
Fluctuo. 
A boysterous, or troublesome
weather.
1 Tempestas, f.
A boysterous winde, beating
downe trees and howses.
1 Turbo, prester, m.
Boysterous.
1 Tempestuosus, ad.
Boysterous water, falling downe
from hilles, and mountaines, very
swiftlie.
1 Terrens, m.


A Boyst, being a ves­
sell of brasse. 
1 Lecythus, m.

To Breake, activum. 
1 Frango, confringo, infringo, 
rumpo, obrumpo, tero, cello, 
elido, dirimo, 2 Imminuo, sol­
vo, percudo, quasso, obtundo, 
labefacio, labefacto, macto. 
To breake in pieces.

tero, pertero, distringo, effrin­
go, infringo, perfringo, præ­
rumpo, petrumpo, contundo, 
pertundo, prætundo, 2 quasso, 
dissipo, discutio, scindo, 3 in­
frio, suffrio deruncino, fru­
sto, frustito.
To breake a sunder, or in 2 pieces.

diffringo, distero, distringo, di­
rimo 2 discindo, dissuo, in­
ter cido, divido, dilanio, di­
straho.

1 Abrumpo, derumpo, 2 rescin­
do, discindo, detergo. 
3 Procio
To break, and leaue of for a time.

To breake about.

To breake, or burst open.
1 Refringo, refrango.
To breake open violently.
1 Expugno.
To breake vp.

profindo, proscindo, rescin­
do.
To breake downe.
1 Diruo, destruo, 2 Excudo, 
3 Defringo.
To breake downe an hedge.

To breake before.
1 Præfringo.
To breake one thing against a­
nother.
1 Affringo, adfringo, 2 Affrio.
To breake, or bruise small.
1 Tero, contero, vid: to braie, 
and crumble. 
To breake vnder.
1 Suffringo.

a lawe.

lædo.

To be broken.
1 Rumpor, frangor.; 3 Frageo, 
Frangesco.
Broken, or burst.

fragosus, ad. 2 Dissolutus,

broken.

tritus, infractus, p.

the middle.

noyse, as a bladder full blowen.

Broken off.

To Breathe. 
1 Spiro, respiro, anhelo, 3. 
halo. 
To draw breath with difficulty.
1 Anhelo.
To breathe out quickly & fast.
1 Anhelo. 3 Hippaco, halito.
To breathe out, or cast forth a
breath, or fume.
1 Exhalo, vaporo, evaporo, 
prospiro.
To breathe, or aire.
1 Vaporo, exsicco.
To breathe in, or vpon.
1 Inspiro, inhalo, adhalo.
To breathe betweene.
1 Interspiro.
To breathe through.
1 Perspiro.
To breathe out, or giue vp the
ghost.
1 Expiro. animam.
Exhalo animam.
Efflo animam.
A breathing.
1 Respiratio, perspiratio, f. 
respiratus, m.
A breathing with difficulty.
1 Anhelatio, f.
A breathing vpon.
1 Afflatus, m.
A breathing betweene.
1 Interspiratio, f.
A breathing out.
1 Expiratio, evaporatio, f.
Breath.
1 Halitus, anhelitus, m. spi­
ratio, f. 2 flatus, animus, m. ani­
ma, f. spiritus, m. pneuma, n.
A short breath.
1 Suspirium, n.
A moist breath, or aire.
1 Vapor, m.
A drie breath, or fume.
1 Exhalatio, f.
Thicknes of breath.
1 Dascia, f.
The passage, whereby the breath
issueth out.
1 Respiramen, spiramentum.
A breathing hole, out of which
breath, winde, aire, or smoke
passeth.

The shortnes of breath.

Spirandi difficultas.
The stincking of the breath.

That breatheth.

2 Spiritualis, animalis, pneu­
maticus. 3 spiritalis, ad.
That, whereby wee breathe.
1 Spirabilis ad.

treated of before.

latio, f.

1 Sententiola.

compendiosus, 2 Succinctus
concisus, contractus, angu­
stus, circumscriptus, astri­
ctus, paucus, modicus, ad.

vibus, perbreviter, paucis, 
summatim, summarie, com­
pendiose. 2 Concise, præcise, 
succincte, cursim, laconice,

To make Browne.

Hee that maketh browne co­
lour.
1 Fuscator, m.
Browne, or natural colour.
1 Pulligo, f.
Browne.
1 Fulcus, subniger, nigellus, 
leucophæus. 2 Bæticus, his­
panus, 3 Raviscellus, ad.
Somewhat browne.
1 Subfuscus, ad. vide colors. 
Browne, or not ranged, vide
 breade.

carpo.

snowe time.

small.

2 commolo, quasso, commi­
nuo, delibo, tudiculo, vide
braie.

quassatus, pressus, pinsitus,

Brused vpon.

A brusing.
1 Collisio, f. collusus, m. con­
fractio, contritio, f.

pots cleane within.

masc.

with.

owne ground.

A builder.

uerie thing is equall, and
straight.

dum, non ita pridem.

1 Emo, mercor, emercor. 
2 Comparo, conduco. 
To buie together.
1 Coemo, commercor.
To buy, to the end to sel for gain
1 Promercor.
To buy before hand, or to buie
out of ones hande.
1 Præmerco.
To buy againe. 1 Redimo.
To buy vnder the price, or valu
1 Ademo.
To buy and sel, or make mer­
chandise.
1 Mercor, nundinor, nundi­
no, negotior, venundo, licito
To buy meate, or victuals.
1 Opiono.
To buie often.
1 Empto, 3 emptito.
To haue a list to buie.
1 Empturio.
To be bought. 1 Emor.
Bought.
1 Emptus, mercatus, p.
Bought againe. 1 Redemptus.
Bought for a low price.
1 Ademptus, p. ademptivus, ad
A buier. 1 Emptor, 
mercator, inlicitator, m.
One that buyeth, and selleth.
1 Mercator, nundinator, ve­
nundator, negotiator, lici­
tator, m.
A great buyer. 1 Emax, ad.
A buyer of forfeited goods.
1 Sector, m.
Hee that buieth anie thing a
great, and selleth it againe for
advantage. 1 Manceps, co. g.
A buying. 1 Emptio, f. 
mercatus, m. mercatio, f.
A buying together.
1 Coemptio, f.
A buying and selling.
1 Nundinatio, mercatio, li­
citatio, venundatio, negoti­
atio, f.
Affection, or desire to buy.
1 Emacitas, f.
Communication for buying &
selling.
1 Commercium, n.
Thinges bought at advantage, 
to be solde againe.
1 Promercalia, orum. n.
That maie be bought.
1 Mercabilis, emptivus. ad.
Which is often in buying.
3 Coemptionalis, ad.


To make Buxome, 




meeke, or gentle. 
3 Mistico. as. 
To be buxome, or obedient.
1 Obsequor, teneor.
Buxomenes, or meekenes.
1 Obsequium, n clementia, f. 
3 Obsequela, misticia, f.
Buxome, or obedient.
1 Obsequens, obediens.
Buxomely.
1 Clementèr, obedientèr.


By. 
1 Per. 
By, or nigh to.
1 Iuxta, secus, prope, 2 præ­
ter, circa, tenus, pr. & adu. 
apud, pr. propinque, comi­
nus, adu.
By and by, or out of hande.
Immediate, iam, impigre, re­
pente, derepente, subito, ce­
lerius, ocyus, ocyssime, in­
continenter, excontinenti, 
adu. vide anon. 
By reason of.
1 Propter.
By it selfe.
1 Separatim, adu, vi: asonder. 
By turne.
1 Vicissim, adu.
By same maner, meanes or rea­
son.
1 Aliquatenus, aliqualiter.
By some place, waie, or means.
1 Aliqua.
By what means, reason, or sort
so ever it be.
1 Quomodocunque, quo­
modolibet, qui, quomodo, 
quo pacto.
By what waie, or place.
1 Qua.
By chance.
1 Casu, forte, fortuito. adu.
By my faie, or in good soth.
 Ecastor, mecastor, per Ca­
storem & Pollucem, hercle, 
mehercle, pol. ædepol.



C ANTE A.

A CABANET, or
little coffer. 
1 Phylaxa, capsula, f. 


A Caberne, or Ca­
bin in a ship. 1 Stega, f. 
A cabin, vsed by occupiers in
faires, or markets, v.  boothes.
A little narrowe cabin, or
darcke lodging.
1 Gurgustium, n.
A verie litle strait cabinne, or
lodging.
1 Gurgustulum, gurgustio­
lum, n.
A cabin, or cottage, vid.  cot­
tage.


A Cable rope. 
1 Rudens, m. vel f. prymne­
sium, anchorale, 2 linum, 3
sason. n. 
Cables.
1 Funes nautici, vel ancho­
rarij, retinacula, stupea pup­
pis.


A Cackrell, so cal­
led, because it maketh the eat­
ers laxatiue. 
1 Mæna, mænola, f. 


A Cage, or place to
keepe birds in. 
1 Aviarium, ornithon, orni­
thotrophium, ornithobosci­
um, n. cavea, f. 3 volucritium. 
A cage to sell, or punish bond­
men in.
1 Catasta, f.


A Caitife. 
1 Improbus, ad. vid. wicked. 


To carie certaine Cakes, 
called strues, to the Temple, to
be offered to Gods. 
3 Strufector. 


The Cake, which
is brought, so to be offered. 
1 Strues, f. 
They that brought such cakes.
1 Strufectarij.
A cake.
1 Placenta, f. 3 popanum, 
n. collyrida, f.
A wheaten cake.
1 Farreum, n. adorca, f.
A beane cake.
1 Fabacia.
A cake made of hony, meale, 
and oile.
1 Libum, n. libus, m.
A cake made of sundrie grains
and spices.
1 Fartum, n.
A cake of bread, cut in sacri­
fice.
1 Secivium, n. secium libum.
A cake made to comfort the
stomacke. 2 Mustaceum, n.
A kind of cake, made of cheese, 
wine, milke, and herbs.
1 Moretum, n.
A fine cake made of hony, &
flower. 1 Crepis, f.
A cake, made like to a trendle.
1 Spira, f.
A cake, made with cheese, 
meale, and water.
1 Semilissula, vel semilixula.
A cake, made of frumenty, oile, 
& hony, offered to the Gods.
1 Subucula, f.
A great cake, such as are made
at weddings, and churchings of
women. 1 Summanalia.
A kinde of cake, made of the
herbe Sefama, & virgin hony.
1 Sesaminis, f.
A kinde of cake, sacrificed to
Janus. 1 Ianual, n.
A kind of spice cakes.
1 Nastipanes, m.
A spice cake.
1 Panis dulciarius.
Fine cake bread.
1 Artologanus, m.
Swete cake-bread.
1 Itrion, n
A cake, baked vnder the ashes.
1 Panis subcineritius.
They that make fine cakes.
1 Nastocopi, libarij, & liba­
rius, m.
They that eat such cakes.
1 Nastophagi.
Pieces of bride cakes, throwen
out among the people.
1 Emissitiæ, f.

first daie of euerie moneth.

To Call. 
1 Voco, appello, compello, 
arcesso, vel arcessio, cito, 
Clamo, cico, 3 Calo. 
To cal often.
1 Vocito, appellito, clamito.
To cal to, as to one that cal­
leth.
1 Advoco, accio, & accieo. 
3 Procalo.
To cal to often.
1 Accito, advocito.
To call to, as to him that is
called.
1 Inclamo.
To call by some name.
1 Nuncupo, nomino.
To cal by name.
1 Indigito.
To call by a nicke, or wrong
name. 1 Agnomino.
To cal, or raise vp.
1 Cieo.
To cal for.
1 Arcesso, arcessio, accerso, 
accersio.
To cal for one. 1 Inclamo.
To cal for aloude. 1 Exclamo.
To call instantly for a thing.
2 Fatigo, vt fatigare marten. 
To cal instantly for battaile.
To call vppon.
1 Invoco.
To cal vpon often, or instantly.
1 Inclamito. 2 Insto, vrgeo.
To cal vpon for help.
1 Imploro, invoco, cieo.
To cal vpon for help, or debt.
1 Appello.
To cal together.
1 Convoco, cito, concieo, &
concio.
To call aside.
1 Sevoco.
To call apart, or away.
1 Avoco, devoco, sevoco.
To call in.
1 Introvoco, invoco, incla­
mo.
To cal out, or forth.
1 Evoco, excio, provoco, 
accessio, accerso.
To cal out of bed, or sleepe.
1 Suscito.
To cal backe againe.
1 Revoco, 2 Repeto, præ­
verto.
To cal backe, or recal a saying, 
or doing.
1 Revoco, 2 recino, recanto, 
retracto.
To cal a farre off.
1 Provoco.
To cal one doune.
1 Devoco.
To call to witnesse.
1 Testor, contestor, obtestor.
To cal to remembrance.
1 Recomminiscor, reminis­
cor. 2 Recognosco, recolo.
To goe to cal.
1 Arcesso, arcessio, accerso, 
accersio.
Not to cal.
3 Invoco.
To cal like a partridge.
3 Cacabo.
To be called.
1 Vocor, advocor, accersior.
To be called, or named.
1 Nuncupor, dicor, vocor, 
nominor.
To be called vp.
1 Excior.
To be called againe.
2 Repetor.
To be called before the counsel.
3 Inconsilior.
Called.
1 Vocatus, citatus, p.
Called for.
1 Accitus, p.
Called, or called for.
1 Arcessitus, p.
Called by some name.
1 Nuncupatus, p.
Called often.
1 Vocitatus, p.
Called out, or forth.
1 Evocatus, p.
Called backe.
1 Revocatus, p.
Called vp.
1 Excitus, p.
Called vpon.
1 Invocatus, imploratus, p.
Called to, being a far off.
1 Clamatus, p.
Called by a wrong name.
1 Agnominatus, p.
Not called.
1 Invocatus, ad.
Not called backe.
1 Irrevocatus, ad.
A Caller.
1 Vocator, m. trix, f.
A caller for, or hee that goeth
to call.
1 Accersitor, m.
A caller forth.
1 Evocator, m.
A Calling.
1 Vocatus, m. tio. f.
A calling by name.
1 Compellatio, f.
A calling to.
1 Advocatio, f.
A calling from.
1 Advocatio, f.
A calling forth, or a suddaine
calling forth to battaile.
1 Evocatio, f.
A calling vpon.
1 Invocatio, f.
A calling together.
1 Convocatio, f.
A calling, or sending for.
1 Accersitus, accitus, m.
A calling backe.
1 Revocatio, anaclesis, f. re­
vocamen, n.
A calling backe of ones deeds, 
or sayings.
2 Retractatio, f.
A calling to remembrance.
2 Recognitio, f.
Of, or belonging to calling.
1 Appellatorius, vocativus.
That maie be called backe.
1 Revocabilis, ad.
That cannot bee called backe.
1 Irrevocabilis, ad.
By calling.
1 Vocative, adu.

ad. 2 compositus, silens, paca­

solutus, p. placidus, issimus,

To deale the Cardes. 
2 Distribuere chartas.

2 Folia miscere
Chartas miscere.
To cut the cardes.

To Care for, or haue

2 video, consulo, laboro, vt
laborare de verbo, non de
re, to care, or haue regarde to
the word, and not to the mat­
ter.
To care more for. 2 Præverto.
To care for diligentlie.
2 Studeo, invigilo.
To haue care of.
1 Curæ esse alicui. 
2 Cordiesse alicui.
To take care, or heede to.

vigilo.
Care, or regard.

Care or diligence.

f. studium, n. attentio, f.
Carefulnesse, or diligent care.

A thing cared for.
1 Pensum, n.
Careful, or diligent.

lus, studiosus, ad. vide di­
ligent. 
Verie carefull.

Carefullie, or diligentlie.

diose, curiose, accurate, se­
dulo, solicite, magnopere, 
intente, obnixe, 2 provide, 
vigilanter, firme, impresse,

To Carie, or beare. 
1 Fero, porto, gero, gesto, 
veho, vecto, subveho suffero
To carie often.
1 Vecto, vectito, convecto, 
subvecto, gestito, portito.
To cary by cart, or water.
1 Veho.
To cary in, by cart, or waine.
1 Subveho.
To carie backe.
1 Reporto, refero, regero.
To carie backe by cart, or such
like.
1 Reveho.
To carie from, or awaie.
1 Aveho, aufero, deporto, 
degero, abduco.
To carie from one to another.
1 Transfero.
To carie from one place to an
other.
1 Transporto, transfero, a­
veho, asporto.
To carie from, to, downe, or
awaie.
1 Deveho.
To carie away from the flocke.
1 Abgrego.
To carie awaie by force.
1 Rapio, abripio.
To carie awaie rubble, or broc­
kle, of old decaied houses.
1 Erudero.
To carie to.
1 Apporto, asporto, defero, 
deveho.
To carie to a place.
1 Adveho, perveho.
To cary often to a place.
Advecto.
To cary before. 1 Præfero, 
præveho, 2 prætendo.
To carie in.
1 Infero, ingero, importo, 
inveho, invecto.
To carie betweene.
1 Interfero.
To carie beyond, or through.
1 Præterveho, præterfero.
To carie together.
1 Congero, confero, com­
porto, contollo.
To carie over.
1 Transfero, transveho, trans­
porto, trajicio.
To carie about.
1 Circumveho, circumfe­
ro, circumporto, circumago.
To carie about with him.
1 Circumgesto, portito.
To carie about often.
1 Circumvecto.
To carie asunder, or into di­
verse parts. 1 Differo.
To carie out, or forth.
1 Egero, eveho, exporto, 
effero.
To carie out of the waie.
1 Duco.
To carie forth, a farre off.
1 Proveho, progero, pro­
fero.
To carie closely, or privily.

To carie vp.

A Case, or matter. 
1 Causa, res, f. 
A case in Lawe, properly that
which riseth in contention, vpon
the point of the matter, which
must bee replied vnto, and ei­
ther confessed, denied, or tra­
vessed.
2 Status, m.
A booke case, or case in Lawe, 
which being once decided, is a
president against all like matter
1 Præjudicium, n.

thing in. 1 Theca, entheca, f. 
2 Locus, m. loci, et loca.

mentes were kept.

or fling. 1 Iacio, conjicio, mit­
to, contorqueo.

sterno, diruo, verto, everto, di­
ripio, collabefacto, 2 arieto.

To cast or lay down. 1 submitto.
To cast down often. 1 Dejecto.
To cast downe headlong.

To cast down violently. 1 proruo.
To cast downe vnder feete,




1 Pessundo.

ground. 1 Disterno, perverto.

To cast in.

gero, vt semen solo ingerere.
To cast seed in the ground.

To cast in by force.

To cast in, or into.
1 Injicio, demitto, conjicio, 
impingo, compingo, 2 Ago, 
depello, Induco, vt inducere
in amorem. incutio, vtincu­
tere errorem, To cast or bring in­
to an errour.

To cast out, or forth.

trudo, egero, progero, elimi­
no, 2 Extermino, exigo, ex­

To cast out, or send forth.

harmes waie.

To cast out of a ground.

1 Denundino.

doth her castings.

To cast or sprinckle liquor vpon.
1 Inspergo, aspergo, affundo,

To cast all aboute.
1 Circumjacio, circumjicio.
To cast all abroad, or spread.
1 Spargo, prospergo, jactito.
To cast vp, vide Vomite.
To cast vp, as men do corne with
the fanne.
1 Subjecto, subjacto.
To cast vp, as the water doth the
waues.
1 Exæstuo, 2 egero.
To cast vp, as the sea doth any
thing from the bottome.
2 Expuo.
To cast forth. 1 Iacto.
To cast forth, or send forth as
the sunne doth light, or heate.
1 Emitto.
To cast forth largely.
1 Profundo.
To cast forth violently, with the 
arme, or sling.
1 Torqueo.
To cast forth a breath, or fume.
1 Exhalo, anhelo.
To cast over, or beyond.
1 Trajicio, transjacio.
To cast ouer, or vppon.
1 Superinjicio, superjacto, su­
peringero.
To cast ouer any thing, to cloake
a matter.
1 Objicio, 2 offundo, obduco, 
Induco.
To cast through. 1 Trajicio.
To cast through often.
1 Trajecto.
To cast awaie.
1 Abjicio, rejicio, 2 Amoveo, 
depello.
To cast awaie, or shake off.
1 Dejicio.
To cast away by disdaine.
1 Abjicio, rejicio, 3 abjecto, 
rejecto.
To cast awaie wastfullie.
1 Sumo consumo, 3 dissipo.
To cast a way vtterly. 1 occido.
To cast of, as to cast of a garment
or such like.
1 Exuo, projicio.
To cast of, or renounce.
1 Aspernor, rejicio, abdico, as
repudio, 2 Abdico, is.
To cast of one thing for another.
1 Commuto.
To cast of vntil another time.
1 Rejicio.
To cast a farre of.
1 Prodo, 2 Iaculor, ejaculor. 
3 Iaculo, ejaculo.
To cast to.
1 Adjicio.

To cast to, or together.
1 Coadjicio.
To cast againe. 1 Rejicio.
To cast back againe.

his eies.
2 Reflecto.

3 Retergo, postergo.
To cast, or put betweene, or among.
1 Interjicio, interpono, inter­
mitto, intermisceo.
To cast against.
1 Objicio, impingo.
To cast violently.
1 Infligo.
To cast asunder.
1 Disjicio, 2 Spargo.
To cast dartes, or arrowes.
1 Iaculor, 2 Contendo, 3 Ia­
culo.
To cast, as the Iurie casteth pri­
soners. 1 Damno.
To cast meate to poultrie.
1 Obsipo.
To cast, or revolue in ones mind.
1 Reputo, cogito, 2 Verso, ja­
cto, agito, recolo, recoligo.
To cast a meer or furrowe, with
a plough. 3 Vrbo.
To cast himselfe so, that hee may
rise himselfe without helpe.
3 Vruo.
To cast, as when any thing ca­
steth her young.
1 Ejicio, 2 Elido.
To cast seed in the ground, vide
 To sowe.
To cast in ones teeth, or vpbraid
one.
1 Objicio, objecto, exprobo, 
2 Impropero, vide vpbraid. 
To cast into a basket. 3 Corbito.
To cast account, vide account.
To cast the fault vppon.
2 Transferre culpam.

Inclinare culpam.

dolorem, cieo, concito. 2 creo­
pario, gigno.
There is cause. 1 Est, impers.
A cause, or occasion.
1 Causa, occasio, gratia, f.
The cause, or reason.
1 Causa, ratio, res, f.
A cause, or action. 1 Dica, f.
The first cause.
1 Elementum. n.
The chiefe cause of any thing, 
whether it be good, or euill.
1 Origo, f. initium. 2 Semina­
rium, n. fons, m.
A smale, or little cause.
1 Causula, f.
A causer, or cause.
1 Effector, m. trix, f. 2 au­
thor, concitor, m.
He that in causes judiciall, ioy­
neth with the plaintiffe.
2 Subscriptor, m.
For many causes.
2 Multis nominibus.
That is the cause of doeing of
a thing.
1 Causatius, causativus, ad.
For what cause.
1 Cur, quamobrem, adu. qua
gratia. 2 Quo nomine.
For that cause.
1 Ergo, ideo, idcirco, et iccir­
co, con.
For an other cause, then that is
mentioned.
3 Præterpropter.
Without cause.
1 Immerito, adu. injuria, abl.
Not without cause.

adu. optimo jure, non, inju­

1 Aedes, f. plu.

A camber, wherin sick men do ly.

A chamber, with two beddes, 
or roome with two tables.
1 Biclinium, n.
A bedde chamber, wherein the
husband and wife do lie.
Thalamus.
A little chamber, neare the ma­
sters chamber, where the ser­
vantes lie.
1 Pros, antithalamus, m.
A double bedde-chamber.
1 Amphithalamus, m.
A chamber for one bedde, and
two stooles, joined to another
chamber all in one.

A chamber, wherein the sexton
or church-keeper doth lie.
1 Pastophorium, n.
A bride chamber.
1 Pastophorium, n.
An inner chamber, or parlour.
1 Conclave, n.
A chamber in the vpper part of
the house.
1 Cœnaculum, n.
A chamber, where vnto men on­
lie resort.
1 Andron.
A chamber onlie for women, 
wherein they spinne and weaue.
1 Gynæcium, n.
A secret chamber.
1 Cella.
A counsell chamber.
1 Discretorium, n.
A chamber of presence.
1 Cubile salutatorium.
Chambers, or many houses vn­
der one keye.
1 Conclavia, n.
A letting forth of vpper cham­
bers to hire.
1 Cænacularia.
He that so letteth his chambers.
1 Cænacularius, m.
A groome of the chamber.
1 Cubicularius, m.
An vsher of the chamber.
1 Admissionalis, m.
A chamber-fellowe.
1 Contubernalis, contuber­
nio, m.
A chamberlaine, chamberer, or
he, or shee, that waiteth in a
chamber.

alter.

1 Pollinctor, m.
Such a chesting.
1 Polinctura, f. pollinctus, m.
A chest, wherein dead bodies
are caried.
2 Loculus, m.


A Chest, or coffer. 
 Arca, cista, capsa, f. capsus, 
Ploxenus, ploxinus, vel plox­
imus, m. Scrinium, gazophy­
lacium, repositorium, recon­
ditorium, custodiarium, n. 
A litle chest.
1 Arcula, Arcella, Cistula, 
Cistella, Capsula, Capsella. 
fæm. Scriniolum, n. 2 Locu­
lus, m.
A little Cheste, wherein lottes
were put, at the chusing of Of­
ficers.
1 Citula, f.
A chest to keepe bookes in.
 Librarium, n.
A chest to keepe any papers, or
writings in. 1 Chartophylacium. 
A cheste, or place, wherein eui­
dences, or such like writinges are
kept.
1 Tabularium, n.
A chest covered with leather, as
is a truncke.
3 Riscus, m.
A cheste, wherein Apparell is
kept.
1 Vestiarium. n.
A cheste, wherein Mercers put
their wares.
2 Nidus, m.
A chest, or coffer maker.
1 Scirniarius, m.
That beareth a chest.
1 Cistifer, ad


A mans Cheste, or
breast. 
1 Pectus, n. 
One that is hollowe chested.
1 Pectorosus, ad.


A Chestin, or chest­
nutte. 
1 Nux, castanea, glans sardea­
na, glans Iovis, glans sacra, 
nux heracleotica. 
A kinde of great chest-nut, cal­
led a Marron.
1 Balanus, f.
A kinde of great, or round chest­
nutte.
1 Balanites, f.
A chest-nutte tree, or the chest­
nutte it selfe.
1 Castanea, f.
A place set with Chest-nutte
trees.
1 Castanetum, n.
Made of chest-nutte trees.
1 Castaninus ad.

Children.
1 Liberi, fætus, filij, m. proles, 
f. 2 Pignora, n.

tulus, pupus, pupulus, puellus
puerulus, pusillus, pusillulus.

A childe borne after his fathers
death.

proles, posthumus, m.

death.

tonlie brought vp.

A childe of one yeere olde.

forward.

vestures of purple, vntill they be
17 yeeres of age.
1 Prætextati, et prætextatæ.
Children taken by elfes, vide
 chaunglings.
A childe new borne.
1 Puerperium, n.
A childe borne when the father
is out of the countrie, or an
olde man.
1 Proculus, m.
A childe whose father dieth be­
fore his grand-father.
1 Opiter, m. et opitrix, f.
A childe delivered by incision, 
or one cut out of his mothers
belley.
1 Cæso, cæsonis, m.
A childe borne slowlie, such an
one, as it is long before they be de­
livered of it.
2 Chordus puet, et cordus, ad.
A childe cast, or throwne out in­
to the street, whose father is vn­
knowen.
1 Expositus, vel puer
Exposititius puer.
Projectitius puer. 
Præjectus puer.
A childe, that having beene a­
bused against nature, is nowe to
stale for that vnlawfull plea­
sure.

The childe in the mothers wombe
before it haue perfect shape.
1 Embrio, com: g. et Embry­
on, n.
A childe, or twinne, which
being borne with another, that
being abortiue, dooth come to
perfect birth.

A childe, whose father liveth.

To make a Circle. 
1 Gyro. 
A circle, or round compasse.
1 Circulus, gyrus, orbis, 
circus, m. sphæra, spira, f. 3
peritorium, n.
A little, or narrowe circle.
1 Orbiculus, m. sphærula, spi­
rula, f.
A circle about the moone.
1 Halo, & halos, 2 corona, f.
Circles in the spheare.
1 Coluri, m.
A circle, dividing one part of
the firmament from the other.
1 Horizon.
A circle in heaven, wherevn­
to, when the sun commeth, the
daies be at the shortest.
1 Chimerinus, ad.
A circle in heaven, to the
which the sunne comming, the 
daie & night be of one length.
1 Æquator. m. 3 architre, f.
Circles, & lines in the spheare
of the world, drawen from the
East, to the West, having one
of the poles for their centre, &
in everie part, one equall di­
stante from another.
1 Paralleli, m.
Two circles in the heavens be­
ing of equall distance from
the æquator, the one beeing
called Tropicus Cancri, the
other, Tropicus Capricorni.
1 Tropici, m.
A circle, which is called Ho­
rizon.
1 Piniens, p.
A little circle, in the middest
whereof, Gnomon is fastned.
2 Vmbilicus solis.
Circles, or Spheares, one inclo­
sing another.
1 Eccentrici orbes.
Circles made of Branne, vsed
in sacrifice.
1 Arculata.
The black circle around the eie.
2 Iris, f.
A circle, or ring of a cart.
1 Aspis, f. Orbile, n.
Halfe a circle.
1 Hemicyclus, m.
Belonging to a circle.
1 Circularis, ad.
Circle-wise.
1 Circulatim, orbiculatim, 
adu.


To go in Circuite. 
1 Gyro. 
To circuite, or compasse about, 
vide to compasse.
A circuite.
1 Circuitus, peribolus, or­
bis, m. 3 periagesis, periago­
ge, f.
A circuite, or compassing
round.
1 Ambitus, m.
The circuite of a roofe.
1 Orbile, n.
The circuite, or compasse of
any thing, as of a church, house, 
or such like.
1 Ambitus, m.
A circuit, without the walles
of a towne, where men may
wake for their solace.
1 Tyrsis.

amputo.

tia, f.

or warie. 
1 Caveo, discaveo, 2 cir­
cumspicio, provideo, pro­
spicio, vigilo.

prospiciens, p. cautus, catus, 
providus, consideratus, 
prudens, ad. 2 vigilans, p. 3
cautelosus, ad.

Circumspection.
1 Circumspectus, m. circum­
spectio, circumspicientia, 2
prospicientia, dispicientia, 
vigilantia, cura, f.
One that foreseeth circum­
spectly.
1 Cautor, m.
Circumspectly.
1 Caute, cautim, conside­
rate, provide, prospicien­
ter, circumspecte, vigi­
lanter, adu.


A Circumstance of
 wordes. 
1 Ambage, abl. & ambages, 
plu. f. 


A Circumstance, or
quality, that accompanieth
a thing, as time, place, and
such like.

A citie where one is borne.

came once from an other citie, 
that was before it, or an vnder
citie.

A citizen.

2 Civitas, f.
The state of citizens.
2 Civitas, f.
A citizen discharged of his
freedome, and after paieth mo­
ney as a straunger.

zen. 2 Improles & improlis.

linites, m.

vilis.

To laie, cover, or foule with

To become claie.
1 Lutesco.
Clay or dirte.
1 Lutum, delutamentum, n.
Potters claie.
1 Argilla, glis, ssis, f. 
Figularis terra. 
Sigillaria terra.
White clay.
1 Leucargillon, & leucargili­
um, n.
A white clay, or marble, wher­
of goldsmithes pottes, wherein
they melt their metal be made.
1 Tasconium, n. creta tasconia
A kinde of claie vsed in graf­
fing. 2 Intrita, f. & intritum.
A kinde of clay, or lime, clam­
mie like pitch, vsed in olde time
for morter, and in lampes to
burne in steede of oile, being of
the nature of brimstone.
1 Bitumen, n.
Mixed with that clay.
1 Bituminatus, ad.
Belonging to such clay.
1 Butumineus, ad.

beterol. 1 Petrolium, n.

Claie ground.

or clayish.
1 Argillaceus, ad.

To close vp.
1 Complico, vt complicare
epistolam, vel librum.
To keepe close in.
2 Coerceo, vt coercere a­
ves carcere, to keepe birdes
close in a cage. 
Closed in round about.
1 Circumclusus. 
2 Præcinctus, p.
Closed in, or about, as beeing
besieged.
1 Obsessus, circumventus, 
part.
Closed about by defence.
1 Circummunitus, stipatus, 
2 Septus, circumseptus, 
part.
Closed in, or inclosed.
1 Inclusus, septus, p.
Closed, or healed vp.
2 Ductus, p.
Closed vppe.
1 Opertus, obsignatus, p.
A closing in. 1 Inclusio, f.
A closing, or closure.
1 Sepes, vel sepis, f. disseptum, 
vel dissepium, n.
A closing, or drawing toge­
ther.
2 Pressus, m.
A close keeping in.
2 Compressus, m
Close, or hidden, vide hidden.
Closely, or couertly.
1 Tecte, dissimulanter, oper­
te, abscondite, involute, oc­
culte, cælatim, obscure, astri­
cte, tacite, adu.
To close fast together.
1 Denso, 3 denseo.
To close as a wound doth.
1 Solidesco.
To close and open, as the eies do.
1 Conniveo.
Closed together.
1 Densus, condensus, ad.
Closed together.
1 Compressus, ad. vt com­
pressi oculi.
Close together.
1 Dense, adu.
Close, or narrowe.
1 Arctus, ad.
Close, secret, or vnknowen
1 Arcanus. 2 Obscurus, ad.
Close, or darke, as the awe is in
time of raine. 2 Austrinus, ad.
Verie close, or darke.
1 Tenebrosissimus, ad.


A Close, or pasture. 
1 Clausum, septum, conseptum. 


A Closet. 
1 Conclave, n. cella, cellula, f. 
armarium, abditorium, n. 
A little closet. 1 Armariolum, n.


A Clot, v:  clod and burre.


To Cloth, apparell, 
arraie, or attire. 




1 Vestio, amicio, conve­
stio, paro, apparo, induo. 
runico, velo, como. 3 stolo.
To cloath often. 1 Amicto.
To cloath, or cover rounde a­
bout. 1 Circumvestio.
To Cloath together.
1 Coamicio.
To cloath againe. 1 Revestio.
To be cloathed, or clad.
1 Vestior, amicior, induor, 
tunicor.
Cloathed, or clad.
1 Amictus, vestitus, indutus, 
tunicatus, 2 comptus, poli­
tus, p. & ior, issimus.
Cloathed, clad, or wrapped in, 
or cloathed with wool.
1 Lanatus, ior, ad.
Cloathed with a long robe.
1 Palliolatus, palliatus, ad.
Cloathed, or clad with a peti­
coate, shirt, or wastecoate.
1 Indusiatus, ad.
Cloathed, or clad with a robe
of estate. 1 Prætextatus, ad.
Clothed, or clad with russet, or
graie. 3 Leucophæatus, ad.
Cloathed, or clad with silke.
1 Sericatus, ad.
Cloathed or clad with wool.
1 Lanatus, ad.
Cloathed, or clad with gold, or
garment, finely wrought.
1 Segmentatus, ad.
Cloathed with blacke, mour­
ning, or poore apparell.
1 Pullatus, ad.
Cloathed with purple.
1 Purpuratus, ad.
Clothed with the cloath, which
is made of the wood Cannisura.
1 Cannisatus, ad.
Clothed in white.
1 Candidatus, ad.
Cloathed in a gowne wrought
full of palme trees, which con­
querours vsed to weare in time
of warre, and constables in
time of peace.
1 Palmatus, ad.
Clothed with a linnen vesture.
1 Linteatus, ad.
Cloth. 1 Pannus, m. 2 vestis, f.
A peece of cloth, or little cloth, 
or fine cloth. 1 Panniculus, m.
A linen cloath.
1 Linteum, linteolum.
A seere cloath, which beeing
nointed over with some salue, 
is laide to a sore.
1 Pittacium, n.
Cloath of Arras, or tapestrie.
2 Tapes, & pis. m. & petum, 
vel tapete, n.
Cloath wrought, or frised on
both sides.
1 Amphimallus, m. lum. n. 
amphitapa, f.
Cloath of needle worke.
1 Acupicta vestis. 
3 Acubita vestis.
Cloth of golde.
1 Segmentum, segmen, n.
Course cloath, of a lowe price.
1 Levidensa, f.
A table cloath.
1 Mappa, f.
A cloath to wipe anie thing
with.
3 Saccaonum, n. saccaonia, 
fæm.
An horse cloath.
1 Instratum, stratum, dorsu­
ale, n. 2 sudaria, f.
Cloath with an high noppe, as
baies and cotton.
1 Pannus villosus.
Cloth, or a garment of silke, 
whereon be wrought round fi­
gures like a cob-web.
1 Vestis scutulata.
Cloth, or a garment woven 
of, or hanging with diverse 
coulours.
1 Babilonica vestis.
Clothes of haire.
1 Capillacea vela.
Clothes to cover boothes, or
tents.
1 Velaria, n.
Clothes of a bed.

rale, thoralium, n. stragula, 
lodix, f.
Clothing, vid.  appareling.
A clothing about.

Clothing, or making of
cloth.

A shorte kinde of clothing, 
which commeth to the hands
only.
3 Mantum, n.
A clothier.

nifex, pannicularius, m lana­

To coine before.

To coine more.

Coined.
1 Cusus. 2 Percussus, confla­
tus, part.
Coine.
1 Nummus, m. vide money. 
A Coiner.
1 Cusor monetarius, num­
marius, m.
The marke, which the coine
beareth.
2 Forma, f.
A certaine coine of gold.
1 Philippeus, & pus.
A little peece of coine.
1 Nummulus, m.
A kind of coine, worth 2 shil­
lings 4. pence.
1 Stater, m.
An ancient coine, of the same
summe, having the image of
Darius on it.
1 Daricus.
A coine among the Romanes, 
being the fourth part of De­
narius.
1 Sestertius, m.
A certaine coine valuing 1000
Sertertij.
1 Sestertium, n.
A coine among the Romanes, 
worth 3 shillings 6 pence, after
some eight pence.
1 Denarius, m.
A coine called the Romane
penie, worth foure sestertios, 
& went in paie for 10. Asses: 
of it were three sortes, one the
sixte part of an ounce, another
the seventh part of an ounce, 
the third, the eight part of an
ounce.
1 Denarius nummus, dena­
rius, m.
The coine quadrans, or triunx, 
having on it the forme ratis.
1 Ratitus, m.
A coine called quadrans.
1 Dichalcum, n.
A coine lesse than that which is
called quadrans by the thirde
part. 1 Sextans, m.
A coine, having the image of
victorie vpon it, and is valued
to semidrachma.
1 Victoriatus, m.
A certain English coin, amoun­
ting to the sum of 16 shillings
eight pence.
1 Rosatus Anglicus.
A coine of English monie, called
a crowne.
1 Aureus, m stater aureus.
A coine containing in valew 4
drammes, which was 16 pence
sterling. 1 Nummus, m.
A coine of the valew of foure
groates eight to an ounce, called
Pallas foole. 1 Tetradrachma, f.
A coine of the same summe.




1 Siclus, m.
A coine among the Romanes, 
beeing the tenth part of obolus.
1 Chalcus, m.
An auncient coine, having on
it a man, bearing a pannier, 
beeing in value as much as
three obols, and an halfe.
1 Cistophorus, m.
A coine of foure oboli, which is
about foure pence halfe peny of
our money.
1 Tetrabolum, tetrobolum.
A small coine, being about the
value of a farthing. 1 Triens.
The least coine in Rome, being
in value, the twelfth part of
assis. 1 Vnclaria stips.
A coine, or price.
2 Cyclus, m.

with one handle. 
1 Haustellum, n. 


A Colloppe. 
1 Offa, offula, offela, 3 Frixa. 
To worke by collusion in plea­
ding, or doe anie thing by collu­
sion or coven.
1 Prævaricor, colludo.
A collusion, or, coven among
lawiers. 1 Prævaricatio, col­
lusio, f. 3 Colludium, n. syco­
phantia, Coltio, f.
He that pleadeth by collusion, 
or doth any thing by collusion.
1 Prævaricator, collusor, m.
By collusion or coven.
1 Collusorie, adu.


To Coloure. 
1 Coloro, tingo, 2 Inficio. 
To colour, or counterfaite.
1 Fuco, infuco, 2 Obtendo, 
prætexo.
To laie on a colure. 1 Fuco.
To colour, or cloke, vi:  cloke.
Coloured.
1 Coloratus, p. perpictus, ad. 
2 contactus, tinctus, p.
Set out with colour.
1 Circumlinitus, p.
Coloured, or counterfaited.
1 Fucatus, infucatus, p.
A colour. 1 Color, m. 3 croma
Counterfaite coloure. 1 Fucus.
A colour, shadow, or pretence.
2 Titulus, m. transcriptio, spe­
cies, vmbra, latebra, f.
The grounde coloure, whereon
the perfect colour is laide.
1 Sublitio, f.
A loosing, or destroying of color
1 Decoloratio, f.
That hath lost coloure.
1 Decoloratus, ad.
Of one colour 1 Vnicolor, ad.
Of three colours. 1 Tricolor.
Of the same colour. 1 Concolor.
Of sundry colours.
1 Discolor, varicolor.
Of diuerse coloures.
1 Multicolor, 2 Stragulatus.
That changeth colour.
1 Versicolor.
Ill colour. 1 Decolor.
False coloured. 1 Fusilis, ad.
Of a verie high, & red coloure.
2 Ardentissimus, ad.
Without colour or pretence.
1 Incolorate, adu. v: coloures. 


A Colme, vide coape.


A Colt. 1 Pullus, mannu­
lus, mannus, 2 Natus, m. 
A horse colt. 1 Equulus, 
m. equinus pullus.
A mare colt. 1 Equula, f.
The colt of a wilde asse.
3 Lalisio, f.
The foling of a colt. 1 Pullities
Coltish, or of a colt.
1 Pullinus, ad.


A Columne, as in a book. 
1 Columna, f.

A combate betweene two men
onlie. 1 Monomachia, f. duel­
lum, singulare, certamen, n.
The place where a combate is
fought. 1 Pancratium, n.

To combe often.
1 Pexo, pexito.
To combe downe, or at length
1 Propecto.
To combe againe. 1 Repecto.
To combe haire diligently.
1 Depecto.
To pul awaie by combing.
1 Depecto.
To comb an horse. 2 Distringo.
To be combed. 1 Comor.
Combed, or kembed. 1 Pexus, 
depexus, pectinatus, p. 
3 Pectitus, ad.
Combed againe, or wel combed.
1 Repexus, p.
Combed finelie. 1 Comptus, p.
Combed downe right.
1 Propexus, p.
A combe, or kempe.
1 Pecten, n. 2 Dens, m.
An horse combe, or curry comb.
1 Strigil, n. strigilis, f.
A little horse combe.
1 Strigillecula, f.
An hony combe. 1 Favus, m. 
2 Stabulum, n. 3 brisca vnica.
A little hony combe.
1 Favulus, favillus, m.
A combe-maker.
1 Pectinarius, m. & ria, f.
Of the fashion of a combs teeth.

 ioine together.

comber. 1 Impedio, intertur­
bo, vexo, 2 Implico.

2 Implicor, obruor.

situs, 2 Implicatus, implicitus

sus, vt salebrosa loca, comber­
some places, or where one canne
