inexplicitus, ad.
Comberously. 2 Permolestè.


To Come. 
1 Venio, incesso, commeo, 
vt literæ ad nos comineant. 
2 Fluo, vt inde fluere, to
come thereof. 
To come often. 1 Ventito.
To come to.
1 Advenio, adeo, accedo, ad­
vento, subcedo, aggredior, 
immigro, progredior, vt pro­
gredi in eum locum. to come
to that point.  2 tango, aspiro, 
evado, applico, vt applicare
vnum annum, to come to one
years age,  transeo, vt transire
ad partitionen, to come to speak
of the partition,  recipere se.
To come to a place. 1 Pervenio.
To come to by a little & little.
2 Prolabor, vt prolapsa est
huc libido, her wilfulnes came 
to this. 
To come to his iournies ende.




1 Pervenio.
To come to often.
1 Subvento, adventito
To come to nothing. 2 Defluo.
To come to passe, vide chaunce
and happen.
To come to passe, or to bee
brought to passe.
1 Fio, fore, futurum esse. 
3 Conforo.
To come wel to passe. 3 perfore.
To come to the knowlege of men
1 Enotesco, innotesco. 
2 Permano.
To come often to minde.
2 Occurso, recursare animo.
To come in.
1 Ingredior, introgredior.
To come in the place of another
1 Succedo. 2 Subeo.
To make to come in.
1 Intermitto.
To come in place. 1 Occurro.
To come in vse. 2 Occurro.
To come, as to come to minde, 
or remembrance. 2 Occurro, 
subeo, obversor.
To come in the meane while.
3 Intervenio.
To come before, or first.
1 Prægredior, prævenio, an­
tevenio, 2 Anteverto, vt an­
tevertere aliquem.
To come downe. 1 Descendo
devenio. 2 Defluo.
To come or goe againe.
1 Redeo, regredior, recedo, 
remigro. 2 Reverto, rever­
tor, recurro. 3 Revenio.
To come to himselfe againe.
1 Resipisco. 2 Recipio.
To come againe by, and by.
1 Redito, recurro, redambulo.
To come again to see. 1 Reviso.
To come against.
1 Contravenio, obvenio.
To come forth.
1 Prodeo, procedo, provenio

To come out, or issue forth.
2 Emergo.
To come out. 1 Exeo, egredior
To come off, or proceede from.
1 Existo.
To come from, or issue out of.
2 Mano, dimano, promano, 
fluo, Orior.
To come together.
1 Convenio, coco, congredi­
or. 2 Confluo, convolo.
To come vpon. 1 Supervenio.
To come, or fal suddainelie vp­
pon. 1 Ingruo.
To come vpon one sodainlie, as
he is doing any thing.
1 Intervenio.
To come vppon, or after ano­
ther. 1 Supervenio.
To come abroad, or into an o­
pen place.
1 Expato. 2 Emano, vt ema­
navit fama, the same came a­
broade. 
To come or follow after.
1 Sequor postvenio.
To come quickly. 2 Advolo.
To come priuilie, vnlooked for, 
or vnawares. 1 Supervenio, 
2 obrepo. 3 Antexpecto.
To come late, or slowly.

To come leasurelie, or slowlie.
2 Serpo.
To come narrow together.
2 Procumbo.
To come vp young.

To be almost come. 1 Insto.
They come forth. 1 Proditur. 
impers.
Some bodie commeth forth.

He is come. 1 Venit, impers.
They come. 1 Venitur, impers.
They are come. 1 Ventum est,

They came sodenlie on.
1 Interventum est, impers.
The matter commeth to the
same purpose. Res eodem revolvitur.

Come hither. 1 Adesto, acce­
de, adesdum, ehodum.

A Comedie. 
1 Comœdia. 2 Scæna, fabula
A comedie, wherein the plaiers
were simplie araied.
1 Planipedia.
A comedie, or tragedie, wherein
diuerse persons are brought in, 
some tarying, & some departing
1 Drama, n.
A comedy, or enterlude, done by
vile personages.
1 Comœdia taberna­
ria. 
2 Fabula taberna­
ria
Certaine comedies so named.
1 Baptæ
A part of a comedie. 1 Actus, m
The most busy part of a comedy.
1 Epitasis.
The end of a comedie.
1 Catastrophe.
A writer, or maker of come­
dies. 1 Comicus, m.
A plaier of comedies.
1 Comaædus, scænicus, scena­
lis, scenaticus, scenatilis, 
Actor, m & actrix, f.
A comical poet.
1 Comœdiographus, m.
Comicall, pertaining to, or han­
dled in comedies.




1 Comicus. 3 Comœdicus, ad
Of, or belonging to playing co­
medies. 1 Scænicus, ad.
Like a comedie.
1 Comice, scænice, adu.

on of the aire. 1 Disceus, m.

of 7 were appointed in commission

chorus, concessus, comitatus. 
congressus, m. multitudo,

1 Dissociatio, f.
A company of men, great or
smal. 1 Decuria, f.
Of one company. 1 Sodalis, ad.
A company of naughty persons.
2 Colluvies, colluvio, f.
A company incorporate, of any
craft. 1 Sodalitas, f. sodalitium. 
A company of men of warre.
1 Exercitus, m. cohors, f.
A company of ten souldyers to­
gether in a pavilion.
1 Contubernium, n.
A company of horse-men in
war, containing 40 souldiers.
3 Pyrgus, m.
They that assemble in compa­
nies. 1 Catervarij, m.
He that hateth the company of
men. 1 Misanthropos.
Pertaining to companies.
1 Catervarius, ad.
By companies, flockes, or bands.
1 Turmatim, gregatim, ma­
nipulatim, catervatim, adu.


A Companion, 
vide fellowe. 
A companion, or fellowe in an
office. 1 Collega, m.
A companion by the way.
1 Convena, co g. affectator.
A companion in warres.
1 Commiles, com. g. commi­
lito, m.
A companion in service. 1 Con­
servus, m. conserva, f.
Companions dwelling together
in one house. 1 Periœci. m.
Companions, where manie men
doe one thing together.
3 Actitiosi, m.
Companions in warre.
1 Systratiotes, m.
Companions of Monckes.
1 Synoditæ, m.
A companion, or partaker.
1 Particeps, consors, ad.
A little companion.
1 Comitellus, m. v. fellowe. 


To Compare, or
make comparison. 1 Compa­
ro, confero, assimulo, com­
pono, 2 contendo, copulo. 
To compare, or make equall.
1 Æquo, adæquo, æquiparo, 
peræquo, coæquo.
To compare, or set together, to
see the likenesse, or difference.
1 Committo
To be compared. 1 Æquor.
Compared. 1 Collatus, p.
A comparing, or conferring.
1 Collatus, m collatio, f.
Comparison, or likenesse.
1 Comparatio, æquiparatio, 
proportio, f.
A comparison, or comparing of
like things.
1 Parabola, assimulatio, f.
A comparison of things con­
trarie. 1 Syncrisis.
The comparatiue degree.
1 Comparativum, n.
That may be compared.
1 Comparabilis, æquiparabi­
lis, ad.
Wherein is comparison.
1 Comparativus, ad.
In maner of comparison.
1 Comparative, adu.
In comparison of. 1 Præ, præp.


To Compasse, or en­
viron, vide environ. 
To compasse one round about.
1 Amplector, complector.
To compasse, or goe about.
1 Lustro, perlustro, prælu­
stro, oblustro.
To compasse with a trench.
1 Obvallo, vallo.
To compasse about with a wall.
1 Obmuro.
To fetch a compasse about.
1 Flecto.
To compasse, or goe in circuite.
1 Gyto.
To make a compasse with a cir­
cle. 1 Circino.




To compasse, or attaine.
1 Comprehendo.
To bee compassed. 1 Obeor. 
2 capior, vt, capi dolis, to bee
compassed with deceits. 
Compassing, or going round a­
bout. 1 Obiens, p.
Compassed, or gone round about.
1 Lustratus, prælustratus, p.
Compassed with a ditch, or
trench. 1 Vallatus, obvallatus.
Compassed or set about, as with
a garland. 1 Redimitus, p.
Measured with a compasse.
1 Circinatus, p.
Compassed foure square.
1 Quadratus, p.
That must be compassed, or done.
2 Obeundus, p.
A compasse, v.  circle, & circuit.
An instrument called a compas.
1 Circinus, circinulus, m.
A compas. 2 Menia, n. vt mæ­
nia mundi. The compas of the
world. Orbita, f. vt orbita lu­
næ, The compas of the Moone. 
The compas of the firmament, 
which incloseth al thinges.
1 Cœlum, n.
The compasse, whereby the po­
sition & elevation of the pole
unknowen.
1 Pyxidicula nautica, f.
The compas about the apple of
the eie. 1 Iris, 3 Eon.
The compasse, or limits of any
thing, vide Boundes.
The compasse of the yeare.
1 Anniversalis, ad.
A compasse, or turning, as in
waies. 1 Ambage, ab. ges. pl. f.
A compassing, or going rounde
about. 1 Lustratio, f.
A compassing, or bringing a­
bout. 1 Circumferentia, f.
A compassing course.
1 Circinatio, f.
Hee that compasseth or goeth
about. 1 Lustrator, m.
A peece of grounde, which the
water compasseth about.
1 Circumluvium, n.


To haue Compassi­
on of, vide Pittie.


To Compel, v.  constrain.

To Complaine of
anie thing that grieveth him. 
1 Queror, conqueror, deque­
ror, clamo. 
To complaine, & crie.
1 Deploro, clamo, v. to lament. 
To complaine softlie. 1 Musso.
To complaine greatly.
1 Queritor, clamito.
To complaine of, or make a com­
plaint. 1 Defero, incuso, ac­
cuso, criminor, postulo, ex­
postulo, causor.
To complaine wrongefullie.
1 Sycophantor, sycophantisso.
Complained. 1 Questus, p.
A complaining for a thing don.
1 Expostulatio, postulatio, 
criminatio.
A complainer of wrong done
to him. 1 Postulator, expostu­
lator, m. & trix. f.
A secret complainer. 1 Delator
A false, or wrongeful complainer.
1 Sycophanta, m.
A complaint, or mone making.
1 Querela, queremonia, que­
ritatio, conquestio, f. questus, 
conquestus, gemitus, m.
A complaint put vp against one
1 Delatio, incusatio, expo­
stulatio, f.
A complaint, secretlie or fal­
slie made. 1 Sycophantia, f.
A bil of complaint. 1 Delatio, 
f libellus, accusatorius. m.
One that complaineth, or ma­
keth his mone.
3 Queremoniarius, m.
One that is ful of complaints.
1 Querulus, queribundus, ad.

dia, 3 convenientia, homo­
næa, f.
Concord in singing.
1 Synpsalma.
Concord in musick, or any tune.
1 Harmonia, symphonia, f.
A con­
cord in
musick, 
Of 2. notes, or a note
and a halfe, called a
third note.

A con­
cord in
musick, 
Of 2. and a halfe cal­
lled a fourth.
1 Diatessaron.
A con­
cord in
musick, 
Of 3. notes, & a halfe, 
called a fift.
1 Diapente.
A con­
cord in
musick,
Of 5. notes and 2. half
notes, called an eight.
1 Diapason.
A concordance. 1 Concordantia
Theevish concordance, or concord.

To concorporate, or make one

To Condemne. 
1 Damno, condemno, judico. 




to condemn or mislike. 1 improbo
To condemn before. 1 prædamno.
To be condemned. 1 Damnor, 
condemnor, reus peragor.
Condemned, 1 Condemnatus, 
judicatus, damnatus, p.
Condemned before. 1 Prædam­
natus, præjudicatus, p.
Worthy to be condemned.
1 Damnandus, p.
Not condemned. 1 Incondem­
natus, ad.
He that condemneth.
1 Condemnator, m.
A condemnation. 1 Damnatio, 
catacrisis, f. damnatus, m.
A condemnation vpon an exile­
ment. 1 Proscriptio, f.
A place in Rome, where condem­
ned persons were cast downe hed
long by staires. 1 gemoniæ scalæ
One condemned to fight with
beastes in the sight of people
1 Bestiarius, m.
He that buieth the goods of the
condemned, for little or nothing.
1 Sector, m. sectrix, f.

A Conduite. 
1 Aquæductio, f. aquæductus, 
ductus, m. aquagium, aquæduc­
tile, n. inductio aquarum. 3 aquæ­
drivale, aquælotium, catadupta. 
Great conduits, or large pipes of
water, brought from conduits in 
to great mens houses, & drawen
at cockes, & serving for every of­
fice. 2 Nilus, vel nili, m.
A conduite pipe. 1 canalis, dub.
Meatus aquæ. 
2 Iter aquæ.
An head, or heades of conduite. 
1 Dividiculum, 2 castella, n.
The conduites, or passages, by the
which the seede passeth from the
kidneis in generation.
1 Parastatæ parastaticæ, f.
Like a conduit pipe.
1 Canalitius, ad.

and fleame out of the stomacke.

ces and honie, 1 Diacydonium, 
diacytoniten.

A Conie. 
1 Cuniculus, 3 dasypus, m. 
Young conies taken from the
dammes bellie, or taken from the
teats, beyng sodden with their en­
trals wel cleansed: in olde time it
was counted a most delicat meat.
1 Laurices. um.
Full of conies. 1 Cuniculosus.
A conigre, vide warren.

Bambacium, & bambasion, 2
grossapin a, f.
White cotton.

or hearbes are. 1 Lanuginosus.
Cotton cloth.
1 Xylinus pannus. 
Villosus pannus.
Of, or belonging to cotton.
1 Xylinus, ad.

To aske Counsell, or
advise.

sulto, 3 consilior, consilio.

suadeo, 2 consuadeo, hortor, 
adhortor, instruo, moreo, 
permoveo.
To take counsell.
1 Delibero.
To be asked, or sought to for
counsell. 1 Consulor.
Counsell.
1 Consilium, monitum, n. ad­
monirio, f. Suasus, m. 2 Mens, 
vide advise.
A counsell house.
1 Curia, f. consistorium, syne­
drium. augustale, senacu­
lum, prytaneium, concilia­
bulum, consiliatorium, pre­
torium, comitium, n.
A generall counsell.
1 Synodus, f. concilium, n.

Generall Counselles: holden An. D. 
320 At Nicia in Bithinia. concilium Nicænum.
361 At Arminium in Italie. concilium Ariminense.
346 At Antioche in Syria. concilium Antiochenum.
419 At Carthage in Affricke. concilium Carthaginense.
453 At Calcedon in Bithinia. concilium Calcidonense.
813 At Orleance in Fraunce. concilium Arelatense.
869 At Constantinople. concilium Constantinopolitanum.
1428 At Ferraria in Italie. concilium Ferrariense.
1414 At Constance in Helvetia. concilium Constantiense.
1345 At Basill in Almaine. concilium Basiliense.
1216 At Rome, in the Pallace 
Lateranum. concilium Lateranense.
1273 At Lions in Fraunce. concilium Lugdunense.

counsell is holden.

A counselling.

ching the life of a man.
1 Sententia, f.
Want of counsell.
1 Aporia, f.
A counsellour, or he that gives
counsell.

admonitor, persuasor. consili­
ator, consiliarius, m.

To put out of the Court. 
1 Excurio.
A court, or yeard. 1 Area, f.

fore an house.

A courte of husbandrie, or
place where poultry is fedde.
1 Chors, f.

f. palatium, prætorium, au­
gustale, n. basilica, f.

wherein people vse to walke.
1 Platea, f.

1 Curia, f.
A little court. 1 Curiola, f.
The common place where courtes
were kept, and matters of iudge­
ment handled, and decided.
1 Forum, judiciale.
A place in the courtyard about
the gate, or comming in, where
the images of forraine people, 
painted tables, scutcheons, coat-­
armoures, and other such orna­
ments were kept. 1 Pinacotheca
A broad place in the court of
an house to stand in. 1 Cavædium
Court barons.
1 Curiæ dominicales.
Court daies 1 Festi dies.
A courtier. 1 Aulicus, m.
Noble courtiers, that haue done
service in the field.
1 Augustales.
Courtlines. 1 Curialitas, f.
Court like. 1 Aulicus, m.
Belonging to a princes court.
1 Palatinus, aularius, ad.
Courtlike, or after the manner
of the court. 1 Aulice, adu.

A Courtaine, v: curtain. 

A Courier, vide currier.

To make Courtesie. 
1 Ingeniculo, & lor, genicu­
lo, & lor. congeniculo. 
3 Suffraginor.
To speake courteouslie againe, 
being spoken to. 1 Resaluto.
A making of courtesie.
3 Suffraginatio, f.
Courtesie, or gentlenes.
 Humanitas, vrbanitas, be­
nignitas, facilitas, comitas, 
clementia, civilitas, benevo­
lentia, 2 Commoditas, f. can­
dor. m. collibentia, v. gentlenes. 
Courtesie in talk. 1 Affabilitas
A courteous speaking againe, 
after one is spoken to.
1 Resalutatio, f.
That maketh curtesie.
3 Suffraginatus. p.
Courteous. 1 Humanus, vrba­
nus, benignus, comis, comes,
clemens, mitis, facilis, blan­
dus, lenis, placidus, civilis, 
tractabilis, bellus, 2 candidus
commodus, 3 antismos, antis­
micus, vide gentle. 
Verie courteous. 1 Perhuma­
nus, perurbanus, perbenig­
nus, percomis, permitis, per­
tractabilis, perindulgens, 
mansuetus, issimus, 2 Suavis, 
issimus, ad.
Verie courteous in wordes.
1 Affabilis, perblandus, ad.
Without courtesie. 1 Rusticus.
Courteouslie, or gentlie.
1 Humane, & iter, vrbane, 
benigne, comiter, civiliter, 
blande, officiose. 
3 Vrbanatim, adu.
Verie courteouslie.
1 Perhumaniter, perbenigne.
Courteouslie in words.
1 Affabiliter, adu.

venca, f.

To seeke by Crafty meanes. 
1 Aucupor.
To bring in craftily. 1 Immitto
To be craftie. 2 Vulpinor.
Craftines, or craft. 1 Calliditas
solertia, ars, versutia, panur­
gia, vafritia, fraudulentia, a­
stutia, captio, f. astus, dolus, 
m. vide deceit.
Craftie meanes to deceaue.
2 Machina, f.
A craft, or craftie imagination.
1 Techna, f.
Craftie handling. 1 Fallicia, f.
Craft, or cunning. 1 Artisicium, 
n. ars. 2 Minerva, f.
Craft of running, or other feats
of activitie. 1 Athletica, f.
The crafte to work brasse, or 
such like mettal. 1 Ærisicium.
Craft to get fauour, or goods.
1 Captatio, f.
Craft to ordaine a banquet, or
supper. 1 Cænacularia, f.
A crafty deceit, or crafty wor­
king. 1 Sutela, f.
A craftie polishing of a thing
to make it saleable.
1 Mangonium. n.
Craftie prankes, or touches.
3 Offutiæ, offuciæ, offucetæ, 
offudæ, f.

A crafty beginning of an ora­
tion. 1 Insinuatio, f.
The stealing, or creeping into a
thing by crafty meanes.
1 Obreptio, f.
A crafts man. 1 Mæchanicus, 
opifex. com. g. vide artificer.
Hee that exerciseth a craft to
the end to gaine thereby.
1 Quæstuarius, ad.
He that setteth forth a craft.
1 Technophyon.
An old craftie foxe.
1 Veterator, m. trix, f.
A crafty fellow. 2 Versipellis.
Crafty knaues, or liers.
1 Tenebriones, m.
A craftie inventour.
1 Technides, m. technicus, ad
A crafty talker.
1 Versutiloquus. ad.
Things craftilie handled.
1 Veteratoria, n.
Crafty, or subtile. 1 Astutus, 
vafer, versutus, veteratorius, 
solers, cautus, fallax, fraudu­
lentus, percautus, callidus, 
astus, insidiosus, dolosus, sub­
dolus, argutus, perfidiosus, 
pellax, deceptorius, malitio­
sus, malus, 2 Vulpinus, vulpi­
n aris, ad.
Crasty, or cunning. 1 Ingeniosus
artificiosus, technicus, ad.
That setteth forth things craf­
tily, that they may be saleable.
1 Mangonicus, ad.
He that is not crafty.
1 Incallidus, ad.
By craft. 1 Ex insidijs.
Craftily. 1 Astute, ver­
sute, veteratorie, vasre, per­
astute, dolose, solerter, frau­
dulenter, callide, caute, per­
sidiose, scite, insidiose, subdo
le, malitiose, adu. astu, abl.
Craftily, or workingmanlie, vide
artificially.

spasma, n. convulsio, ectasis, f. 
distentio nervorum.
A kind of cramp, happening to

moue anie way.
1 Tetanus, emprosthotonus.
A crampe hapning to the hinder
partes of the bodie, and turning
the head awrie to the backe, or
shoulders.
1 Posterganeus raptus.
One taken with the crampe.

micus, ad.

serching diligently. 1 Perrepto.

such like. 1 Erro.

tro, intono, vlulo, exululo.

To crie out often.
1 Clamito, conclamito.
To crie out as little infaints do.
1 Vagio, obvagio.
To crie often. 1 Vagito.
To cry out vpon one. 1 Obstre­
po, occlamito. 3 occento.
To crie out for aide of the Ro­
manes. 1 Quirito.
To crie vnto. 1 Acclamo.
To crie together, or cry & call 
vpon with a loude voice.
1 Conclamo.
To cry softly.
1 Succlamo, concrepo.
To crie in the market, as the 
bel man doth. 3 Præconiso.
They crie out against.

Crying. 2 Mugiens, p.

To Crowne. 
1 Corono, redimo.
To crown with laurel. 3 laureo
Crowned. 1 Coronatus, redi­
mitus, 3 Diadematus, p.
Crowned with laurell.
1 Laureatus, p.
A crowne. 1 Corona, f.
A little crowne.
1 Corolla, coronula, f.
A kings crowne.
1 Diadema, n. corona, f.
A crowne given to him, that
first invaded the enimies campe
1 Corona vallaris. 
Corona castrensis.
A crowne giuen to him that
first scaled the walles.
1 Corona muralis.
A crowne, or garland of oake, 
given to him that saved a citi­
zen. 1 Corona civica.
A crowne given to him, which
first boorded a ship.
1 Corona navalls, 
Corona rostrata.
A crowne given to a captaine, 
that raised a siege.
1 Corona obsidionalis.
A crowne sent to the emperor, 
in honour of triumph.
1 Corona triumphalis.
A victorious crown, giuen to a
prince, or captain, for a victo­
rie without slaughter of men.
1 Corona ovalis, ovale, n.
The crowne, or top of a thing, as
of an hil, or such like.
1 Vertex, & vortex, m.
The crowne of the heade.
1 Apex, m. 3 Aequalium, mi­
socraneum, n.
A crowne of mony. Aureus, m
A crowning. 1 Coronatio, f.
A crowner, or hee that putteth
on a crowne. 1 Coronator. m.
A crowner, an officer so called.
1 Quæstor, vel quæsitor ho­
micidij, quæstor paricidius.

To Crucifie. 
1 Crucifigo.
Crucified.
1 Crucifixus, p. 3 dierectus.
A crucifixe. 3 Crucifixa, f.

To Crud, vide curde.

Crudity, or lack of good di­
gestion. 1 Apepsia, cruditas, f.
Crudity, or rawnes. 1 Cruditas.

To be cruell, or ex­
ercise crueltie. 
1 Sævio, ferocio, 3 Dureo.
To be cruell againe. 1 Resævio.
To shewe extreame crueltie a­
gainst one.
1 Desævio. 2 Hispanizo.
To shew extreame crueltie in a
place. 1 Degrassor.
To wax more cruel. 2 Crudesco
To doe cruelly.
3 Maligno, malignor.
Cruelty. 1 Atrocitas, sævitia, 
crudelitas, diritas, feritas, im­
manitas, inclementia, trucu­
lentia, carnificina, tyrannis, 
importunitas, sævitudo, au­
steritas, impietas, indignitas
tetritudo, 2 Acerbitas, duri­
tas, rabies, acritas, barbaria, 
fœditas. 3 carnificia, trucitas
rigiditas, bestialitas, hispa­
nitas, fœm.
Cruel. 1 Crudelis, jor, issimus
ferus, dirus, efferus, teter, ior, 
erriimus, ferox, atrox, sævus, 
issimus, severus, malignus, im­
mitis, immansuetus, incomis, 
implacidus, issimus inclemens
issimus, austerus, trux, trucu­
lentus, vesanus, tyrannicus, 
paricidialis, terribilis, violen­
tus, inhumanus, tetricus, ne­
farius, importunus, issimus
improbus, impius, sceleratus, 
indignus, jor, issimus 2 rigidus
ferreus, asper, cruentus, bar­
barus, funestus, exitialis, fu­
nebris, rabidus, rapidus, vt ra­
pidi leones, cruell lions. acer, 
acris, sanguineus, sanguina­
rius, inhospitus, injustus, 
spurcus, issimus, viperosus, a­
cerbus, vt acerbum specta­
culum, a cruel sight, fædus, tur­
pis, prorervus, fænetarius, 
tragædicus, crudus, vt ensis
crudus, a cruel sword, manli­
anus, belluinus, tragicus, in­
cicur, truculentus, sanguinans, 
bestialis, hispanus, ad.
Cruell in lookes. 1 Torvus, ad.
Cruelly. 1 Crudeliter, issime, 
atrociter, fæviter, inclemen­
ter, violente, impie, indigne, 
immisericorditer, impoten­
ter, inhumane, inhumaniter,

To Cutte. 
1 Seco, scindo, accido, sindo, 
conseco, reseco, cædo, exe­
co, 2 laucio, sulco, vt sulcare
maria, 3 delorico.
To cut, or hacke.

To cut, or hew with an axe, 
bill, or hooke.
1 Ascio, falcito, dolo, dedolo
To cut ones throate.
1 Iugulo.
To cut verie much.
Ocseco.
To cut againe, or behind.
1 Recido.
To cut, or mowe againe, that
which before was not well
cut.
1 Sicilio.
To cut off.
1 Abscindo, disseco, seco, de­
tondeo. defalco, decido,

cbes, or leaues.

it many other may be planted.

1 Elimo.
To cut off or betweene.
1 Interputo.
To cut off, or in peeces.

tersecatio, f.
A cutting awaie. 1 Putatio, 
amputatio, syncopa, vel syn­
cope synthonomia, f.
A cutting awaie, off, or again.
1 Rescissio, recisio, f.
A cutting awaie of the bone 
with the wounde.
1 Aposteparnismos.
A cutting down 1 Dejectus.
A cutting short 1 Detruncatio
Cuttings, or that is cut off.
1 Procisium, segmen, segmen­
tum, secamentum, n. sectio.
Cut in foure partes.
1 Quadrisidus, ad.
Cut often. 1 Sectilis, sectivus.
Easie to be cut.
1 Sectilis, sissilis, scissilis, ad.
That cannot be cut.
1 Insectabilis, ad.
Vsed to be cut, or lopped.
1 Cæduus, ad.
Not vsed to be cut.
1 Incæduus, inciduus, ad.
Cut off, or pared from the prin­
cipal. 1 Subcæsivus, ad.
That is cut before.
1 Præcidaneus, ad.
That wherewith one cutteth.
1 Excisorius, ad.
Belonging to cutting of trees.

us, ad.
Cuttedly.

to consult of matters.

A pleading day, as in terme
time. 1 Dies fastus, Ovid.

nor sitting to hear, or determine

confessed a debt, to provide mo­

lawfull to medle with the deb­
tour 1 Dies justi.

This entry runs without interruption into the next, "To desire, or covet."

Certaine devilles, who in a coun­
terfaite shap of women alluring
young springals, were thought to 
destroie them. Apuleius calleth
them the ladies of the fathress.
1 Lamiæ, f.
Devills, which in the likenes of
men accompaned with women.
1 Incubi.

women lay with men.
1 Succubi, m.
A place where Devilles gaue
answere in inots.

Deuilish.

moriacus, ad.

Diligent. 1 Diligens, sedulus, 
studiosus, industrius, Navus, 
Indeses, 2 Intentus, assiduus, 
impiger, fervidus, ad. Vigilans
p. Vigil, com. g.
Very diligent.
1 Perdiligens. diligentissi­
mus. 2 Pervigil, ad.
Diligent about his affaires.
2 Attentus, p.
Diligent to attend vpon one.
1 Observans, p.
Diligent to laboure, and worke.
1 Operosus, ad.
Diligent in seeking.
1 Quæritabundus, ad.
Diligent in dutye, or office.
1 Officiosus, ad.
Diligent to doe that hee is com­
maunded.
3 Obsequibilis, Obsequio­
sus, ad.
Diligent, or hee that beareth
the charge, which the people
should.
3 Munis, ad.
A Favourer of the diligent.
1 Spudastes.
Diligently.
1 Diligenter, sedulo, Studio­
se, Curate, Industriè gnavi­
ter, Naviter, Solicitè, 2 Instan­
ter, Attentè, intentè, Vigi­
lanter, Impigre, Religio­
se, Enixe, Enixim, A mus­
sim, adamussim, Examussim, 
Ad, vnguem, 3 amussatim, ex­
amussatim, adu.
Verie diligentlie and curious­
ly.
1 Accurate, Perdiligenter, cu­
riose, 2 Perattente, strenue, 
Enixius, adu.
Diligently, or serviceably.
1 Officiose perofficiose, adu.
Diligently, or with much sear­
ching.
1 Indaganter, adu.
More diligently.
1 Industrius, adu.
Without diligence.
1 Defunctorie. Perfuncto­
rie, adu.

A Dilling, or childe
borne when his father is old. 
1 Proculus, m.
A dilling, or wanton.
1 Prædagium, n.

A Dimilance. 
1 Lanceola, f.
A dimilancer, or light horseman.
1 Flexumen, vel flexamen, lan­
cearius, m. lancifer, veles, ad.

To Diminish, or a­
bate. 
1 Minuo, diminuo, imminuo
2 infringo, decoquo, defalco
Levo, 3 Minoro, v: To appaire, 
or make lesse.
To be diminished.
1 Recedo, extenuor.
Diminished.
1 Minutus, diminutus, immi­
nutus, comminutus, Attenu­
atus, Tenuatus, 2 Castratus, 
Castigatus, Attonsus, contra­
ctus, Attritus, 3 minoratus, p.
Not diminished.
2 Indelibatus, Inattenua­
tus, ad.
A diminishing.
1 Diminutio, Imminutio, 
Attenuatio, Extenuatio, 2
Hebetatio, Elevatio, 3 Mi­
noratio, f.
A diminitiue.
1 Diminitivum, n.

To Dimitte. 
1 Dimitto.

To Dimme, or make
dimme. 
1 Obscuro.
To be dimme of sight. 1 Lippio, 
caligo, cæcutio.
Dimmenes. 1 caligo, obscuritas
2 Vertigo, f.
Dimmenes of sight.
1 Caligatio, luscio, luscitio, 
scotomia, f. scotoma, n. 3 a­
maurosis, f.
He that is dimme of sight.
1 Lippus, ad. caligans, p. lus­
ciosus, luscitiosus, luscius, ad.
Dimme, or darke. 1 caliginosus.

To Dine. 
1 Prandeo, meridio, meridior.
To dine, or eat often. 1 Pransito.
That hath dined.
1 Pransus, p.
That hath not dined.
1 Impransus, ad.
He that is at dinner.
1 Pransor, m.
He that dineth with another.
1 Compransor, m.
A dinner. 1 Prandium, 2 men­
sa, f. 3 Merarium, n.
A little dinner, or short commons.
1 Prandiolum, prandiculum, 
prandiusculum, n.
A starting dinner, a snatch and
away. 1 Statarium prandium.
A dinner of fiue sundrie dishes.
2 Pentapharmacum, n.
A dinner given at a departure.
1 Prandium viaticum.
A dining place. 1 pransorium.
Belonging, or serving for din­
ner. 1 Pransorius, ad.

Dinne, vide Noise.

Dint, vide Dent.

A Diocesse. 
1 Diœcesis, f. territorium, n.

A diphthong, or two
vowels contracted into one sil­
lable. 1 Diphthongus, f.

To Dippe in liquor, 
1 Intingo, tingo, 2 Immergo, 
Mersito.
To Dippe vnder. 1 Submergo.
To dip to the bottom. 1 demergo.
To dippe in againe. 1 Retingo.
To dippe often.
1 Merso, mersito.
Dipped in.
1 Demersus, submersus, tin­
ctus, intinctus, insectus, p.
Dipped first in.
1 Prætinctus, p.
A dipping.
1 Baptismus, m. baptisma, 
baptismum, n. Immersio, f.
A dipping vnder.
1 Submersio, f.

To Direct, or rule.

grummor, regulo.
To direct toward a place.
1 Appello, tendo.
To direct, or make right by a 
smal thing.
3 Momento.
Direct.
1 Directus, p.
Directing.
1 Moderans, p.
Direction.
1 Moderamen, n. directio, f.
Directlie.
1 Rite, expresse, directe, dire­
cto, adu.




Directlie against.
1 Eregione, ex adverso.

Dirt, or mire. 
1 Cænum, n. vide durte.

base.

To Disagree. 
1 Dissentio, dissentior, differo, 
vario, discrepo, disconvenio, 
dissideo, discordo, 2 pugno, 
depugno, dissono, disto. Ab­
sentio.
To disagree from.
2 abhorreo, cum præp. vide
 resist. 
Excido, cum præp. vide
resist.
To disagree often.
1 Discrepito.
A disagreeing, disagreement, or
discord.
1 Discordia, dissentio, discre­
pantia, contrarietas, f dissidium, 
n. dissidentia, simultas, lis, fac­
tio, seditio, f. litigium, n. 2 re­
pugnantia, pugna, disjunctio, 
scissura. 3 Dividia. vide strife
Descord in musicke.
1 Diaphonia.
Disagreement betweene man &
wife.
2 Frigusculum, friviculum, n.
Disagreeable, or that disagreeth.
1 Inconveniens, incompetens
dissentaneus, 2 absonus, in­
concinnus. 3 discordabilis.

prooue. 1 Improbo, reprobo, 
culpo, 2 Damno.
Disalowed.

To Disanker, or
weigh vp the anker and take the

anchotis solutis.

To Disanull.

co, tollo, antiquo, annihilo,

rescindo, oblitero, extermino, 
induco, retexo, interverto, insir­
mo, convello, evello, expun­
go, vide to abolishe.
To disanull by publique iudge­
ment.
1 Abrogo.
Disanulled.
1 Abrogatus, p.
A disanulling.
1 Abolitio, abrogatio, f.

fringo, decollo, perimo, resol­

A Disease. 
1 Morbus, 2 malum, gravedo. 
invaletudo, valetudo, ægro­
tatio, f.
A disease when the heares of the
head fal of. 1 apoptosis, alopecia.
A disease in the head, aking, with
little round pustles, or soares ri­
sing. 1 Heterocrania.
A disease in the heade, comming
vp of the humor betwene the skin
& the skull. 1 Hydrocephalos.
A disease in the eye, which being
in the blacke of the eye, is white, 
and in the white, is redde.
1 Argema, n.
A disease in children, proceeding
of inftammation of the braine.
1 Siriasis. f.
A disease in the eye, having a 
white pimple like a haile stone.
1 Chalasium, n. chalasia, f.
A disease in the eye, named Di­
latatio pupillæ. 1 Mydriasis.
A disease making the eyes to 
stare. 1 Ecpiesmus.
A disease when the nether lid of
the eye cannot close to the other.
1 Ectropium, n.
The disease of the stone.
1 Calculus, m. lithiasis, f.
Subiect to that disease.
1 Calculosus, ad.
A disease, when the eyes mooved
with inflammation, by rupture
fall out of their places.
1 Proptosis.
A disease in the eies, when the
eye liddes doe not mooue downe­
ward. 1 Lagophthalmus.
A disease in cattell, by the which
the guts and lights doe rot.
1 Craura. f.
A disease in the eyes, called Suf­
fusio.
1 Hypochysis, et hypochyma.
A disease on the nose, called no­
li me tangere.
1 Polypus, carcinodes.
A disease in the mouth, like to 
the great kernels.
1 Antiades, adenes.
The disease called tongtidenes, or
speachlessenes, 1 anciloglossum.
A disease in the throte, like a




Squincie 1 Angina, f.
A disease breeding in the fingers
of men oftentimes.
1 Panaritium.
A disease in womens paps that
giue sucke, comming by swal­
lowing downe a heire.
1 Trichiacis.
A disease in the lungs, with a 
consumption of the whole body.
1 Pthisis, f.
One so, diseased. 1 Pthisicus.
A disease, when through the
lunges stopped, a man can hard­
ly fetch his breth, but with whea­
sing in the breast.
1 Asthma, Asthmaticus.
A disease about the members, 
called a Winchester goose.
1 Pudendagra.
A disease when one cannot hold
his water, but runneth from him
without staie, or as fast as hee
drinketh.
1 Diabetes.
A disease in women called the
mother.
1 Vulvæ strangulatio, Plin.
A disease in the fundament, ma­
king a wart like a figge.
1 Syosis.
A disease in the fundament, like
the chaps that the march winds
make. 1 Ragades.
A disease in the coddes.
1 Cirsos.
A disease called the collick pas­
sion. 1 Coliacus morbus, 
coliaca passio.
A sharpe disease, wherof a man
eyther dieth quickly, or recouereth
1 Oxia, morbus acutus.
A disease in the milt.
1 Lienecis.
One so diseased.  Lienicus, ad.
 a disease of hote chollerick bloud
which beginning to blister, grow­
eth to a soare, or scabble, like a
tetter: it is called Saint Anto­
nies fire. 1 Pusula.
That which causeth diseases.
1 Morbificus.

vide determine.

away. 1 Ablego.

To dispatch, or rid out of.
2 Extraho, explico, dissolvo.

1 Confungor, defungor.
The matter is dispatched, and
ended.
1 Confectum est. 
Transactum est.
Dispatched.

tus, peractus, perfectus, per­

transactus, effectus, p.

ctio, peractio, perfectio, f.

A dispending. 1 Sumptus, m.

To Dispense.

Dispensed.
2 Solutus, despensatus, p.
A dispenser. 1 Dispensator, m.
Dispenses.

A dispensation, or immunitie.
1 Vacatio, dispensatio, 2 solu­
tio, indulgentia, f.

ter. 1 Spargo, dispergo, dissipo
disjicio. 2 dissemino.
Dispersed.

Dispersed, abroad. 1 Displicatus
palatus, dispalatus.

2 Lacer, lacerus, ad.
As it were dispersed here and
there.

content. 1 Offendo, displicio, 2
rado, commoveo.
To displease a little.
1 Suboffendo.
To do one a displeasure. 1 Incom­
modo, male mareri. 2 molesto
To be displeased.
1 Gravor infenso, stomachor.
To be halfe displeased.
1 Subirascor.
It displeaseth.
1 Displicet. imperf.
Displeased.
1 Infensus, offensus, 2 pertæsus
indignans. aversus, p. perini­
quus, vide angrie.
Greatlie displeased.
1 Aversissimus, ad.
Displeasure, or breach of loue.
1 Simultas, offensio, offensa, of
fensus, offensiuncula, 2 ira, ini­
micitia, f. odium, n. stomachus, 
3 offendo.
A displeasure, or shrewd turne.
1 Malefactum, maleficium, n. 
maleficentia, f. incommodum, 
n. incommoditas, f.
She that displeaseth.
3 Displiciva, f.
A little displeasure.
1 Offensiuncula, f.
A displeasure. 1 Displicentia, f.
Displeasaunt.
1 Molestus, 2 inscitus, ad.
Some-what in displeasure.
1 Subinvisus, subodiosus, ad.
Some-what displeasant.
1 Submolestus, ad.
Displeasantlie.
1 Gravate, gravatim, ingrate, 
moleste, Ægre. 2 Aspere, re­
pugnanter, acerbe. 3 Gravan­
ter, adu.
Some-what displeasantlie.
1 Submoleste, adu.

order.

penso.

Disposed, or set in order

Disposition. 1 dispositio, affe­
ctio, f. dispositus, m. dispositum. 
2 Proclivitas, f. Ingenium, n. 
Animus, m. indolis, f. legitur
apud Verg. in plu. Indoles.

An ill disposition of the bodie.

The natural disposition, or vaine
of a man.

A perpetual disposing of things,

Without disposition.

Disposed to vomit.

Without disposition.

dinatè, adu.

To Divine, or pro­
phesie. 1 Divino, prædivino,

cto, conjecturo.
A diviner, south-sayer, or wi­
serd. 1 Divinator, hariolus, au­
gur, divinus, præsagus, 2 con­
jector, magus, fatidicus, fati­
canus, faticinus.
A diviner by looking in beastes
bowels. 1 Aruspex, haruspex.
Shee that divineth.
1 Haruspica.
Divination, or divining.
1 Mantia, auguratio, divi­
natio, prædivinatio, auguri­
um. 2 conjectio, conjecta­
tio, conjectura, aruspicium, 
haruspicium, hariolatio, præ­
sagium, præsagitio, 3 magi­
namentum.

telling of thinges to come.

Divination by the aire.
Aeromantia, f.
A devination by water. 1 Hy­
dromantia, lecanomantia.
He that vseth that divination.
1 Lecanomantes, hydro­
mantius.
Diuination by looking into the
fire. 1 Pyromantia, ignispicium.
A divination by lotts.
1 Sortilegium, f
Divination by looking into a 
glasse. 1 Catapyromantia.
A divination by birdes.
1 Oscinum, n.
The dignitie, or state of divi­
ners. 1 Auguratus, us, m.
The ornaments of diviners.
1 Augurale, lis.
Established by divination.
1 Auguratus, ad.
A tower, or castle, where men
divined of matters.
1 Auguraculum, n.
In divining a birde that crieth
from the top of any thing.
1 Supervaganea avis.
Pertaining to divination.
1 Auguralis, aruspicalis, va­
ticinus, haruspicinus, ad.
By divination.
3 Augurato, adu.

nity. 1 Theologus, gi. m.

A Doe, vide Bucke.

To Doe. 
1 Ago, facio, efficio, patro, 
perpetro.
To doe a thing againe. 1 Itero, 
reitero, redintegro.
To doe a thing slily, as to picke
a purse. 1 Manticulor.
To doe often.
1 Actito, agito, factito.
To go about to doe. 1 Facesso.
To doe, or accomplish. 1 Exe­
quor. perago, is. conficio.
To doe a thing diligently.
1 Recuro, satago.
To doe amisse. 2 Erro, oberro, 
prolabor.
To doe after the countrie fa­
shion, 1 Ruro.
To doe a good turne. 1 Gratifi­
cor, promereor, 3 promereo.
To doe, & vndoe. 1 Retexo.




To doe all things at others
commandement. 1 Obsecundo.
To doe a thing by measure, or
number. 1 Modulor.
To doe by course, or turne.
1 Alterno.
To doe a thing in vaine.
1 Frustro, frustror.
To doe a thing hastely.
1 Maturo, propero.
To doe a thing negligently.
2 Varico, varicor.
To doe like for like.
2 Retalio.
To doe a thing vnadvisedly.
2 Præcipito.
To doe a thing before another.
2 Præverto, anteverto.
To doe wel. 1 Benefacio.
To be done.
1 Fio, consio, effio.
I wil doe.
1 Faxo, profaciam, defect.
Done. 1 Perpetratus, actus, fa­
ctus, gestus, habitus, facessi­
tus, patratus, p.
Done before. 1 Anteactus.
Sodainly don. 1 Approperatus
That must be done. 1 Obeundus
Done, and dispatched.
1 Perfectus, transactus. p.
Done by stelth. 1 Surreptitus.
Done curiously. 1 Accuratus.
A door. 1 Factor, actor, effe­
ctor, patraror, m.
He that doeth anie thing often.
1 Factitator, m.
A thing done, vide deede.
A doing. 1 Executio, perfun­
ctio, actio, factio, effectio, 
factura, f.
The vertue, or power to doe.
1 Efficientia, f.
Rightful doing.
1 Catorthosis, f.
Enforcement to doe. 1 Nixus, us.
Late done. 3 Nuperus.

deliratio. 2 Anilitas, f.
Doting.
1 Delirans, p. delirus, vecors, 
ad. desipiens, p. 2 Anilis, insa­
nus, ad. insaniens, p.
Ful of doting. 1 delirabundus.
Dotingly. 2 Aniliter adu.




To Double. 
1 Duplico, adduplico, con­
duplico, congemino, gemi­
no, ingemino, 2 Itero.
To double againe.
1 Reduplico.
To double foure times.
2 Quadruplico.
Doubled. 1 Geminatus, dupli­
catus, ingeminatus, 2 Itera­
tus, p. 3 diplonius, ad.
A doubler. 1 Duplicator, 3 di­
plonator, m.
A doubling. 1 Duplicatio, 
conduplicatio, geminatio, f. 
duplicatus, m.
A doubling foure times.
1 Quadruplicatio, f.
A double linnen cloth.
2 Diploma. n.
The double.
1 Duplum, n. duplio, f.
A single worde, having a dou­
ble meaning.
3 Diptonia, f.
Doubling of wordes.
1 Anadiplosis, f.
Double.
1 Duplex, duplus, geminus, ge­
mellus, 3 Alterplex.
Double-edged. 2 Anceps.
Three times double.
1 Triplex, triplus.
Foure times double.
1 Quadruplex, quadruplus.
Fiue times double.

Doubling wise.

To doubt, or bee in
doubt. 1 dubito, addubito, am­
bigo. 2 hæreo, hæsito. cun­
ctor, contor, moror, fluctuo, 
nuto, pendeo, delibero, æstuo
titubo. 3 dubio.
To doubt somewhat.
1 Addubito.
To be halfe in doubt.
1 Subdubito.
It is in doubt.
1 Ambigitur, dubitatur, im­
pers.
To make doubtfull.
3 Incerto. as.
To keepe one in doubt.
2 Suspendo.
Not to doubt. 3 Indubito.
Doubted.
1 Dubitatus, addubitatus, p.
A doubt, or doubting.
1 Dubitatio, f. dubium, am­
biguum. n. 2 Hæsitatio. sus­
pensio, suspicio, fluctuatio, 
quæstio, aporia, f. scrupus, 
scrupulus, m. offendiculum, n. 
3 dubietas, f.
Doubtfulnes. vide ambiguity. 
A doubtful sentence.
1 Amphibologia, amphibolia
f. amphibolum, n. vel lon.
Doubtful speech.
1 Ambages, ambilogium, n.
One that doubteth, or a doubter
2 Hæsitator, m.
A little doubt.
1 Subdubitatio, f.
Doubtful. 1 Dubius, anceps, 
incertus, ambiguus, crepetus
2 Perplexus, nutans, æstu­
ans, fluctuans, suspensus, con­
troversus, trepidus, perdiffi­
cilis, multiplex, inexplicitus, 
medius, scrupulosus, 3 Ambi­
guosus, dubiosus, perplexibi­
lis, hæsitativus, ad.
Not doubtfull. 1 Indubius, ad.
Doubtfully. 1 Dubitanter, 
dubie, ambigue, incerte, du­
bitatim, 2 perplexe, lubrice, 
cunctanter, fluctuatim, per­
plexim, scrupulatim, scrupu­
lose, mussitanter. 
3 Perplexibiliter, mussim.
Without doubt, or doubtlesse.
1 Certe, indubitanter, qui­
dem, nempe, profecto, pro­
culdubio, næ, vero, indubie, 
haud dubie, hercule, meher­
cule, scilicet, nimirum.

To Draw. 
1 Traho haurio.
To draw by force, or violence.
1 Pertraho, protraho, prori­
pio, avello, rapto, rapio.
To draw forth, or out.
1 Promo, expromo, extraho, 
eruo, detraho, exhaurio, de­
haurio, exantlo, 2 Effero, e­
duco, exigo, elicio.
To draw out, as liquor.
1 Egurgito.
To draw out the bowels of anie
thing. 1 Exentero.
To draw backe, or refuse to doe
a thing. 1 Detrecto, as.
To draw to with a hooke.
1 Inunco, adunco, as.
To draw away, or withdrawe.
1 Subduco, subtraho, ab­
straho.
To draw a tooth. 1 Edento, as.
To drawe to. 1 Attraho, 
2 Excepto, adduco.
To drawe backe.
1 Retraho, retroago, retra­
cto, restito. 2 Revoco, subdu­
co, retroduco.
To draw by faire meanes.
1 Allicio, allecto, illicio, ille­
cto, induco, invito, allicifa­
cio.
To drawe neare, vide to ap­
proch. 
To drawe the first draught, as
painters doe.
1 Delineo, 2 adumbro.
To draw before a thing.
1 Obtendo.
To draw with pen, or pencil.
1 Lineo, delineo. 
2 Exaro, 3 Effigio.
To draw together.
1 Contraho, contorqueo.
To draw a great shippe with a
lesse vessel.
1 Remulco, as.
To drawe out oile cleane from
the mother.
1 Examurco, as.
To draw, or sucke the substance
out of a thing.
1 Defrudo.
To draw in length.
1 Produco, protraho.
To draw forwarde.
1 Produco.
To draw vp water.
1 Haurio, exhaurio, antlo, ex­
antlo, extraho, 2 Evoco, 
educo
To draw along, or traile.
1 Verro.
To draw asunder.
1 Diripio, diduco.
To draw breath.
1 Anhelo, suspiro.
To drawe in breath.
1 Inhalo.
To draw a bow.
2 Sinuo, curvo, incurvo.
To draw, as an hound by sent.
1 Investigo. 2 Odoror.
To drawe out from betweene.
1 Intertraho.
To draw out often.
2 Elicito.
To drawe a weapon out of a
sheath.
1 Evagino. 2 Exero, stringo, 
recludo.
To draw close together.
3 Trigo.
To draw cuts, or lots.
1 Sortio, sortior.
To draw to an issue, or sore.
1 Exulcero.
To be drawen asunder.
1 Diripior.
Drawen.
1 Haustus, prætentus, exer­
tus, tractus, p.
Drawen out by force.

tractus, p.

lence.

Drawen to.

Drawen awaie by violence.

1 Allectus, p.
Drawen out.
1 Expromptus, depromptus. 




protractus, extractus, liba­
tus, p.

To Drincke. 
1 Bibo, poto, 2 haurio.
To drincke much, or to quaffe.
2 Adbibo.
To drincke together.
1 Combibo, compoto.
To drinke vp all.
1 Epoto, ebibo, obbibo, de­
bibo, interbibo, 2 exugo, ex­
haurio.
To drincke all day, or continu­
ally. 1 Perpoto.
To drincke often.
1 Potito.
To drincke a little, or sippe.
1 Subbibo, pitisso.
To drincke to one.
1 Propino, præpoto, præbibo.
To drincke before.
1 Præbibo, præpoto.
To drincke in.
1 Imbibo, 2 adbibo.
To drincke warme drincke.
1 Thermopoto.
To drincke round.
1 Circumpoto.
To drincke more than is neede.
1 Superbibo.
To fil drincke to one.
3 Cyathisso.
To giue a drincke to horses, vid. drenche.
Men drincke.
1 Bibitur, impers.
Druncke vp.
1 Epotus, p.
That woulde faine drincke.
1 Poturus, p.
To be druncke.
1 Potandus, p.
A drincker.
1 Potor, potator, m.
A great drincker.
1 Bibax multibibus, ad. 
3 micio, bibulus, m. bibo­
sus, vide drunckard.
He that drincketh water al­
waies.
1 Hydropota, m.
A drincker of much wine.
1 Meribibulus, vinosus, me­
robibulus, ad.
They that drincke hoat drinck.
2 Thermopota, arum, m.
A drincker of milcke.
1 Galactopota, com. g.
A drincker of no wine.
1 Abstemius, 3 invinius. m.
A drincker, or beginner to one
in a cuppe.
1 Propinator, m.
They whose duty it was that all
shoulde drincke alike, when the
Grecians met at any feast.
1 Oenopotæ, m.
Drincke.
1 Potus, m. potio, f.
A drincke tempered with
bloude and wine.
1 Pissaratum, n.
A drincke of water and honie
sodde together.
1 Melicraton, n.
A small householde drincke, 
made with grapes mingled with
water in the presse.
1 Posca, lora, vel loria, f.

herbes, water, iuice, wine, salte, 
bread, oile, honie, and pepper.
2 Dodra, f.
Drincke made of mault.
1 Bryton, n.
A drincke made with Elicam­
pane.
1 Nectaritis.
A drincke made with salt, and
the fruite Sorba, to helpe the
chollicke.
1 Saprum, n.
Hee that drincketh such a
potion.




1 Saprophagus, m.
Immortall drincke.

li, itos, propoma, n.

combes sodden.

the Thracians vsed to drinke
vp at a draught wincking.

A drinking. 1 Potio, pota­

1 Circumpango.
To be driven. 2 Iactor.
To be driven out.
1 Expellor.
Driven. 1 Pulsus, com­

gitatus, p.

1 Abactus, profligatus, pro­
pulsus.

ver Padus

they passe the ordinary course of

tertinctus, infectus, imbutus, 
2 Fucatus, infucatus, conta­
ctus, part.

infector, offector, m.

3 Crocotularius, m.
He that dyeth a violet colour.
3 Violarius, m.

yealow veiles, or garmentes, as




the high priestess wife did weare.

He that dyeth a couloure neere
the violet, like the flower of
mallowes.

A dying.

made perfect.

To lay in the Earth, 
or interre, vide to bury. 
To make a thing of earth, as
pottes. 1 Plasmo.
The earth, or ground.
1 Terra, humus, tellus, f. 
solum, n.
A kinde of earth, yelow in co­
lour, found in mines of golde &
silver. 1 Sil, is. n.
An lute, or ashy earth, which
maketh the shinne wrinckled
and giveth a very amiable co­
loure to the whole bodie.
1 Chia terra.
A kind of earth, whereof lattin
mettal is made.
1 Cathmæa, & cathimia, f.
A kinde of earth, found in the
Isle Samos, and marked like a 
starre.
1 After Samius.
A kinde of earth, which beeing
rubbed with the fingers, maketh
a noise like the worne, or broken
pumish stone. 1 Melia terra.
A kinde of earth, growing a­
bout Seleucia in Syria, where­
with husbandmen annointe
their vines, to bill the wormes.
1 Ampelitis, f.
The description of the earth.
1 Geographia, f.
A describer of the earth.
1 Geographus, m.
A thing made of earth.
1 Fictile, figlinum. n.

thing of earth.

1 Flasles, m.

earth.

Formed of earth.

To Endure, or sustain
1 Sustento, fero, patior, 2 hausio
To endure paine.
2 Laboro.
To endure or continue.
1 Supersum, 3 perenno, vid: To
abide and continue. 
To endure all the sommer.
1 Peræstuo.
To endure al the winter.
1 Perhyemo.
That can endure or sustaine.
1 Patiens, p.
That hath endured.
1 Passus, p.
Enduring. 1 Patiens, perpeti­
ens, tolerans, p.
An enduring, or suffering, vide 
biding. 
Enduring all daie long.
1 Perdius, ad.
Enduring a long time.
1 Perdiuturnus, ad.

To make Enemies. 
3 Inimico.
To become enemies.
1 Inimicor.
An enemie.
1 Inimicus, m. hostis, com. g.
An enemie that maketh warre
against one.
1 Perduellis, com. g.
Enimitie.
1 Inimicitia, Hostilitas, f.




The enemies lande.
1 Hosticum, n.
A taker of enemies.
1 Hosticapax, ad.
Pertaining to an enemie.
1 Hostilis, hosticus, ad.
Like an enemie.
1 Hostiliter, inimice, issime, in
fense, adu.

To Enfeeble, vide
weaken.

To Enforce, or strain
himselfe earnestly. 
1 Conor, enitor, 2 certo, con­
tendo, intendo, insurgo.
Enforcing himselfe to doe a 
thing.
1 Adnixus, adnisus, p.
An enforcement, or constraint.
1 Coactus, m. 2 contentio, f. vi: 
constraine.

To Enfranchise, or
make free, vide to make free.

To Engender. 
1 Genero.
To engender againe.
1 Regenero, regigno.
Engendred, vide begotten.
Engendred together. 1 congenitus
Engendred in, or of nature.
1 Innatus, ingenitus, p.
He that hath the charge of bea­
stes when they covet to engender, 
& putteth the stalion to the mare
1 Peroriga, proriga, pruriga.
That hath power to engender.
1 Genitivus, ad.
That is easilie engendered.
1 Generabilis, ad.
Serving to engender.
1 Genitalis, ad. vide to beget.

An Engine. 
1 Machina, f. machinamentum.
A small engine.
1 Machinula, f.
An engine of warre, to shoote
dartes and quarrels.
1 Catapulta, f.
An engine vsed in warre.
1 Tormentum, n.
an engine to besiege a citty with.
1 Helepolis.
An engine of warre wherewith
walles were battered.
1 Sambuca, f.
An engine to throwe great stones
with. 1 Tortum, n.
Engines wherewith shippes are
drawen to the shoare.
1 Chamulci, m.
A place where a great engine is
laied. 1 Balistarium, n.
A maker of engines.
1 Machinator. 2 organarius, m.
One that casteth with an engine
in warre. 1 Machinarius, m.
Belonging to engines, or instru­
mentes of warre. 1 Machinalis, 
machinarius, machinosus, ad.
With an engine.
2 Organice, adu.

To Engraffe, vi: to graffe.

To Engrauè, graue, 
or entaile. 
1 Cælo, insculpo, inscalpo, 
scalpo, sculpo, incido, exculpo
scalpturio. 2 signo, inscribo, ef­
fingo, peraro, complector, duco.
Engraved. 1 Cælatus, insculp­
tus, incisus, scalptus, sculptus, 
scalpturatus, p.
An engraver, or entailer.
1 Cælator, sculptor, scalptor, a­
naglyptes, toreutes, m.
An excellent engraver of ves­
selles. 1 Mentor, m.
An engraver in stones.
1 Lythoglyphus, m.
An engraver of images.
1 Hermoglyphus, statuarius.
The arte of such engraving.
1 Statuaria, f.
An engraver in golde.
1 Aurigraphus, m.
An engraving in gold.
Aurigraphia, f.
An engraving.
1 cælatura, sculptura, scalptura
f. 3 Cælamen, n.
The arte, or science of engra­
ving.
1 Anaglyptice, toreutice, dia­
graphice, f.
Three furrowed engravings in
fashion of a toppe turned vp side
downe.
1 Triglyphi.
Thinges put vnder such engra­
vinges.
1 Guttæ, f.
An engraving, or graving I­
ron. 1 Scalprum, n. scalper, m.
An instrument to engraue with
1 Cælum, n.
That may be engraven.
1 Sculptilis, ad.

To Engrosse a letter, 
or writing. 
2 Tabulas conficio, infero in
tabulas.
He that hath licence to engrosse
certaine commodities, which no
man can sell, or gaine by but he.
1 Monopola, m.
The place where hee engrosseth
such commodities.
1 Monopolium, n.
Engrossers of markets, which
make vittailes deare.
1 Timiopolæ.

2 Influo, illabor, invehor, pe­

rumpo.
To enter in privilie. 2 Irrepo.
To enter in quicklie.
2 Involo.
To enter into by gnawing.

To enter vpon a thing.

To enter into.

in

1 Status, m. conditio. 2 For­
tuna, res, f. vt res publica. The
common estate.

being of one estate. 2 Ordo, m.

a king onely sitteth.

2 Redintegratus, p.
Hee that is not come to mannes e­

To Esteeme. 
1 Duco, æstimo, habeo, 2 pen­
do, specto, repono, probo, ob­
servo, Puto, metior, vide To 
Account. 
To esteeme, thinke, or judge of.
1 Reor, puto, deputo, reputo, 
existimo, opinor, autumo, 2
Pendo, statuo.
To esteeme alike.
1 Coæstimo. 2 æquipenso.
To esteeme better, or more.
1 Antehabeo, Præfero, præ
pono, antepono.
To esteeme greatly. 1 Magnifa­
cio, multifacio, magnipendo, 
2 Miror, admiror.
To esteeme little of.
1 Floccifacio, Floccipendo, 
Parviduco.
To esteeme lesse. 1 Posthabeo, 
2 Postfero, postpono.

the matter.

E ANTE Y.

An Eye. 
1 Oculus, ophthalmus, m. 
2 lux, f. lumen, n.
A little eye.
1 Ocellus, m.
A dropping waterishnes, and run­
ning of the eyes, with paine, shoo­
ting, and rednesse: blearednes, or
bloodshotnes of the eyes.
1 Lippitudo, f.
A disease of the eyes, as when




they are gnawne, without the
fluxe, or running of any humor.
1 Sicca lippitudo.
A little white and harde swel­
ling, or push in the eye lids.
1 Lithiasis, f.
He that hath a dimme and ill
eyesight, that seeth some-what
by day light, worse after the sun
rising, and never a whit at
night. 1 lusciosus, luscitiosus, ad
That fault in the eyes.
3 Luscitio, f.
A wincking or twinckling with
the eyes. 1 Nictatio, f.
That hath but one eye.
1 Monoculus, vnioculus, defi­
oculus, luscus, ad. 2 Thersites, 
cocles, m.
The eye lidde.
1 Gena f. cilium, n.
The ball, or apple of the eye.
1 Pupilla, f.
The eye liddes, or heares that
growe there.
1 Palpebræ, f.
The corner of the eye.
1 Hirquus, m.
The space betweene the eye
browes.
1 Intercilium, n.
The sockets of the light of the
eyes. 2 Loca luminis.
The hole of the eye.
2 Sinus, m.
The white of an eye.
1 Albugo, f.
The webbe in the eye.
1 Leuconia, n.
The watering, or dropping of the
eyes by meanes of a reume, issuing
out thereat.
1 Epiphora, f.
Rowling eyes, gasing beare and 
there about.
2 Emissititij oculi.
A quicke sharpe sighted eye.
 Oculus 2 Aquilinus, 
Oculus Linceus, 
Oculus Milvius, ad.
A swelling of the eye liddes.
1 Emphisma.
He that weareth a peece of cloth
before his eyes.
2 Lanoculus.
The compasse of the eye. 3 Eon.
Eyes that can see by night.
2 Felinei, glauci Oculi. 2 her
bei, nocturni, ad.
The hollownes of the eyes.
3 Conchos, m.
The eye browes, vide browe. 
The eating out of the little peece
of flesh, which is in the bigger
corner of the eye.
1 Rheas.
Full of eyes. 1 Oculatus, ocu­
leus, 3 Oculosus, ad.
Pertaining to the eyes.
1 Ocularius, ad.
One that hath faire bright eyes.
1 Glaucopis.
Eyed, or that hath holes like eies.
1 Ocellatus, ad.
He that hath eyes like an hare, or
whose eye liddes mooue not down­
ward. 1 Lagophthalmus.
Bleare eyed.
1 Lippus, ad.
He that is goggle eyed.
1 Hirquus, m.
They that haue blewe eyes.
1 Cæsuliæ.
That hath drie eyes.
1 Siccoculus, ad.
Great eyed, or that hath eies stan­
ding out. 1 Exophthalmus, m.
Pincke eyed, or that hath little
eyes. 1 Lucinius.
They that haue eyes of azure co­
lour. 1 Raviliæ.
From eye to eye.
3 Oculitus.

teruncius, m. teruncium, n.
A farthing and a halfe.
1 Sembella, f.
3 Farthings. 1 Sesquiobolus.
Belonging to a farthing.
1 Quadrantarius, ad.

To Fashion, or forme. 
1 Formo, conformo, præfor­
mo, informo, figuro, configu­
ro, fingo, affingo, defingo, ef­
fingo, 2 compono, architector
paro, comparo, fabrico, fabricor
3 suffiguro.
To Fashion as the potter doth.
1 Figulo.
To fashion out a thing. 1 Perfi­
guro, 2 defabrico, 3 deplasmo
To fashion before.
1 Præformo.
To fashion, or forme a newe.
1 Reformo, 2 Recoquo.
To change his fashio, or custome.
1 Desuesco, desuefacio.
Fashioned, or formed.
1 Formatus, conformatus, In­
formatus, figuratus, fictus, ef­
figiatus, 2 compositus, creatus
Well fashioned.  Quadratus, p
Fashioned before.
1 Præcompositus, p.
Fashioned ill.
1 Informis, ad.
Begun & not throughly fashioned.
1 Informatus, p.
Fashioned like a pipe.
1 Canaliculatus, p.
He that fashioneth.
1 Informator, formator, m.
A fashioning, or forming of any
thing. 1 Formatura. Informa­
tio, figuratio, 2 Imaginatio, 
f. ductus, m.
A fashion, forme, or shape.
1 forma, figura, effigies, speci­
es, 2 facies, f. Tipus, m.
The fashion, maner, custome, or
behaviour. 1 Mos, modus, m. 
genus, n. status, ritus, m. 2
Consuetudo f. habitus, m. 
Via, ratio, disciplina, 3 Pelli­
cula, f.
The fashion, or forme of the body.
1 Lineamentum, n.
The fashion of the face.
2 Ductus oris.
The fashion of a thing.
1 Conformatio, f.
A continuall fashion, or forme.
2 Tenor, m.
Without any fashion, or forme.
1 Amorphus, ad.
That hath fashion, or forme.




1 Figurativus, ad.
First fashioned, or formed.
1 Protoplastus, ad.
Done only for a fashion.
1 Perfunctorius, ad.
That knoweth no fashion, v. rude
Of like fashion. 1 Conformis.
Of one fashion.
1 Monotropos, vniusmodi, ad
Fashioned, or formed two maner
of waies. 1 Biformis, ad.
In two fashions, or formes.
1 Bifariam, bipartito, adu.
That hath three fashions, or
formes. 1 Triformis, ad.
That hath foure fashions, or
formes. 1 Quadriformis, ad.
That hath manie fashions.
1 Multiformis, polymorphus
In manie fashions.
1 Multifariam, variatim, adu.
In a diverse fashion, or sort.
1 Dissimiliter, adu.
In manner, or after a certaine
fashion.
1 Quodammodo, quadam­
tenus, adu.
After another fashion.
1 Alias, aliusmodi, adu.

To Fasten. 
1 Pango, expango, figo, asfi­
go, suffigo, oppango, 2 necto, 
vide binde. 
To fasten vnder. 2 Subnecto.
To make fast. 2 Obdo.
To fasten, and set vp surely.. 
1 Refigo.
To fasten againe. 1 Repango.
To fasten, or sticke before.
1 Præfigo.
To fasten to some thing.
1 Alligo, as, adalligo, affigo, 
offigo, adigo, annecto.
To fasten together.
1 Configo, connecto. 
2 Ferrumino.
To fasten with a wedge.
1 Cuneo, as.
To fasten to the grounde.
1 Depango.
To fasten about.
1 Circumpango.
Fastned, or tied.
1 Infixus, defixus, suffixus. 
2 Nexus, religatus, concre­
tus, obditus, p.
Fastned to.
1 Alligatus, colligatus, astri­
ctus, affixus, p.
Fastned vnder. 1 Subfixus, p.
Fastned, or set in the fore part.
1 Præfixus, p.
Fastned, or compact together.
2 Pressus, sutus, p.
Fastned in the earth.
1 Depactus, p.
A Fastning.
1 Colligatio. f.
A fastning together.
2 Ferruminatio, f.
Fastnes. 1 Tenacitas, firmitas, 
firmitudo, f. 
2 Stabilitas, f.
Fast or firme.
1 Fixus, p. firmus. 2 Stabilis, ad
constans, p.
That wil fasten.
1 Fixurus, p.
Fastly, or sure.
1 Tenaciter, firme, adu.
Fastly, or swift in pace.
1 Tolutim, adu.

A Fast for a boat, or
shippe. 
1 Prymnesium, n.

To Fast. 
1 Iejuno.
To be sicke of fasting.
1 Laborare jejunio.
A fasting.
1 Iejunium, n.
Fasting, or which hath not di­
ned.
1 Impransus, jejunus, ad.
Fasting daies, whereon men doe
forbeare meate.
1 Feriæ esuriales. 
Dies jejunij publici.

To be like ones Fa­
ther. 
1 Patrisso, 3 Patrizo.
A father. 1 Pater. 
2 Sator, geniter, m.
A father, or mother.
1 Parens, com. g.
A god-father. 1 Compater, 
patrinus, 2 Susceptor, m. 
Mysticus, vel lustricus parens
A father in years, or dignity.
1 Presbyter, m.
Fore-fathers. 1 Patres.
A father in lawe.
3 Maspiter, vide alliance. 
A little father.
1 Paterculus, m.
Hee that hath another father, 
then he supposeth.
1 Falsiparens, com. g.
A man, whose father and mo­
ther come of diverse countries.
1 Hybrida, m.
My wifes father, vide alliance, 
That hapneth to one by his fa­
ther. 1 Patritus, ad.
He that is a father, his father
being aliue.
1 Pater patrimus.
That hath a father aliue.
1 Patrimus, ad.
A fatherlesse child within age, 
an orphan.
1 Pupillus, orphanus, m. or­
bus, orbus patre.
A worde derived from the pro­
per name of a father.
1 Patronimicum, n.
Belonging to a father.
1 Paternus, patrius. 
3 Paternalis, ad.
Fatherly. 1 Patrie, paterne.

Fatte.

Fatnes, or grossenes.

To commit a Fault, 
vide to offend. 
To lay fault to ones charge, that
blameth others.
1 Recriminor.
Faults are committed.
1 Peccatur, impers.
A fault, or offence.
1 Peccatum, vitium, delictum, 
crimen, n. noxa, culpa. 
2 Labes, f. morbus, m.
A smal fault.
1 Mendaculum, n.
A fault, or offence in orthogra­
phie, or writing.
1 Menda, f. mendum, n.
A fault in speech, when the let­
ter L is pronounced too thicke.
1 Lambdacismus, m.
A fault in the vine, when she
beareth no fruit, but turneth al
her substaunce into braunches, 
and wood.
1 Hirculatio, f.
A fault, or error, comming by
ignorance.
1 Erratum, n. error, m.
A great finder of faults.
2 Exactor, m.
A fault in the principal part
of the soule, whereby not onely
the memory, but also the vse of
reason is empaired.
1 Morosis.
A fault in miscontenting the
audience.
2 Offensum, n.
A fault in trees, when through
too much beate, they burne and
starue.
1 Siriasis, f.
Faulty. 1 Obnoxius, mendo­
sus, vitiosus, ad.
Belonging to a fault.
1 Noxalis, ad.
Faultles. 1 Inculpatus, irre­
prehensus, irreprehensibilis.
Without fault.
1 Emendate, adu.
Ful of faults. 1 Mendose, adu.

To Faulter, or stum­
ble. 1 Titubo.
Faultering. 1 Titubatio, f.
Faultring, or ready to fal.
1 Succiduus, ad.

1 Faveo. 
2 suffragor, foveo, astipulor, 
juvo, sustineo, adjuvo, diligo, 
amplexor, respicio, colo, sub­
scribo, annuo, is. sustineo, su­
stento, tribuo aspiro.
To favour with a reverent loue
2 Observo.
To procure, or win the fauour of
men. 2 Intercolo.
Seeking for the favour of men.
1 Ambitio, f.
Favour. 1 Studium, n. favor, 
m. gratia, f. 
2 Suffragium, n. amor, m. a­
micitia, f. vultus, m. benevo­
lentia, dignatio, laus, 
3 Gratiositas, f.
Favour of the people.
2 Aura, f.
Favorers.
2 Aurarij, orum.
Favour, or countenance.
1 Forma, f. vultus, m. species, 
figura, f.
Favour tendered towardes the
people: also the favour of the
people.
1 Popularitas, f.
A favourer. 1 Fautor, m.
A favorer of the people, or of
the common weale.
1 Publicola, m.
She that favoureth.
1 Fautrix. 
2 Nutricula, f.
A favourer of well learned
men.
2 Mecænas, philomusus, m.
A procurer of fauour.
1 Conciliator, m.
Winning of favour.
1 Conciliatio, f.
A favouring.
2 Venia, f.
Favourable.
1 Benignus. 
2 Amicus, benevolus, facilis, 
propitius, placidus, placatus, 
præmollitus, dulcis, candidus
secundus, bonus, dexter. 
3 favorabilis, gratiosus, 
ad.
That seeketh over much to haue
the favour of men.
1 Ambitiosus, ad.
Favoured.
2 Charus, ad.
Well favoured.
1 Speciosus, ad. 
2 Nitens, p.
Ill favoured.
1 Deformis. 
2 Incultus, sordidus, inorna­
tus, squallidus, Incomptus, 
horridus, hispidus, asper, 
hirsutus, ad.
Not favouring.
2 Aversus, ad.
Not woorthie to bee favou­
red.
3 Infavorabilis, ad.




That speaketh faire to winne
favoure
3 Charitorius, ad.
Wel favouredly.
1 Pulchre, adu.
Favourably.
1 Benigne, indulgenter, 2 a­
mice, propense, 3 gratiose, 
favorabiliter, venialiter, adu.
Il-favouredly.
2 Squalide, adu.

F ANTE E.

Fealtie, or fee.

To Feare, terrifie, or
make afraide, activum. 
1 Terreo, conterreo, exter­
reo, territo, tremefacio, ter­
rafacio, terrifico, perterrefa­
cio, perterreo, horrefacio, 
perpavefacio, 2 exanimo.
To feare awaie.
1 Absterreo, proterreo.
To feare, or dreade, neutrum.
1 Timeo, extimeo, paveo, 
metuo, pavesco, trepido, tre­
mo, vereor, reformido, 2 pal­
leo, pallesco, 3 nagubernor.
To feare which, or dread greatly.
1 Horteo, exhorreo, formido
abhorresco, exhorresco, re­
formido, permetuo, pertime­
o, pertimesco, extimeo, ex­
timesco, intremo, conster­
nor.
To feare before any harme com­
eth.
1 Præmetuo, prætimeo.
To beginne to feare.
1 Pratimesco.
To feare often.
1 Pavito
To feare, or haue in reverence.
1 Vereor, revereor.
To shake for feare.
1 Contremo, contremisco.
To be made afraide.
1 Pavesio.
To be halfe afraide.
1 Subtimeo, subvereor.
Fearing.
1 Veritus, p.
Feared. 1 Deterritus, ab­
sterritus, formidatus, treme­
factus, 2 exanimatus, attoni­
tus, part.
Greatly feared.
1 Performidatus, p.
Feared, or put in feare.
1 Centerritus, exterritus, p.
A fearing.
1 Trepidatio, consternatio, 
formidatio, daformidatio, 
reformidatio, 2 contractio, f.
Feare, or dreade.
1 Timor, metus, tremor, ter­
ror, horror, m formido, timi­
ditas, paviditas, pavitudo, f. 
2 frigus, n.
Great feare, or dreade.
1 Pavor, m. extimescentia, 3
terribilitas, f.
A little feare.
1 Meticulus, m.
Feare, or reverence.
1 Reverentia, f.
A sodain fear, wherwith one is
distraught, comming without
cause.
1 Panicum, n.
Feare of minde, to do any thing
repugnant to the lawe of God.
1 Religio, f.
Feare of a thing to come.
1 Præmolestia, f.
Fearful or dreadful.
1 Timidus, horridus, perhor­
ridus, pavidus, tremebun­
dus, formidans, formidolo­
sus, tremulentus, muricatus, 
horriser, timorosus, meticu­

nimis, suspensus, inaudax, 
muliebris, 3 timoratus, ad.
Somewhat feareful

To be feared, or fearfull.
1 Terribilis, horribilis, for­
midabilis, ad. timendus, ve­
rendus, horrendus, p. 3 terri­
bilosus, ad.
Not fearing, or not feared.
1 Impavidus, intrepidus, ad.
Readie to flie for feare.
1 Fugax, ad.
Fearefully, or dreadfully.
1 Timide, trepide, meticulo­
se, pavide, trepidanter, for­
midolose, 2 gelide, obnoxie, 
adu.
Fearefully, or reverently.
1 Religiose, adu.
Without feare.

To Feast together. 
1 Epulor.
To keepe Bacchus feastes.
1 Bacchor.
A feast, or banquet.
1 Convivium, symposium, n. 
dapes, f. syssitia, orum. 2 cæ­
na f, prandium, n.
A feasting, or banqueting.
1 Comessatio, epulatio, f.
A feaster, or banqueter.
1 Convivator, obsonator, 
symposiastes, m.
A feast guest. vide guest. 
A sumptuous feast, made with
great costes and charges.
1 Persicus apparatus, geni­
alis cæna.
A greate feast solemnely made
to a multitude.
1 Epulum, solenne, is. solen­
nia, orum, n.
Feastes, or diners, wherein is no
wine.
1 Nephalia, orum.
A drye feast.
1 Xyrophagium, n.
Feastes made at a buriall.
1 Silicernium.
Feastes made at the burials, or
funeralles of parents, or ance­
stours.
1 Parentalia, orum.
Feastes made at the nativity, or
birth of children.
2 Repotia, orum.
Feastes wherevnto onelie men
doe come.
1 Andronæ, arum.
Solemne feastes about welles.
1 Fontanalia, fontinalia, n.
A feast made in reioycing of vi­
ctorie.
1 Epinicia, orum.
Feastes whereto kins-folke
come together.
1 Charistia, orum.
Feastes of Saint Peter, and
Saint Paule.
1 Petrea, Paulea, orum.
Sainte Martins feastes.
1 Vinalia, Fithegia, orum.
Ordinarie Feastes. 1 Statæ, f. 




itati, orum, feriæ anniver­
sariæ.
Feastes solemnised in crosse
streets, & waies.
1 Compitalia, orum.
Belonging to those feastes.
1 Compitalitius, ad.
A feast in Rome, the next daie
after Terminalia, on which
daye Tarquinius fledde out of
Rome. 1 Rexifugium, n.
Feastes dedicated to the God
Terminus.
1 Terminalia, orum.
Feastes dedicated to Saturne.
1 Chronia, orum.
Feastes dedicated for the honor
of Adonis.
1 Adonia, orum.
A feast in Athens during fiue
daies, solemnised to the honor
of Pallas.
1 Quinquatrus, m.
A feaste not vnlike to that of
the lewes, called the dedication
of the Temple.
1 Eucænia, orum.
Feastes dedicated vnto spirites­
in funeralles.
1 Lemuria, orum.
Feastes ordained for preserving
the corne from blasting.
1 Rubigalia, orum.
Feastes dedicated to the goddesse
Ops. 1 Opalia, orum.
Feastes dedicated to Vulcane.
1 Vulcanalia, orum.
A feast which the Pagane priest
vsed in the olde time.
1 Adjicialis cæna.
The feastes of Bacchus, or the
daies when the feastes were
kept. 1 Bacchanalia, vinalia.
The place where Bacchus feast
was kept, sometimes the feast it
selfe. 1 Bacchanal, vinale, 
bacchanale, n.
Liberall in feastes.
3 Epulosus, ad.
Belonging to a feast.
1 Convivalis, epularis, ad.
That hath beene at a feast.
1 Epulatus, ad.
The feastes of Saturne.
1 Saturnalia, orum.
Of, or belonging to the feast of
Saturne.
1 Saturnalitius, ad.

Festivall daies, or
holy daies. 1 Solennia, orum. 
feriæ, arum.
A festival day, a feast, or great
cheare.

A festival, ioyful, or merry day.

of Laurentia, the nurse of Ro­
mulus and Remus.
1 Laurentalia, orum.
Festivall daies for matrones, 
wherein they prayes to their
Gods, for the preservation of
their husbandes.
1 Matronalia, orum.
Not festivall.

Festivall daies dedicated to the
goddesse Palis, for the preser­
vation of cattle.
1 Parilia, orum.

veo, farcio, sustento, sustineo,

together.

Fed, or nourished. 1 Pastus, al­
tus, 3 cibatus, part.
A feeder of cattle.

no, prosequor, termino, per­
texo, 2 colophonem addere, 
exædisico, absolvo, edolo, 
percolo, perpolio, 3 finito.

Finished. 1 Finitus, perfe­

defunctus, complerus, decur­
sus exhaustus, expletus, trans­
actus, exantlatus, p. v. ended.

lutus, p.

To beginne to flowe.




1 Scatesco.
To flowe al over, or on al parts.
1 Permano, diffluo, perfluo. 
pereffluo.
To flowe, or runne before a 
place. 1 Præfluo.
To desire to flowe out.
3 Scaturizo.
To flowe in. 1 Influo.
Flowing. 1 Fluxus, ad. vn­
dans, p. fluidus, ad, profluens, 
influens, p.
Flowing about.
1 Circumfluens, p.
Flowing over.
1 Profluus, superfluus, ad.
A flowing.
1 Fluxus, m. effluentia, 2 de­
cursio, f.
Flowing of bloud out of sundry
members. 3 Tullij, m.
The flowing of the sea.
1 Salamia, f.
The flowing about of waters.
2 Circumluvio, f.
A floude.
1 Fluvius, m. fluvium, flu­
men, n.
A little floude.
1 Fluviolus, m.
A floude, when water mixed
with claie covereth the ground.
1 Alluvies, alluvio, f. alluvi­
um, neut.
A floude, or streame, descen­
ding from hilles into valleys, by
aboundance of raine.
1 Torrens, m.
A floude of water, stirred by a
tempest.
1 Fluctus, m.
An outragious floude, or over­
flowing of water.
1 Inundatio, f.
A Floud, or deluge of water.
1 Cataclysmus, m. inunda­
tio, f. diluvium, n.
A floudgate, or water stoppe.
2 Septum, n.
Floudegates.
1 Commata, n. cataractæ, f.

Flowre of meale. 
1 Simila, similago, f.
Fine flowre.
1 Pollis, m. pollen. n. cri­
braria, fæm.
Pertaining to fine flowre.
1 Pollinarius, ad.
Made of fine flowre.
1 Similagineus, ad.

Flowre of herbes, vi. Flourishe.

A Flute. 
1 Aulos, m. fistula, tibia, 2 sy­
rinx, syringa, f.
A plaier on the flute, or small
trumpet.
1 Tibicen, aulædus, fistula­
tor, masc.

Fluxe, v. Flixe.

sequor.

deo cum dat.

sure.

nula, agredula, f.

Greene frogges.

Croaking frogges.

A kinde of frogges the biggest of
all other, and liveth onely among
brambles.
1 Phrynon, n.
Toung frogges.
1 Ranarum fætus.
The croaking of frogges.
1 Coaxatio, f. coaxum, n.
A place where frogges be.
1 Ranetum, n.

To gather, or take all
the Fruite of any
thing. 
1 Defrugor.
The fruite of generation, and
some times taken for the fruit of
trees.
1 Fetus, fructus, m.
All kinde of fruite serving for
sustenaunce that the earth brin­
geth forth.
1 Fructus cereales, fruges, f. 
fænus, n. 3 Frux. f.
Fruit, or profit. vide profit. 
Fruite, or profit taken of cattell, 
or goods.




1 Vsusfructus, m.
The fruit, or bery of a ceder tree.
1 Cedris, f.
Al fruits having hard shales, or
rindes, as nuts, and such like.
1 Acrodrya, n.
Fruites that haue no hard pilles
or shales. 1 Oporæ, arum, f.
A fruit in India called of the a­
pothecaries the nut of Egypt.
1 Myrobalanum, n.
A fruit called of the apothecaries
Sebesten. 1 Myxa, myxaria.
A fruit in India, called Tameri­
num: the fruit of the date tree.
1 Phænicobalanus, m.
a fruit called of the apothecaries
Injuba. 1 Ziziphum, n.
A fruit called Tuber, having a
good smel, and taste. 1 mysy, yos.
Fruits that be like to teates.
1 Orthomastica.
A fruit of the kind of carets.
1 Delphides.
The fruit of cornus, which is not
in England, the French cal it Cor­
noiller. 1 Cornum, n.
A fruit in India like the green
damascens. 1 Tamarindi.
Divers small fruits, and pulse.
1 Ospratura, f.
Fruits not ripe. 2 Cruda poma.
First fruits of the yeare, offered
to Gods. 1 Primitiæ, arum.
A fruit loft. 1 Oporotheca.
A Fruiterer. 1 Pomarius, m.
Fruit time. 2 Vindemia, f.
That beareth fruite on both sides.

That beareth fruit.

gifer. 2 Fætifer, ad.
That beareth fruit yearelie.
2 Restibilis, ad.
That beareth fruit twise.
1 Bifer, biferus, ad.

To vse Games, or
pastime. 1 Ludo.
A game. 1 Ludus, m. lusio, f.
Games of running, which the
Romans kept. 1 Circenses ludi, 
vel circensis, sine adjectione.
Certaine games vsed in Greece for
the honour of Hercules.




 Nemæea, n.
Games dedicated to Apollo.
1 Pythia, n.
They which were conquerours at
those games. 1 Pythonices.
A game called rifling, where he
that throweth most vpon the dice, 
taketh vp all the money.
3 Plistobolinda.
Games celebrated for the health
of youth. 1 Iuvenalia, n
Games instituted of Hercules, for
the honour of Jupiter: they were
celebrated every 15. moneth, the
exercises were these fiue, called
Cælus, Cursus, Saltus, Discus, 
Palæstra. 1 Olympia, f.
He which in those games was
conquerour. 1 Olympionices, m
Pertaining to those games.
1 Olympicus. ad.
A little game, or gamboll called
the haltering of Hickes mare.
3 Oscillatio, æora, f
They that vsed a kinde of games
with swordes winking.
3 Andabatæ.
Hee that iudgeth in games of
wrastling, or running: also the
Master of the game, that giveth
the prices. 1 Athlotheta, athlo­
thetes, brabentes, m.
He that maketh a common game
and paieth the prices.
1 Agonotheta, m.
He that keepeth rule at games.
3 Alytarcha, m.
They which accompany the ma­
sters of the games.
3 Magidophori, m.
Cunning at all kinde of games.
1 Pancratiastes, pantathlus.
Game-plaiers, or gamesters.
1 Ludij, ludiones, m.
A cogging gamester at the dice.
2 Prævaricator, m.
Vnskilfull in games, and exerci­
ses. 1 Apalæstris, ad.
Full of games, or pastime.
1 Iocosus, ad.

Every vppermost garment.

A little garment. 1 Amiculum
A garment of cloth of gold, or
fine ornamentes.

2 Atralica, vestis.
Garments stiffe with golde.

Garments of cleane golde.
1 Holobrizæ vestes.
A garment all of silke.
1 Holoserica vestis.
A garment, or garments of fine
silke. 1 Cois, coa, multicina, f. 
multicia, bombycina, n. 
Cea vestis. 
Coa vestis.
A garment of silke, wherein bee
wrought round figures, like cob­
webbes. 1 Scutulata vestis.
A garment, or vesture mixed
with purple silke for noble mens
children to weare, vntill they
came to 7 yeares of age, and ther­
fore were called Pretextati.
1 Prætexta, f. prætexta toga.
A garment of changeable silke.
1 Soriculata vestis.
A garment which the Senators, 
or lordes of the Parliament doe
were, wrought with purple silke, 
studs, or naile heades. 1 Laticla­
via, f. laticlavium, n. laticlavus.
He, or she that weareth that kind
of garment. 1 Laticlavius, ad.
A garment, or robe of scarlet.
1 Coccina vestis, coccium, n.
A garment which the Consull
did weare, when hee denounced
warre, which hee threwe backe­
ward, and girded him-selfe with
a part of the same.
1 Cinctus gabinus.
A purple garment.

women were accustomed to

A square Garment, which they
that did weare, did cast one part
over their shoulders at their
backes, like spanish capes: also a 
womans mourning goune.
1 Recinium, recinum, ryci­
num, n. 3 Ricinus, m.
A thick garment, furred, heirie,

were wont to lie in in the warres.

that euerie third threed was big­

To Gest, vid. to jest.

To Gesture, or de­
clare any thing, by the outwarde
motions of the bodie. 
1 Gestio, ago gestum.
To make much gesture.
1 Gesticulor.
A gesture. 1 Gestus. 
2 Motus, m.
Gesture of the body.
1 Status, m.
Comelie gesture.
1 Eurythmia, f.
A gesturing with the handes
1 Manuum gesticulatio.
A gesture with the handes in
carving of meate, or dauncing.
1 Chironomia, f.
He that teacheth one to gesture
with the handes, or he that ge­
stureth with the handes.
1 Chironomus, chirono­
mon, m.
He that with voice, or gesture, 
expresseth mens manners.
1 Ethologus, m.
Ful of gesture.
3 Gestuosus, gesticulo­
sus, ad.
Of, or belonging to gesture.
1 Gesticularius, ad.

To Gette. 
1 Comparo, nanciscor, paro, 
arcesso, arcessio, concilio, ac­
quiro. 2 apprehendo, conflo, 
consector, contraho, expe­
to, adipiscor. 
3 Indepto, vide to obtaine. 
To get by labour.
1 Demereo, vide to earne. 
To get by flattery.
1 Eblandior. 
3 Expalpo.
To gette painefully.
1 Quærito.
To gette a thing by hypocrisie.
2 Obrepo.
To get by crafte.
2 Venor.
To gette by entreatie.
1 Impetro.
To gette children.
3 Patro.
To gette with childe.
1 Gravido, impregno. 
2 Tollo.
To gette againe.
1 Renanciscor.
To gette vppe againe.
1 Recolligo.
To gette before another.
1 Occupo, præoccupo.
To get by chaunce, or lotte.
1 Sortior.
Gotte, or gotten.
1 Adeptus, assequutus, ac­
quisitus, nactus, indeptus, ap­
tus, 2 Inventus, contractus, 
collectus, p.
Gotten by flattery.
1 Eblanditus. 
3 Expalpatus, p.
Gotten by chaunce.

Gotten of enimies, or overcome
1 Incursatus, p.

3 Adepticus, ad.

1 Gravida facta. 
2 Deprehensa.
Gotten by falshoode, or slealth

tius, ad.

A getting.

To Giue. 
1 Do, reddo, tribuo, præbeo, 
attribuo, largior, trado, exhi­
beo, vt vires exhibere, to giue
strength. 2 contribuo, addo, 
vt addere nomen, to giue a 
name, colloco, edo, vt edeve
leges, to giue lawes. 
To giue, or assigne. 1 Assigno.
To giue wholy, as to giue ones
selfe, or his minde whollie to
any thing. 2 Dico, as. dedico, 
as. adjungo, colloco, conjicio.
To giue overplus, or to heape
vpon.
1 Superingero, supergero, 
adjicio.
To giue liberally.
1 Elargior, 2 congero.
To giue again, or to giue backe.
1 Retribuo, redono, vide to 
restore. 
To giue, or minister together.
1 Comministro.
To giue vp, or over. 1 Depono, 
desero, exhalo, efflo, vt effla­
re anima, to giue vp the ghost
To giue over his right to ano­
ther, or to giue over to.
1 Transcribo.
To giue himselfe for ever, or
wholy.
1 Dedo, mancipo, emancipo.
To giue almes, or to giue to them
that aske. 1 Erogo.
To giue backe, or to yeelde
grounde.
1 Cedo, retrogredior.
To giue himselfe to, or to serue.
1 Deservio.
To giue over from one to ano­
ther. 1 Transdo, 3 protrado.
To giue sufficiently.
1 Suppedito, suppeditor.
To giue good eare.
1 Ausculto, attendo.
To giue part to another.
1 Impartio, impartior.
Given. 1 Datus, tributus, 
contributus, traditus, præbi­
tus, attributus, exhibitus, 2
impositus, ad.

1 Addictus, consecratus 2
propensus, p.
Given to, or inclined most vn­
to. 1 Projectissimus, ad.
Given over, or assigned.

A giver. 1 Dator, tributor, 
exhibitor, præbitor, m.
A giving. 1 Datio, donatio,
