A God-father, vi. fa­
ther.

A God-mother, vi. 
mother.

To Goe. 
1 Eo, proficiscor, vado, gra­
dior, meo, concedo, 3 oggras­
sor, badizo, bito.
To goe often. 1 Ito.
To goe often to, or to haunt.
1 Adito, 2 Frequento.
To goe quickly.
1 Propero, acceleco 2 advolo
To goe out from, or forth.
2 Exeo, egredior, prodeo, 
proficiscor, evado, excedo, 
recedo, extraeo. 3 Extro.
To goe out quickly. 2 Exilio.
To goe out of the right way.
1 Prævaricor.
To goe awaye, or apart.
1 Discedo, abcedo, abeo, de­
meo. 2 Avolo.
To goe away a maine pace.
3 Grandigro.
To goe awaye privilye out of
some place. 1 Proripio, 
2 Subduco.
To go in. 1 Intro, introeo, ineo
introgredior, ingredior, im­
migro, immeo.
To goe to. 1 Accedo, adeo, ap­
peto.
To goe forwarde.
1 Progredior, promoveo.
To goe forwarde, or profit, as in
any arte. 1 Proficio.
To goe on forwarde, or to sticke
to that which is begun. 1 Pergo
To goe or passe by.
1 Prætereo, prætermeo, 3 præ­
terbito.
To goe from one place to dwell
in another vide to remoue. 
To goe backe. 1 Regredior, re­
cedo, retrogredior, retroce­
do remeo, retroeo.
To goe backe, aside, or out of the
company. 1 Secedo.
To goe over. 1 Supermeo, 
permo, supero.
To goe over again. 2 Remetior.
Toe goe vpon. 1 Supergredior.
To goe vpon foure feete.
3 Quadrupedo.
To goe about. 1 Obeo, circum­
eo, vide to endevoure. 
To goe, or walke about a place.
1 Peragro.
To go about the watch. 1 Fraxo
To goe vnder.
1 Subeo, protergredior.
To goe before. 1 Præcedo, præ­
gredior, antegredior, præmi­
gro, anteeo, antecedo, præ­
venio, præpeto.
To goe before, and shew the way
1 Præmonstro.
To goe before and governe: also
to make to goe before in march, 
or aray. 1 Præmoderor.
To goe softly. 1 Ambulo.
To goe softly before.
1 Præambulo.
To goe softlye, or slowly like a 
snaile. 1 Repeto, repetito.
To goe through.
1 Pervado. 2 penetro.
To goe vp. 1 Ascendo.
To goe downe. 1 Degredior, 
demeo, descendo.
To goe downe, as the sunne doth
1 Occido.
To goe downe before, as one star
before another. 1 Præoccido.
To goe beyonde. 1 Transgredi­
or, transeo, transmeo, præ­
tergredior 3 Transabeo.
To go together. 1 Congredior, 
commigro, convado, ceoe, 
commeo, vide to accompany, 
To goe hither and thither.
1 Oberro, circumversor, 
commeo.
To goe by stealth, or privily.
1 Suggredior.
To goe on tiptoes.
1 Pitylisso, vel pytilisso.
To goe about to doe.
1 Facesso.
To goe on pilgrimage.
3 Peregrinor.
To goe statelie, holding the nose
vp in the winde.
1 Incedo, 2 Supino.
To goe and come with.
1 Commeo.
To goe betweene. 1 Intermeo. 
2 Intercurro
To goe to see. 1 Viso, proviso
To goe backe to see: 1 Reviso.
To go asawt, blissoming, horsing
or ruddering, which is the desire
betweene the male and female
kinde. 1 Catulio.
He is gone, or they are gone, &
so in other persons of both num­
bers with the preposition, and
his casual word. 1 Itur, impers.
Going, like as the pismire mo­
veth. 3 Formicans, p.
That goeth. 1 Gressus, p.
Gone, or gone away. 1 Disces­
sus, 2 Elapsus, p.
Gone forth, out, or beyonde.
1 Egressus, profectus, 
3 grassatus, p.
Gone backe. 1 Recessus, p.
Gone about. 1 Peragratus, p.
Gone before. 1 Prægressus, p.
Gone downe. 1 Degressus, p.
A goer. 1 Itor, gradator, m.
A goer apace, or a fast goer.
2 Volaticus, ad.
A goer backwarde.
1 Retrogradator, m.
A goer barefoote.
1 Planipes, com. g. nudipes.
A goer, on a cord, or rope, v cord
A goer out of his country, into
a forraine country to dwell.
1 Profugus, ad.
A goer by the countrey, or high
way, vide waifaring man. 
A goer to supper vnbidden. vi.
vnbidden guest.

gressus recessus, m.
A going in. 1 Ingressio, f. in­
gressus, introitus, m.
A going to. 1 Aditus, accessus
m. accessio, f.
A going, or comming to a place.
1 Obversatio. f.
A going forward. 1 Progressio
f. progressus, processus, pro­
fectus, m.
A going about. 1 Ambitus, m. 
lustratio, peragratio, f.
A going before.

A going vp.

Agoing a pace, or ietting.

One that goeth slowly.

Golde. 
1 Aurum, n. chrysos.
A little peece of golde.
1 Aureolum, n. aureolus, m.
Golde fined.
1 Chrysoma, arum factum
Golde oare, or golde vnfined.
2 Balluca, f. aurum subæra­
tum, aurum imitatitium, n.
Pure, or fine golde, perfectlye
tried 1 Obrizum, n.
Golde readie to be coined.
1 Apilascus, m.
Golde digged in pittes, where
the vaine runneth along like a 
conduit pipe. 1 Aurum canalitium
Golde for crownes, called crown
golde. 1 Autum coronarium.
Golde gravell. 1 Balux.
A house where golde is fined.
1 Chrysoplysium, n.
A wedge of golde.
1 Palacra, f. balux.
Golde-foile, thinne leaues, or
raies of golde.
1 Bractea, f.
A little raie, or leafe of golde.
1 Bracteola, f.
Golde fome. 1 Chrysitis, f.
A golde-mine, vide mine. 
A golde-smith, or golde-finer.
1 Aurifex, aurarius, aurifa­
ber, vascularius, 3 auricidus.
Golde-finers. 1 Chrysoplytes.
A golde-smithes shoppe.
1 Aurificina, f.
A golde-beater, or golde-laier.
1 Bractearius, bracteator, m.
A goldstealer. 3 Aurilegus, 
aurifur, m.
Golden haire, vide haire. 
That beareth golde.
1 Aurifer, auriger, ad.
That bringeth forth golde.
1 Chrysogonum.
Sprinckled with gold.
1 Chrysopastus, p. auro as­
persus.
Full of golde. 1 Aurulentus. 
3 aurolentus, ad.
Golden, or of golde. 1 Aureus, 
aurarius, aureolus, aurosus.

Goldilockes, or wo­
mans haire, which lieth out be­
fore over their fore-heades.

juvo, vide to profite.

Good. 1 Bonus, melior, opti­

To Govern, or rule. 
1 Rego, guberno, moderor, 
modero, impero, dominor, 
administro, regulo, tempe­
ro, 2 fræno, tracto, constituo, 
3 magistro, principor.
To governe, leade, or guide.
1 Duco.
To governe a shippe.
1 Naviculor.
To governe diligently.
1 Curo.
To governe often.
1 Regito, imperito.
To haue the governance, or
protection of any thing, pro­
vince, place, or people.
1 Præsideo.
To be governed.
1 Dominor, regor, regulor.
Governed, or ruled.
1 Gubernatus, rectus, regu­
latus, p.
A governer, or ruler.
1 Imperator, gubernator, 
rector, dominator, archarius.
A chiefe governer.
1 Rex, regnator, princeps, 
præses, præfectus, satrapa, sa­
trapas, archigubernius, dyna­
stes, 3 dynasta, m.
A chiefe governour in a town, 
or citty. 1 Primas, m.
A governour of a diocesse.
1 Diæcetes, m.
A governour of the fourth part
of a countrie. 1 Tetrarcha, m.
A governoure, or protectour of
a realme, during the nonage of
of a Prince. 1 Interrex, m. 
procurator regni.
A governour of a realme, from
the space of the death of one
Prince to the choosing of an o­
ther. 1 Interrex. m.
Governoures.
1 Proceres, magistratus, m.
A governoure of a shippe.
1 Nauclerus, naviculator, 
navicularius, m.
A governoure, or protectour of
the commons.
1 Demarchus, 2 tribunus, 
ephorus, m.
A governesse.
1 Imperatrix, rectrix, guber­
natrix, dominatrix, modera­
trix, regnatrix, f.
Ten noble men appointed a­
mongest the Romanes, in steede
of Consuls, to governe the com­
mon wealth.
1 Decemviri.
The office, or dignity of those
ten. 1 Decemviratus, m.
Pertaining to that office.
1 Decemviralis, ad.
An holy governoure.
1 Hierarcha, m.
An holy governance.
1 Hierarchia, f.
Pertaining to an holy gover­
nance. 1 Herarchicus, ad.
A governance. 1 Diæcesis, f.
The governance, or protection, 
during the minority of a Prince. 
or during the time that there is
no Prince. 1 Interregnum, 
interregimen, n.
A governance, where one bea­
reth chiefe rule.
1 Monarchia, f.
Such a governoure.
1 Monarcha, m.
Seven governoures of greate
authority. 1 Septemviri. m.
One of those governoures.
1 Septemvir, m.
The governance, where seven
beare rule.
1 Septemviratus, m.
Belonging to such a governance.
1 Septemviralis, ad.
The governance which the peo­
ple haue amongest themselues, 
without any other superiours, 
or governours, except such as
they themselues make, or by them­
selues are established.
1 Democratia, f.
Hee that favoreth such a go­
vernment. 1 Democraticus.
A governance when the best
beare rule. 1 Aristocratia, f.
A governance when a fewe
haue authority.
1 Oligarchia, f.
They which woulde haue such a
governance.
1 Oligarchici, m.
A iust governoure.
1 Dicæarchus, m.
A iust governance.
1 Dicæarchia, f.
Want of governance.
2 Anarchia, f.
A governoure of a place.
1 Toparcha, m.
Such a governance.
1 Toparchia, f.
A governing.
1 Gubernatio, moderatio, 




administratio, rectio, ordina­
tio, temperatio, procuratio, f
ductus, m.
A government, or rule.
1 Regimen, regnum, mode­
ramen, imperium, regnum, n
dynastia, f. ducatus, m. 
2 Habenæ, f. sceptrum, n.
Without governaunce of him­
selfe 1 Incontinenter, adu.

G ANTE R.

ble, vide to graple.

Grace. 
1 Gratia, charis, f. charisma, n
Grace, or favour. 1 Amor, m.
The grace, or pleasantnes of a
thing. 1 Genius, m.
Grace, or goodnes. 1 Benigni­
tas, f. vt benignitas Dei.
Good grace. 1 Eucharistia. f.
Good grace in speaking.
1 Facundia, f. lepor, lepos, 
decor, m. venustas, f. charien­
tismus, 2 sal, m.
A grace, such as is vsed to bee
saide before, or after meates.
1 Gratiarum actio.
Gratiousnes. 3 Gratiositas, f.
Gratious, or ful of grace.
1 Gratiosus, 3 Eucharis, ad.
Gratious, or favourable.
1 Gratiosus, ad. amans, p. ior, 
issimus, comis, benignus. 
2 Facilis, ad.
Gratious, or that hath a good
grace, or comelines.
1 Venustus, decorus, charo­
pus, ad.
Gratiouse in woordes, or that
hath a grace in speaking.
1 Facundus, lepidus, concin­
nus dictis, affabilis, ad.
Very gratious, or courteous.
1 Percomis, ad.
Very gratious. 1 Epicharis, ad.
Very gratious in wordes.
1 Perlepidus, perelegans, ad
Most gratious. 2 Serenissimus.
Gracelesse, or past grace.
1 Acharis, impudens, 2 Cy­
nopes, impenitens, ad.
Growen past grace.
3 Impudicatus, ad.
Without grace, gesture, or come­
lines 1 Inelegans, invenustus
inconcinnus, illepidus. 
2 Subinsulsus, infantissi­
mus, ad.
With a grace, or gratiously in
words. 1 Lepide, facete, per­
facete, decore, venuste, affa­
biliter, 2 Attice, Salse, adu.
GratIously, or courteously.
1 Comiter, 2 blande, adu.
With a very good grace, or pre­
tily. 1 Pereleganter, adu.
Without a good grace.
1 Invenuste, 2 pueriliter, adu.
Without grace, or courage.
2 Frigide, adu.

To Graffe. 
1 Seto, sevi, satum, insero. 
2 Pango, repango, vide to
plant, and sette. 
To graffe betweene, or ioining
to. 1 Assero.
To graffe betweene.
1 Intersero.
To graffe by cutting a rounde
hole in the barke of a tree, and
with claie to set in the budde of
another tree. 1 Inoculo.
Graffed. 1 Insitus, assitus, adsi­
tus, p. 3 insitivus, ad.
A graffe. 1 Insitum, n. planta, 
f. 2 Virgultum, n.
A graffe of a foote long, cutte
from a tree, & set in the ground: 
or a graft cut on both sides to be
set in the earth, or a stock set in
the ground to graft on. 1 Talea
A little graffe, or twig.
1 Calamus, m.
A young graffe. 1 Surculus, m. 
clavola, 3 Clabola, f.
A graffer. 1 Sator, insitor, em­
phitenta, m.
A graffing. 1 Insitio, f. insitus, 
m. plantatio, emphiteusis. 
2 Immissio, f.




A graffing, when a budde of one
tree is cut off rounde with part
of the barcke, and set on an o­
ther: or when an hole is bored in
a tree, & a kernell put in with a 
little lome. 1 Inoculatio. f.
Such a graffer. 1 Inoculator.
That beareth graffes.
1 Plantiger, plantaphoros.
That bringeth forth graffes.
1 Surcularis, ad.
Belonging to, or set with graffes.
1 Surcularius, ad.
Like a graffe.
3 Surculaceus, ad.

To waxe Graie, or
to haue graie haire, as men in
olde-age. 1 Canesco, caneo.
To waxe graie as beastes.
3 Grizesco.
Cloathed in graie, or russet.
1 Leucophæatus, ad.
Graie-eied. 1 Glaucopis, ad.

A Graie, Badger, or
brocke. 1 melis, f. taxo, grumus

A Graie-hounde, v. 
dogge.

A Graine, or corne. 
1 Granum, n.
A graine in the toppe of the
eare, lesse than a corne. 3 Frit.
A small graine, called a milet, 
or hirse. 1 Milium, n.
A graine of salte.
1 Salimica, f. salis frustum.
A white graine, pulse, or corne, 
growing in India, whereof
oile is made. 1 Sesama, f.
Of, or belonging to that graine.
1 Sesaminus, ad.
Graine of Paradise.
1 Cardamomum, n.
A graine called cich, in fashion
like a Rammes head.
3 Arietinum cicer, n.
A littel graine. 1 Granellum, n.
All manner of graine.
1 Frumentum, n.
The graine of a tree, whereby
it cleaveth. 2 Pecten, n.
Graine, wherewith cloath is
grained, or wherewith scarlet is
died. 1 Coccum, n. coccus, m.
That beareth graines.
1 Granifer, ad.
That hath many graines.
1 Granatus, ad.

A Graine, v. weight.

A Grainer, v. garner.

The art of Grammar. 
1 Grammatica, grammati­
ce, 2 literatura, f.
A grammarian, or teacher of
Grammar. 1 Grammaticus, m
2 literatus, ad.
A young grammarian.

grapes scant ripe. 1 omphaces

fellowes.

a grape which in Africa is ga­

tia, f. dolus, astus, m. panur­
gia, 2 circumductio, f. 3 pig­
mentum, n.

of guile. 1 Dolosus, vafer, frau­
dulentus, falsificus, 2 capta­
torius. 3 Fraudulosus, ad.
Guilefully. 1 Vasre, fraudulen­
ter, callide, adu. vi. crafte and
deceit.

The Gumme, of trees. 
1 Gummi, indecl. gummis, resina.
A certaine gumme. 1 Lacca, f.
A gumme dropping out of a 
firre-tree. 1 Cassitias, f.
A gumme much like to the
mirre, but farre more precious, 
and odoriferous. 1 Labysus, m.
Gumme thinner then rosen, and
thicker then hony, fattie, drop­
ping from the oliue trees in Sy­
ria. 1 Elæomeli.
The gum of a tree in Arabia, 
like to waxe, sweete in savour, 
& bitter in taste. 1 Bdellium.
Gumme rising out of a certaine
herbe in sommer time.
1 Galbanum, n. galbanus, m.




Of that gumme. 1 galbaneus.
The gumme Lapdanum, or lan­
danum, vsed in pomanders.
1 Ladanum, n.
A sweete smelling gumme in
Media. 1 Hadrobolus, ad.
The gumme Armoniake grow­
ing in Affrica, where Jupiter
Ammons temple was.
1 Ammoniacum, n.
A certaine gumme being the
right Ladanum. 1 Cesyphum.
A gumme comming from the
tree Larix, it is vsed for turpen­
tine. 1 Larigma resina.
A sweete gumme called storax.
1 Styrax, f.
A certaine gumme issuing out
of the herb Lacerpitum. 1 laser, n
The gumme of the balme tree.
1 Opobalsamum n
A sweet gumme called mirrhe.
1 Mirrha, f.
An ointing with gumme.
3 Gummitio, f.
Full of gumme. 1 Gummosus, 
gummatus. 3 lacceus, ad.
Made of gumme. 1 gumminus.

rifragus, turrifragus, m.

petarij, tormentarij. 3 Mo­
nobarbuli, charomardarij, m

To drawe out the Guttes, 
or inwardes of a fish. 
1 Exenterare piscem.
A bowell gutte.
1 Intestinum cecum, n.
A gutte of all other the strai­
test and narrowest, cleaving to
the stomacke. 1 Ile, n.
A great gutte rising from the
left side to the right, in which is
the disease, called the collicke.
1 Colon, vel colum, n.
The stomacke gutte.
1 Intestinum primum.
The hungrie gutte.
1 Intestinum jejunum.
The great gutte.
1 Magnum intestinum. 
colon intestinum.
The small gutte.
1 Intestinum tenue.
The small guttes. 1 Ilia, n.
The small guttes, by which the
meat passeth out of the stomake.
1 Lactes, f.
The long gut, or arse gutte.
1 Longanum, cholon, n. 
1 Longum, intestinum. 
Rectum intestinum.
The guttes, or inward partes of
a beast. 1 Exta, n.

A Gutter. 
1 Canalis, dub. g: colluviari­
um, n. Cloaca, canalicula, 
colliquiæ, collitiæ, f. aqua­
litium, n.

passe in. 1 Incile, n. incilla, f.
An hollowe gutter, as in reba­
ting of pillars. 1 Strix, f.
A gutter, or space between two
walles. 1 Andron.
A gutter receiving the raine
of divers houses. 1 conpluvium.
Gutters into which eaues drop.
1 Deliquiæ, f.
A gutter tile 1 Imbrex, dub. g
Fashioned like a gutter.

Note that SEMI, and SES­
QVI, may likewise be ioined to 
many moe wordes, then are heere
expressed.

To waxe Hoarie, as
men doo in age. 
1 Incanesco.

Hoarie haires. 1 Cani, orum.
To waxe hoarie, as bread, or such
like thinges, being stale.
1 Mucesco.
To be so hoarie. 1 Muceo.
Such hoarines. 1 Mucor, m.
Hoarie. 1 Mucidus, ad.
Hoarie, as in age men common­
lie be. 1 Incanus, canus, præca­
nus, ad. 2 Albescens p.

To Holde. 
1 Teneo, amplector. 2 Habeo, 
vt habere senatum, to haue a
seaate. Obtineo, vt obtinere vr­
bem armis, to holde a towne by
force. 
To holde backe.
1 Attineo, distineo, retineo, 2
de terreo. 3 pigro.
To holde vp.
1 Extollo, attollo.
To holde close together.
1 Comprimo.
To holde in.
1 Cohibeo.
To take holde vppon, or about.
1 Amplector. 2 Adhæreo, ad­
hæresco, complector.
To hold vp, or sustaine.
1 Sustento, fulcio.
To hold violentlie.
1 Occupo.
To take holde on.
1 Comprehendo.
To holde ones peace.
1 Taceo, consileo, sileo subti­
ceo, conticeo, conticesco. 2
Obmutesco.
To holde fast in.
1 Detineo.
To holde fast in often.
1 Detento.
To be holden.
1 Teneor.
To hold ones breath.
2 Comprimere spiritum.
Holden backe.
1 Distentus. 2 Refrænatus, p.
Holden. 1 Comprehensus, 2
Habitus, p.
Holden fast. 1 Detentus, p.
Holden in.
2 Compressus, p.
Holden out.
1 Protensus, p.
Holding, or taking by the middle.
2 Intercarpens, p.
Holden, that which is holden vp
by the feete, or by some stake.
3 Sedatus.
A holding backe.
1 Retentio, 3 Distentio, f.
Holding, or the force in holding
1 Tenacitas, f.
A holding, or keeping in.
1 Cohibitio, f.
A holding vp.
1 Sustentatio, f. Sustentamen­
tum, n.
That which holdeth vp.
1 Suffulcrum, fulcrum, susten­
taculum, n.
That holdeth fast.
1 Tenax, pertenax, ad.

To make Holes. 
1 Lacinio.
To bore, or make a hole in a
thing.
1 Terebro, Perterebro, foro, 
perforo.
To make a hole through.
2 Transfodio.
A hole, or hollowe place.
1 Cavus, m. cavum, n. caverna.
A hole boared with some instru­
ment.
1 Foramen, n.
A hole in any thing.
1 Foramen, n.
A Hole, or lurking place.




1 Spelæum. n. specus, m. et f. in
sec. quarta decl. n. in ter.
A hole in the ground.
1 Cuniculus, m. cuniculum. 
n. 3 tumba, f.
A hole in a rocke.
1 Spelunca, f.
A hole where birdes builde their
nestes
1 Cava, f.
A Foxe, or Badgers hole.
1 Lucanar, n
A pocke hole.
3 Adibedo, f.
The arse hole.
1 Podex. m.
The hole in a mannes yarde.
3 Dindimus, m.
The sight hole in a cros-bowe.
1 Scutula, f.
A place of boardes, made with
holes, for Pigeons, and Conies.
1 Loculamentum, n.
The holes in such boardes.
2 Cellulæ, f.
Holes in the toppe of a maste.
1 Liæ, f.
A touch hole.
2 Foramen, n.
Holes in shippes, or barges, where
the ores bee: or holes by which the
water is let out of them which
haue the timpanie.
1 Columbaria, n.
The holes in a honie combe.
1 Cyttarus, m.
A hole in the earth verie intri­
cate.
1 Angiportus, m.
The arme hole.
1 Axilla, acella, f. subhirci, m.
Holes left in buildinges, for cer­
taine purposes.
1 Apertura, f.
A hole in a paire of bellowes.
2 Gula follis.
The holes of the eyes. 2 Orbes.
The holes of the nose.
1 Naris spiramina.
A breathing hole, or a hole out
of which aire, smoke, winde, 
or breath issueth: also a dampe
hole.
1 Spiraculum, spiramen, spira­
mentum, n.
Of, or pertaining to holes.
1 Cavaticus, ad.
Full of holes.
1 Multicavus, multicavatus, 
multiforis, et rus, cavernosus, 
lacunosus, foraminosus. 2 Lo­
culosus, ad.
By holes, or mines in the earth.
1 Cuniculatim, adu.

To keepe Holidayes. 
1 Ferior, festivo, 2 Concele­
bro.
An holieday.
1 Festum solenne, n. dies fe­
stus.
Holiedayes.
1 Feriæ, f. solennia, n.
Holieday eues.
1 Feriæ præcidaniæ.
Set holie daies.
1 Feriæ anniversariæ, 
Feriæ Statæ, 
Feriæ Stativæ.
Mooueable holidaies, or feastes.
1 Feriæ conceptivæ.
Holiedaies commaunded by the
Magistrate for the newes of vic­
torie, or the princes safetie.
1 Imperativæ feriæ, f.
Holie daies dedicated to Iupi­
ter. 1 Latinæ, f.
Holidaies among the Atheni­
ans dedicated to Ceres.
1 Plynteria, n.
Holidaies dedecated to Mutius.
1 Mutia, n.
Holidaies and plaies instituted
in the honour of Flora, who was
supposed to bee the goddesse of
flowers.
1 Floralia, n.
an holiday among the Romaines
so called, because that on that day
they gathered eares of corne, to of­
fer for sacrifice.
1 Floriferium, n.
Holiedaies dedicated to the god­
desse Opeconciva.
1 Opeconciva, n.
A holie daie when a cowe with
calfe was offered in sacrifice.
1 Fordicidia, n.
Bakers holidaies, wherein cer­
taine services were done in the
bake-house.
1 Forna calia, n.
Certaine holidaies amongest the
Athenians.
1 Dorpia, n.
Of, or belonging to holie daies.
1 Festus, festivus, ad.

A poopish Holiwater
pot
3 Annula, f.
A poopish holie water sticke.
1 Aspergillum, n.

A little hollowe place.

The hollownes of a cuppe, or the
hollowe parte of the hand.

The hollownes that is made in a
body by dashing a thing against
it.

I ANTE M.

To make Images: 
also to represent, or cast the
figure of ones image. 
1 Imagino.
An image, forme, or likenesse.
1 Imago, figura, species, ef­
figies, icon, iconia, f. simula­
men, n. 3 agalma.
An image of a man, or woman.
1 Simulacrum, n.
An Image of mettall, ivory, or
stone. 1 Statura, f.
An image that could speake, &
was carried about for common
sightes. 1 Citeria, f.
An image of exceeding great­
nesse, made for the honor of any
person, as in Rhodes was one 70
cubites highe. 1 Colossus, m.
In forme of such an Image.
1 Colosseus, colossicus, ad.




An image, or forme either seene
in deede, or imagined to be seene
1 Spectrum, n.
An image deformed, pale, leane, 
and horrible.
1 Larvale, n.
An image that beareth vppe a
table, or dresser.
1 Trapezophorum, n.
An image representing Mer­
curie and Minerva together.
1 Hermathena, hermercu­
la, f.
Images of Mercurie made of
marble. 1 Pentelici, 2 hermæ.
A little image. 1 Imaguncula
f. sigillum, n. 
3 Statula, iconcula, f.
Little images, sette by great i­
mages. 1 Chamæteræ, chamæ­
terides, f.
Smal images with winges.
1 Hermerotes, f.
Little images for children to
play withall. 1 Sigillaria, n.
Images of women on horse backe
1 Hippiades, f.
Images carried in pageantes, 
with great cheeks, wide mouths, 
and making a great sounde
with their teeth.
1 Manduces, f.
Images in diverse formes, and
looking diverse waies.
1 Catagrapha, n.
Images in tables.
1 Sigilla plutearia.
Images laide vpon sepulchers.
1 Hermæ, f.
Images of men, bearing vp pil­
lars, postes, or somewhat else in
building.
1 Acroteria, n. 2 Atlantes, m.
The place where images are
solde. 1 Hermopolium, n.
A carver, or maker of images.
1 Statuarius, hermogliphus.
The craft of carving images.
1 Statuaria, f.
He that maketh poppets, or lit­
tle images. 1 Coroplathus, m.
He that maketh images on wax.
1 Ceroplastes, cerarius, m.
He that beareth an image.
1 Signifer, ad.
Of, or belonging to images.
1 Statuarius, ad.
Ful of images.

To breede an Impo­
stume. 1 Suppuro.
To renewe impostumes.
1 Redulcero.
An impostume, which is a
course of evill humors gathered. 
to some parte of the bodie. 1 A­
postema, n. suppuratio, vo­
mica, f. 2 collectio, abscessus.
An impostume, or sore that com­
meth of matter distilling from
the head, into the burres, or ker­
nels of the eares.
1 Parotis, idos, f.
An impostume, or rottennesse
of the lunges, consuming the
whole bodie.
1 Tabes, f.
An impostume of the lunges, 
with an inflammation thereof, 
which a shortnes of the breath, 
and a rednesse of the cheekes, &
iawes doe followe.
1 Peripneumonia, f.
A kinde of impostume, wherein
matter like fatte is contained.
1 Steatoma, n.
An impostume that burneth
in the fleshe.
1 Rumentum, n.
Impostumes about the share, or
members.
1 Bubones.
An impostumation vnder the
rootes of the nailes of man, or
beast, as a felon, &c.
1 Paronychia, f. paronychi­
um, n.
That runneth with an impo­
stume. 1 Suppuratus, p.
That causeth an impostume to
runne. 1 Suppuratorius, ad.

pud, vt apud posteros, in time

inter hæc, in the meane time.

An inflammation of the vt­
termost skinne of the eie, called
Adnata, proceeding either of
the fulnesse of the body, or of
the sharpe biting cholericke hu­
mour, or of grosse humoures and
windinesse puffing vp the place.

An Instrumente to
make, or doe any thing withall. 
1 Instrumentum, organum, n.
An instrument of musicke.
1 Psalterium, organum, n.
An instrument having but
three stringes. 1 Pandura, f.
An instrument having but
foure strings. 1 Tetrachordon.
An instrumente having ten
stringes. 1 Decachordium, n.
A kinde of instrument, in some
pointes all one with the Psal­
ter. 1 Pectis, f.
One that plaieth on an instru­
ment.
1 Psaltes, organicus, masc. 
psaltria, f.
A maker of instrumentes.
1 Organarius, m.

An Instrumente of
warre. 
1 Machina, 2 machinatio, f.
An instrument in warre, that
serveth for a little broch, and a
candle. 3 Obelescolychnium.
An instrument which Physiti­
ons vse to conveigh medicines
into the belly. 1 Metrenchyta.
An instrument of surgerie, ha­
ving at both ends a long round
knob made like an oliue stone, 
which is put into sore mouthes, 
with linen wrapt about.
1 Dipyrenum, n.
An instrument wherewith the
skinne is cut.
1 Paracenterium, n.
An iron instrumente where­
with the fleshe of the gummes
is parted round aboue from the
tooth in the tooth-ache.
1 Pericharecter, m.
An instrument to drawe out
matter of sores.
1 Piulcus, m. piulcum, n. gam­
moides, f.
Instrumentes of moving in the
toppe of the muscels, made of si­
newes and ligatures, and knit­
ing them to the bones.
1 Tendones, tendines, m.
An instrument which Chirur­
gians vse, called also Terebra.
1 Abaptistum, n.
Instrumentes which Chirurgi­
ans vse to draw out the bones of
fishes, which sticke in a mannes
throate. 1 Acanthavola, n.
An instrument to take salues
out of a boxe. 2 Lingua, f.
Instrumentes, to let bloude
with.
1 Phlebotomum, n.
An instrument, wherewith a­
nie thing is made rounde.
1 Teretrum, n.
Instrumentes vsed in torture.
1 Anchorisci, m.
An instrument wherwith high
thinges are measured.
1 Altimetor, altimeter, m.
An instrument vsed to trie the
windes. 1 Amusium, n.
An instrument by which is
founde out the course and ele­
vation of the Sunne, and other
like matters.
1 Astrolabium, n. analem­
ma, fœm.
An instrument, or engine to
drawe water.
1 Hydraulus. masc. hydrau­
lis, fœm.
An instrument wherewith
stones are polished.
1 Hippagogeus, seu potius
hypagogeus, m.
An instrument vsed in choo­
sing the situation of citties.
1 Sciater, m.
An instrument pertaining to
the kitchine, wherewith a pot is
remooved.
1 Torina, f.
An instrument serving to dig
vp gold, or silver, or to purge it.
1 Auramentum, n.
Instrumentes made with teeth
like a sawe, which being draw­
en with Oxen, plucke vp by the
rootes flagges, and great weeds
growing in medowes.
1 Scirpices, m.
An instrument, or toole having
two teeth.
1 Bidens, m.
An instrumente having three
teeth. 1 Tridens, m.
Instrumentes, or tooles of all
sortes.
2 Arma, orum, n.
An instrument of crafte, and
falshode.
1 Armille, n.
Instrumentes, or deedes of
writinges.
2 Literæ, tabulæ, formule, f.
The place where such instru­
ments be laide.
2 Tabularium, n.
An instrument to graue with.
2 Calum, n.
An instrument, or toole of
iron.

I ANTE V.

To Iudge, or deeme. 
1 Iudico, vide thinke. 
To iudge betweene two.

To delaie in iudgement.
2 Amplio.
To iudge first, or before other to
whom the matter pertaineth.
1 Præjudico.
To iudge, or giue sentence.
1 Iudico, adjudico, jus dicere, 
censuram agere, statuo. 2
Pronuncio, arbitror.
To heare a matter debated, as
iudge to determine it.
1 Cognosco vt cognoscere
causas, to iuge, or decide causes. 
To sit in iudgement.
1 Sedere pro tribunali, forum
agere.
By iudgement to giue to.
1 Adjudico.
By iudgement to giue away.

Iuged.

Which is not iudged.

or that which is appointed by the

dicatio, 2 Sententia, dica, f.

To Knit. 
1 Necto, 2 texo, plecto, plico.
To knit often. 1 Nexo, as, & is.
To knit, or tie. 1 astringo, necto
To knit, or weaue with. 1 attexo
To knit, or tie knottes. 1 Nodo.
To knit in. 1 Innecto, is, intexo
3 Innecto, as, innexor.
To knit, or binde about. 1 Innecto
To knit, or binde to.
1 Astringo, annecto, alligo.
To knit vp or to. 1 Deligo.
To knit vnder. 1 Subnecto, 
Subnodo.
To knit fast. 1 Obnecto, innodo
To knit, or fasten one thing to a 
nother. 1 Pronecto.
To knit, or tie together.
1 Connecto, connexo, is, con­
nodo, colligo, internecto, 2 co­
pulo, compagino, conglutino, 
contraho, adjungo, cogo, con­
cilio, vnio.
To knit a net. 3 Reticulo.
To be knit. 1 Annector.
Knit. 1 Nexus, p.
Knit fast.
1 Obnexus, p. Illigatus, 2 Ad­
junctus, p.
Knit together. 1 Connexus, 
annexus, 2 Adjunctus, vnitus.
Knit together, as a ioint.
1 Verticillatus, p.
A knitting together. 1 connexio
f. connexus, m. 2 Conglutinatio
Compositio, f.
A fast knitting 1 Obnexio, f.
A knitting vnder. 1 Subnectio.
A knittinge, or weaving.
2 Textura, f. textus, m.
That may be knit, or tied.
3 Nexibilis, ad.
That may be knitte, or tieds also
stronglie knit, or wrought.
1 Nexilis, ad.
That may be knit with the lombe, 
or needle. 1 Texilis, 3 texibilis.

A knit kerchiefe, such
as women weare. 2 Plagula, f.

To gather it selfe to
a Knobbe, or bunch. 
1 Tubero, protubero.
A knobbe, or bunch.
1 Gibbus, m. tuber, tubercu­
lum, n. 3 tuberus, m. v: bunch. 
A knobbe in the midest of a buck­
ler. 1 Vmbo, m.
Knobbie 1 Tuberosus, ad.

To Knocke. 
1 Tundo, contundo, ferio, pulso
To Knock, or thumpe, as to knock
ones breast. 1 Plango.
To knock, beat or dash. 1 impingo
To knocke, or beate together.
1 Collido, plango.
To knock about. 2 committigo, 
vt committigare caput alicu­
jus To knock about the pate.
3 Circumpavio.
To knock often, or to knock at of­
ten. 1 Pulto, pulsito.
To knock at. 1 Percutio, ferio, 
pulso, vt pulsare fores.
To knocke againe. 1 Relido.
To knock vehemently. 1 perlido
To knock, or buffet one. vi:  Boxe. 
Knocked. 1 Pulsatus, contusus.
Knocked againe. 1 Relisus, p.
One that knocketh.
1 Percussor, pulsator, m.
A knocking, or beating.
1 Contusio, pulsatio, f.
A knocking, beating, or striking
1 Planctus, m.
1 Collisio, f. collisus, 2 Confli­
ctus, m.

To make knottes. 
1 Nodo
To make three knottes.
3 Trinodo.
Knotted. 1 Nodatus, p.
A knotte. 1 Nodus, nexus, m. 
colligatio, f.
A little knotte. 1 Nodulus, m.
A knotte or iointe in twigs of
trees, or such like.
2 Articulus, m.
A knotte in a tree, piece of tim­
ber, or stone. 1 Tuber, centrum.
The knotte of a cap-band, or hat
band, whereby the cappe or hatte
is fastned, or slacked. 2 Offendi­
mentum, n. offendix, f.
A knotte in Venus girdle.
1 Acidylus, m.
A knotte in a cord to hold wilde
beastes. 1 Capulum, n.
The knotte, or iointe of an hearb.
1 Geniculum, n.
The knottes, or ioints of the bones
in the knees, knuckles, and such
like 1 Condylus, m.
The knotte, or iointe in the backe
bone 1 Spondylus, m. 
Atlius nodus. 
Atlantius nodus.
Knottines 1 Nodatio, f.
Of three knots.
1 Trinodus, trinodis, ad.
Of foure knottes.
1 Quadrinodus, ad.
Knottie, or full of knottes.
1 Nodosus, centrosus, gibbo­
sus, geniculatus, 2 Articulosus
3 Condylomaticus, nexosus, 
nexibilis, ad.
Without knottes
1 Enodis, enodus, ad.
From knotte to knotte.

To Knowe. 
1 Nosco, cognosco, scio, Scis­
co, 2 Teneo. 3 Noro, Suscio.
To knowe before hand.
1 Præcognosco, prænosco, præ­
scio, præscisco.
To knowe much, or often.
1 Noscito, cognoscito.
To knowe a thing among other.
1 Internosco.
To knowe by divers partes.
1 Dignosco.
To knowe by inquirie.
1 Deprehendo.
To knowe certainly, perfectly, or
throughly.




1 Percognosco, pernosco, per
calleo, comperio, perspicio. 
Certum habeo. 
2 Compertum habeo. 
Manifestum habeo. 
Exploratum habeo.
To Knowe distinctly.
2 Discerno.
To Knowe by some token: also to
knowe of olde. 1 Agnosco.
To know well. 2 Calleo, ignosco
To Knowe that which is kept se­
crete. 1 Rescio, rescisco.
To Know againe. 1 recognosco
To know, or haue knowledge.
2 Sapio.
To know a woman carnally. 1 sub­
agito, subjicito, 2 cognosco.
Not to knowe. 1 Descio,  vide 
to be ignorant. 
To desire to knowe. 1 Noscito.
To make to knowe.
1 Condocefacio.
To make knowen.
1 Notesco. 2 Publico, manife­
sto, indico, palam facio.
To make knowen by open procla­
mation. 1 Promulgo.
To come to ones knowledge.
2 Permanesco.
To be knowen. 1 Notesco, enotes­
co, consto.
To be knowen abroad.
2 Emano, permano.
To be knowen of all men. 1 Inno­
tesco, inclareo, inclaresco.
I Knowe. 1 Memini, consul­
tum est, vt neque qua quæram
consultum est, neither doo I
knowe where to seeke him. 
It is well knowen.
2 Lucet, impers.
It shall be knowen. 1 scibitur.
It is vnknowen 1 nescitur, im.
Not knowing. 1 Insciens, p. vi:
ignorant. 
Knowen. 1 Notus, cognitus, ag­
nitus, intellectus, 2 deprehensus
animadversus, p. notabilis, 
Luculentus, manifestus, ad. 
spectatus, p.
Knowen, or notorius. 2 Notatus.
Knowen well, surely, or through­
lie. 1 percognitus. 2 perspectus
exploratus, compertus, inve­
stigatus, p.
Knowen openly. 1 Vulgatus, per
vulgatus, testatus, p. manife­
starius, ad.
Knowen before. 1 Præcognitus.
Well knowen. 1 Gnarus, ad.
Notoriouslie, or well knowen.
2 Clarus, ad.
That which is well knowen.
1 Notabilis, luculentus, 2 ma­
nifestus, ad. 3 cognobilis, ior.
Better knowen. 1 cognitior, ad.
Exceeding well knowen.
1 Cognitissimus. 2 pernobilis.
Not knowen. 3 Apocryphus.
A knower of many thinges.
3 Polyhistor, m.
That knoweth, or knowing.
1 Sciens, notus, p. conscius, pru­
dens, gnarus, ad.
Knowing much. 1 multiscius, ad
Knowing before what shal follow
2 Præscius, ad.
Desiring to knowe.
1 Noscitabundus, ad.
That may be knowen. 1 scibilis.
Not knowing. vide ignorant. 
When it was knowen, or tried.
1 Comperto absolute.

vide
acknowledge.
To come to the knowledge of a 
thing 2 Deprehendo.

notitia, notio, peritia, gnosis, 3

entia infirmitatis suæ, of the 
knowledge of his owne infirmity
A fore-knowledge.
2 Mens, f.
Sure, or prefit knowledge.

The knowledge of divine and
humane thinges.

A Knowledging.

L ANTE A.

A LABELL.

A Labell hanging on each side
of a miter.
1 Insula, f.
A Labell hanging downe on gar­
mentes, or crownes.
1 Lemniscus, m.
A little labell. 2 Appendicula.
That hath labelles, or jesses hang­
ing downe.
1 Lemniscatus, ad.

To Labour, travaile, 
or take paines. 
1 Laboro, Illaboro, Allaboro, 
Operor, Enitor, Nitor, vt niti
pro aliquo, to labour, or tra­
vaile in defence of ones cause.
2 Molior, vt nulla opera moli­
tur, he laboureth about nothing.
Ago, Præsudo, 1 Exerceo. 3
Tudito.
To labour, or endevour.
1 Nitor, Enitor, Studeo, vid 
endeuour. 
To labour earnestlie.
1 Allaboro, 2 Præsudo.
To labour against.
1 Renitor, obnitor.
To labour together earnestly.
1 Connitor.
to labour until be sweat 2 sudo
resudo, desudo, 3 desudasco.
To labour cunninglie, fast, or
apace.
1 Elaboro.
With great labour to set some
thing against a place where one
must needes passe. 1 Obmoior.
To labour for. 2 Ambio, Quæro.
To labour men to giue their voi­
ces. 2 Prenso, prehenso.

To Laie, as one laieth
a foundation. 1 Struo, construo, 
jacio, conjicio, colloco, loco, 
pono.
To laie, or set together. 1 confero
To laie handes on one. 2 Involo
To laie over. 1 Obduco.
To laie vnder. 1 Subjicio, sup­
pono, substerno.
To laie, or put aboute.
1 Circumpono.
To laie out, or forth. 1 erogo, im­
pendo, dispenso, dispendo.
To laie from one to an other. 2
Immitto, vt immittere ligna, 
vel trabes. To laie rafters or
beams from one wall to another. 
To laie apart, or asunder.




1 Sepono repono, secerno.
To laie aside, or leaue.
1 Posthabeo, mitto. 2 Exuo, vt
exuitur æqualitas, equalitie is
laide aside. 
To laie downe.
1 Depono, demitto.
To laie vp, or vppon: also to laie
now on one side, now on another.
1 Repono.
To laie vp safe.
1 Repono, condo, recondo. 
2 Loco.
To laie, or put against.
1 Oppono, objico.
To laie, or put vppon, or over.
1 Superinjicio, superjacio, su­
perjicio, superdo.
To laie, or cast together, or vpon.
1 Congero, adaggero, coaddo
To laie out abroade.
1 Expono.
To laie, or set to. 1 Applico.
To laie betweene. 1 Interjicio.
To laie before one, or in his way.
1 Objicio.
To laie a dead, or fained thing, in
steede of a true, and liuely thing.
1 Suppono.
To laie on heapes.
1 Aggero.
To laie along.
1 Prosterno, vt prosternere
corpora humi, to laie bodies a­
long vpon the ground. 
To laie before, or represent.
1 Repræsento.
To laie exception against.
2 Præscribo, vt reus accusato­
res præscribit.
To laie waite.
2 Peto, vt vnum me petunt, it is
onelie I that they laie waite for, 
To laie by line.
3 Degrummor.
To laie to ones charge.
1 Objicio.
To laie snares. 1 tendere casses.
To laie for a thing before it come.
1 Prætendo.
To laie an excuse.
1 Prætendo, obtendo.
To laie egges.
2 Pario.
Laied. 1 Positus, p.
Laid asunder, or apart.
1 Sepositus, p.
Laid aside, or left of.
1 Postpositus, missus, p.
Laied betwixt. 1 Interpositus. 
interjectus, p.
Laied vnder. 1 Substratus, p.
Laied against. 1 Objectus, op­
positus, contrapositus, p.
Laied by, or to. 1 Appositus, p.
Laied in. 1 Immissus, p.
Laied down, or lefte in an others
keeping. 1 Depositus, p.
Laide downe. 1 Demissus, p.
Laide vp safe. 1 Conditus, re­
conditus, repositus, repostus. 2
Congestus, p.
A laying on. 1 Impositio, f.

To Lament, waile, or
mourne. 1 Lamentor, delamen­
tor, ploro, deploro, comploro
opploro, lugeo, delugeo, que­
ror, conqueror, querulor, mæ­
reo, querimonior, gemo, con­
gemo, congemisco, circumge­
mo, fleo, defleo, deplango, 2
doleo, 3 Querelo, vide weepe. 
To lament much.
1 Ingemo, ingemisco.
To lament a long time.
1 Prolugeo.
To beginne to lament.
1 Lugesco.
To lament fainedlie. 1 Affleo.
To lament greatlie.
1 Illachrymo.
To lament for the losse of some
bodie. 1 Elugeo, 3 nænior.
To lament, weepe, waile, or mourn
to, or with one. 1 Apploro.
To lament with an other.
1 Congemo, callachrymo.
To lament ones misfortune.
1 Miseror.
To make lamentable.
3 Lugubro.
They lament. 1 Lugetur, gemi­
tur, impers.
Lamented.
1 Lamentatus, querendus, p.
Lamented for. 1 Ploratus, de­
ploratus, fletus, defletus, p.
Worthy to be lamented.
1 Lachrymabilis, ad.
Not lamented. 1 Indeploratus, 
indefletus, p.
A lamentour. 1 Lamentator.
A lamenting, wayling, or lamen­
tation.
1 Lamentatio, deploratio, 
querela, ploratio, f. ploratus, 
questus, ejulatus, gemitus, m. 
ejulatio, f. lamentum, threnos, 
threnum, n. plangor, planctus. 
2 Vlulatus, m.
A lamenting, or wailing toge­
ther. 1 Comploratio, colla­
chrymatio, f.
A lamenting, or mourning.
1 Mœror, luctus, fletus, m.
A lamenting with beating the
brest. 3 Tympanaria, f.
Lamentablenes. 1 Elegia, f.

ses. 1 Elegidium, elegia, n. ele­
gus, m. elegia, monodia, f. epi­
odium, threnos, threnum, n. 
canticum.
A lamentable song at burialles.

thing, whereby a man is greeved

A Lancelot, v: launce

Lande. 
1 Fundus, m. 2 possessio rusti­
ca, 3 Terrenum, n.
A land, or region. 1 Terra, 2 ora, f
Landes vntilled.
1 Chersos.
Landes tilled. 2 Rus, n.
Ley lande. 1 Selio.
Lande that hath lien ley, turned
in the spring time.
1 Vervactum, n.
Land lien ley, after newlie tilled
1 Rudetum, n.
Lande tilled every other yeere, or
lands newlie eared to be sowne.
1 Novale, n. novalis, f.
Lande sowed.
2 Seges, f.
A peece of land in the countrie, 
without any dwelling house.
1 Ager, m.
They whose landes lie by the high
waye.
1 Amsegetes.
Landes which by the civill lawe
might be given, or solde.
1 Censui agri.
Free lande, or free hold lande.
1 Optimo jure prædia.
Landes given by fee simple, or fee
taile, to be holden of the donour, 
by some service.
1 Beneficiarius fundus.
He that requireth to haue parte
in the division of landes.
1 Agripeta.
A land lepper, vide loiterer. 
A peece of land fallen by inheri­
taunce.

Lawyers which neglecting the e­
quitie of the law stick to the ve­
rie wordes. 1 Acribodicæi, m.
Such a strict lawe.
1 Acribodicæum, n.
Lawyers who having studied the
law one whole yeare, added the
second yeere also therevnto.
1 Edictales, m.
One that loveth to prate alwaies
of the lawe. 1 Philodicus, m.

By leapes, or leape by leape.
1 Saltatim, exultim, assul­
tim, velitatim, saltim, adu.

A Leape, or weele
to take fish in. 




1 Nassa, f.
Leapes to take eeles.
1 Caudecæ, f.

The Leape yeare, v. 
yeare.

To Learne. 
1 Disco, addisco, 2 Præcipio, 
comprehendo, apprehendo, 
intelligo, cognosco.
To learne together.
1 Condisco.
To learne before. 1 Prædisco.
To learne by hart, or perfectly.
1 Edisco, perdisco.
One that learneth in his child­
hoode.
1 Pædamathes, m.
One that learneth in his olde
age, which never learned before
he was aged.
1 Opsimathes, m.
Such learning. 1 Opsimathia.
A lover of learning.
1 Philomathes, m.
Loue of learning.
1 Philomathia, f.
Learning. 1 Doctrina, eruditio
disciplina, literatura, literæ, 
mathema, 
2 Cognitio, f.
That learning which compre­
hendeth all the seven libe­
rall sciences.
1 Encyclopædia, f.
Learning by demonstration.
1 Mathesis, f.
Aptnes to learne.
1 Docilitas, f.
Learned of himselfe, without
his masters helpe.
1 Autodidactus, ad.
Learned.
1 Literatus, doctus, eruditus
p. ior, issimus, prudens, subti­
lis, 2 Peritus, p.
Very well learned.
1 Perdoctus, p. literatorius, 
literosus, 2 Perperitus, p.
Somewhat learned.
1 Eruditulus, semidoctus, ad.
Learned in the 7. liberall arts.
1 Heptatechnus, ad.
Learned no thing at all.
1 Agrammatus, ad.
Apt to learne.
 Docilis, disciplinosus, ad.
Pertaining to learning.
1 Literarius, ad.
That may be learned.
1 Disciplinabilis, ad.
Learnedly.
1 Docte, perdocte, literate, 
erudite, pererudite, adu.

ring, or farming of a thing.

A lease.

pers, vide to gleane.

Leasing, v. lying.

1 Multesimus, ad.

Least any man.

1 Nequando, adu.
Least that. 1 Ne, ni, neve, adu

2 vacuus, issimus, ad.

visement what to doe.

Leasure. 1 Otium, n. vacauo, 
f. Vacuum tempus.
Leasure, or tariance.

re locum.

1 Otiose, vacanter, 3 vacatim

little. 1 Cunctanter, otiose, 
ductim, minutatim, sensim,

To Leaue. 
1 Desino, mitto. 2 prætereo, 
depono.
To leaue, or forsake. 1 Desero, 
destituo, desisco, linquo, re­
linquo, derelinquo, deficio, 
2 Descedo, vt discedere ab
amicis, to leaue the frindship of
men.  Decedo, vt decedere
possessione.
To leaue of.
1 Desino, desisto, absisto, mit­
to, dimitto, intermitto, re­
mitto, 2 Recedo, conquiesco, 
Parco, abrumpo, remo­
veo.




To leaue behind.
1 Postmitto, postergo.
To leaue out a thing that
shoulde bee spoken, or to leaue
vntouched.
1 Prætermitto, 2 prætereo.
To leaue out, that ought to bee
spoken, as effectuall to the mat­
ter handling.
1 Prævaricor.
To leaue off from dooing of a 
thing.
1 Supersedeo.
To leaue, forsake, or put away.
1 Repudio.
To leaue the olde woonte.
1 Desuefacio, desuesco.
To leaue off for a time.
1 Intermitto.
To leaue mourning.
1 Elugeo.
To leaue playing.
1 Eludo.
To leaue worke.
2 Cesso.
To leaue alone.
3 Viduo.
To leaue without succour.
1 Desolo, 2 prodo.
Left, or forsaken. 1 Desitus, 
relictus, derelictus, 2 vitatus.
Left, or not medled with.
1 Omissus, p.
Left off 1 Desitus, p.
Left off for a time.
1 Intermissus remissus, p.
Left alone. 1 Desolatus, p. 
desolatorius, ad. viduatus.
Left out. 1 Paralipomenon.
That must be left off.
1 Desuescendus, p.
A leaving, or forsaking.
1 Rejectio, relictio, dereli­
ctio, destitutio, desertio, fæm
derelictus, m.
A leaving vntouched.
1 Omissio, f.
A leaving out.
1 Prætermissio, f.
A leaving off for a time.
1 Intermissus, m.
A leaving without comfort.
1 Desolatio, f.
Leavings, or things left.
1 Reliquiæ, f.
That is left.
1 Reliquus, residuus, ad.

pace tua.

A house of lechery. 1 Lupanar, 
lupanarium, v. brothell house.

without studie.

Letters gratulatorie, sent for a 
welcome home.

Letters excusatorie.
1 Epistola excusatoria.
Letters crookedly written.
1 Literæ vacillantes.
Letters patents.

Letters of pardon.
2 Dimissoriæ literæ.
Letters tanting, or biting.

Blinde letters, that can hardly
be read.

A private mans letter.
1 Diographæ literæ.
Letters sent from one to an o­
other.

ring other letters.

pistolophor, m. v. Carrier.

2 remissio, 3 lysis, f.
Lewsenesse.
1 Lebefactio, resolutio, laxi­
tas, f. laxamentum, n. 2 vacil­
latio, f
The lewsenesse and clefte of the
skinne about the roote of the
nailes.
1 Reduvia, redivia, sœm, re­
divium, n.
Lewse.
1 Laxus, ad. exolutus, resolu­
tus, 2 fluxus, fluens, diffusus, 
fluctuans, remissus, p.
Easie to be lewsed.
1 Solubilis, solutilis, dissolu­
bilis, ad.
That cannot be lewsed.
1 Indissolubilis, ad.
Lewsely.
1 Solute, laxe. 
2 Incomposite, adu.

I had Leyfer. 
1 Malo.


L ANTE I.

A liberall giver.

A liberall giving.

Liberality, or bountifulnesse.

largitas, bonitas, amplitas, 
effusio, prolixitas, prolixitu­
do, 3 polidoria, munerositas, 
fœm.

neficus, dapsilis, 2 Largus,

dulgentissimus, clementissi­
mus, ad.

Liberall, as the sciences.

fice, 2 Large, prolixe, libere, 
accumulate, strenuehumane
humaniter, solute, glomera­

magnificentissime, 2 Largis­
sime, amplissime, solutissime.

Full of such liberty.

Liberty without correction.

owne lawes.

That is of that liberty.

The assertion of libertye, or
freedome.

A setting one at liberty.

To Loth, or detest. 
1 Fastidio, detestor, abhomi­
nor. 2 Nauseo.
To be loth to doe a thing.
1 Gravor, pigeo.
It lotheth. 1 Piget, impers.
It lotheth greatly.
1 Pertædet, impers.
It beginneth to loth.
1 Pertædescit, impers.
Loth to doe. 1 Gravatus, p.
That lotheth, or hateth.
1 Pertæsus, p.
Lothed, hated, or disdained.
1 Fastiditus, p.
A lother of a thing.
2 Nauseator.
A lothing of a thing.
2 Nausea, f.
Lothsomnes. 1 Fastidium, n. 
2 Satietas, f.
Lothsome. 2 Impurus, ater, 
Fœdus, horridus, ad.
Loth to doe. 2 Piger, ad. vt pi­
ger militiæ, loth to goe to war­
fare. 
Ful of lothing. 1 Fastidiosus.

To cast Lottes.

That hath cast lottes.
1 Sortitus, p.

cuttes.

1 Sortialis, ad.
Not by lotte. 1 Insortitus, ad.
By lotte. 1 Sorte, sortito, adu.

To Loue. 
1 Diligo, amo, 2 Amplector, 
colo, appeto.

lie. 1 Amo, adamo, peramo, 
examo, deamo, 2 Osculor, 
amplexor, observo.
To loue mutually.
1 Redamo, 2 cohæreo.
To loue with ielousie.
1 Zelo, zelor.
To loue ardently, or be fervent­
lie in loue with. 2 Ardeo, fla­
gro, depereo, demorior.
To be in loue with.
2 Miror, admiror, inflammor
Loved 1 Dilectus, amatus, p.

L ANTE V.

vile service in an house.

To make Luckie. 
1 Secundo, prospero.
To bring ill lucke.
1 Obscæno.
Lucke, or chaunce.
1 Fortuna, f. vide chaunce. 
The lucke, or fortune of some
thing to come, gathered by some
signe.
1 Omen, n.
Good Lucke. 1 Faustitas, f. Eu­
fortunium, n.

happie. 1 Prosper, prosperus, se­
cundus, faustus, fortunatus, 
fælix, 2 Lætus, ad.

cundissimus, ad.

tendeth good, or evill lucke.

Luckie, or that bringeth good
lucke. 2 Auspicatus, p.
That bringeth, or signifieth ill
Lucke.

dexter Apollo, Virg.

fauste, fortunate, fortunatim,

auspicato, læto omine, bonis
avibus, secundis ventis, se­

bono auspicio, prospero omi­

cæ involucrum.

mentio, demento, 3 rabio, 
accisso, gallo.

Madde Priestes.

cerdotes.
A Madde fellowe without witte
2 Vacerra, ceritus, m.
A madde tooth.
1 Rabidus dens.
Madnes. 1 Furor, m. insania, in­
sanies, insanitas, vesania, amen­
tia, morosis, seu motosis, vecor­
dia, dementia, mania, rabies
2 melancholia, f. œstrum, n. 3 ba­
chania, f.
The madnesse of a dogge.
1 Rabies, rabia, f.
A kind of phrensie, or madnesse, 
wherewith some being haunted, 
doe forsake the companie of men, 
and hide themselues in holes, and
caves, and crie like wolues.
1 Lycanchropia, f.
Madde, or franticke.
1 Vesanus, furiosus, vecors, de­
mens, furiens, amens, insanus, 
ceritus, Lymphatus, lympha­
ricus, rabidus, rabiosus, 2 abre­
picius, maniacus, proceritus, 
insaniens, abderiticus, ad.

or prophesying.

Madde by seeing some thing in
the water.
1 Lymphatus, Lymphaticus.
Madde at certaine moones.
1 Lunaticus.
Madde as a dogge.

rabidus, rabiosus, ad.
A little madde.

1 Furibundus, ad.
Running madde.

places, whither they came, vn­
luckie, or vnhappie.
1 Lucumones, m.
Madlie.

a kind of magistrats, which haue

do against iustice.

To Make. 
1 Facio, efficio, fingo, effingo, 
confingo, fabrico, molior. 2 texo
figuro, compono, procreo, excu­

1 reficio, 2 renovo, recudo, re­

a wife.

Sibi adjungere Vxorem.

is signified that a mannes wyfe is
his master.  vt vxori nolo nu­
bere meæ. I will not marie a 
wife to serue her.

To Matche, or make
æquall.

cio.
To match, or bestowe in mariage.
3 Loco.
To matche, or be like.
1 Æquiparo, æquo, vt nemo, 
est qui me factis æquiparet,
None may match me many doings
cælum æquat pontus, The sea
matcheth the heavens in heighte

a matching. 1 Adæquatio, 2 con­

A measure.
1 Proportio, mensura, f. men­
sus, permensus, m. metrum, n. 
2 Numerus, m. circumscriptio.
Measure, or meane. vid: meane.
A measuring.
1 Mentio, dimentio, f.
Measuring of landes.
1 Geodæsia, f.
A measure in musicke.
1 Modulus, 2 modus, m.
A measure containing 2 ounces
and a halfe.
1 Acetabulum, n.
A measure containing 4 gallons
and a halfe.
1 Vrna, f.
A measure containing 9 gallons
1 Ephi.
A measure containing 4 Ro­
maine bushels.
1 Demensum, n.
A measure of ground containing 
2 furlonges.
1 Diaulus, m.
A measure of ground among the
Jews containing 4 Italian miles.
1 Chæmis, f.
A measure of ground containing
100 foote.
1 Plethrum, n.
A measure containing so much
ground as a yoke of oxen wil eare
in a daie, in length 240 foote, in
breadth 20, which multiplied, 
commeth to 28800.
1 Iugerum, n.
The measure of 2 Palmes or 8
fingers.
1 Dichas, f.
A measure of 9 Ounces.
1 Nonuncium, n. 2 Dodrans, f
A measure containing 50 paces.
1 Leuca, f.
The same measure among the He­
brewes, that  Sextarius Atticus
is among the Græcians.
3 Log.
A measure whereby wee buy and
sel whatsoeuer is requisite for
our sustenaunce.
1 Metrum bioticum.
A measure of liquide things, con­
taining 72 Sextaries.
1 Batus, m.
A measure of wine among the
Greeks in weight 2 drams, one scru­
ple, and 4 fiue partes of a graine.
1 Cheme, vel chema, f.
A measure containing a bushell.
1 Modiatio, f.
A measure to weigh water with.
1 Dioptra, f.
A measure containing a gallon, 
and almost a pinte.
1 Gomor.
A measure the halfe of sextari­
us.
1 Emina, f.
A measure that is the same a­
mong the Græcians, which Con­
gius is among the Romanes, con­
taining 6 sextaries.
1 Chus, m.
A measure of ground containing
3 miles and 3 quarters after our
measure.
1 Parasanga, f.
An Hebrewe measure of nine
inches
1 Zeneth.
A measure containing 11 oun­
ces, or 11 cyathi, which is 22 oun­
ces, also 11 partes of 12.
1 Deunx, f.
A measure fowre inches long by
squire, 303 inches deepe, & as ma­
ny broad, which is the true sexta­
rius: according to this accounte, 
it is iust our pinte and a halfe, 
for in our wine pinte is but 10
ounces.
1 Sextarius, m.
Belonging to the measure, quan­
titie, or weight of Sextaries.
1 Sextantarius, ad.
A measure of 2 gallons and a
quarte.
1 Rhytum, n.
A measure, of 2 bushels.
1 Medimnum, n. medimnus, m
A kinde of measure, which con­
taineth sixe heminaes.
1 Maruda, f.
A measure containing 2 sexta­
ries, or after some foure.
1 Cabus, m.
The measure of an hand breadth
1 Palma, f.
the least measure of liquid things, 
which being taken twelue times, 
filleth vp the measure Cyathus.
1 Cochlearium, n.
A certaine measure called also
hemina, containing halfe a sexta­
rie.
1 Cotula, f.
A measure containing 8 chani­
ces. 1 Octeus.
A measure of wine.
1 Olibantum, n.
A kinde of measure.
1 Olvatium, n.
A measure, or rule of 5 foote long
1 Quintupedal, n.
A measure containing 9 ounces
and 2 quartarios, that is 3 quar­
ters of a pinte. 1 Hemina, f.
The measure of 7 cubites.
1 Heptapachys, f.
A measure containing 12 sexta­
ries. 1 Hin.
The measure of grounde among
the Frenchmen, as much as halfe
an acer with vs. 1 Arepennis, f.
A measure of the Persians, con­
taining 72 sextaries.
1 Artaba, f.
A corne measure among the Per­
sians, containing 45 medimnes.
1 Achana, f.
A measure of liquides containing
6 sextaries, which is of our mea­
sure a gallon and one pinte, it may
be taken for our gallon.
1 Congius, m.
Pertaining to that measure.
1 Congialis, ad.
That holdeth, or containeth that
measure. 1 Congiarium, n.
A measure containing 2 bushels
1 Culeus, m.
That pertaineth to the measure
Culeus. 1 Culearis, ad.
A measure as Diose saith it con­
taineth 10 congios, that is of
our measure 10 gallons, and ten
pintes, which is eleven gallons
and a halfe.
1 Metreta, sive metreta Atti­
ca.
A measure of 4 fingers ioyned to
gether.
1 Palæstra, f.
A measure from the elbowe to the
toppe of the knee, when the hand
is fast together.
1 Pychon.
Measurable, or moderate.
1 Moderabilis, moderatus, me­
diocris. 2 Modicus, ad.
Pertaining to measure.
1 Metricus, ad.
Measurably, or moderately.
1 Temperate, temperanter, 




mediocriter, modice, adu.
By measure. 1 definitè, præfinitè
Beyond measure.
1 Impendio, præmodum, infi­
nite, 2 in immensum.
To a certaine measure.
1 Aliquatenus, adu.

To prepare, or pro­
vide Meate for. 
1 Opsono, obsono, opsonor.
To sit downe at meat. 1 cumbo.

3 Sublabro.
Meate. 1 Cibus, pastus, m. edu­
lium, opsonium, cibarium, ci­
baria, orum, esculentum, n. 
esca, epulæ, f. 3 esculetum, syn­
cerastum, n.
he that beareth meate to the table
1 Discophorus, discifer, ad.
Daintie meates, and pleasant in
eating.
1 Dapes, f. scitamenta, orum, n
Meates of good iuice.
1 Euchyla, euchyma, n.
Minsed meates.
1 Protrimenta, orum, n.
Drie meates.
1 Xerophagia, orum.
Meate wherewith any thing is
pampered, or fatted.
1 Sagina, f.
Rosted meate.
1 Assatura, assaria, f.
Meate burned in rosting.
1 Subverbusta, f.
Meate chewed, which Nurses
giue to their children.
1 Mansus, præmansus cibus.
Meates called junckets.
1 Iunculi, orum, n.
Meates made with honie.
1 Cibariamellita, 3 mellipecta
Meate made of honie, and poppie
seede.
1 Cocetum, n.
Meate stewed vppon a chaffing
dish.
1 Patinarium, n.
Meate made of the pappes of a
sowe, cut from her the day after
shee had farrowed, and powdred
with salt.
1 Sumen, n.
Meate made of sodde quinces, 
peares and honie, commonlie cal­
led Cotonearum. 1 Cydonites.
A kinde of meate made of flesh, 
chopped with bloud, sewet, and
sweete liquor.
1 Creocaccabis.
A kinde of meate vsed in olde
time, and customablie eaten hote
and warme. 1 Forbea.
Meate sprinkled with salt, which
was powred all over vppon the
sacrifice.
1 Vlochyton, n.
Meate made of the inwardes of
beastes
1 Oximum, n.
A kinde of meate vsed of the
vplandish people of Italie.
1 Myttitos.
A meate made of the garbage of
pullen, or such like.
1 Gigeria, orum.
Meate made of fatte, and honie.
1 Syrmæa.
Meate which is holsome for one, 
and hurtfull for another.
1 Cibus anceps.
A kinde of meat invented in Lu­
cania.
1 Lucaniæ, arum.
Bees meate while they labour.
1 Erythace, f.
White meate made of milke.
1 Lactaria, lacticinia, orum, es­
culentum, n.
Meates made of beanes.
1 Conchis, f.
Meates made of meale.
1 Farracea, orum.
Meates dressed 3 daies past.
1 Pridianus cibus.
Meates preserved, seasoned, or
well sauced.
1 Conditania edulia.
Broken meates, or fragments.
1 Analecta, orum, fragmentum, 
fragmen, n.
Desire of daintie meates.
1 Cupedia, f.
A messe of meate, vide messe. 
A place where meate is solde.
1 Opsopolium, n.
Full of meates.
2 Farinosus, ad.
Made of meates.
1 Farmaceus, ad.
Pertaining to meate.

barius, ad.

A Mediatour. 
1 Intercessor, mediator, me­
dius, 2 Conciliator, interven­
tor, m.
A mediatour, or hee that is a
meane of bargaining between two
parties. 1 Proxenæta.
A mediator in contract between
man and woman for mariage.
1 Paranymphus, m.
Shee that is a mediatour in such
a matter. 1 Paranympha, pro­
nuba, f.
A woman mediatour.
1 Mediatrix, f.
A mediation, or meane betwene
2 parties.
1 Mediatio, intercessio, f. 2 in­
terventus, m.

To Medicine, cure, or
heale a sicke body. 
1 Medico, medicor, medeor.
A medicine. 1 Medicina, f. me­
dicamentum, medicamen, Re­
medium, pharmacum, n. medela
A medicine, ointment, or salue
causing rednes, and making the
body to breake out in wheales, and
pushes. 1 Phænignus, m.
A medicine against poyson.
1 Prophylacticum, n. alexiphar­
macon, antitodum, n. antido­
tus, m.
A medicine causing vomitati­
on of fleagmne.
1 Apophlegmatismus, m. 
commansum, n.
A medicine which will make the
teeth white. 1 Dentifricium, n.
Medicines which be burning hot.
1 Caustica medicamenta.
Medicines which do binde.
1 Styptica medicamenta.
A medicine to provoke vrine.
1 Vrinale Medicamentum. 
Diureticum Medicamentum.
A purging medicine.
1 Catharticum, medicamentum
Ventrifluum medicamentum
Medicines depilating, or opening
conduits. 1 Ecphractica medi­
camenta.
Those things the gumme whereof




is medicinable against corrupt
heares. 1 Anacollia.
Medicines that heale men of a­
gues. 3 Lexipyreti.
A medicine taken at the begin­
ning of fluxes, to driue backe an 
humour, or other malady.
1 Repellens medicamentum.
A medicine, or salue that openeth
or maketh thin those places of the
body, wherby breath is let out, and
maketh a way for the matter to 
haue an issue.
1 Relaxans medicamentum. 
Rarefaciens medicamentum.
A medicine, or salue, that taketh
away filth.
1 Repurgans medicamentum.
A medicine provoking travell
before time.
1 Amblothridion.
A medicine to licke, or suppe.
1 Illinctus, m.
A medicine of the iuice of wilde
cucumbers, to purge choler, and
fleagme.
1 Elaterium, n.
A medicine made of foure things
1 Tetrapharmacum, n.
A medicine against the cough.
1 Bechia, f.
A kinde of moist medicine laide
on linen, to hath any place of the
body to coole the liver.
1 Epithema.
A medicine to put in the nose, 
like a tent.
1 Errhinum, n.
Medicines given to sicke men.
1 Præbia, orum.
A medicine, or plaister for the
kings evill. 1 Strumum, n.
A medicine of the decoction and
iuice of the bramble roote.
1 Lycion.
A medicine, ointment, or salue
made partly of mustard, serving
to raise blisters on the skin.
1 Sinapismus, m.
a medicine to take away wrinkles
1 Tetanothrum, n.
Medicines which by provoking
sleepe, do put away paines and
griefes. 1 Anodina, orum.
A soveraigne medicine.
1 Medicametum Præsens, 
Medicametum præsentaneum
Remedium Singulare, 
Remedium Efficax.
A medicine against the biting
of wilde beasts.
1 Theriacum medicamentum
A medicine, or salue that draw­
eth out corruption, and matter.
1 Medicamentum attrahens.
A medicine or salue that driueth
away a malady, or disease, through
the pores of the skin.
1 Medicamentum discussorium
A medicine, or salue that doth
mollifie and soften.
1 Medicamentum emolliens.
A medicine, or salue that maketh
an apostume, or draweth a swel­
ling to matter 1 Medicamen­
tum suppuratorium.
A medicin, or salue that is sharp, 
biting, and smarting, and openeth
the vaines, and arteries.
1 Medicamentum anastoma­
ricum, osculans.
A medicine that stoppeth, and
shutteh the vessels of the body, not
suffering any thing to passe by
evaporation, or emptying.
1 medicametum obstipans, 
medicametum obstruens.
A medicine, or salue that dul­
leth the sense, and causeth a num­
nes with his coldnes.
1 Medicamentum soporiferum. 
stupefaciens.
A medicine, salue, or ointment, 
serving to keepe in the naturall
heate. 1 Medicamentum em­
plasticum.
A medicine to fetch a dead child
out of the wombe, that the woman
in labour fall not into daunger.
1 Ecbolia, orum, ecbolinæ, 
arum.
A medicine that destroieth, and
casteth the childe out of the wombe
by causing an aborsment, which is
heinous. 1 Med: abortivum.
A medicine causing barrennes.
1 Mediatocium.
A medicine, or salue that ser­
veth for greene wounds to dry, and
close them vp.
1 Med: Glutinans, Siccans.
A medicine, or salue that bring­
eth a skin, or scar over a wound, 
or sore. 1 Med: cicatricem du­
cens.
A medicine to stanch bloud.
1 Med: sanguinem sistens.
A medicine, or salue that bring­
eth flesh, or filleth vpon hollow
place with new flesh, after it is
well clensed from all malignant
matter.
1 Med: incarnans: cujus tria fa­
ciunt genera, 1 Cephalicum, 
quod peculiariter calvariam
incarnat, 2 catagmaticum, quod
reliquis fractis ossibus adhi­
betur, vt coalescant, 3 emot­
ton, quod penicillo exceptum, 
vulneri immittitur, quasi peni­
cularium dicas.
A medicine, or salue, that cau­
seth blisters, and wheales to rise
vpon the skinne.
1 Med: exulceratorium.
A medicine, or salue that eateth
away hard and superfluous flesh.
1 Med: depascens.
A medicine that serveth in steed
of fire, and is vsed to restore life
vnto the parts. 1 Pyroticum med.
A medicine, or ointment to take
away haire. 1 Dropax. 
Med: Deglabratorium, 
Med: Depilatorium.
A medicine, or remedy against
the dropsie, that will fetch the
water from them.
Med: hydragogum, med: aqui­
ducum.
A softe & liquid medicine, wher
in tents are dipped, before they bee
put into the hollow places of sores
1 Emmotton.
a medicine made of powder, being
tempered with oile, stayeth swea­
ting, if one be anointed ther with
1 Alispasma.
A dry medicine made of dry pow­
ders, which is throwne either a­
mong apparell, to make it smell
sweete, or cast into a sore, or
wound. 1 Diapasma.
A drinking medicine, or potion.
1 Medicata potio.
A medicine against wearines, pro­
cured by overmuch moving of
the body. 1 Acopum, n.
A medicine whereby drunkennes
and surfetting is avoided, & put
away. 1 Acræpalum med.
A medicine to make one loue.
1 Philtrum, n. 2 delenimentum
A medicine for the eies, when
the soares of them bee not well
cured.
1 Calliblepharum, n.




A kinde of medicine for the eies.
1 Diaglaucion.
A medicine for the headache.
1 Diatheton.
A medicine to slirre a man to
the lust of the bodie.
1 Diasatyrion.
A medicine made of goates dung
1 Diacapregias.
A medicine made of cummine, 
pepper, and rue.
1 Diospoliticon.
An excellent medicine made of
fruite.
1 Oporice, f.
A liquid medicine made of rose
water and vineger, laide to the
head of them, which are trou­
bled with the frensie.
1 Oxyrrhodium, n.
Medicines to make the birthe
quicklie delivered.
1 Oxytoca, vel exitoca.
A medicine to breake the co­
licke.
1 Phenus.
Any medicine that serveth to
the arteries. 1 Arteriace, f.
All kinde of medicines, which
quence thirste.
1 Adipsa.
Medicines which either asswage
hunger, or keepe a man from it.
1 Alima.
Medicines made without fat.
1 Alipænea.
A medicine against the disease, 
called Vua.
1 Adronium, n.
Medicines helping without
paine. 1 Aponia.
Having medicines preservatiue
before hand.
1 Præmedicatus, p.
That is medicinable.
1 Medicinalis, medicabilis, 
medicinabilis, medicamento­
sus, medicatus, medicinus, ad.
Pertaining to medicines.
1 Medicamentarius, ad.
That hath manie medicines.
1 Polypharmacus, ad.
Medicinablie.
2 Salutariter, adu.

2 Subicito, libidinor, v: whore.

A putting in mind of.
1 Commemoratio, f.
The minde. 1 Animus, m. ani­
ma, mens, dianoia, f. 2 cor, n.
The minde, or meaning.
1 Voluntas, intentio, f.
The minde, or opinion.
1 Sententia, f.
Of a gentle and quiet minde.
1 Æquanimus, ad.
Of one minde. 1 Vnanimus. 
vnanimis, homopsycus, ad.
Of sundrie mindes.
1 Multivolus, ad.

To be Mindeful of. 
1 Reminiscor, v. to remember. 
Mindefull.
1 Memor, inoblitus, 3 memo­
rosus, ad.

To Mine. 
2 Fodio.
A mine.
1 Scaptensula, 2 Fodina, f. 
metallum, n.
Mines, out of which mettals
are digged vp.
1 Mineria, mineralia, n.
A mine of golde.
1 Auraria, arrugia, auriso­
dina, f.
A mine of silver.
1 Argentarium metallum.
A mine of iron.
1 Ferraria, ferri fodina.
A mine of brasse.
Aeraria, f. Secturæ ærariæ.
A mine of vermilion, or sinople.
1 Minaria, f.
A mine, or hole in the ground.
1 Cuniculus, m.
A miner.
1 Cunicularius, m.
Miners, or diggers of mettall.
1 Metallici, metallarij, m.
Ful of mines, or holes in the
grounde.
1 Cuniculosus, ad.
By mines, or holes in the ground
1 Cuniculatim, adu.

Mine. 
1 Meus, pron.
For mine owne cause.
1 Meapte causa.

To Mingle, or mixe
together, or with other. 
1 Misceo, commisceo, per­
misceo, intermisceo, immis­
ceo, admisceo, promisceo, 
remisceo, consundo, 2 con­
texo, intexo, intersero, inter­
pono, appono.
To mingle diversly.
1 Vario.
To mingle with chaffe.
1 Acero.
To mingle, mixe, or temper.
1 Tempero, 2 diluo.
Mingled.
1 Mistus, mixtus, commistus, 
commixtus, intermistus, in­
termixtus, permistus, permix­
tus, immistus, immixtus, ad­
mistus, admixtus, remistus, 
remixtus, confusus, 2 condi­
tus, interpositus, interjectus, 
part.
Mingled amongest.
1 Intermistus, intermixtus, 
interpositus, intersertus, p.
Mingled, or mixed with.
1 Suffusus, p.
Mingled, mixed, or tempered.
1 Temperatus, 2 dilutus, p.
A mingling together.
1 Mistura, mixtura, admi­
stio, admixtio, permistio, per­
mixtio, commistio, commix­
tio, confusio, 2 compositio, f.




A mingling, mixing, or tempe­
ring. 1 Temperatura, tem­
peratio, f.
A mingling of diverse thinges
together.
1 Cinnus, m. miscellanea, n.
Mingled together without or­
der. 1 Promiscuus, ad.
Mingled with diverse thinges.
1 Miscellus, miscellaneus, ad
That cannot be mingled.
1 Incoibilis, ad.
In mingle mangle wise, or con­
fusedlye.
1 Permiste, promiscue, inde­
finite, adu.

little, vide lesse and diminish.

ex æquitate aliquid deroga­
re, to minish equity somewhat.

laugh at.

deo, ludo, illudo, deludo, 2 per­
despuo, cavillor, jocor.
To mocke, or taunte with a
false tale. 1 Fabulo, fabulor.
To mocke with bending the
browes, and snuffing vp the nose.
1 Subsanno.
So mocked. 1 Subsannatus.
Mocked, or deceived.
1 Elusus, lusus, delusus, p.

Such a mocking.

to be good, and is naught.

A mocke, or scoffe.

ludibrium, n.
A mocking, or laughing.

That is to be mocked at.

Money given for scholers at
their entrance, or admission to
the schoole.
1 Isagogicum, n.
Money given to the poore, offe­
red to Gods, or laide vp in the
common treasurie.
2 Stips, stipis, f.
Money borowed.
2 Æs alienum.
Money lent for gaine.
2 Æs circumforaneum.
Money caried over the sea.
1 Trajectitia pecunia.
Money coined
1 Argentum signatum, con­
flata pecunia.
Money newe coined.
2 Asper nummus.
Money delivered to one, to bee
paide to another.
1 Attributa pecunia.
Money paide for the cariage
of a thing.
1 Vectura, f.
A kinde of olde money, two
drachmas of our money, a little
more then 11. pence halfepenie.
1 Didrachmum, n.
A summe of money of an hun­
dred drachma.
1 Mina, f.
A money bagge.
1 Theca nummaria, vide 
bagge, and pouch. 
A money board, or table.
1 Trapeza, f.
The having of aboundance 
of money.
3 Nummatio, f.
Fulnes of money.
3 Nummositas, f.
He that is given to money.
1 Nummarius, ad.
He that requireth money.
1 Poscinumius, m.
Having much money.
1 Pecuniosus, multinummus, 
multinummatus, ad.
Monilesse.
2 Emunctus, p.
Of, or pertaining to money.
1 Nummarius, pecunialis, 
moneralis, ad.

To Monish. 
1 Moneo, admoneo, com­
moneo.
Monished.
1 Monitus, admonitus, com­
monefactus, p.
A monisher.
1 Monitor, admonitor, m.
A monition, or warning.
1 Monitus, m. monitum, n. 
vide to warne.

To bee made a 
Monke. 
3 Monachor.
A Monke.
1 Monachus. 3 Claustriensis.
The society, or fellowshippe
of monkes.
1 Monachium, n.
Belonging to a monke.
1 Monachalis, ad.
Of, or belonging to monkes, and
monasteries.
1 Monasticus, monasterialis.

A Monkie. 
1 Cercopithecus, cæbus, m. 
sphinx, cercolopis, f. caudata
simia.

A Monster. 
1 Monstrum, portentum, 
prodigium, ostentum, n. 
2 Bellua, f.
A monster, or anie wondrous
sight.
3 Monsterna, f.
The monsters called Centaures.
1 Bimembres, m.
A little monster.
1 Prodigiolum, n.
That breedeth, or bringeth
monsters.
1 Monstrifer, ostentifer, ad.
Ful of monsters of the sea.
2 Belluosus, ad.
That procureth monsters, or
strange signes.
1 Prodigialis, ad.
Monstrous.
1 Monstrosus, portentosus, 
prodigiosus, 3 Monstrificus, 
monstrificabilis, ad.
Monstrously.
1 Monstrose, portentose, 
prodigiose. 3 Monstrifice.

A Monument, or re­
membrance. 
1 Monumentum, monimen­
tum, n. 2 Titulus, m.
A monument, or remembrance
lefte with ones friende in re­
membrance of some thing.
1 Mnemosynum, n.
A monument of the deade, as a
sepulchre, graue, or tumbe.
1 Cenotaphium, n. tymbus, 
m. 2 Mausoleum, n.
A monument keeper.
3 Mnemophylax.

The Moone. 
1 Luna, Phœbe, f.
The newe moone.
1 Nova luna, 
Rediens luna.
A conjunction betweene the




Sunne and moone, she being not
seene.
1 Interlunium, intermen­
struum, n. 
Coitus lunæ, 
Cojunctio lunæ. 
Lunæ & solis concursus, 
Intermenstris Luna. 
Intermenstrua Luna. 
2 Tacita Luna. 
Silens Luna.
The time of the newe moone.
1 Novilunium, n. neomenia, f
The halfe moone.
1 Semiluna, f. 
1 Dimidia luna, 
Dimidiata luna.
The moone more then halfe
rounde. 1 Luna gibbosa.
The moone crooked with horns, 
as it is three daies after the
change, and the full.
1 Corniculata Luna. 
Cornua Luna. 
Curvata Luna.
The ful moone.
1 Plenilunium, n. Panse­
lenos. 
Luna plena, 
Luna semestris.
The eclipse of the moone.
1 Eclipsis Lunæ. 
Defectus Lunæ. 
Deliquium Lunæ. 
Obscuratio Lunæ. 
2 Labor Lunæ
A certaine circle about the
moone. 1 Halo, & halos. 
2 Corona, f.
The state of the moone, not yet
come to the halfe compasse.
1 Amphicyrtos.
The space between the new
moone and the olde.
1 Interlunium, intermen­
struum, intermenstrua lunæ.
The moone shining by night.
1 Noctiluca, f.
Like a moone. 1 Lunatus, ad.
Before the moone.
1 Proselenus, ad.
Of, or belonging to the moone.
1 Lunaris, ad.
Belonging to the space between
the old moone, and the new.
1 Intermestris, ad.

yers doe.

firmare fauces, obstruere
fauces lorimentis.

A thing with twigs, & strings
to moozle beasts, that they bite
not young springs.

To make More, or
encrease. 
1 Amplio, exaggero.
To be more then enough.
1 Supersum.
A little more, or somewhat
more. 1 Plusculum, n.
More. 1 Plus, ad.
Somewhat more.
1 Plusculus, ad.
More then enough.
1 Supervacaneus, superva­
cuus, ad. vide superfluous. 
More. 1 Plus, magis, amplius, 
vltra, adu. vt nihil vltra re­
quirunt, they passe for no thing
more.  Vltra, præp. vt vltra pla­
citum, more then liketh. 
Much more.
3 Demagis.
More then enough.
1 Satis superque, adu.
More or lesse.
1 Plus aut minus.
More and more.
1 Impendio, adu.
Moreover.
1 Porro, deinde, deinceps, de­
in, insuper, deinsuper, præte­
rea, adhæc, adhoc, adhuc, 
adde huc, præterquam, præ­
terhæc, quinetiam, propor­
ro, scilicet, adeo, jam, super, 
etiam, itemque, dehinc, am­
plius, adu. vide also.

sum commovere, adduco. 
3 Emolior.
To moue, or wagge, or to moue
often. 1 Iacto, ago, agito.
To moue vnto, or provoke.

cieo, irrito, impello, propello
2 Stimulo, perstimulo, exa­
cuo, moveo, commoveo.

To moue together. 1 Coagito.

To moue with great force.

To moue the mouth.

gito.

Mus agrestis, 
Mus rusticus, ad.
A kinde of mouse called a
shrewe, which if he goe over the
backe of any beast, he shall bee
lame in the chine, & if he bite, 
he swelleth to the heart, and
dieth.

vessell, or such like.

great cheekes.

A mowe.
1 Fœnile, n. fœni acervus.
By mowes.
2 Acervatim, adu.

So much, as more cannot be.

Much, or many.

mus, ad.

3 multissimus, ad.

A nourcerie.
1 Nutricula. Alimoniarium, 
nutriciarium.
A nourcerie, or place, where one­
lie women abide.

Pertaining to nources.
1 Nutricius, ad.

nutrio, Adnutrio, Cibo, Nu­
trico, nutricor, pasco, pabulor,

vp in sustenance, maners, or

Now, even now.

jam dudum, modo, inpræ­
sentiarum, ad præsens, non
ita pridem.

inde, nonumquam, aliquando, 
interdum, identidem, quamdoque

Now at length.
1 Demum, jam demum.
Now hereafter.

Now a daies.

ævo.

benummed.

account. 1 Numero, annu­

ro, dinumero, 2 censeo, percen­
seo, recenseo, recognosco.

2 Censeor.
Numbred.

A numbering.

census, m.

A number or quantitie.

A great number, or companie.

A number found thrise in a­
nother number.
1 Triplaris numerus.
Which is contained in any 
other number twise, thrise, or
many times. 1 Submultiplex
numerus.

blenes. 3 Innumerabilitas, f.
Of, or belonging to number.

putabilis, numerabilis, ad.
In great number.

Of what number. 1 Quotus.
To what number. 1 Quoteni.
More in number.

That cannot be numbred

hensibilis, inexplicabilis, ad.

O ANTE A.

O Is a Vowell
which hath divers signi­
fications, & is found ei­
ther an adverbe of calling, as O
Syre, o Sirus, or an interjection
of sorrowe, as O me perditum,
O wretch that I am.

O, or oh. 
1 Proh, inter.

O alas. 
1 O, Ah, ehu, euhoe, inter.

An Oare of a boate, 
or shippe. 
1 Remus, m. 2 tonsa, arbor, f.
An iron Oare.
1 Strictura, f.
The handle of an Oare.
2 Manubrium, enchiridion, n.
The broadest part, or blade of the
oare.
1 Palmula, tonsa, f.
A round peece of wood, whereat
the oares doe hang by a leather
thong.
1 Scalmus, m.

The Oare, or foile of
brasse, that is so light, that the
winde bloweth it away. 
1 Pompholix, f.

Oates. 
1 Avena, f.
Wilde oates.
1 Festuca, festucago, f.
Oaten meale dried, or fried.
1 Omelysis, f.
An oaten fielde.
1 Avenarium, n.
Oaten meale.
1 Avenacea farina.
He that selleth oaten meale.
1 Avenarius, m.
Oaten. 1 Avenarius, avenaceus

Offices. 1 Munia, orum.

A small office.
1 Munusculum, n.
An officer. 1 Officialis, m.
The office of a Master.
1 Magisterium, n.
A head officer. 1 Magistratus.
Chiefe officers.
1 Magnates, proceres, m.
An officer, having the benefit, 
without doing the thing, belon­
ging to the office.
1 Beneficiarius, m.
A chiefe officer among the Ro­
mans, which for halfe a year had
a kings power, never chosen but
in great daunger, and trouble of
the common wealth, and at the
halfe yeares end, vnder paine of
treason, yealded vp his authority.
1 Dictator, m.
The office of a Dictator.
1 Dictatura, f
Belonging to the office of a dicta­
tor. 1 Dictatorius, ad.
Officers in Rome, being ten no­
ble men appointed among the
Romanes in steede of consuls, to
governe the common wealth
with like authoritie, vntill such
times, as the lawes weare establi­
shed and confirmed among them
which they had chosen, and pic­
ked out of the auncient Greeke
lawes, and made of them the law
of the 12 tables.
1 Decemviri, orum.
The dignitie, and office of the 10
ioint governoures.
1 Decemviratus, m.
The office of Decemprimi.
1 Decemprimatus, m.
Officers in free citties belonging
to Roome,
1 Decemviri, orum.
Officers in Rome, where 20 were
of like authoritie.
1 Vigintiviri, orum.
The office of 20 men of like au­
thoritie.
1 Vigintiviratus, m.
One of the fiue men in like office
among the Romanes.
1 Quinquevir, m.
His office.
1 Quinqueviratus, m.
Fowre men in like office.
1 Quatuorviri.
Their office. 1 quatuorviratus.
Any office, wherein 3 jointly be
ioined together, and be all of like
authoritie.
1 Triumviratus, m.
One of those officers.
1 Triumvir, m.
Of, or belonging to the office wher
3 beare rule.
1 Trium viralis, ad.
Officers in Rome, having Au­
thority over prisons, and iailes, 
as our Judges.
1 Duumviri, orum.
The office of two men of like au­
thoritie.
1 Duumviratus, m.
Pertaining to that office.
1 Duumviralis, ad.
New officers made, and added
to the old, and auncient number
1 Ascriptitij.
An office in Rome, properly
of him that is Pretor.
1 Prætura, f.
An officer which dealeth spoile, 
or the kings gifte among souldi­
ers.
1 Clavarius, m.
Officers constrained to resigne, or
willing to surrender.
1 Abacti, orum.
An officer to be alwaies at com­
maundement.
1 Stator, m.
Officers to attach one of a great
offence.
2 Conquisitores, apud Liv.
An officer attendant on great
magistrates, to summon, and at­
tach. 1 Apparitor, m.
His office. 1 Apparitura, f.
Officers to see good rule kept in
the night. 1 Circitores, m.

1 Delegatio, f.
Of, or belonging to offices.

vatus, ad.

genie.

f. minores, posteri, m. posteri­
tas, 2 propago, f.

1 Primordium, n. origo, f.

Oftnes. 
1 Crebritas, crebritudo, f.
Often. 1 Creber, frequens, as­
siduus, 2 Densus, ad.
Oftentimes. 1 Frequenter, sæ­
pe, sæpius, sæpenumero, per­
sæpe, crebro, creberrime, 
multoties, plerunque, com­
pluries, non raro, 2 Subin, 
subinde, 3 Sæpicule, sepi­
uscule, adu.
Very often. 1 Sæpissime, adu.
So often.
1 Toties, 2 Intotum.
As often as.
1 Quoties, quotiescunque, 
quandoque, adu.


O ANTE I.

of one vessel into another.

Oile. 1 Oleum, 3 clæon, n.

& mirrhe, being cut, or launced, 
called of the Apothecaries sto­
rax liquida.

purge the bellie.

Salet oile.
1 Oleum cibarium.
Oile that naturally runneth out
of a stone.

Oile made of bevers stones vsed
in medicine.
1 Castoreum.
Oile of the whale fish.
1 Oleum balænæ.
Oile wherewith wrestlers were
annointed, and the place where
they were annointed.
1 Ceroma, n.
Annointed with the oile that
wrestlers were wont to be an­
ointed withall.
1 Ceromaticus, ad.
A place where the bodies of them
that were washed, were accusto­
med to bee annointed with the
oile of the annointer.
1 Elæothesium, n.
Oile of the blossome of aples.
1 Melinum.
Oile and vineger mixed toge­
ther.
1 Oxoleon.
Tarte, and sharpe oile.
1 Oleum acerbum.
Sweete, and fresh oile.
1 Oleum viride.
Annointed with sweete oile.
1 Nimbatus, ad.
The leeze, and mother of oile, vi:
dregs, and lees. 
The oile boxe, or glasse.
1 Libæum, n.
A maker, or seller of oiles.
1 Olearius, m.
The place where oiles are kept.
1 Olearium, n.
Oile vessels.
1 Mirobrechi.
He that taketh oile out of a ves­
sell without a ladle.
1 Capulator, m.
Buying of oile.
1 Elæemporia.
The quantitie of oile oliues yeal­
ded at everie pressing.
3 Hostus, m.
Annointed with the oile called
balanon.
1 Balanatus, ad.
Made, or mixt with oile.

Oilie. 1 Oleaceus, oleosus, 
vnguinosus, vnctiusculus, ad.
Perteining to oile.

Chrisis, f Chrisma, n. myro, e­
pichrista, pharma, f.

Aples.
