An ointment made of the ber­
ries of poplars.
1 Aegirinon.
An ointment made of the flow­
er-deluce.
1 Irinum, n.
An ointment made of saffron.
1 Crocinum.
An ointment which wrestlers
vse. 1 Alemon, colema, n.
A kinde of ointment savouring
like a libbard and a Panther.
1 Pardalium.
An excellent kind of ointment
vsed in Rome, and much of wo­
men, and especially of the richer
sorte. 1 Spicatum, n.
A pleasant ointment that wo­
men in Rome vsed.
1 Foliatum, n.
An ointment, or medicine, wher
with hairy places of the body are
made smooth and bald for a time
1 Dropax.
A base ointment which all men
doe vse. 1 Epiligna
A kinde of very base ointment.
1 Epilimna.
A dry ointment.
1 Xeromirum, n.
Sweete ointment.
1 Sardianus, mundus, m. me­
galium, n.
Moist ointments.
3 Hydromyra, orum.
A thinne, and spreading oint­
ment.
1 Synchrisma, n.
A kinde of ointment made for
the health of the body. 1 crimna
Ointment which harlottes vse.
1 Stibium, n.
Ointments made of gold.
1 Auripigmentum, n.
Bitter ointments.
1 Amaracum, n.
An ointment to soften, and
fetch a way scabbes, and hardnes
of the skinne. 1 Ectyloticum.
An ointment to put away 
wrinkles from the face, and to
make it smooth.
1 Vnguentum erugatorium. 
3 Tentipellium, n.
And ointment maker, or seller.

oiles are solde.
1 Seplasium, miropolium, n.
A dry ointing, without washing

Ointed, vide annointed.

Elephante.

To gather Oliues. 
1 Olivo.
An oliue.
1 Olea, oliva, f. 3 oleaginum, n.
Olives, or oile beries betweene
greene and ripe, waxing blacke.
1 Drupæ, f.
A kinde of Oliues to be beaten, 
being round, and like to codde
stones.
1 Orchites.
An oliue roiall, or of the grea­
test sise.
1 Phaulia, f.
Bitter oliues.
1 Picridiæ, f.
A meane to conserue oliues.
1 Epithyrum n.
That which is squized, or strai­
ned out of the white Oliue.
1 Spanum, n.
A kinde of oliues, not ripe be­
fore the sixt Ides of Februarie.
1 Majorina.
Oliues beries condite in pickle, or
brine.
1 Colymbades, halmades.
Oliues ripe, and readie to fall of
the tree.
1 Drypetæ.
Wilde Oliues.
1 Agryclæa, f. agrippum, n.
A long little oliue.
1 Radiolus, m.
Plentie of oliues, or revenewe
comming of oliues.
1 Olivina, f.
A kinde of oliues called also Li­
ciniana.
1 Licinia, f.
The place where oliues growe.
1 Olivarium, olivetum, oletum




The time of getting oliues.
1 Olietas, olivitas, f.
The kernell of oliues.
1 Pyren.
Pertaining to vnripe oliues.
1 Omphacinus, ad.
Which beareth, and bringeth
foorth oliues.
1 Olifer, ad.

pen a doore, or such like.

duro.
To open, or vnbuckle.

vide disclose.

nifest. 2 Propalo, manifesto.
To open, or shewe foorth.

To open that which was stop­
ped. 1 Relino.
To open that which is sealed.
1 Resigno.
To open that which is shut.

or such like. 1 Expando, pan­
dere se, hiaso, dehisco, patulico
2 Discedo.
To begin to open. 1 Patesco.
To open, as a beane doeth, or any
like huske when is springeth.

rent. 1 Pateo, patesio.
Opened. 1 Pansus, passus, expas­

1 Series, f.
Belonging to order. 1 Ordinalis.
Contrarie to an order common­
ly vsed.
1 Extraordinatius, ad.
Without order.
1 Indigestus, indirectus, in­
compositus, Irregularis, ad.
Of what order.
1 Quotus, ad.
Orderly, or in good order.
1 Disposite, composite, ordi­
natè, ius, ordinatim, Ordine, 
abl. exordine, exdisposito, ex­
composito, inversum, 3 confor­
miter, adu.
Not orderly.
1 Incomposite, adu.
In an order.
1 Circumscripte, adu.
By order, or consequently.
1 Consequenter, adu.

Ordinarie, or that
chaungeth not. 
1 Statutus, status, p. vt dies, 
vel reditus stati.
Ordinarie, or vsuall.
1 Vsitatus, ordinarius, 2 Quo­
tidianus, frequens, solennis.
Ordinarily.
1 Vsitate, 2 Assidue, adu.

Ordure, or doung of
man, or beast. 
1 Fimum, n. fimus, m. Merda, 
Subluvies, 2 Alyus, f. excre­
mentum, Retrimentum, E­
gestum, n.
The carying out, or avoiding of
ordure, or doung.
1 Ejectio, f. egestus, m.
Ordure, or filth washed from any
thing.
1 Proluvies, f. Proluvium, n.
The ordure of the eares.
1 Cerumen, n.
The ordure of a shippe drawen
out at the pompe.
1 Nautea, f.
Ordure of stincking water.
1 Illuvies, f. vide Filth.

pum, n.

1 Originatio, f.
Originall, or the first.

migenius, ad.




Of one original, or beginning.
1 Conjugata.
Originally.

An Ornament. 
1 Ornamentum. 
2 Lumen, n. lux, f color, cul­
tus, m. vt cultus animi, the or­
nament of the minde. 
Ornaments of the heade.
1 Canautæ, f.
An ornament of the head, that
maketh ruffling.
1 Crepitulum, n.
An ornamente for womens
heads, or neckes.
1 Redimiculum, n.
A white ornament four square
and long, which the Vestall
virgines did weare vpon their
heades.
1 Subfibulum, n.
An ornament with great and
pretious stones, to weare about
the necke.
1 Viria, viriola, f.
A kinde of ornaments for
the armes.
1 Dardanium, n.
An ornament that gentlemen, 
and men of armes vsed in
Rome.
1 Phalera, f.
Ornamentes of gates, and
doores.
1 Antipagmenta, n.
Ornamentes of artes.
2 Chromata, n.
An ornament of Rhetoricke.
2 Flosculus, m.
An ornament, or figure, special­
ly in speach.
1 Schema, n.

fatherlesse.

the manner of true

P ANTE A.

To goe with a 
softe PACE. 
1 Suspenso graduire.
A pace going.
1 Passus, gradus, m.
A pace, or measure in dancing.
1 Staticulus, m.
A swifte pace.
1 Citatus gradus.
A short, and thicke pace, like a
pismire.
2 Gradus formicinus.
A long striding pace, as it were
vpon stilies.
2 Gradus gallatorius.
A slowe pace.
Gradus testitudineus. 
Gradus lentus.
With a slowe pace.
1 Suspenso gradu.
A pace, or rather a steppe, con­
tayning two foote and a halfe, 
which is vsually the distance
from the toes of the fore foote, to
the heele of the hinder foote.
1 Passus minor. 
Passus simplex.
A pace of 5 feete, containing
2 steppes, and by this pace, bee
miles measured.
1 Passus major, vel geome­
tricus.

To be Pacient,
vide
quiet
To waxe pacient. 2 Deferveo, deferbuo, de­
fervesco.
To be out of pacience.
1 Indignor, vide to be angry. 
To suffer paciently.
1 Æquo animo ferre.
Long pacience.
1 Longanimitas, f.
Pacience, or quiet moderation
of the minde.
1 Æquanimitas, animi æqui­
tas.
Pacience. 1 Patientia, 2 Cle­
mentia, tolerantia, toleratio, 
f. silentium, n.
Patient, or hee that taketh all
thinges quietly.
1 Patiens, 2 Mitis, tolerans, 
clemens, tractabilis, sedatus, 
placidus, pacatus, tacens, 
tacitus, ad.
Of a pacient, and milde minde: 
hee that is neither extolled in
prosperitie, neither discomfor­
ted in adversitie.
1 Æquanimis, æquanimus, 
animæquus, ad.
Pacient, that suffereth long.
1 Longanimus, ad.
That maketh pacient.
1 Pacisicus, ad.
Paciently. 1 Patienter, longa­
nimiter, placate, æquanimi­
ter, 2 Clementer, leniter, qui­
ete, mite, molliter, lente, pla­
cide, moderate, modice, hu­
mane, sedate, to leranter, for­
titer, silentio, tranquille, tran­
quillo, constanter, 3 tranquil­
lamente. 3 Tolerabiliter, adu

pease. 1 Place, mitigo, vnifico.

To be pacified.
2 Mollesco, delenior.

pitiatus. 2 Mitigatus, deleni­

swaged.

peased.

tor. 2 Propitiator. m.

charge. 1 Solvo, luo, pendo, de­
pendo, Diribeo. 2 Numero, 
annumero, satisfacio, reddo.

remunero, refundo.

appointed.
2 Ad diem respondeo.
To paie before the day.
2 Prærogo, repræsento.
To paie ready money downe.
1 Denumero, 2 Repræsento.
To paie, or discharge severall
debtes. 1 Dissolvo.
To pay costes, and damages.
3 Sarcito.
To pay often. 1 Pensito. 3 luto.
They pay. 1 Penditur, impers
To take some thing in ful paie­




ment, or in part of that which
is dewe.
1 In solutum accipere. 
In solutum cedere.
Paide. 1 Solutus, ior, issi­
mus, impensus, 2 numeratus.
Paide againe. 1 repensus, p.
Not paide. 1 Insolutus, ad.
A paying, or paiment of debts.
1 Solutio, 2 numeratio, præ­
statio, satisfactio, f.
A paying of mony in hande.
1 Denumeratio, 2 repræsen­
tatio, fœm.
The paiment, or that which is
paide for. 1 Pensa, f.
A paiment, pension, or yeerlye
fee. 1 Pensio, f. stipendium, n.
A full and perfect paiment.
1 Exsolutio, f.
A souldiers paye, or wages.
1 Stipendium, n.
A little paiment.
1 Pensiuncula, f.
Paiment of debt before the daie.
2 Prærogatio, f.
A present paiment.
1 Numerata pecunia.
A paie-master, or distributer
of money.
1 Distributor, masc. 
Diribitor, masc. 
3 Mercedonius, masc.
Paiers of pension, rent, reve­
new, or tribute.
1 Vectigales viri.

A Paile to cary wa­
ter in. 
1 Situla, vide bucket. 
A milking paile.
1 Mulctra, f. mulctrum, mul­
ctrale, n.

To cause one to
haue Paine. 
3 Doloro, vid. grieue. 
To be in paine, or to hee verie
sicke.
1 Condoleo, 2 laboro.
Being in paine.
2 Dolens, part.
Pained, vide grieved. 
A paine in the heade of long
continuance.
1 Cephalæa, f.
Paine in the guttes.
1 Cordapsus, m.
Paine, or griefe.
1 Dolor, cruciatus, m. pæna
molestia, afflictio, afflictatio, 
f. 2 supplicium, n. 3 cruciabi­
litas, f. vide punishment, and
griefe. 
Painefull, or full of paine.
1 Ærumnatus, p. ærumno­
sus, ad. ærumnis plenus, 2
gravis, ior, issimus, laborio­
sus, 3 ærumnabilis, cruciabi­
lis, ad. vide grievous. 
Wherein is great paine, and
labour.
1 Ærumnalis, ad.
To take much paines, toile, and
labour in any thing.
1 Laboro, elaboro, 
Suscipio laborem. 
Impendo laborem.. 
Dependo laborem. 
2 sudo, insudo, vigilo, advigi­
lo, evigilo, vide labour. 
With paine to put, or remooue
awaie.
1 Amolior.
A putting awaie with paine.
1 Amolitio, f.
Taking paines.
1 Elaborans, p.
That one hath taken much
paines to worke it cunningly.
2 Sudatus, p.
Painefulnesse.
1 Opera, operositas, 2 diffi­
cultas, 3 laboriositas, f.
Paines taking.
3 Nictelamen, n.
Little paines.
1 Operula, opella, f.
Painefull.
1 Laboriosus, 2 indefessus, ad.
Painfully by night.
3 Noctanter, adu.
Painfully, vide laboriously.

To Painte. 
1 Pingo, appingo, depingo, 
expingo, 2 tingo, lino, fuco, 
infuco, describo, 3 picto, de­
picto.
To paint, or polishe anew, where
olde painting hath beene.
2 Interpolo.
To painte againe.
1 Repingo.
To painte the face ruddye, as
harlots doe.
1 Purpurisso.
To painte often.
3 Depictito.
To painte with the finger.
3 Digito.
To paint, or colour with vermi­
lion. 1 Minio, as.
To painte, or trimme vp faire.
1 Mangonizo.
Painted.
1 Pictus, depictus, colora­
tus, 2 fucatus, p. fucosus, ad.
Painted out, or liuely drawen.
1 Expictus, 3 expinctus, par. 
iconicus, ad.
Painted in diverse parts.
1 Perpictus, 2 interstinctus, p
Halfe painted.
1 Semipictus, p.
Painted, or trimmed vppe to
make it seeme the fairer.
1 Mangonizatus, pigmenta­
tus, part.
A painter.
1 Pictor, 3 expinctor, ana­
glypharius, m.
A painter, which painteth, or
writeth with vermilion, or any
red colour. 1 Miniator, mi­
niographus, m.
Painters, or polishers of olde
wares.
1 Mangones, m.
A painter of trifles, or base
thinges.
1 Rhyparographus, m.
Painters, that painte with
Ivorie.
3 Elephantozographi, m.
A painter of beastes.
1 Zoographus, m.
A painting. 1 Depictio, pi­
ctura, 2 fucus, m. 3 graphice.
Painting, or writing with ver­
milion. 1 Miniatio, minio­
graphia, f.
A painting, or polishing of old
thinges. 1 Mangonium, n.
Pertaining to the painter, or
setter forth of such thinges.
1 Mangonicus, ad.
A woorke cunningly painted, 
so that it seemed to be embossed
out, and graven in some place.
1 Museacum, neut.
He that painteth such workes.




1 Musearius, m.
As it were a painted girdle, or
border, wherein are diverse
thinges graven.
Zophorus, m.
Painting that women vse.

1 Cerussatus, p.
Red painting, where with har­
lots painte their faces.

A maker, or seller of painting
for women.

Painting, drawing, or first sha­
dowing of a thing.
2 Vmbra, 3 semipictatio, f.
A kind of painting, when many

of diverse colours are fitly sette
vpon chestes, or playing tables.

To Part, or separate
1 Abjungo, vide to diuide. 
To part, or distribute 1 Com­
munico, impertio, partior, 
distribuo, elargior.
To part often. 1 Partito.
To part, or diuide with bounds, 
or limits. 1 Collimito.
To part, or make partition, as
between coheirs. 1 Ercisceor, hercisceor
To part in the middest.
1 Dimidio, 2 intercido.
To take part, or participate.
1 Participo, communico.
To be parted. 1 Distribuor, 
dispertior.
To take in good part.
1 Boni consulere.
To take ones part.
1 A causa alicujus stare.
I thought it my part.
2 Videbatur, visum est, imp.
Parted, or divided. 1 Discretus
2 Diremptus, descriptus perscis­
sus, digestus, sectus, dissectus, 
desectus, discissus, segregatus
That hath parted. 1 Partitus, p
Parted in two parts. 1 Biparti­
tus, bipertitus, p. 2 Bisidus
Parted into three parts.
1 Tripartitus, p. 2 trifidus, ad.
Parted into 4. parts. 1 Qua­
dripartitus, p. 2 quadrifidus.
Parted into many parts.
1 Multificus, ad.
That is, or maie be parted.
1 Dividuus, ad.
A parter, or divider. 1 Parti­
tor, distributor, divisor, m.
He that conferreth, or laieth
like part with other. 1 Collator
A parting, partition, or divi­
ding. 1 Dividuitas, prosectio, 
partitio, distributio, disjun­
ctio, divisio, f. dividuum, disci­
dium, dividium, n. 2 Sectio, 
scissura, f. segmentum, n.
A partition, as in a wal-nut, 
or like thing. 1 Dissepimentum.
A part, or portion.
1 Pars, portio, 2 Sors, f.
A little part, or portion.
1 Portiuncula, particula, f.
A part of the body. 1 Membrum
A part of people divided into
three parts. 1 Tribus, f.
When part is vnderstood by the
whole, or the whole by part.
1 Synecdoche, f.
The fourth part of a daies work.
1 Quadrans operæ.
Of two parts. 1 Bimembris.
Of three parts. 1 Trimembris.
Of 4 parts. 1 Quadrimembris.
Parted among the strong men.
1 Viritanus, vt viritanus ager.
That cannot be parted.
2 Insecabilis, ad.
By parts, peeces, or parcels.
1 Partim, particulatim, mem­
bratim, distribute, distribu­
tim 2 Carptim, adu.
For the most part. 1 Magna ex
parte, Plerumque, fere, quam­
plurimum, adu.
In part, or partly. 1 Parte, abl
ex parte, in parte, partim, 
partite, adu.
In two parts. 1 Bipartito, 
bipertito, adu.
In some part. 1 Aliquatenus, 
quadantenus, adu.
On the other part.
1 In adversum.
What part soever.
1 Quaqua, quoquo, adu.
On both parts. 1 Vtrinque, 
vltro citroque, adu.
Of al parts. 2 Circum, adu.
Apart, or asunder. 1 sequestro.
Divided in partes. 1 Divise, 
partite, distribute, adu.
In 4. parts. 1 Quadripartito.

Partialitie. 
1 Iniquitas, 2 Injuria, f.
Partial, not indifferent, or iust.
1 Iniquus, ad. vt judex ini­
quus, a partial iudge.

1 Particularis, specificus. 2
Proprius, privatus, præcipuus

particulariter, sigillatim, sin­
gulatim, speciatim, specifice
specialiter, 2 Calculatim, de­
finite, separatim, private, pri­
vatim, nominatim, adu.

To Passe, excelle, or
surmount, v. excel, and exceed. 
To passe by. 1 Præ ereo, præter
gredior, prætermeo, lego
2 Præterfluo, prægredior, 
prætervolo, præterveho, 
perveho.
To passe over, or goe beyonde.
1 Transeo, pertranseo trans­
meo, transgredior, permeo, 
2 Metiro, permetior, penetro
præterlabor, trajicio, transi­
lio, transcurro, trano, transno, 
transmitto. 3 Travio.
To passe over quickly. 2 Trans­
volo, transcurro, carpo.
To passe bounds. 1 Excedo.
To passe over negligently.
2 Varico, varicor.
To pas over the sea. 1 transfreto
To let passe, or passe over.




1 Omitto, missum facio. 2
prætermitto, præterveho, 
præteo, 3 præterito.
To passe, as to passe his life.
1 Dego, transigo, traduco.
To passe to. 1 Proficiscor.
To passe before. 1 Prævio, 
2 prælabor, præmetior.
To passe through, or into.
1 Pervado, permeo, per­
transeo, permano, 2 penetro.
To passe over, or vpon.
1 Supervado.
To passe away. 2 Labor, effluo.
To passe, or flowe over, or
through. 1 Transfluo.
To passe without damage.
1 Evado.
To passe awaie swiftly.
2 Curro, volo.
To passe forth.  Produco.
To passe through often.
2 Percurso.
To passe over.
1 Decurro, procurro.
To passe from one place to ano­
ther. 1 Migro, commigro.
To passe between. 1 Intercedo
To bring to passe, vide bring. 
It is passed over, or they passe
over. 2 Percurritur, decurritur
It is past. 1 Abijt, præterijt.
To come to passe.
1 Evenio, succedo, 2 fio.
I passe not. 1 Nihilifacio, 
floccifacio, floccipendo.
Let passe. 2 Supersede.
Passe forth, go to, tell one
2 Perge, procede.
It is past remedie.
2 Conclamatum est.
Passed over. 1 Exactus, trans­
actus, transitus, peractus, 2
decursus, mensus, emensus, 
præmensus, part.
Let passe for a time.
1 Intermissus, p.
That is gone and past, or passed
by. 1 Præteritus, egressus, 2
effluxus, præterlapsus, p.
That hath passed over. 1 Pro­
gressus, transgressus, p.
Passed over with out regard, 
or accounte 2 Posthabitus, p.
Passed, or ended long agone.
1 Anteactus, transactus, p.
Passed, or escaped.
2 Exhaustus, p.
Passed through often.
2 Percursus, p.
Passed over, as the time is
passed. 2 Traductus, p.
That is to be let passe.
1 Prætereundus, p.
A passing, or going over.
1 Transgressus, transitus, m. 
transgressio, transitio, f. 2 trans­
cursus, trajectus, m. traje­
ctio, traductio, f.
A passing, or passage.
1 Transitus, transmissus, me­

through.

iourney. 1 Migratio, f.

A passing over the sea.

stones, as marble, or such like

A pauement, or floore.

of bricke, or tyle, set side to side,

and chimnies.

Pauements. 1 Delapidata.
A pauement of bordes.

stratum, neut.
A pauement made with square
stones checkerwise.

vel tesseratum

and coloures.

A Pensioner in the
court. 1 Doryphorus, m.
A pension, or paiment
1 Pensio, f. vectigal, n.
A smal pension 1 pensiuncula
An yearly pension. 1 Annuum
A pension for one moneth.
1 Menstruum, n.
A pension of the 20. part of
ones revenues.
1 Vigesima, vicesima, f.
Belonging to that pension, or re­
ceived of that pension.
1 Vigesimarius, vicesimarius
A certain pension that the Ro­
manes paide for their houses.
1 Colonarium, n.
A certain pension paid by way
of exemption, to liue out of com­
mon affaires, or businesse.
1 Solarium, n.
He that paieth, or is bound to
pay a pension to one.
1 Pensionarius, m. vectigalis

People which goe with their

To Perceaue, or see. 
1 Video, cerno, concerno, 
Conspicor, perspicio, aspicio
pervideo.
To perceaue, or vnderstand.
1 Percipio, intelligo, nosco, 
cognosco, recognosco, ani­
madverto, adverto, noto, 
sentio, calleo, 2 Teneo, video
accipio, invenio, reperio, com­
prehendo, sapio, degusto, 
comperio, audio, odoror, ol­
facio, colligo, v. vnderstand. 
To perceaue and vnderstand
wel and throughly.
1 Persentio, persentisco.
To perceaue by inquiry, or exa­
mination. 2 Deprehendo.
To perceaue, or vnderstand be­
fore hand. 1 Præsentio, præ­
sentisco.
To perceaue somewhat, or to
haue some inckling in a matter
1 Subsentio, sentisco, recog­
nosco, 2 Subaudio, suboleo, 
subodoror.
To perceaue quickly, or sharply
or to be quick of sight. 3 Sagio
It is perceaved. 1 Cernitur.
Men perceaue, and vnderstand.
1 Intelligitur, impers.
You may perceaue, or see. 1 Vide
re est, cernere est, videas.
Perceaved or seen.
1 Visus, perspectus, p.
Perceaved, known, or vnderstood
1 Perceptus, intellectus, cog­
nitus, animadversus, explo­
ratus, vide vnderstood.

hand. 1 Præscius, ad.
That perceiveth things before
they come. 1 Præsagus, ad.
Perceaved before it come.

A Pillar. 
1 Columna, f. 2 Fulcrum, ful­
cimen, fulcimentum, firmamentum.

2 Stylus.
A little pillar set on a greater.
1 Epistylium, n.
A chiefe pillar, or buttresse.
1 Anteris, erismæ, arum, f.
Chiefe pillars. 1 Antes.
A square, or flat sided pillar.
1 Stela, pila, f.
The foot of a pillar that systai­
neth any thing. 1 Basis, f.
The place between two pillars.
1 Intercolumnium, n.
The body of a pillar between the
chapiter, and the base. scapus. 
The nether part of a pillars foote
bearing the forme of 4 square tile
stone. 1 Plinthus, m.
The blunter part of a pillar in
the very toppe, like a goats nose.
1 Sima, f
Those parts in furrowed pillars
which stand vp higher then the
furrows, or gutters.
1 Striæ, arum f.
The foote stall of a pillar.
1 Stylobata, stylobates, f.
Hercules pillars. 2 Gades.
A part of a pillar, wheron an
arch standeth especially.
1 Incumba, f.
A place set about with pillars.
1 Circumcolumnium, n.
A certain pillar in Rome, wher
vnto fugitiue servants & theeues
were bound. 1 Monia, f.
A kind of pillars so graven, that
the carved worke resembleth the
rowling waues. 1 Cymatium, n.
Wher as is but one pillar. 3 mo­
nostylon.
The making small of pillars to
wards the toppe. 1 Contractura
The part of the chapiter of a pillar
which is cut, and graven like 
teeth 2 Denticulus, m.
Building or proping with pillars.
1 Columnatio, f.
One pillar by an other. 1 Pilatim

To Place. 1 Loco, colloco
statuo, constituo, pono, 2 Ex­
truo, Describo.
To place fitly. 1 Apto.
To place, or set behinde.
1 Posthabito.
To choose in ons place. 2 subgero
To giue place. 1 Cedo, decedo.
Placed or set. 1 Locatus, collo­
catus, situs, positus, p.
Placed between.




2 Interjectus, p.
Placed by measure, and featlie
set in order.
2 Descriptus, p.
A place. 1 Locus, 2 Sedes, f.
A little place. 1 Loculus, m.
A sunnie place, or place which
is open to the sunne.
1 Locus apricus.
A place in Rome where the peo­
ple sate, and beheld the plaies &
games, which were called Cir­
censes. 1 Circus, m.
A great place in a cittie, voide
of houses, where marchantes re­
sorte. 1 Area, f.
A little resting place.
1 Statiuncula, f.
A place dedicated to praier.
1 Oratorium, n. delubrum re­
ligiosum.
A place vnder the hil Palatine, 
dedicated by Arcadius to the
God Pan, who kept the wolues
from the sheepe. 1 Lupercal, n.
Pleasant places goodlie to behold
1 Amœna, n.
Places which are cold in sommer
whither beastes doe withdrawe
themselues for heate. also a place
for souldiers to rest in the sum­
mer. 1 Æstiva, n.
Places that cannot be passed by.
1 Avia, n.
A place where the head is polled, 
and the nailes pared, after ba­
thing. 1 Curiceum, n.
The place where the fish Scylla
is taken. 1 Scylletum, n.
A place betweene the stage and
common seates, where many Se­
natours, and noble personages
sate to behold plaies, and open
games. 1 Orchestra, f.
A place where accusers, witnes­
ses, or the accused persons did sit.
2 Subsellium, subsellia, plu n.
A place without Rome, where
were certaine hote waters, in
which they vsed to washe and
bathe. 1 Lautulæ, lautolæ, f.
A place of pleasure, where Poets
supposed dead mens souls to dwel.
1 Elysium, n. elvsij campi.
A place where Remus did hono­
rably, enterprise the building of
the cittie. 1 Remurus locus.
A place, or land almost enviro­
ned with water on every side.
1 Peninsula, f.
A place by a bath, where men
put their garments.
1 Apodyterium, n.
A place where spoilers are taken
1 Spoliatorium, n.
A place of assemblie, as a con­
vocation, or parliment.
1 Comitium, n.
A place of beholding, or looking
about. 1 Spectaculum, n.
A place to receiue, and keepe
thinges safely in.
1 Receptaculum, n.
A place of execution.
1 Carnificina, f. locus, capi­
talis.
A place of hearkening, or to
heare. 1 Auditorium, n.
A place, or seate of judgement.
1 Tribunal, n.
A place of refuge. 1 Perfugium
refugium, profugium, n.
A place onlie for women.
1 Gynæceum, n.
A place, steede, or roome. 1 Vicis
A place, seate, or throne of estate
1 Solium, n.
A place set with pillars.
1 Circumcolumnium, n.
A place to keepe spices in.
1 Narthecium, n.
A place to keepe birdes, beastes, 
fowles, fishes, or such like.
1 Vivaritim, n.
A place covered where men sate
to talke for recreation, or plea­
sure. 1 Præstega, f.
A place to sup in. 1 Cœnaculum
A place to walke in.
1 Ambulatorium, ambulacrum, 
deambulatorium, n.
A place vnder the ground, arch­
ed over the head.
1 Hypogæum, n.
A place where they burned dead
bodies. 1 Bustum, n.
A place where horses run for
wagers. 1 Catadromus, m.
A place wherein water is cast.
1 Aquiriola, f.
A place where two streames
meete. 1 Confluens, m.
A place ordained for minstrels, 
or singers, to play, or sing in.
1 Odeum, n.
A place wherin men liue in com­
mon. 2 Cænobium, n.
A place wherin negromancers
do call vp spirites.
1 Psychomantium, n.
A place where recordes, or wri­
tinges be laide.
1 Grammatophylatium, n.

may come.
3 Aornos.
A place where three waies meet
1 Trivium, n.
A place where foure waies meet
1 Quadrivium, quadruvium, n
A place to set young plantes in.
1 Seminarium, n.
A place in a house, where seats, 
or formes are orderly disposed
on every side.
1 Sellaria, f.
Places broken, where one can nei­
ther go vp, nor downe.
1 Loca 1 Prærupta, 
Loca Abrupta, 
Loca 2 Abscissa.

tentes are.

present. 2 Ago.

meridianus, m.
A plaier with a long swoord.
1 Ludio, ludius, m.
A plaie, sport, or pastime.
1 Lusus, ludus, m. lusio, f. ludi­
crum, n.
A little plaie.
1 Ludulus, m.
A plaie, or enterlude.
2 Ludicrum, n.
A plaie, or pageant.
2 Spectaculum, n.
Publique plaies.
2 Ludi, orum.
A place where plaiers make them
ready 1 Scena, f.
The plaie called one penny.
1 Basilinda, f.
A kinde of plaie, called clout
clout to beare about, or my hen
hath laid.
1 Schænophilanda.
Plaies, or games set out by the
Romanes, in the honour of Bac­
chus.
1 Honoraria, honorarij ludi.
Plaies in the honour of Sibyll.
1 Megalesia, megalensia, n.
Plaies instituted to the honour of
Flora. 1 Floralia, orum.
A kind of plaie, called sun and
moone.
1 Dielcystinda.
Plaies made in the honour of
Consus, who was thought to be the
God of counsell.
1 Consualia, orum, n.
Solemne plaies, or sacrifices, de­
dicatde to Pan.
1 Lupercalia, orum, n.
A plaie vsed in Italie, which is
called in France and Spaine, the
plaie of loue.
1 Digitis micare.
A kinde of plaie vsed among
children, called hollowe, or flatie, 
lice, or nittes, night, or day, which
plaie is not now in vse, but maye
be taken for crosse, and pile, as al
so for winter, and summer.
1 Ostracites, ostracinda.




The plaie called king by your
leaue, or the olde shewe.
1 Apodidrascinda, f.
Money given to see plaies.
1 Lucar.
The plaie called handie dandie.
1 Arteres.
Plaies exercised of men naked, 
and annointed.
1 Ludi gymnici.
A kinde of plaie, called a ducke
and a drake, and a halfe pennie
cake. 3 Epostracismus, m.
The plaie called selling of peares
or how manie plums for a penny
1 Chytrinda, f.
A kinde of plaie, wherein boyes
driue a stake into moyst, or softe
earth, and standing on foote, en­
deuour to overthrowe, and lay
along with throwing something
thereat. 1 Cindalismus, f.
He that setteth out the fight of
sword plaiers, or other like games
to the people. 1 Munerarius.
The space betweene plaies.
1 Diludia.
A plaie called draughts.
1 Scruporum duodecim lusus. 
vide games. 
Plaies for young men.
1 Iuvenilia, n.
Plaies vpon scaffoldes.
1 Amphitheatrales ludi.
Plaiers apparell. 1 Choragi­
um, n. vestes personatæ.
A playing place. 1 Lusorium, n
Pertaining to plaiers.
1 Histricus, histrionalis, ad.
Pertaining to plaies. 1 Ludi­
crus, lusorius, ludicer, adu.
Belonging to sword playing.
1 Gladiatorius, ad.

sicke. 1 Splenium, n.

P ANTE O.

Poares, or little holes
of the body, through which sweat
and other excrements doe issue. 
1 Pori, m. cuticulares meatus. 
2 caulæ, f. invisibilia foramina
Things that maybe avoided by
poares. 1 Halituosa, n.
Full of poares. 1 Porosus, ad.

vide Egge.

canker. fretting the skin, and ea­

ta, ecthymata, n. pustulæ, varæ, 
f. vari, m.

lues venerea, morbus gallicus

1 Mentigo, f.

a poet, one that writeth of divers

sista, m.

etissa, f.

Poesis, musæ, f.

2 Carmen, n. 
Numerosus Sermo. 
Astrictus Sermo. 
Ligatus Sermo.
A base kinde of poetrie, which en­
deth troublesome matters merily
1 Dramaticum, n. dramaticus
stylus.
A nipping kinde of poetrie, rebu­
king vices sharpely, and not regar­
ding persons. 1 Saryta, f.
Of, or belonging to such poesies, 
or satires, or hee that vseth such
poetrie. 1 Satyricus, satyrus, ad.
Poeticall. 1 Poeticus, ad.
that maketh a poet. 1 Poetificus
That hath long vsed poetrie.
1 Poemeneus, ad.
Belonging to poemes.
1 Poematicus, ad.
Poetically. 1 Portice, adu.

A Poinado. 1 Pugiunoulus.

To Point at. 2 Monstro. 
Demonstro, ostendo.
To point at with the finger.
1 Indigito.
Pointed at. 2 Monstratus, p.

To Point, or make sharpe at
the point. 1 Cuspido, spiculo.




To be pointed sharp. 1 mucronor
Pointed, or having a point.
1 Cuspidatus, mucronatus, 
acuminatus, p.
Pointed with iron. 3 præferratus
The point of a weapon.
1 Cuspis, acies, f. spiculum, n.
A little point. 1 Apiculus, m.
The point of a weapon, or sharpe
top of hearbes, or any thing els.
1 Mucro, m.
That hath three pointes.
1 Tricuspis, ad.
Pointwise. 1 Cuspidatim, adu.

To Pointe. 
1 Puncto, articulo.
Distinguished with pointes.
1 Distinctus, interpunctus, p.
A point, or tittle. 1 Punctum, in­
terpunctum, n Punctus, articu­
lus, m. interpunctio, f.
A distinction by pointes.
1 Interpunctio, f. interpunctum.
The verie point of time.
1 Articulus, m.
The point in the part of a sen­
tence without perfect sence.
1 Comma, n. 2 Incisio f.
The point in the middest of anie
round thing. 1 Centrum, n.
That which is pointed, or set in
the middest.
1 Centralis, ad.
A terme in cosmographie, signi­
fiyng the point of the firmament
directly over ones head, whereso­
ever he be. 1 Zenith.
A point, or marke.
1 Stigmatias, f.
At the point of. 1 Sub, præp.

The principal Point, 
or state among oratours, wherein
the controversie consisteth. 
1 Status, m. constitutio, f.
The chiefe, or principall point of
a matter. 1 Summa, f. 2 Caput, 
n. cardo, dub g.
The principall pointe, or founda­
tion of a cause, or matter.
1 Firmamentum, n.
A point, or issue.
 Locus, m. vt in eum locum
res redijt the matter is come to
that point, or passe. 
To this point, or passe.
 Huc, eo, adu.

A Point in the tables
2 Statio, f. locus, m.
The ace point.
1 Monas, 2 statio prima.
The dewce point.
1 Dyas, 2 statio secunda.
The treye point.
1 Ternio, 2 statio tertia.
The cater point.
1 Quaternio, 2 statio quarta.
The Cinque point.
1 Pentas, 2 statio quinta.
The sise point.
1 Senio, 2 statio sexta.

To make Pointes. 
1 Corrigio.
Pointed, or tied with pointes.
1 Ligulatus, p.
A trussing point.
1 Ligula, f. strigmentum, astri­
gmentum, n. corrigia, f.
Pointes of cheverell.
1 Ligulæ hædinæ.
A pointe-maker. 1 Corrigi­
arius. 2 Fibularius, m.
Pertaining to pointes.
1 Corrigialis, ad.

To Poise, vi: weigh.

To Poison. 
1 Conveneno, intoxico, vene­
no. Toxicor, venifico.
Poisoned 1 Venenatus, intoxi­
catus, veneno infectus, toxi­
catus, p.
A poisoner, he, or shee.
1 Intoxicator, m. trix, f. vene­
ficus. 2 Venefex, m.
A seller of poison. 1 venenarius
Poison. 1 Venenum, toxicum, 
virus, 2 aconitum, n. tabes, con­
tages, f.
A kinde of poison, wherewith
hunters killed wolues, being in
bones couered with rawe fleshe.
1 Lycoctonon, n.
A poison vsed to anoint arowes
to shoote at hartes.
1 Cervarium venenum.
The arte, or craft of poisoning.
1 Veneficium, n.
Poisonous, or full of poison.
1 Venenosus, virosus, virulen­
tus. 2 Contagiosus, tabificus, 
fœdus, ad.

A Poitrell, v: peitrell.

A Poke, or bagge. 
1 Pera, funda, f. sacculus, m.

A Polcate. 1 Martes, ictis.

A Pole to measure
land with. 1 Pertica, f. vide
perche.
A long pole to gage water with.
1 Contus, m.
A rowe pole, wherewith a vessell
sticking fast in the shallow, is re­
mooved: a rowing pole.
1 Trudes, f. contus, m.
A pole, or long staffe, called a 
speare staffe.
1 Hastile, n. hasta, hastula, f.
a pole to draw water out of a wel
1 Telon, telones, m.
A pole having an hooke of iron.
1 Harpax, m.
A pole, or thwarte peece laied
crosse way. 1 Longurius, m.
The pole ende, or point of the ax­
ell-tree, where on Astronomers
imagine heaven to be mooved.
1 Polus, m.
The pole Articke.
1 Polus articus, polus septen­
trionalis. 2 axis, f. sydus sublime
The pole antarticke, or south pole
1 Polus antarticus.
The poles of the worlde.
2 Cardines mun n.
Measuring poles, vide pearches.
Belonging to poles. 1 Perticalis.

To Pole, notte, or
play the barber. 1 Tondeo, de­
tondeo. 2 deseco, reseco, re­
cido.
To pole neere. 1 Attondeo.
Poled. 1 Tonsus, detonsus, at­
tonsus, circumtonsus, p.
Not poled. 1 Indetonsus, ad.
A poling, or rounding.
1 Tonsura, f.
Pol money gathered by the heade
of the people. 1 Capitecensus.

To Pole, pill, or plaie
the extortioner. 1 Compilo, 
expilo. 2 Arrudo, exhaurio, 
exigo.

To Pole, and pill for
monie. 2 Emungo, eviscero, ex­
osso, excarnifico, exentero.
Poled, or pilled. 1 Compilatus
expilatus. 2 Exhaustus, p.
A poler, or piller.
1 Expilator. 2 exactor, m.
Poling, or pilling.
1 Compilatio, expilatio, rapa­
citas. 2 Exactio, f.




Somewhat poling. 2 mordaculus

Policie in governing
a common wealth. 1 Politia, f.
Pollicie, or counsell. 1 consilium
A policy, or witty shift in warre
1 Stratagema, n.
Politique. 1 Politicus, 2 faber.

To Polish. 
1 Polio, expolio, depolio, per­
polio, excolo, percolo, mango­
nizo, interpolo, edolo, colo, 2
pumico, expumico. limo, eli­
mo, lenio, lævigo, complano, 
adlævo, condecoro, interrado
orno, mulceo, oblimo, torno, 
pecto.
To polishe a new, or againe.
1 Repolio, recoquo.
Polished. 1 Politus, expolitus, 
perpolitus, depolitus, percul­
tus, mangonizatus, p. interpo­
lis, ad: 2 ornatus, extersus, li­
matus, elimatus, pumicatus, 
pectitus, elucubratus, p. inter­
rasilis, elegans, lævis, ad.
Somewhat polished. 1 limatulus.
Very well polished.
1 Expolitissimus, ad.
Polished with sundry coloures.
1 Variegatus, p.
Not polished. 1 Impolitus, 2
inelegans, ad.
A polisher. 1 Interpolator, e­
limator, m. trix, f.
A polisher of olde wares, to make
them seeme fresh, & new. 1 mango
A polishing. 1 Politio, expoli­
tio, interpolitio, perpolitio, 
politura, 2 pumicatio, lævitas
f. lepos, m.
a polishing, or trimming of wares
1 Mangonium, n.
The last polishing, being newly
corrected. 2 Lima, f.
Pertayning to polishing, or trim­
ming of wares. 1 Mangonicus.

To Pollute,
vi. defile
and beraie.
To pollute, or defile by incest. 1 Incesto, 2 invitio, effædo.
To pollute with a dead body.
1 Funesto.
To pollute together. 1 confædo.
Polluted. 1 Fædatus, pollutus, 
inquinatus, p. incestus, ad.
Polluted with touching a dead
body. 1 Funestus, ad.
A polluting. 1 Pollutio, f.
That polluteth with incest.
1 Incestificus, ad.
Pollutedly. 1 Inceste, pollute.

By Pollux his temple
1 Ædepol, adu.

ball, or sweete perfume.

The flower of the pomegranate.

The graine of the pomegranate.

graine of the pomegranate is clo­

The smale skinne that devideth
the graines in the pomegranate
one from an other.

A Ponde, or poole, 
wherein duckes, or geese do swim, 
& are kept. 1 Natatile, natato­
rium, 2 vivarium, n.
A pond, or standing poole, towa­
ter beastes. 1 Stagnum, n. lacus.
A pond where sheepe were wa­
shed that should be sacrificed.
1 Probatica piscina.
Great ponds, & pooles neere the
sea side, where fishes are taken, &
salted. 1 Cetaria, orum, n.
A fish pond. 1 Piscina, f. Ichthy­
otrophium, 2 vivarium, n.
A keeper of a fish ponde.
1 Piscinarius, m.
Pertaining to a fish ponde
1 Piscinalis, ad.

3 paupera, f.
The poorer sort of Romane citi­
zens, not fit for warre.

The poore people. 1 Plebecula, f.
Poore folke. 3 Hebiones.

tas, pauperies, inopia, 2 ege­
stas, tenuitas, indigentia, hu­

stuosus, egestosus, ad.

lars. 3 Pentastichæ, f.

To Possesse, or to
haue in possession. 1 Possideo, oc­
cupo, potior, 2 teneo, habeo, 
servo.
To possesse before. 1 Præoccupo
By long possession, & prescription
to attaine, or get a thing. 
1 Vsucapio
To put out of possession.
2 Dejicio, dimoveo, depono.
To alter possession. 2 Alieno.
To put another in possession, &
to dispossesse himselfe.
1 Mancipo, emancipo.
Possessed. 1 Possessus, potitus, p
Possessed with busines.
1 Occupatus, p.
A possessor of any thing.
1 Possessor, potitor, m.
Possession. 1 possessio, occupatio.
Great possessions, & lands
2 Latifundium, n.
a smal possession. 1 possessiuncula
The attaining to be owner of a 
thing by prescription, or possessi­
on of long time.
1 Vsucapio, f.
A possession of time out of mind
1 Possessio secularis.
Possession to an other mans vse.
1 Possessio fiduciaria.
Deliverance of possession to ano­
ther. 2 Alienatio, f.
Long possession. 2 Vsus, m
She that possesseth. 3 possestrix.
Possessed with a spirit.

Dæmoniosus, ad.
A possessiue. 1 Possessivum, n.
Possessiue. 1 Possessivus, ad.

a pot vsed in sacrifice. 1 capedo

a pot for wine alwaies set on the

take as much as he would.

A Pottle. 
1 Cabus, m.

A Pouch, or bagge.
1 Pera, f pero, m. mariupium, 
sacciperium, n. 2 folliculus, m. 
vide bagge, and purse.
A little pouch. 1 Sacculus, m.
A letherne pouche. 1 Scortea, f.

To Pouder. 
1 Sallo, sallio, aliquando sa­
lio. 2 Condio, aspergo.
To pouder with salte. 1 Sallio.
Poudered. 1 Sallitus, 2 Condi­
tus, p. condititius, ad.
A poudering.
1 Salitura, f. 2 Conditus, m. 
conditura, conditio, f.
Poudered meates 1 Taricus, m. 
condititia cibaria.
That is, or may be poudered, or
kept. 1 Conditivus, condititius

To Pouder, or bring
a thing to pouder. 
1 Pulvero, dispulvero. 2 Resol­
vo. 3 Pulverizo.
To pouder againe. 1 Repulvero.
To be turned into pouder.
1 Pulveresco.
Pouder. 2 Pulvis, m. & f.
Pouder, or gunne pouder.
1 Nitratus pulvis, pulvis bom­
bardicus, 2 Nitrum, n.
Pouder comming out of timber
bored, or cutte. 2 Lanugo, f. vide
sawe dust. 
Power of filing, or shaving.
1 Peripsema, n. limatura, f.
Pouder blowen from brasse mel­
ted.
1 Psegma, n.
Pouder of sweete spices.
1 Alephanginæ species.
Fine powder. 1 Pulvisculum, n. 
pulvisculus, m. 3 Pulviusculum.
Sneesing pouder.
1 medicamentum sternutatorium.
Sweet powder laide in garments.
1 Pulvis Damascenus.

Povertie, vi: Poore.

To Poule, vide pole. 
To poule neere. 1 Attondeo.

To Poure. 1 Fundo.
To poure out. 1 Fundo, effundo
vergo, futio. 2 Abjicio.
To Poure out largelie. 1 Effun­
do, profundo, refundo.
To poure out liquor. 1 Deliquo.
To poure out of one vessel into
another. 1 Detrullo, elutrio, 
transfundo.
To poure often. 1 Fundito.
to poure in. 1 infundo. 2 ingero
To poure in, or vpon. 1 Superfun­
do, affundo, perfundo. 2 spargo
To poure by little and little.
1 Instillo.
To poure downe.
1 Defundo, suffundo.
To poure out by turnes.
1 Interfundo.
To poure out on everie parte.
1 Perfundo.
To poure about.
1 Offundo, circumfundo.
To poure out estsoones. 1 refundo
To be poured on. 1 Infundor.
Poured. 1 Fusus, p.
Poured in, or vpon. 1 Affusus, 
infusus, 2 Ingestus, p.
Poured in by drops.
1 Diffusus, instillatus, p.
Poured in againe. 1 Refusus, p.
Poured vpon. 1 Superfusus, p.
Poured out. 1 Effusus, p.
Poured out of one vessell into an
other. 1 Elutriatus, p.
A pouring in or vpon.
1 Infusio, suffusio, f.
A pouring all over. 1 Perfusio.
A pouring in by droppes.
1 Instillatio, f.
A pouring out.
1 Effusio, profusio, 2 resparsio, 
f. resparsus, m.
A pouring out of one vessell in­
to an other. 1 Transfusio, f.
That may be soone poured out.
1 Futilis, ad.

To Pownce. 
1 Concido.

To be of Power. 
1 Valeo, evaleo, pollei, æqui­
valeo, æquipolleo.
To giue power. 1 Permitto.
I haue power. 1 Licet, liberum est
Power, authoritie, or dominion.
1 Potestas, f. 2 res. 3 dynastia, f. 
cratos, vide authoritie.
Power, abilitie, or force.
1 Potestas, potentia, pollen­
tia, valentia, factio, opes, seu­
opis, f. potestatus, m. 2 vis &
vires, virtus, copia, manus, co­
piola, f. conatus, nervus, m. 
conamen, n.
Power over any other.
2 Mancipium, n.
Power over all. 1 Omnipoten­
tia, vniversipotentia, f.
Power of God. 1 Numen, n.
Power to doe, or speake.
1 Facultas, 3 habentia, f.
Power royall. 1 Majestas, f.
Great power. 1 Potentatus, m
That hath power.
1 Potens, pollens, p
That hath power over others.
1 Præpotens, prævalidus, ad.
Of chiefe power. 1 Primipotens
Of power in many thinges.
1 Multipotens, ad.
That hath power over all.
1 omnipotens, vniversipotens
That lacketh power.
1 Impos, impotens, ad.
In ones power. 1 Penes, præp.

P ANTE R.

To Practise, or exer­
cise. 1 Meditor, exerceo, exer­
cito, insuesco, commolior, ja­
ctito, 2 Colo, ago, actito.
To practise againe. 2 Recolo.
To put in practise. 1 Incepto.
To practise hostility.
1 Inimicor.
To practise in lawe-matters.
2 Actito.
Practised. 1 Exercitus, exer­
citatus, assuetus, 2 subactus, 
part.
Not practised. 1 Inexercitus
inexercitatus, ad.
A practiser in the law.
1 Pragmaticus, m.
A practiser to draw out writs.
1 Formularius, m.
Practitioners, or practisers in
the law. 1 Cautores, concep­
tores, stipulatores, astipula­
tores, basilicani, m.
A practiser of phisicke.
1 Empiricus, m.
A practise, or exercise.
1 Experientia, exercitatio, 
practica, f.
The practise of a craft, or occu­
pation. 1 Artificium, n.

To Praie, or make
praiers. 1 Oro, precor, com­
precor, obsecro, posco, vt
Deos poscere. to pray the gods
quæso defect. rogo, invoco.
To pray vnto. 1 Adoro, adpre­
cor, erogito, exoro.
To pray hartily. 1 Deprecor, 
2 corrogo, derogito.
To pray to God. 2 Testor.
To pray contrary to that he
desired before: to pray eftsoones.
1 Resecro.
To pray for other. 2 Intercedo
To pray together. 1 Comprecor
Praied. 1 Oratus, p.
A praier. 1 Precatio, rogita­
tio, supplicatio precis, ci, cem
ce, in sing. preces, plu. medi­
tatio, obsecratio, rogatio, f. 
votum, precamen, supplici­
um, n. comprecatio, f oratus
2 Rogatus, m.
A praier for the appeasing of
Gods wrath. 2 Propitiatio, f.
A praier to God. 3 Proseuche
proseucha, f.
Morning praier.
1 Matutinæ preces.
Evening praier.
1 Vespertinæ preces.
Certaine praiers spoken of di­
viners, telling the successe of mat­
ters at the ende of their divi­
nation. 1 Effata, orum, n.
That which is gotten by praier.
1 Precarium, n.
Belonging to morning praier.
3 Matutinalis, ad.
Granted to one by praier.
1 Precarius, ad.
By praier. 1 Precario, precarie

A pray getter. 1 Prædator, m

for. 1 Pecunia manubialis.

1 Manubiarius, m.

1 Prædaceus, prædativus,

To Prate, prattle, 
babble, chat, or chatter. 1 Gar­
rulo, garrio, blatero, debla­
tero, fabulo, & lor, loquitor, 
blatio, loquacito, prodico. 
2 Obstrepo, instrepo, ineptio
futio, effutio, gannio, obgan­
nio, decanto, crepito. 
3 Rumifico.
To prate, or chat pertly.
1 Argutor.
To prate, as a nurse doth to hir
childe. 1 Lallo.
To prate every man in the com­
pany, and not obserue what is
saide. 2 Circulo.
A prater, or babler. 1 Dicax, 
dicaculus, garculus, loquax, lo­
quaculus, linguax, linguacu­
lus, blatero, blactero, verbo­
sus, argutator, spermologus, 
battologus, adolescnus, m. 
lingulaca, f. 2 Futilis, rima­
rum plenus, 3 frequentidicus
A prater, or pratler of trifles.

quus, stultiloquus, m.
He that prateth alone, or to
himselfe. 1 Sililoquus, m.
A prating, or babling. 1 Dica­
citas, loquacitas, garrulitas, 
blateratio, adoleschia verbo­
sitas, fabulatio, f. multiloquium
n. 2 Colloquutio, futilitas, f.
Vain, or foolish prating, or prat. 




ling. 1 Inaniloquium, stulti­
loquium, n.
A prating alone, or to himselfe.
1 Soliloquium, n.
The prating of nurses to young

scitulus, 2 blandus, ad.

Very prety. 1 Perelegans, ad.
Nothing prety. 1 Inelegans.

parvus, parvulus, exiguus, ad.
Pretie, or mery. 1 Lepidus, ad.
Pretily, finely, or featly.

Very pretily. 1 Pereleganter.
Nothing pretily.
1 Ineleganter, adu.
Pretily, or merily.
1 Lepide, facete, festivius.

To Prevaile. 
1 Valeo, prævaleo, præva­
lesco, invalesco, polleo, 2 pro­
moveo, procedo, v. to availe.
Prevailing much, or that is of
much force. 1 Efficax, ad.

To Prevente.

verto, præverto, præterverto,

dior.
To prevent, take, or snatche be­
fore an other. 1 Præripio, oc­
cupo, præsumo, anticapio, 
antecipo, præcipio, 2 præcer­
po, præcido.
To prevent, or apprehend vn­
awares. 1 Intercipio.
To prevent in the possession of a
thing. 1 Anteoccupo, occupo.
To prevent in answering that
one might object.
2 Occurro, ire obviam.
Prevented. 1 Interceptus, 
præventus, 2 incisus, p. vt inci­
sa spes, hope prevented. 
Prevented, or taken before.
1 Anticipatus, occupatus, 
præoccupatus, præsumptus, 
præceptus, p.
A prevention. 1 Præventio, 
2 prægressio, f.
A prevention, or taking before.

ries objection. 2 Præsumptio, f

To Price, or valewe. 
1 Æstimo, adæro, liceor, lici­
tor, appretior.
To set at a price.
2 Indico, destino.
To offer the price: also to set the
price higher. 1 Liceor, licitor.
To bring to a lesse price.
1 Depretio.
To be of small price. 1 Vileo, 
vilesco, 2 jaceo.
To be of like price. Æquivaleo.
To be priced. 1 Liceo.
Priced. 1 Æstimatus, licitatus, 
indicatus, appretiatus, p.
Brought to a lesse price.
1 Depretiatus, p.
A pricer. 1 Æstimator, licita­
tor, m.
One that enhaunceth the price.
1 Licitator, m.
A pricing. 1 Licitatio, 2 indi­
catio, æstimatio, indicatura, f
A price. 1 Pretium, n. centio, 
2 indicatura, f. valor, m.
Worthy to bear away the price.
1 Palmarius, ad.
Of a little and lowe price.
1 Vilis, 2 parvus, ad.
Of no price. 2 Nullus, ad.
Of what price? 1 Quanti?
At that price, or for so much.
1 Tantidem.
At so little a price. 1 Tantulo.
Of so great a price. 1 Tanti.
At a great price. 1 Magno. 
care, adu. vt care æstimare.
For a little price.
1 Vili, ius, minimo, adu.

To Pricke. 
1 Stimulo, extimulo, persti­
mulo, instimulo, pungo, com­
pungo, fodico.
To pricke againe. 1 Repungo.
To pricke often.
1 Pungito, repuncto.
To pricke, or stirre forward.
1 Incito, instigo, 2 exacuo, a­
gito, stimulo, instimulo, exti­
mulo, perstimulo, 3 stigo.
A pricker forwarde.
1 Instigator, m. trix, f. instin­
ctor, 2 stimulator, m. trix, f. 
extimulator, m.
A pricking. 1 Punctio, pun­
ctura, stimulatio, compun­
ctio, dispunctio, f.
A pricking forwarde. 1 Insti­
gatio, f. instigatus, instinctus, 
m. incitamentum, m.
A pricking in the body, as with
wormes. 1 Vermina, n.
A thing that pricketh.
1 Stimulus, aculeus, m.
A thing that pricketh forward
1 Stimulus, m.
A pricke with a pinne, or such
like. 1 Punctus, m. punctum, n.
A little pricke with a needle, or
pinne. 1 Punctiuncula, f.




A little pricke, or sting.
1 Aculeolus, m. vide sting. 
A pricking as it were, or cut­
ting of the skinne with a laun­
cer, and sharpe pointed instru­
ment, to draw water from them
that haue the dropsie.
1 Paracentisis, f.
Pricking, or that pricketh.
1 Stimuleus, 2 asper, ad.

A Pricke vsed in
writing. 1 Punctus, m pun­
ctum, neut.

A Pricke, or marke
to shoote at. 
1 Meta, f. scopus, m.

The Pricke, & price. 
1 Primæ, f.

A Pricket, v. bucke.

A Prickle, or grissel
of an hedgehog, or such like. 
1 Spina, f. vide sting. 
That beareth such prickles.
1 Spinifer, ad.
Prickie, or that hath prickles.
1 Hirsutus, ad.
Prickie, like the herbe, Acan­
thus. 1 Acanthinus, ad.

To make a Priest. 
2 Consecro.
A priest. 1 Sacerdos, sacri­
cola, co. g. mysta, mystes, m:
A chiefe priest, 1 Hierosar­
cus, hierosarca, m.
A massing priest. 1 Sacrificus, 
sacrificulus, 2 sacrilegus, li­
niger, masc.
A great priest among the gen­
tiles. 1 Flamen, n.
A priest which was appointed
to doe the sacrifice to that god­
desse which served Palatium.
1 Palatualis, m.
A little priest. 3 Sacerdulus, 
sacerdotulus, m.
The chiefe of Sibyls priests.
1 Archigallus, m.
Sacred priestes in Ægypt, more
honored than the others.
1 Pastophori, m.
Priests, or magistrats among
the Athenians.
1 Eumolpidæ, m.
The priest of Pan, who on the
day of their sacrifices, ranne vp
and down the citty naked, and
stroke the hands and bellies of
women that were great with
child, with a goates skin, there­
by to signifie both fruitfulnesse, 
& easie delivery. 2 Luperci, m.
The Priesthoode, or dignity of a 
priest. 1 Sacerdotium, n.
Of, or belonging to a priest.
1 Sacerdotalis, ad.
Priestly. 3 Sacerdotaliter.

Princes vnder the Prince of the

A princely house. 1 Palatium, n.
Without a prince. 1 Anarchus.
Pertaining to a Prince.
1 Principalis, ad.
Prince-like. 1 Regalis, regius, 
regificus, basilicus, ad.
Princely. 1 Regie, regaliter, re­
gifice, basilice, principaliter.

It is profitable. 1 Expedit, 
confert, conducit, refert, imp.

thing. 2 Profectus, m.
Profite gotten by laboure.
1 Emolumentum, n.
Profite, where one that hadde
the vse of a thing, called vsus
fructuarius, surrendereth that
right and title vnto the Lorde.
1 Consolidatio, f.
The profite, and vse of another
mans goodes, with the consent of
the owner, the stocke and sub­
stance beeing saved.
1 Vsusfructus, m.
Small profite. 1 Quæstiuncu­
lus, m. 2 lucellum, n.
A profiting. 2 Progressus, m.
Profitable, or commodious.

gifer, idoneus, commodus,

dibilis, ad.

salubriter, belle, adu.

That is pronounced.

riclitator, cognosco, v. to assay

2 compositio, f.
The proportion or likenes of any

A proportion, or agreeablenes
of one thing with another.

sponsus, m.
A due, and equal proportion,

Iuvenca gallina. 
Pullastrata gallina

A Pulley wherein a
corde runneth to drawe any
thing. 1 Trochlea, f. artemon.
The pullie in the top of a shippe.
1 Carchesium, n.
The corde of a pulley.
1 Ductorius funis.
The pinne of iron which goeth
through the pulley. 2 Aciculus.

A Pulpit. 
1 Suggestus, m. suggestum, 
rostra, vel rostrum, lustrum, 
pulpitum, 2 monitorium, ana­
barathrum, n. concio, f. 3 ana­
logium, legium, n.

Pulse, as beanes and
pease. 1 Legumen, legumentum.
A kind of pulse somewhat like
fetches. 1 Orobus, m. ervum, n.
A kind of pulse called lupines.
1 Lupinus, m. lupinum, n.
The place where the pulse doth
growe. 1 Lupinetum, lupinarium.
A kinde of pulse. 1 Cicera, f.
A kinde of small pulse rising
vp by tendrels, so high, that men
may make arboures of them.
1 Faseolus, phaseolus, m.

A moving, or beating of the arte­
ries, called the Pulse. 
1 Pulsus, m.
The pulses. 1 Arteriæ, venæ
pulsatiles, 2 venæ, f.

To Pumpe out. 
1 Antlo, exantlo.
To pumpe water out of a skip.
1 Sentino.
A pumpe to draw water.
1 Antlia, cochlea, f.
The pumpe of a shippe.
1 Sentina, f.

A Pumpe, or pinson
1 Endromides, f.

To Punch, or pricke
1 Pungo, vide to pricke.

A Punchion, or joist
of ten, or twelue foote long. 
1 Asser, m.

To Punishe. 
1 Punio, plecto, affligo, ver­
bero, 2 vlciscor, exequor, vin­
dico, coerceo, reposcere pœ­
nas, v. to chastice, and correct. 
To punish hastily.
2 Supplicia repræsentare.
To punish by fine, or forfaiture.
1 Multo, mulcto v to amerce. 
They haue beene punished.
2 Vindicatum est, impers.
Punished. 1 Punitus, mulcta­
tus, 2 anima, versus, p.
Not punished.
2 Inultus, ad.
A punisher. 1 Punitor, mul­
ctator, 2 vltor, m.
A punishing.
1 Castigatio, punitio, verbe­
ratio, animadversio, f. verbe­
ratus, m. punimen, n. 2 vltio, 
vindicta, coerctio, coertio, co­
ercitio, f.
A punishing by the purse, or
otherwise. 1 Mulctatio, f.
A punishment. 1 Supplicium, 
n. pœna, mulcta, f.
A punishment, or condemnati­
on done by the Censor.
1 Censio, f.
A kind of punishment by draw­
ing out the haires of the privie
members of poore men taken in 
adulterie. 1 Paratilmus, m.
A kinde of punishment among
the Persians, where the toppes
of two trees were drawen toge­
ther, and the offenders beeing
bounde to eche of them by the
legges, were drawen asunder.
1 Disphendomena.
The punishment that the soules
doe abide 2 Manes, m.
An equall punishment for an
offence, as a hand for a hand, 
or one bone for another. 1 Talio.
Punishment, or penalty.
3 Pænalitas, f.
Lacke, or pardon of punishment.
1 Impunitas, f.
A person woorthy of punish­
ment. 1 Verbero, m.
Punishable. 2 Criminosus, ad.
Without punishment.
1 Impune, adu.

A Pupil, fatherlesse
child, or warde. 1 Pupillus, m. 
pupilla, f.
Pertaining to a pupil.
1 Pupillaris, ad.

A Puppet, or poppet
like a child. 1 Pupus, m. pupa.
A puppet or little babes given
to children. 1 Sigillaria, n.
Dauncing with puppets.
1 Gesticularia, f.
A puppet plaier. 1 Gesticula­
tor, 2 Circulator, m.

A Puppy, v. whelpe.

To make Purblind. 
1 Elusco.
To be purblinde. 1 Habere
oculos luscos.
Purblindnesse. 1 Eluscatio, f.
Purblind. 1 Luscus, nyctalimi­
cus, ad. vide blinde.

To Purchase, or
buie. 1 Emo, vide to buie. 
To purchase, or get. 1 Acquiro, 
commparo, paro, 2 colligo, con­
traho, v to attain, & obtaine.
Purchased, or gotten.
1 Partus, acquisitus, adqui­
situs, conciliatus, p.




A purchaser, or getter.
2 Emptor, m. vide get. 
A purchasing, or buying.
1 Emptio, redemptio, f.
A purchasing, or procuring.
1 Captatio, f. vide get.

To make Pure. 
1 Purifico.
Purenesse of life, or puritie.
1 Synceritas, castimonia, pu­
ritas, pudicitia, 2 integritas, f
Purenesse without mixture.
1 Meracitas, f.
Pure, cleane, or vncorrupt.
1 Purus, castus, immacula­
tus, syncerus, sanctus, incor­
ruptus, temperans, putus, 2
integer, ad.
Pure without mixture.
1 Merus, ad.
Pure, or cleare. 1 Limpidus, 
liquidus, 2 candidus, ad.
Pure, trimme, or fine.
1 Tersus, p. 2 limatus.
Somewhat pure.
2 Limatulus, ad.
Pure as water. 3 Eliquus, ad.
Pure without mixture, or cor­
ruption. 3 Pisticus, ad.
Almost pure. 1 Submerus, ad.
Purely, syncerely, or vncorrupt­
ly. 1 Pure, syncere, pie, ca­
ste, incorrupte, pute, puriter, 
2 inviolate, integre, adu.
Purely, or clearly. 1 Liquidius.
Purely, finely, or neatly.
1 Limate, emendate, adu.
Purely, without mixture.
1 Mere, adu.

womans gowne, or garde.

tum, segmen, effilatum, n.

1 Limbolarius, m.
That hath purfles.
1 Segmentatus, ad.

any liquide thing. 1 Eliquo.
To purge diligently.
1 Repurgo, perpurgo.
To purge out.
1 Expurgo, excerno.
To purge out.
2 Diruncio, diruncino.
To purge by sacrifice. 1 Pio, 
expio, lustro, sacrifacio, pro­
curo, februo, vide clense. 
To purge from sand, or gravell.
3 Exareno.
To purge from chaffe. 1 Exacero
Purged. 1 Purgatus, expurga­
tus, mundatus, putus, 2 ex­
cretus, incretus, decoctus, p.
Purged by sacrifice.
1 Lustratus, expiatus, p.
A purger. 1 Purgator, m.
A purger by sacrifice.
1 Procurator, m.
A purgation, or purging.
1 Purgatio, expurgatio, de­
purgatio, f. purgamen, repur­
gium, n. 2 Dissolutio, de­
tractio, f. 3 exfitus, m.
A purgation made of aloes.
1 Aloidarium, n.
A purging, or pleasing God by
sacrifice. 1 Expiatio, f. expia­
men, expiamentum, n lustra­
tio, 2 procuratio, fæm. lustra­
mentum, n.
Purging, or such thinges, as
the sea, or rivers caste alande.
1 Ejectamentum, n.
A purging by fire.
3 Catharmos.
A purgation of the citty by sa­
crifice, every fifth yeere.
1 Lustrum, n.
A purgation by washing.
3 Clysmus, m.
A common purgation, called
Casia fistula. 1 Casia fistularis.
Thinges pulled away in purging, 
or making cleane.
1 Decermina, orum, n.
Sacrifices for purging of soules.
1 Februa, orum, n.
So purged. 1 Februatus, p.
That may be purged.
1 Expiabilis, lustrabilis, ad.
Pertaining to purging.
1 Purgatorius, lustralis, ad.
Purgatiue. 1 Catharticus, ad.
That hath power to purge.
1 Piacularis, ad.

Purgatorie picke­
purse. 3 Purgatorium, n.

To Purpose, or in­
tende. 1 Destino, meditor, 2
conor, intendo.
To purpose before. 1 Prædestino.
To remooue one from his pur­
pose. 2 Deduco.
To breake one from his purpose
in talke. 1 Interpello, 2 abrum­
po, intercipio, intercido.
I am purposed.
1 Deliberatum est. 
Constitutum est.
It serveth to no purpose.
2 Vacat, impers.
It is to the purpose. 1 Refert.
Purposed, or intended.
1 Meditatus, destinatus, 2
cogitatus, propositus, p.
He that hath his purpose.
1 Compos, vt libertatis compos.
He that hath obtained his de­
sired libertie. 
He that can by no terrour bee
drawen from his purpose.
3 Acolithus, m.
A purpose. 1 Destinatio, f. 
propositum, præpositum, in­
stitutum, constitutum, 2 con­
silium, studium, n. animus, m. 
voluntas, intentio, ratio, sen­
tentia, mens, f.
An earnest purpose.
1 Impetus, m.
All thinges beside the princi­
pall purpose. 1 Parergum, n.
To the purpose. 
2 Congruus, ad. appositus, p.
To another purpose.
2 Alio, aliorsum, adu.
Besides the purpose.




1 Obiter, præter propositum
To no purpose. 1 futile, futiliter
To what purpose. 1 Quo, adu.
To that purpose. 1 Eo, adu.
To the purpose. 2 Commode, 
convenienter, apte, expresse
Not to the purpose.
1 Insequenter, adu.
Not of purpose. 1 Inconsulto.
Of set purpose. 1 Consulto, de
industria, dedita opera, co­
gitato, cogitate, composite, 
ex disposito, ex composito.

Q ANTE V.

A QVADRAN­
GLE having
foure corners. 
1 Quadrangulus, tetragonus
Quadrangled. 1 Quadrangu­
latus, p.

Quadrate, or foure
square. 1 Quadrum, quadratum
n. tessera, f.
Quadrate. 1 Quadratus, p.

Quadrate aspect of
the planets, or fourth part of the
zodiacke circle, wherein the 12. 
signes be. 1 Tetartemorion, n.

Quadripartite, or of
four partes. 1 Quadripartitus.
Quadripartitely, or after the
maner of foure partes. 1 Qua­
dripartito, quadrupliciter.

Quadruple. 
1 Quadruplus, ad.

A Quest. 
1 Duodena, 2 inquisitio, f. duo
decemviratus, m.

To aske a Question. 
3 Quæstionor.
A question. 1 Percontatio, 
quæstio, rogatio, interrogatio
rogatus, m. erotema, 2 quæsitum
A little question or demaund.
1 Rogatiuncula, interrogati­
uncula, quæstiuncula, f.
A darke question or subtile. 1 Æ­
nigma, n. 2 gryphus, scrupus. 
1 Herculanus Nodus. 
Herculeus Nodus.
A question in rebuke of one.
3 Valgulatio, f.
One that proposeth darcke que­
stions. 1 Ænigmatistes, ænigma­
tista, m
Questionles 1 procul dubio, 
indubius, adu.
By asking of questions.
1 Interrogative, adu.

A Quest, or the office
of a questor. 
1 Quæstura, f.

To Quicken. 
1 Animo, vegeto, 2 vivifico.
To be quicke. 1 Vigeo, vigesco,
Quickning. 1 Vegetans, p.
Quickned. 2 experectus, vivifi­
catus, p.
Quicknes. 1 Agilitas, celeritas
impigritas, gnavitas, celeritu­
do, 2 velocitas, pernicitas, ra­
piditas, f.
Quicknes of witte. 1 Solertia, 
2 Sagacitas, acrimonia, f.
Quicknes of vnderstanding, or
sight. 1 Perspicacia, perspicaci­
tas, f.
Quicke, or liuely.
1 Vivificus, ad. animatus, p.
Quicke, or nimble to doe anie
thing. 1 Agilis, celes, citatus, ci­
tus, gnavus, navus, expeditus, 
tissimus, impiger, perexpedi­
tus, properus, præceler, inci­
tus, ocyor, yus, yssimus, facilis, 
ior, issimus, festivus, vegetus, 
velox, prævelox, ad.
quicke, or a liue.  Vegetans, vege­
tativus, vegetabilis, v. living. 
Very quicke. 1 præproperus.
Quicke of spirite, or witte.
1 Solers, alacer, 2 promptus, 
vegetus, ad.
Quicksighted. 1 Oculatus, dor­
ceus, ad.
Quicke againe. 1 revividus.
Quicke of sent.
1 Sagax, sagacissimus, ad.
Quickely, or speedily.
1 Impigre, agiliters celeriter, 
actutum, breviter, cito, cita­
tim, perceleriter, properato, 
protinus, ocyus festinanter, ma­
ture, maturate, maturime, ve­
lociter, astatim, properatim, 
2 Curriculo, perleviter, perni­
citer, velis equisque, rapide

strenue, 3 Topper, adu.

More quickly. 1 Maturius, adu

Quickly, or subtilie. 2 Acute.

1 Syrtes, f.
Quicke, and sharpe sayings.

A Quiditie, or subtile

To be Quiet. 
1 Acquiesco, conquiesco, qui­
esco. 2 sileo, silesco, desævio, 
taceo, ocior, vide to be calme. 
To begin to be quiet, or appeased.
1 Quiesco. 2 Residesco.
To make quiet, or patient. 1 Per­
paco, mitificio, vi: to appease. 
To be at quiet. 1 Requiesco. 2
Resideo, desedeo.
Quieted. 1 Pacatus, p.
That cannot be quieted, or quen­
ched. 2 insecutus, p. ab insequor
Quietnes.
1 Quies, 2 tranquillitas, sereni­
ras, pax, almities, securitas, pla­
ciditas, taciturnitas, f. silentium
ocium, n. 3 quietudo, f.
A quietnes, or hartes ease.
1 Euthymia, f.
A quieter, or he that bringeth 
quietnes. 1 Pacator, pacifer, pa­
cificatorius, m.
Quiet daies at the sea, during
which time, the birde Halcyon
buildeth his nest on the sea shore.
1 Halcyonides, f. halcyonei di­
es, alcedonia, n.
A quiet minded man, he which
taketh all thinges very patient­
lie, and in good part, vi: patient. 
Quiet. 1 Quietus, ad.
Quiet, or calme. 1 Serenus, tran­
quillus. 2 quietus, quiescens, pla­
cidus, clemens, mitis, almus. 
ad vide calme. 
Quiet, or without care.
1 Securus, 2 Tutus. 
Vacuus curis. 
Solutus curis.
3 Animæquus, ad.
Quiet from henceforth, or after
this day. 3 Transquietus, ad.
Quiet, or peaceable. 2 Facilis, 
tacitus, ad.
Quietlie. 1 Quiete, tranquille
2 Placite, placide, adu.
Quietlie without care. 1 secure.
At a quiet time.
1 Tranquillo, adu.

1 Penna, pinna, 2 calamus, m.

A quill, or bowe to play on the

ctrum. 2 Pecten, instrumentum.
The quille, or space betweene
two ioynts of herbes, or such like.
1 Internodium, n.

A Quilte, or Iacke.

A quilte, or curtaine.
1 Cadurcum, n.

peeces. 1 Centunculus, m.
A quilt made of leather.
1 Salganum, n.
A quilt maker for beddes.
1 Plumarius, m.
Quilted. 1 Culcitratus, p.

rabian word so signifying. 
1 Elixir.

The Quincie, a dis­
ease in the throate. 1 Angina, 
synanche, f.

the Quire of a church

gor. vt munus munere expun­

quitte, or forgiven. 1 Impunitus

R ANTE A.

TO RABAT, vide
rebate.

A Rabbet, or young
Conie. 1 Cuniculus, m.

A Rabble, or flocke. 
1 Cætus, m. Turba, f.

To Race, vide rase.

A Race, or course. 
1 Cursus, circuitus, m. 2 Seri­
es, f. spatium, n. vt spatium vi­
tæ, the race of ones life. 
A short race.
1 Curriculum, n. curriculus, m.
A race, or continuall order.
1 Tenor, m.
A race of an horse halfe a mile, 
or foure furlonges. 1 Equestre, n
The place, or barres,  from which
the race is taken. 1 Carceres, m

A Race, or stocke. 
1 Prosapia, f. 2 Sanguis, m. prin­
cipium, liminium, n. v: Linage.

To Racke. 
2 Torqueo, emedullo.




To racke to death. 3 Romanizo
A racker. 2 Tortor, contortor
A racke to racke, or torment one
2 Equuleus, eculeus, m. Tor­
mentum, n. vide Torment.

a chese racke. 1 crates casearia.

to laie the broch in as the fire.

A Racke for a crosbowe. 
2 Harpago, harpax, m.

with, at tennis. 2 Reticulum, n
Transenna, f. feritorium, Pilamen

belonging to a rafter. 1 tignarius

R ANTE E.

To Reach. 
1 Porrigo, exporrigo.
To reach one by an other.
1 Apporrigo.
To reach, or giue that which is
asked for.
1 Subministro.
To reach to something.
1 Pertingo.
A reaching out. 1 Porrectio, f. 
Porrectus, m.
Which reacheth farre.
2 Amplivagus, ad.

To Reade. 
1 Lego.
To reade over a thing slightly.
1 Sublego.
To reade againe. 1 Relego.
To reade out with a lowde voice.
1 Recito.
To read over. 1 Perlego, trans­
lego. 2 evolvo, pervolvo, volvo
To reade distinctly. 1 Accento,
To desire to reade. 1 Lecturio.
To reade as a master to his scho­
ler. 1 Perlego.
To teach to reade. 3 Litero.
To reade before.
1 Prælego, 2 Præeo.
To reade often.
1 Lectito, 3 Lecto, legito.
Readde. 1 Lectus, p.
Readde over. 1 Perlectus, p.
Readde openly. 1 Recitatus, p.
A reader. 1 Lector, m.
A reader in scholles. 1 professor
A reader to schollers.
1 Prælector, m.
A reading. 1 Lectio, lectura, f.
A reading over.
2 Evolutio, f.
A reading before, or openly.
1 Prælectio, f.
That may be readde.
1 Legibilis, ad.

To be Ready at hand
1 Præsto esse, adium.
It is in a readines.
1 Suppetit.

To make readie. 
1 Apparo, 2 Accingo, procin­
go, præsulto, vi: prepare, and or­
daine.
To make ready hastily.
2 Propero.
To set in a readines. 1 Expedio.
Ready, or made ready. 1 Paratus
Readines. 1 Promptus, m. promp­
titudo, 2 Facilitas, facultas, a­
lacritas, f.
Readines to please. 1 Obsequium.
Ready. 1 Promptus, paratus, ex­
peditus, 2 Pronus, arrectus, agi­
lis, expositus, præsentarius, stre­
nuus, accinctus, procinctus, pro­
pensus, ad.
Ready to please. 1 Obsequibilis
officiosus, obsequiosus, ad.
Very readie. 1 Perexpeditus. 
expromptus.
Alwaies readie.
1 Iugis, ad.
Readilie. 1 Prompte, adu.
Readily, as when one is perfect
in that which he hath learned, 
and so can say it readilie.
1 Memoriter, adu.
Readily, or serviceablie.
1 Officiose, præsto, procliviter
parate, expedite. 2 Propense, 
agiliter, celeriter, adu.
Readily and with signification
of good will.




1 In promptu. 2 Studiose, præ­
manibus.

deede. 1 Realis, ad.

To Reason, or dispute
1 Argumentor, 2 Quæro, vide dispute. 
To reason perfectlie. 1 Peroro.
To reason vehementlie.
1 Disserto.
To reason subtillie about words.
1 Cavillor.
To reason against a thing.
2 Oppugno, dissuadeo.
It is good reason.
2 Consentaneum est.
A reasoner. 1 Ratiocinator, m
A busie reasoner, talker, or bab­
ler. 1 Argutator, m.
Such a reasoning. 1 Argutatio.
A reason. 1 Ratio, f. argu­
mentum, n.
A matter to be reasoned of.
2 Quæstio, f.
The reason, or cause.
1 Ratio, causa, f.
Reason, or right. 1 Æquum, n.
A reasoning. 1 Argumentatio, 
ratiocinatio, dissertatio, f.
A captious reasoning.
1 Paralogismus, m.
A small reason. 1 Ratiuncula, f.
Reasonablenes. 1 Iustitia, f.
Reasonable. 1 Rationalis, ad.
Reasonable, or measurable.
1 Modicus, ad.
Reasonable, or right.
1 Æquus, par, ad.
Reasonable, vpright, or iust.
1 Fidelis, ad.
Without reason.
1 Absurdus. 2 Dissonus, ab­
sonus, ad.
That is full of reasoning.
1 Dissertabundus, ad.
Belonging to reasoning, or deba­
ting of a matter by arguments.
1 Ratiocinativus, ad.
That may be reasoned of.
1 Disputabilis, ad.
Against reason and right.
2 Depravate, adu.
Reasonablie, or moderatly. 1 mo­
dice, mediocriter, admodum.
By what reason.
1 Qui, quomodo, adu.

to, refero, recino, recolo, repli­
co, Revolvo.
To rehearse a thing often.
1 Dictito, tenarro, 2 decanto, re­
tracto, itero, reitero, ingemino
inculco, tundo.
Rehearsed. 1 Iteratus, repetitus
2 Decanta tus, inculcatus, p.
A rehearser. 1 Repetitor, 2 Re­
lator, m.
A rehearsall, or repeating.
1 Iteratio, Reiteratio, repetiti­
o, recitatio, 2 enumeratio, re­
latio, geminatio, f. Frequenta­
mentum, n.
An often rehearsall, or repetition
of the same thing in diverse
wordes.
1 Tautologia, battologia, f.

vide despise.

moue one campe where the other
was. declino, vt declinare ag­

to some place. resolvo, deleo.

moveo.

paine. 1 Amolior.

other. 1 Transmoveo, transfero

To Robbe, or spoile
1 Furor, spolio, despolio, ex­
polio, dispolio, 2 Expilo, com­
pilo, suppilo, arrodo, excutio, 
exhaurio, exinanio. 2 Deri­
pio, nudo, denudo.
To rob, or steale privily.
1 Suffuror.
To rob, or spoile countries.
1 Populo, populor, depopulor
expopulor.
To rob the common treasury.
1 Peculor, depeculor.
To rob and take booties by the
high way.
1 Grassor, degrassor, latro­
cinor, prædor, deprædor.
To rob one of his raiment.
1 Expallio, 3 depanno.
To rob often. 2 Rapto.
To rob againe. 2 Renudo.
Robbed. 2 Spoliatus, despoli­
atus, compilatus, exinanitus
expilatus, direptus, præda­
tus, denudatus, p.
A robber, or theefe.
1 Fur, com. g. latro, populator
prædator, prædo, expilator, 
spoliator, deprædator, raptor
direptor, orbator, rapio, de­
nudator, 3 Prædonulus, vis­
pilio, m.
A robber lying in waite by the
high way. 1 Grassator, incessor
3 Hodædocus, stratilles, m.
A robber of a church, chappell, 
or other holy place.
1 Sacrilegus, m.
A robber of the common trea­
sury. 1 Peculator, depecula­
tor.
A robber by sea. 1 Pirata, 
3 Vispilio, m.
Of a robber, or robery by sea.
1 Piraticus, ad. v. pyrate. 
A robber by night.
1 Præmiator, m.
A robber in warre.
1 Excursor, m.
Robbers by night, or shop brea­
kers. 1 Directarij, m.
A robber of the deade by night
3 Vispilio, Bustifragus, m.
A robber, or breaker of doores
& lockes. 1 Effractor, m. vide
burglary. 
That liveth by robbing.
1 Prædabundus, 3 rapinosus.
A robbery, or robbing.
1 Furtum, latrocinium, n. po­
pulatio, prædatio, rapina, 
grassatio, grassatura, spolia­
tio, latrocinatio, compilatio, 
expilatio, 2 Direptio.

sury.

church. 1 Sacrilegium, n.
Robbery by sea. 1 Piratica, f

Belonging to robbing.

To put Robes on. 
3 Stolo.
A robe or garment. 1 Palla, f.
A purple robe. 2 Purpura, f.
A kingly robe, or a robe of e­




state. 1 Basilicon. n. regilla, f. 
Basilica vestis, 
Regia vestis. 
3 Regillum, v. taratha, f.
A robe, or kirtle worne by kings
vnder their mantles of estate.
1 Trabea, f.
Clothed with such a robe.
1 Trabeatus, p.
An aldermans robe. 1 Abolla.
Robes of rich furres.
3 Andromeda.
A robe of honour. 1 Stola, f.
He that weareth a robe of ho­
nour. 1 Stolatus, p.
A long robe. 1 Pallium, n. toga
A robe of scarlet. 1 Toga
purpurea.
A long robe, or gowne garded a­
bout with purple silke, the robe
of estate, that the king of Rome
or other chiefe officers did wear, 
when they sate in their majesty, 
and was woont to bee burned
with them that died in their
office, neither could any iudge
giue sentence on a man, till he
had put off that robe: also a robe
which noble mens children
vsed to weare, til they wear se­
venteene years of age.
1 Prætexta, prætexta toga.
He that weareth such a robe.
1 Prætextatus, p.
Noble mens sons and daugh­
ters, wearing those long robes
garded with purple.
1 Prætextati, m. & prætex­
tatæ, f.
A robe, or Ephod made altoge­
ther of blew silke, having round
about the skirts thereof 72 pom­
granats of blew silke, purple, &
scarlet, and as many bels of gold
betweene them round about.
1 Machil
Iudges robes
1 Vestimenta forensia.
A yeoman, or master of the
robes. 1 Vestiarius, m.
Robewise. 1 Palliolatim, adu.

Rose water. 1 Aqua rosacea.
A pretious stone of rose colour.
1 Rhodites.
Rose garlands. 1 Rosalia, n.
A garden of roses. 1 Rosetum, 
rosarium, n. 3 Rhodonia, f.
Oile of roses. 1 Rosaceum, n. 
rhodinum oleum.
Of the colour of roses, or belong­
ing to roses.
1 Roseus, rosaceus, rosare­
us, 3 rhodinus, ad.

Rosine. 
1 Succinum, n. resina, f.
A certaine rosine dropping from
the tree Merodion.
1 Pyrama, phyrama, n.
Rosined, or made of rosine.
1 Resinatus, ad.
Full of rosine. 1 Resinosus, ad.
Of, or belonging to rosine.
1 Rosinaceus, ad.

refacio.

stus, adustus, 3 inassatus, p.
That maye bee rosted.
2 Coctilis, ad.
Rosted meate.
1 Assatura, f. assum, n.
Rosted vnder ashes.
1 Subcinaritius, ad.
A rosting. 2 Adustio, f.

A Rotchet, v. rochet

To Rotte, putrifie, 
or waxe rotten. 1 Putreo, pu­
tresco, deputresco, compu­
tresco, Exputresco, imputres­
co, marceo, marcesco, im­
marcesco ranceo, 2 tabeo, 
tabesco, intabesco, corrumpor.
To rotte, or putrify with long
continuance.
1 Fraceo, fracesco.
To rotte as a tree doth.
3 Cario.
To make rotten. 1 Putrefacio, 
3 putrido, marcido.
To be rotten.
1 Putreo, putrefio.
Made rotten, or putrified.
1 Putrefactus, p.
Rottennesse, or putrefaction.
1 Putredo, marciditas, f. mar­
cor, rancor, m. 2 tabes, f.
Rottennesse in wood.
1 Caries, 3 caria, f.
A rotten sore.
1 Vomica, f.
Rotten, or putrified bloud.
1 Tabum, n.
Rotten, or putrified.
1 Marcidus, fracidus, putri­
dus, putris, rancidus, cario­
sus, 2 tabidus, vitiosus, im­
probus, ad. corruptus, p.
Rotten as a sore.
1 Purulentus, ad.
Verie rotten.
3 Marcosus, marcidiosus, 
rancosus, ad.
Somewhat rotten.
1 Marcidulus, ranculus, ran­
cidulus.
Rotten againe.
2 Reputridus, ad.
Which doeth cause to rotte.
2 Tabificus, ad.
That maketh rotten, or ripe, 
as matter in a sore: putrefactiue
1 Septicus, ad.
Easie to be rottened, or putri­
fied. 1 Marcessibilis, ad.

such like.

To make Round, or
bring round together. 
1 Globo, conglobo, rotun­
do, corrotundo.
To growe vp rounde.
1 Rotundo.
To turne rounde.
1 Circumvolo, volvo, circum­
roto, converto, circumagito, 
2 torqueo.
To rounde in notting, or clip­
ping. 2 Attondeo.
To make rounde like a steeple, 
broode beneath, and sharpe to­
warde the toppe.
1 Turbino.
To gather rounde together, to
winde rounde, or to gather in a
rounde heape.
1 Glomero, conglomero, 3
conglomino.
To bee rounde, or bee gathered
rounde. 1 Conglobor.
To be round, as maidens breasts
1 Sororior, sororio.
Made rounde like a circle, or
compasse. 1 Orbiculatus, 
circinnatus, p.
Gathered round together.
1 Conglobatus, conglome­
ratus, p.
Made round like a cuppe.
1 Diatretus, ad.
Made rounde like a steeple, or
toppe. 1 Turbinatus, pyrami­
datus, p.
Rounded in notting.
2 Tonsus, p.
Roundnesse. 1 Rotunditas, 
globositas, 2 volubilitas, 3
congialitas, f.
A making rounde.
1 Rotundatio, f.
A gathering round together.
1 Glomeratio, conglobatio.
A rounding, as in notting.
2 Tonsura, f.
A round circle, vide circle. 
A turning rounde about.
1 Circumactus, m. circum­
actio, f.
A rounde figure, such as spin­
ners, or spiders doe make: also
a little rounde thing made in
trees when they are graffed.
1 Scutula, f.
Any rounde thing broade a­
boue, and sharpe beneath, or
sharpe aboue & broad beneath.
1 Turbo, m. pyramis, f. co­
nus, conoides.
The rounde fashion of such a
thing. 1 Turbinatio, f.
Any round thing.
1 Globus, m. sphæra, f.
Everie rounde roote that hath
many pilles one vpon another.
1 Bulbus, m.
A rounde circle like a trendle.
1 Spira, f.
A whirling, or turning round.
1 Vertigo, f.
An instrument wherewith a 
thing is made rounde.
1 Teretrum, n.
The roundnesse of a staffe, or
such like. 3 Teretudo, f.
Any thing that is round like a
ball. 2 Pilula, f.
The roundnesse of bones in the
ankels, elbowes, knees, or knuc­
kels. 1 Condylus, m.
Rounde, or quicke speaking, 
without impediment, or slack­
ing. 2 Volubilitas, f.
The round of a ladder.
1 Climacter, m.
A round place. 1 Cyclus, m.
Round, or of a round figure.
1 Sphæricus, orbicus, rotun­
dus, circularis, globosus, or­
biculatus, 3 exangulus, ad.
Round and long like a tree, or
pillar. 1 Teres.
Having rounde heades in the
rootes. 1 Bulbosus, ad.
Rounde wrought, like a spiders
web. 1 Scutulatus, ad.
Of, or belonging to round run­
ning. 1 Circensis, ad.
That may be rounded.
1 Sphærabilis, ad.
That maie be rounded, or clip­
ped rounde. 2 Tonsilis, ad.
Roundly.
1 Orbiculatim, rotatim, ro­
tunde, 2 volubiliter, adu.
Roundly, or as it were with an
ambling pace. 1 Cursim, 
2 tolutim, adu.

1 Vlcus, n.
A running water. 1 Profluens.
A place where two rivers, or
moe, meet, and run together.
1 Confluens, m. confluges, f.
Pertaining to running.
1 Cursorius, m.
Running, or that never stand­
eth still. 2 Vivus, volubilis, ad.




Running at random.
1 Vagus, erraticus, ad.
That runneth often over.
1 Superfluus, scaturiginosus.
Which runneth, or floweth be­
tweene. 1 Interfluus, ad.
That runneth, or passeth easily.
1 Meabilis, ad.
Running, or in all haste.
1 Cursim, adu.

A Runner, or vpper
stone of a mill. 1 Catillus, m.

An olde Runte. 
1 Vetula, f.

Rurall, v. rusticall.

To Rushe. 
1 Ruo.
To rush in, or vpon.
1 Irruo, irrumpo, introrum­
po, impeto, impetum facere, 
2 incumbo.
To rush out. 1 Proruo.
To rush, or beat at a thing with
the hornes. 1 Arieto.
To rush into extreames.
3 Immodico.
To rush, or runne violentlye a­
gainst one. 1 Ire in aliquem.
A rushing in, or vpon.
1 Irruptio, f.

To bind with Rush­
es. 1 Scirpo.
A bul-rush. 1 Iuncus, m. scir­
pus, sirpus, m. biblos.
A kind of sweete rush.
1 Teuchices, m.
A little rush
1 Iunculus, scirpiculus, m.
Flagges, or wilde rushes.
1 Scirpi, sirpi, m.
A great rush in Ægypt grow­
ing in fens, whereof they made
great leaus to write on, & wher
of the first paper was made.
1 Papyrus, f.
The place where they growe.
1 Papyrio, f.
That bringeth forth such rushes
whereof the first paper was
made. 1 Papyrifer, ad.
The rush whereof the weakes of
watch candles be made.
1 Mariscus, m. mariscum, n. 
juncus levis.
A thing made of rushes.
1 Scirpea, sirpea, f.
A rush-hill.
1 Scirpetum, n.
A place where bul-rushes grow
1 Iuncetum, n.
Full of bul-rushes.
1 Iuncosus, m.
Of bul-rushes, or made of bull-­
rushes. 1 Iunceus, juncinus, 
scirpeus, ad.

nosus, ærugineus, ferrugine­
