To Sacrifice. 
1 Sacrifico, immolo, lito, 
litor, perlito, prælito, 2 Ado­
leo, libo, delibo, prolibo, 
facio, macto, 3 Victimo.
To sacrifice together. 1 collito.
To please with sacrifice.
1 Lito, litor, vide to appease, 
and please. 
To sacrifice againe. 2 Relibo.
They sacrificed.
2 Supplicabatur, impers.
Sacrificed. 2 Libatus, macta­
ctus, p.
A sacrificer. 1 Immolator, m. 
sacricola, com. g. popa, m.
A sacrificing. 1 Sacrificatio, 
immolatio, piatio, 2 libatio.
A sacrifice. 1 Sacrificium, pia­
men, piamentum, supplicium
2 Libamen, libamentum, sa­
crum, n. victima, hostia, 
3 Haruga, f.
A sacrifice killed, and laide on
the aultar. 1 Holocaustum, 
3 Holocaustoma, n.
A kinde of sacrifice which was
done secretly in the honour of
the Goddesse Bona.
1 Damium, n.
A sacrifice pleasing God.
1 Litatio, propitiatio, f.
A sacrifice for sinne.
1 Piaculum, n.
A sacrifice to obtaine victory
of our enemies. 1 Hostia, vi­
ctima, f.
A sacrifice for a victory recea­
ved. 3 Charisterium, n.
A sacrifice wherby the mariage
of priests was confirmed, vide 
mariage. 
A sacrifice made in the winter, 
or spring time. 1 Daps, f.
Sacrifice killed in the seconde
place, where the former did not
appease their gods.
1 Succedaneæ hostiæ.
A black sacrifice that was of­
fered at noone day. 1 Medialis.
Sacrifice done to the infernall
Gods. 1 Inferiæ, f.
The sacrifice of Bacchus done
every third yeare.
1 Orgia, trieterica, n.
A sacrifice done by the priestes
of the Gentiles.
2 Flaminia, orum, n.
A sacrifice of wine to Bacchus
2 Libatio, f.
Sacrifices made to Bacchus in
the night. 1 Nycteleia, n.
Sacrifices done to Romulus.
1 Quirinalia, n.
Sacrifice of those beastes
which chewe their cud.
1 Ruminales hostiæ.
Sacrifices dedicated to the God
of loue. 1 Eleutheria, n.
Sacrifices offered to the God­
desse Furina. 1 Purinalia, n.
A sacrifice made of many mens
offrings. 1 Collativum, n.
A sacrifice for the field with a 
sowe great with farrowe.
1 Ambarvalis hostia.
A sacrifice when the beast that
is offered goeth about the citty.
1 Amburbiale, amburbium.
sacrifices first instituted for the
slaughter of an hundred enemies
1 Hecatomphonia, orum, n.
A kinde of sacrifice which was
done by women only in a se­
cret place, neither was it lawful
for any man, to be present.
1 Opertum bonædeæ.
Sacrifices done to Ceres.
1 Initia, initiamenta, n.
A sacrifice of an hundred
beastes.
1 Hecatombe, f.
A sacrifice made of a beane to
the Gods for good lucke of corn
1 Refriva, f.
Sacrifices yearly done for the
partes of beasts next the taile
for the Bishops. 1 Canæ, cania­
res hostiæ, f.
A sacrifice of the eares of corne
first gathered after raine.
1 Primetium, n.
Sacrifice done to Hercules, of
those that were to take a journy
1 Proptervia auspicia, prop­
tervium sacrificium.
The beast killed in sacrifice for
victory.
1 Hostia, victima, f.
He that selleth beastes for sa­
crifice. 1 Victimarius, m.
The place where sacrifice was
done. 1 Libatorium n.
Things done before sacrifice.
1 Prothymata, n.
They that vsed among the Ro­
manes to kil beasts for sacrifice.
1 Agones, m. sacrificus, ad.
Belonging to sacrifice.
1 Sacrificalis, propitiatorius.

addico, memoro, narro, per­
hibeo, loquor, eloquor.

tedico.
To say by hart. 1 Pronuncio.
To gainesay. 1 Contradico, 
obmurmuro, reclamo, oblo­
quor, refragor, 2 Repugno, 
oppugno, occino, obsisto, 
abnuo.
To saie moreover. 1 Superdico
To saie againe that was saide.
1 Repeto, vide rehearse. 
They saie. 1 Fertur, aiunt, fe­
runt, prædicant, clamitant, 
sermo est, 2 Traditur, imper.
It is a common saying. 1 Tri­
tum est, pervulgatum est, vul­
go dicitur, vulgo circumfertur
To saie nothing. 1 Taceo, reti­
ceo, conticeo, 2 Celo.
To saie nay. 1 Nego.
To saie nay often. 1 Negito. 
2 Reculo, vide deny. 
To saie wel of one. 1 Benedico.
To saie ill of one. 1 Maledico.

Saide. 1 Dictus, p.
Saide before. 1 Supradictus, p.
A saying. 1 Locutio, dictio, 
vox, f. dictum, n.
A saying againe. 2 Reiteratio.
That is to saie. 1 Id est.
That is to saie, that is to wit.

The saile of a ship. 1 Velum, n. 
artemon, 2 Carbasus, m. car­
basa, linteum, n.

winde is weake.

That beareth saile. 1 Veliser.

intinctum, n. intinctus, m.

Sause vsed in olde time.

tenea, f.
Sause made of Oliues.

Sweete sauses. 1 Hedysmata.

bitche, when shee desireth the

S ANTE C.

To make full of Scabbes. 
2 Vlcero.
Scabbed, or scalde.
1 Scabiosus, 2 scabrosus, ad.
A kinde of scabbe, which brea­
keth out at certaine times of the
yeere, & is very hard to heale.
1 Agria, f.
A scabbe among sheepe.
1 Mentigo, f.
The scabbe in lambes & kiddes, 
about their mouthes, being dead
lye vnto them while they are
sucking. 1 Ostiga, f.

To saile over the Sea.

quor, Marmor, Salum, Vadum

2 Liquentes campi.
The maine sea. 1 Altum, n.

the sea. 1 Hadria, f.
The sea bordering vpon Pontus, 
or generally the sea.
1 Pontus, m.
The sea which compasseth the
earth. 1 Oceanus, m.
The bottome of the sea, or the
maine sea. 1 Pelagus, n.
An arme of the sea.
1 Æstuarium, n.
The sea banke, shoare, coast, or
side. 1 Littus, Litus, m. Ora ma­
ritima.
The sea coast. 1 Acta, f.
A sea bancke. 1 Ægialus, Ag­
ger, m.
The flowing of the sea.
Æstus Maris. 
Accessus Maris.
The ebbing of the sea.
Maris Recessus, 
Maris Recipro catio. 
Mare Refluum,

vide coale.

Which belongeth to the sea.

or side.

rius, ad.

partly to the land.

That commeth from beyond sea
1 Transmarinus, ad.
Betweene two seas.
1 Bimaris, ad.
Both by sea and land.
2 Velis, equisque.

welles
1 Putearius, m.
A searcher of watches.
2 Circuitor, m.
A search, or searching.
1 Scrutinium, n.
A searching.
1 Scrutatio, inquisitio, con­
quisitio, disquisitio, quæstio, 
quæsitio, f. quæsicus, m. specu­
latio, investigatio, spectatio.
A searching out.
1 Indagatio, examinatio, f.
A diligent search. 1 Indago
exploratio, indagatio, f.
Pertaining to search.
1 Exploratorius, ad.
With diligent search.
1 Perquisite, explorate, explo­
rato, adu. vide seeke.

To Seare, or marke
with a hote iron
1 Inuro, cauterio, vstulo.
To seare cloth, or silkes.
1 Cero.
Seared. 1 Torridus, ad. inustus, 
vstulatus, cauteriatus, p.
Seared as cloth is. 1 Ceratus, p.
Such a searing.
1 Ceratura, f.
A seare cloth.
1 Ceratum, cerotum, n.
A searing. 1 Vstio, vredo, vstu­
latio, f.
A searing iron.
1 Cauterium, n.
A seared, or dead bough.
1 Ramale, n.
A searing, or burning of corne, 
about the caniculer daies with
drought, or heate.
1 Siriasis, f.

Season, or possession. 
1 Possessio, f.

son meate.

A seasoning.

ditus, m. condimentum, n.

Season, or time con­
venient. 
1 Tempestivitas, f. 2 Tempus.
A seasonable time.
1 Tempestas, f.
A season, daie, or time.
1 Dies, m. et f.
Out of season. 1 Intempestivus
importunus. 2 Immaturus, ad.
In season. 1 Opportunus, tem­
pestivus, ad.
In good time, or season.
1 Tepestive tempore, tempo­
ri, opportune. 2 Mature, ius
rime, vel issime, expectate.
In very good season.
1 Peropportune, adu.
Not in season.
1 Inopportune, intempestive
2 Immature, adu.
In the meane season.
1 Interea, adu.

A Seate. 
1 Sedes, hedra, f. sedile, n.
A seate, or bench of marble.
1 Abacus, m.
A seate in a porch, or other such
like place.
1 Præstega, f.
A iudgement seate.
1 Tribunal, n.
The seate of a great office.
1 Puteal, n.
The seat of estate for king, prince
or potentate.
1 Solium, n.
Seates for gentlemen to beholde
solemne sights, or plaies.
1 Equestria, orum.
A seate, or the seates in a barge, 
boate, or ship, wherein the mari­
ners do sit. 1 transtrum, transtra
jugum, remigum, sedilia, n.
Seates, or benches, whereon men
sate in the theatre, or iudges in
courtes. 1 Subsellium, et subsel­
lia, orum, n.
A seate, or seates where one one­
ly may sit.
1 Sella, f.
A seate whereon two may sit.
1 Bisellium, n.
A little seate.
1 Sedicula, f.

The Second,
v: num­
bers.
The second ward in battell, wher
in were both noble men, and the
principall souldiers. 1 Principia, orum.
That is don secondly, or next af­
ter a principall matter.

Secondly. 1 Secundo. 2 dehinc
iterum, adu.
Every second yeare.
2 Alternis vicibus.

Seconde, a certaine
drincke so called, made of grapes, 
after they be new pressed. 
1 Lorea, lora, f.

strum, n. secessus, seductus, m

of.
1 Tacitus, mysticus, obscurus,

roome. 1 Penetralis, ad.

To See. 
1 Video, cerno, tuor, tueor, 
contueor, intueor, intuor, as­
picio. 3 Specio.
To see to. 1 Consulo, curo.
To see to diligently. 1 pervideo
To goe to see. 1 Viso, proviso.
To goe, or come oft to see. 1 visito
To see but a little, or be halfe
blinde. 1 Cæcutio.
To fore-see. 1 Prævideo, præspi­
cio, prospicio.
To see cleere, or see through.
1 Concerno, perspicio, per­
spicor, transvideo. 3 Specito.
To see farre of, or from far. 1 pro­
spicio, prospecto, speculor.
To see looking downeward.
1 Despicio.
They went to see. 1 Visitur, imp.
It is seene.
1 Cernitur, impers.
Seene. 1 Visus.
Seene of all men.
2 Pervulgatus, p.
Not seene. 1 Inaspectus, ad.
A seeing. 1 Visio, f.
They that see better at even then
at noone.
1 Nastitiosi, m.
He that seeth in the day time
well, in the euening a little, at
night nothing at all.
1 Nyctalops, com. g.
Busie to see, or spie a fault in an
other man.
1 Cernulus, m.
Eies that can see by night.
2 Felinei oculi.
A thing that is, or may be seen.
2 Objectum, n.
A thing to be seene, and looked
on. 1 Spectamentum, n.
That may, or can be seene.
1 Visibilis, conspicuus, ad.
Belonging to seeing.
1 Specularis, ad.
That seeth clearely.
1 Occulatus, issimus, ad.
See him. 1 Eccum, adu.
See her. 1 Eccam. 3 eccistam.
See, loe, or behold.
1 En, ecce, adu.

To bring forth Seed. 
1 Semento.
Seede. 1 Semen, seminium, n
Satus, m.
Seede sowen, or seede time.
1 Sementis, f.
Wormeseede.
1 Semen lumbricorum.
A small seede growing in Syria, 
like parsly, and it is blacke, hoat, 
and long. 1 Sison.
The seede of Lentiscus.
1 Murciolum, n.
The seede of an herbe growing
in Egypt, which being soked in
water, is good for the eies.
1 Acacalis.
A woman that gathereth, and
preserveth the seedes of herbes.
1 Seminaria, f.
Naturall seede wherof things
are engendred. 1 Sperma, n. ge­
nitura, genitiva, f. Vrina geni­
talis, genitale semen.
The fluxe of naturall seede of
man, or woman vnwittingly.
1 Gonorrhæa, f.
The issue of the seede in sleepe.
1 Onoraganos.
Belonging to seede. 1 Seminalis. 
seminarius, ad.

To Sell, or set to sale. 
1 Vendo, vendito, venundo, 
commutare pecunia.
To sell often. 1 Vendito.
To sell openly, or set out to sale, as
in faires. 1 Nundinor.
To sell by port sale, or to him that
biddeth most. 1 Auctionor, Pro­
scribo.
To sell any thing in time of war
setting vp a speare, or javeline af­
ter the maner.
1 Subhasto.
To sell, or make awaie his title to
an other.
1 Mancipo, Emancipo.
To sell a thing to him of whome
it was first bought.
1 Remancipo.
To sell to diverse persons or in
diverse parcels.
1 Divendo.
To sell wine and other victualles.
1 Cauponor.
To buie at the first hand, to sell
againe by retaile.
1 Promercor.
To trimme thinges to the sale.
1 Mangonizo.
To set vp a bill of a house to bee
solde.
1 Ædes proscribere.
To be sold, or set to sale.
1 Veneo, vendor.
To be sold againe.
1 Reveneo.
Sold. 1 Venditus, venundatus.
Sold away, or given over to the
power of an other.
1 Mancipatus, p.
Any thing solde, set to sale, or
that one will sell, after he hath
sufficiently stored himselfe, and his
houshold therewith.
1 Promercalis, ad.
Set out, or proclaimed to be sold.
1 Proscriptus, p.
That is set aside to be solde.
1 Promercium, n.
He that buieth at the best hand
to sell againe for vantage.
1 Propola, m.
A seller. 1 Venditor, m.
A great seller, or that gladly sel­
leth.
1 Vendax, com. g.
He that selleth away his title to
an other. 1 Emancipator, m.
He that selleth by whole sale.

wares. 2 Impostor, m.

givendus, m.

mitto, dimitto, Ablego, relego

or over from one place to an other.

sum mitro.

pose. 1 Immitto.

go.

A Sentence, decree, or iudgment

tentia, f. 2 Diagramma, n.
A little, or short sentence.

clausula, f. Apophthegma, 2 ver­
bum incisum, n.
A Sentence prooved.
1 Axioma, n.
A sentence proposed, containing
the summe of that we will speak
1 Propositio.
A Sentence, when one thing is
ment, and another spoken.
1 Noema, n.
A hard, and darck Sentence.
1 Problema, n.
A perfect sentence.
1 Periodus, m.
A subtill and crafty sentence.
1 Sophisma, n. 3 Scirpi, aliquan­
do sirpi.
A short sentence exhorting to
vertue, or perswading to vice, 
with the authours name added.
3 Chria, f.
A sentence contrived in foure
verses.
1 Tetrastichon, n.
Proper and trimme vtterance of
a sentence.
1 Eloquutio, f.




Where two sentences, are like in
length. 1 Isocolon, n.
A sentence added in the ende of
a thing declared, or proved.
1 Epiphonema, n.
A sentence spoken with such af­
fectation of witte, or gravitie, 
that it seemeth foolish.
1 Oxymoron, n.
A space between full sentences in
writing, or printing.
1 Interductus, m.
Full of sentences. 1 sententiosus
Sententiously. 1 Sententiose.

A Sequele, or that
which necessarily followeth. 
1 Sequela, consequentia, f. 
consequens, n. 2 Connexio, 3
Consequiæ, f.

To Sequester, or to
put into ones handes
as indifferent. 
1 Sequestro.
Such a sequestration.
1 Sequestratio, f.

A Sergeant to arrest. 
1 Lictor, apparitor, stator, 2 sa­
telles, accensus, m.
A sergeant at armes.
1 Stator, m. 2 ductor ordinum.
A sergeant of a band. 1 Ductor
ordinum, 2 præpositor, præpo­
situs, m.
A sergeant, beedle, or other like
officer that warneth men to ap­
peare, or assemble.
2 Viator, m.
A sergeant of a bands office.
2 Præpositura, f.
Pertaining to a sergeant.
1 Lictorius, ad.

That speaketh Seri­
ouslie.

nest.

vide preach. 
A sermon. 2 Sermo, m. homilia

A Serpente. 
1 Serpens, python. m. serpulla.
A water serpent, vide snake. 
A serpente living by the milke
of Rudder beastes. 1 Boos, m.
A serpent that abideth as well
on the land, as in the water.
1 Chersydros, m.
A serpent having hornes like a 
Ramme, and a very little body.
1 Cerastes, vel is, m.
A serpent whose head being cut
of, there arose three in the place
therof. 1 Excetra, f.
A serpent, having a great and
long body, and a small head, ma­
king a furrow in the ground with
his taile. 1 Pareas, f.
A little leane serpent in Italy.
1 Cicinia, f.
A serpent that the Egyptians
worshipped as a God.
1 Seraphis, & serapis, f.
A serpent that lieth vnder trees
and springing sodainly with
great violence, pearceth every
beast that passeth by.
1 Iaculus, m.
A serpent which being slowe in
creeping, stayeth those with the
marvelous varietie of speckles in
his backe, whom otherwise he could
not overtake.
1 Scitalis, f.
A serpent of a sandie coulour.




1 Obites, m.
A serpente with an head at both
endes. 1 Amphysbæna, amphisi­
bæna, f.
A serpente in India, having a
head whiter then milke, his bodie
of a purple colour, wanting teeth
and that which he vomiteth, con­
sumeth whatsoever it toucheth.
1 Porphyrus.
People that eat serpents.
1 Ophiophagi, m.
Bookes of the nature of serpents.
1 Ophiaca, n.
Which engendreth, or breedeth a
serpent. 1 Draconigena, serpen­
tigena. Anguigena.
That beareth serpents.
1 Serpentiger, 2 Anguitenens
A serpents denne 3 Chya, f.
A serpents skinne. 1 Vernatio, 
1 Exuviæ Serpentis. 
Spolium Serpentis. 
Anguis senecta.
Of a serpent. 1 Serpentinus, 3 o­
phiulcus, ad.

To Serue, act. or doe
service vnto.
1 Servio, asservio, inservio, de­
servio, Subservio, præservio, fa­
mulor, & lo, confamulor.
To serue, or minister.
1 Ministro, subministro, admi­
nistro, vt administrare pocu­
lum to serue drinke. 
To serue humbly.
1 Ancillor, deservio.
To serue for wages. 2 Mereo, me­
reor.
To serue in warre for wages.
1 Latrocinor.
To serue vnder another.
1 Subministro.
To serue, neut, or suffice. 1 sufficio
To serue to the vse. 1 Pertinere
ad. vsum.
To be served. 1 Servior.
A servant. 1 famulus, minister, m
ministra, f. administer, ministra­
tor, m. trix, f. servus, m. serva, f. 
dinconus, 2 Puer, m.
A servant that alwaies follow­
eth his master. 1 Assecla, pedis­
sequus, m. pedissequa, f.
A little servant. 1 Ministercu­
lus, m.
A woman servant. 1 Ancilla, 
serva, ministra, administra.
A servant in the parlour.
1 Tricliniarius, m.
The chiefe servant of the parlour
1 Architriclinus, m.
A servant that goeth to meete
his master, and fetch him where
he is abroad.
1 Adversitor, m.
The chiefe servant of an house.
1 Columella.
A servant that is made over
from one to an other. 1 ambactus.
A servant that alwaies serveth
one master. 1 Perenniservus, m
A false servant. 1 Psendolus, m
A servant that hath charge of
the houshold stuffe.
1 Servus suppellecticarius.
An vnder servant. 1 Submini­
strator, 2 Vicarius, m.
A servant, or servantes alwaies
readie at commaundement. 1 sta­
tor, 2 Calatores, m.
A servant that did binde and
scourge others at the commaun­
dement of his master. 1 Lorarius
Servantes out of wages.
1 Exauctorati, m.
A servitor, or he that serveth at
the table. 1 Diætarius, discifer, 
dapifer, discophorus, m. mini­
ster mensarius.
A serving man. 1 Acoluthus, m.
One that loveth his servantes.
1 Philodulus, m.
They which executed servile mi­
nisteries to the Romanes.
1 Brutiarij, brutiani, m.
Service. 1 Servitus, servitudo, f
servitium, ministerium, n.
A serving, or service.
1 Ministratio, f.
Service, or honour. 1 Cultus, m.
The service of a bond man, or
slaue. 1 Dulia, f.
A service, or pleasure done vnto.
1 Officium, promeritum, n. 2
Vsus, m. vt mihi magno fuit v
sui, it did me great service. 
Diligent service.
1 Obsequium, n.
The service of god.
1 Latria, f.
The service of houshold servants
1 Famulatus, m. famulatio, f. 
famulitium, famulamen, n.
Vnder service. 1 Subministratus
Service compelled. 1 Angaria, f.
The last service of three sundrie
dishes. 1 Tripatinum, n.
That which is meet for servants
1 Familiarium, n.
Servile behaviour. 1 vernilitas.
Serviceable, or that serveth.
1 Parens, p. officiosus, ad.
Very serviceable. 1 Officiosus, 
obsequibilis, obsequiosus, ad.

liberalis, ad.

To set before. 1 Præpono,

To set nothing by. 1 Nihilifacio, 
floccifacio, vide esteeme.
To set to. 1 Appono applico, 2
adjungo, admoveo.
With great force, or strength to
set, or mooue to.
1 Admolior.
To set againe in his place.
1 Repono.
To set againe in his first place.
1 Restituo.
To set to hire.
1 Loco, eloco, abloco, obloco

To set, or cast out at length.
1 Promico.
To set forth, or commend.
1 Decoro, commendo, v praise
To set aside. 1 Removeo.

to set vpon. 1 Impono, 2 præsigo
To set in.
1 Indo.
To set awry.
1 Distorqueo.
To set out, or forth as in print.




1 Edo, 2 emitto
To set betweene.
1 Intersero, interpono.
To set, or put betweene, as a day, 
or yeare. 1 Intercalo.
To set open to every man that
commeth. 1 Prostituo.
To set wide open. 1 Recludo,
To set abroad, or open.

venture.

1 Oppono.
To set together againe.
1 Reconcinno.

true. 2 Suppono.

To set in a place.

go.
To set in order.

pono, 2 Accommodo.

where one must passe.

1 Novello.
To set out of line and order.
1 Denormo.
To set a tribute, or taxe.

ver.

cusso.

horse doeth. 1 Succutio, succusso
Shaken. 1 Quassus, concussus,

ctus, commotus, convulsus, p

huskes.

To sharpen throughly.

To Shaue. 
1 Compilo, corrado, tondeo
attondeo, rado, 2 Recido.

To Shewe. 
1 Ostendo, monstro, de­
monstro, indico, præbeo, vt
præbere se, to shewe himselfe.
Exhibeo, 2 Profero, tribuo, 
vt tribuere alicui misericor­
diam, reddo, vt reddere cau­
sas, to shewe causes. 
To shew, or declare plainly.
2 Explico.
To shew that is hidden.
1 Commonstro.
To shewe il tidings, or vnplea­
sant, and vnlucky things.
1 Obnuncio.
To shew by a note, or signe.
1 Designo, signo, significo, 
consignifico.
To shew, or put forth. 1 Exero, 
exerto, exinfulo.
To shew, or pretend.
1 Prætendo, 2 assevero.
To shew, or disclose. 1 Defero, 
Vt deferre, causam ad pa­
tronum.
To shew tidings, or newes.
1 Nuncio, annuncio.
To shew, declare, or tell.
1 Narro, 2 Expono, v. declare. 
To shew forth. 1 Expromo.
To shew, or proue. 1 Comprobo
To shew, or represent. 1 Præsto.
To shew before. 1 Præmonstro
prænarro, prænuncio. 
3 Antedico.
To shew before what shal follow
1 Prædivino.
To shew evidently. 1 demonstro.
To shew abroad. 1 Vulgo.
To shew often, as to shewe for
vaine glory. 1 Ostento.
To shew with ones finger.
1 Indigito.
To shew it selfe. 2 Eniteo, efful­
geo.
To shew one fully his good will, 
and readines to doe a thing.
1 Voluntatem alicui emetiri
To set to shew to be sold.
2 Expono.
Shew, or tel me. 1 Cedo, desec
Shewed. 1 Commonstratus, 
ostentus, exhibitus, præbitus
2 Prolatus, p.

p. vide declared.

1 Exertus, p.

A shewer. 1 monstrator, index

shal follow. 1 Præmonstrator

To Shine, glitter, or
glister. 1 Mico, corusco, ful­
geo, confulgeo, luceo, collu­

dio, 2 Ardeo, flagro, 3 Lucino, 
niseo.
To shine, or shine against.
1 Affulgeo.
To make to shine, or glitter.
2 Crispo.
To shine vpon. 1 Alluceo, su­
perfulgeo.
To shine against, or about.
1 Obradio.
To shine before. 1 Præradio, 
præfulgeo, præluceo.
To beginne to shine. 1 Fulgesco
splendesco, lucesco.
To shine betweene.
1 Interluceo, intermico, in­
terniteo.
To make shining.
1 Fulgido.




To shine againe. 1 Refulgeo, re­
splendeo, reniteo, reluceo.
To shine like starres. 1 Stello.
To shine, or make to shine like
gold. 1 Rutilo.
To shine in a morning. 3 auroro
To shine about. 1 circumfulgeo
To shine somwhat, or giue a little
light. 1 Subluceo.
To shine out. 1 eniteo, enitesco.
To shine through. 1 Transfulgeo
transluceo, pelluceo perluceo
transniteo, compelluceo
To shine together. 1 Colluceo.
To shine, or cast forth brightnes
like the sunne. 1 Radio.
To shine bright, or cleare. 1 Efful­
geo, polluceo, præfulgesco, præ­
nitesco, præniteo, præfulgeo, 
refulgeo, reluceo, renideo, re­
niteo, renidesco, resplendeo, 
perluceo, pelluceo, explendeo
To shine al over. 1 Fulguro.
A shining. 1 Fulgor, splendor, 
m. micatio, micatura, f. mica­
men, n. 3 Fulguritas, f.
Shining. 1 Coruscus, fulgidus.
Shining, red like gold.
1 Rutilus, 2 Rutilatus, ad.
A shining in such sort, that one
may see through.
1 Translucidus, pertranslucidus

1 Prælucidus, ad.
Shining through, or very much.
1 Perlucidus, pellucidus, ad.
Shiningly. 3 Faculenter.

A shippe, or vessell for passage
that goeth with oares and sailes
together.

A Shore shippe, or smal barke to
saile neare to the shoare.

that pirates did vse. 1 myoparo.

prætoria.
a certaine shippe in Athens wher­
in went men to Delos every year

1 Opificina, artificina, fabri­
ca, taberna, f.
A shoppe-keeper. 1 Officina­
tor, Tabernarius, m.
The foreman of a shoppe.
2 Institor, m.
A little shoppe made of boards.
1 Tabernaculum, n.
An apothecaries shoppe.
1 Pharmacopolium, n.
A shoppe for fishe. 1 Piscina, f.
A smithes shoppe.
1 Ferraria officina.
A stationers shoppe.
1 Bibliopolium, n.
A shop let out for yeerly rent.
1 Taberna meritoria.
A shoppe where sweete oint­
ments be solde.
1 Seplasia, f. seplasium, n.
A goldsmithes shoppe.
1 Aurificina, f.
Belonging to shops, or working
houses. 1 Tabernarius, ad.

A Shore, or banke
of the sea. 
1 Littus, n. vide sea.

To Shore, or prop
vp. 1 Pedo, statumino.
Shored, or propped vp.
1 Fultus, 2 nixus, p.
A shore, or prop. 1 Fulcimen­
tum, n. vide Proppe.

Shorne, vide sheare.

To Shorten, or ab­
breviate. 1 Brevio, v. abridge. 
To shorten, or diminishe.
1 Curto, decurto.
To keepe short. 2 Cohibeo.
To shorten a journey.
1 Contrahere iter. 
Reprimere iter. 
Compensare iter. 
Coarctare iter.
To shorten the way.
1 Corripere spatium.
Shortned.
1 Decurtatus, 2 contractus, p.
Short, or cut short.
1 Præcisus, concisus, p.
Shortnesse.
1 Brevitas, angustia, angu­
stiæ, f. vt angustiæ temporum.
Shortnesse of speech.
1 Brachylogia, f.
A cutting short.
1 Concisio, f.
A shortening.
1 Concisio, 2 contractio, f.
Shortnesse of breath.
1 Anhelitus angustia.
A short space of time.
1 Viecula, f.
A short race, terme, or space of
time. 1 Curriculum, n.
A short forme of speaking.
1 Breviloquentia, f. brevi­
loquium, n.
A short forme of speech, contai­
ning much matter.
1 Laconismus, m.
A short abridgement, vide a­
bridgement. 
Short in height.
1 Brevis, pusillus, curtus, ad.
Short, as in speech. 1 Brevis, 
compendiarius, compendio­
sus, brachos, ad. circumscrip­
tus, 2 pressus, succinctus, p.
Somewhat short. 1 Brevicu­
lus, breviusculus, ad.
Very short, or little.
1 Perbrevis, perexiguus, per­
exilis, ad.
Short winded, or breathed.
1 Suspiriosus, ad.
That killeth in short time.
1 Solstitialis, ad. vt solstitia­
lis morbus, a disease, &c. 
Shortly, briefely, or in fewe
wordes. 1 Breviter, præcise, 
comprehense, compendia­
rio, attenuate, districte, cir­
cumscripte, adu.
Very shortly, or as soone as can
be. 1 Quamprimum, adu.
Shortly, or within a while.
1 Cito, propediem, adu.
Shortly, or in short time.




1 Brevi, adu.
Shortly after.
1 Paulo post, mox. adu.
To be short. 1 Ad summum, adu.

To Shoute, or make
a shout, or crie. 1 Conclamo, ac­
clamo, acclamito, succlamo.
To shoute for ioy. 1 Iubilo, 
conjubilo.
A shouter, or crier out.
1 Acclamator, m.
A shouting. 1 Conclama­
tio, acclamatio, f. clamor, m.
A shoute, or crie in the Ro­
mane armye. 1 Barbaricum, n.
A shout of the Romane souldi­
ers, when both armies ioned to­
gether. 1 Barritus, m.
A shoute for ioy. 1 Iubilatio, 
f. jubilatus, 2 plausus, m.
The shouting, or noise that ma­
riners make when they doe anie
thing together, as when they
drawe vp the anker, or when
the Master doth call and en­
courage them.

A Shrubbe. 
1 Frutex, f. arbustum, n.
A shrubbe having a leafe like a
bay, a flower like a rose.
1 rhododaphne, rhododendros
A shrubbe called Tamariske, vi.
heath.
A shrubbe apt to hedge with.
1 Halimus, n.
The shrubbe somewhat hat hearby.
1 Therionarcha, f.
A shrubbe growing in Asia, the
iuice wherof is good against poi­
son.
1 Emboline, n.
A shrubbe that beareth a yeal­
low flower, and is vsed to binde
vines it is taken for broome.
1 Genista, f.




That hath a meane betweene a 
shrub, and a herbe.

A shrub like to mirtles.

cetum, n.

2 Languesco, elanguesco, lan­
gueo, elangueo, laboro.

To be sicke of a fever.
1 Febricito.
To be sicke in bed.
2 Cubo, decumbo.
Sicknes, or disease of the bodie.
1 Morbus, languor, m. vale­
tudo, invaletudo, ægritudo, 
ægrotatio, 2 Infirmitas, f. 
Malum, vitium, n.
An effect following any sicknes
1 Symptoma, n.
Contagious sicknes.
1 Contagio, f. contagium, n.
A sicknes of infants which com­
meth by sucking the first milke, 
or beestings.
1 Colostratis, colostratio, f.
They that haue that sicknes.
1 Colostrati.
A sharpe sicknesse which doth
quickly dispatch, or deliver.

Præceps morbus.

An hungry sicknesse.
1 Caninus appetitus.
A long sicknesse.

ful of water.

away all sensiblenesse from the

The falling sicknes.

nes. 1 Epilepticus, 3 caduarius

1 Cano, canto, psallo, pan­
go, panxi, 2 modulor.

To sing againe.

To sing for ioy. 2 Ovo.

2 Pæanem citare.
To sing to the end. 1 Percino.
To faine in singing. 1 Incino.
To sing tuneablely. 1 Modu­
lor, admodulor, emodulor, 
modulo, 2 meditor,
To sing aloude. 1 Procino.
To sing a part with others.

To sing before, or beginne the
song. 1 Præcino.
To sing softly. 1 Cantillo.
To sing the base.
1 Succino, succento.
To sing the tenor. 1 Decanto.
To sing to, or against, or the con­

to, occano, occanto.
To sing betweene, or to sing a 
mean. 1 Intercino, intercento
To sing the treble. 1 Discino, 
discento, 3 minurio, minurizo.
To sing the plaine song.
1 Mimo observire.
To sing as the nurse doth to her
childe. 3 Lallo.
To sing cheerefully as birdes do.
2 Verno.
To sing as a swan doth.
1 Drenso.
A singer, or singing man.
1 Cantator, psaltes, cantor, 
2 aulædus, 3 choricanus, pa­
sistonus, m.
A sweete singer.

Sweete singing.

1 Cantrix, cantatrix, psaltria
percantatrix, 2 fidicina, f.
A singer to the harpe.
1 Psallocitharista, lyricen, 
lyristes, m.
A singer of descant.




1 Incentor, m.
A man which teacheth to sing.
1 Phonascus, m.
He which beginneth the song.
1 Præcentor, 2 mesochorus, m
He that singeth the base.
1 Succentor, m.
He that singeth the tenor.
1 Decantator, m.
He that singeth the counter te­
nor. 1 Occentor, m.
He that singeth the meane.
1 Intercentor, m.
He that singeth the treble.
1 Discentor, m.
Those that sing in the church
on both sides the quier.
1 Psalmodi, 3 Antipsalmodi.
A singer like a sheepheard.
3 Opunculo, m.
A singer of delicate, or merrie
songs. 1 Hilarædus, m.
A singing. 1 Cantatio, f.
A singing in tune.
1 Concentus, m. concentio, f.
A singing in measure.
1 Modulatus, m. modulatio, f
modulamen, n.
A singing to instruments, or a
singing together of Psalmes.
1 Psalmodia, f.
A singing before, 1 Præcanta­
tio, f. antecantamentum, n.
The base in a song. 1 Basis, f. 
bassus, succentus, m.
The tenour. 1 Tenor, cantus.
The countertenour.
1 Contratenor, occentus, m.
The meane. 1 Medius, inter­
centus, m.
The treble. 1 Discantus, triplex
A song. 1 Cantio, cantilena, 
musa, oda, æ, & ode, es, f. can­

2 Carmen, melos, n. modulus
versus, m. camæna, f.
Songs. 1 Mele, n.
The measure, time, rest, or pause
in singing. 1 Modi, m.
A song to God.

A song made to Apollo. 1 pæan.
A song in the honour of Bac­
chus. 1 Dithyrambus.
A song at a bridal, or mariage
1 Hymeneus, m. talassio, tha­
lassio, f. thalassus, m. epithal­

A little song. 1 Cantiuncula.
A song which the nurse singeth
in dandling the childe.
1 Lallatio, fascinina, f.
A song to the harpe. 1 Lyrica,

lyricum.
A song wherein many sing to­
gether. 1 Choreuma, n.

lone. 1 Monodia, f.
A lamentable, or mourning
song. 1 Elegia, threnodia, f. 
threnum, n. threnos.
A lamentable song at the death
of one. 1 Nænia, f.
A song in the commendation of
a mans vertue.

A composer, or setter of songs.

The compasse of a song. 1 systema
A place in the house appointed
for singers. 1 Odæum, n.
That can sing any thing.

deo, assido.

2 Adhæreo.

To cover, or stoppe with
Skinne.  
1 Pelliculo.
Skinned, or clad with skinne.
1 Pellitus, p.
A skinner. 1 Pellio, m.
A skinne. 1 Pellis, cutis, f. 
3 Corium, n corius, m.
The skinne of a beast. 1 Cori­
um, scortum, tergus, n. byrsa, 
2 Exuviæ, f. 3 Tergum, n.
A little skinne. 1 Cuticula, 
pellicula, f. coriolum, n.
The foreskinne of a man.
1 Præputium, n.




The third skinne that covereth
the eies. 1 Rhagoides.
The skinne that covereth the
skull 1 Pericranium, n.
The skin that compasseth that
skin wherein the child is wrap­
ped: the filme.
1 Alantoides membrana.
The thinne soft skinne that
wrappeth the child in the womb
1 Amnium, n.
A skinne in the secret parts of
a maid, that breaketh when she
is defloured. 1 Hymen, n.
The thinne skinne that wrap­
peth the braine. 1 Pia mater, 
meninx, f. omentum, n.
The skinne growing from the
corner of the eie, and in conti­
nuance covering the sight.
1 Pterygium, n.
The outward skinne of the body.
1 Epiderpius, m.
The skinne that covereth the
rib within. 1 Succingens
membrana.
The vttermost skinne of the eies
1 Superagnata tunica.
When the skinne of the finger
is loose from the naile.
1 Reclivia; orum, reclivium.
The vppermost part of any
thing. 1 Membrana, f.
The skin of serpents which they
cast off every yeare when they
waxe olde. 1 Reduviæ, leberis
2 Vernatio, f. senium, n. spo­
lium serpentis.
The outward skin of the coddes, 
wherein be the stones of a man.
1 Scrotum, n.
Where the skinne of the eie by
some stroke is so hurt, that the
bloud sodenly spreaddeth over
the eie. 1 Hyposphagma, n.
A litle thinne skin compassing
the bone in any part of the body
1 Periostion, n.
The skin of a fallow Deare.
1 Nebris, f.
The skinne, or pil of any fruite.
2 Calyx.
Having a thicke skinne.
1 Callosus, ad.
Betweene the skinne and the
flesh. 1 Subcutaneus, intercus
intercutaneus, ad.
That hath a new skinne.
1 Recutitus, p.
Of skinnes. 1 Pellicus, pellice­
us, scorteus, coriaceus, ad.
That changeth his skinne often.
1 Versipellis, ad.

To Sleepe. 1 Dormio, 
dormisco addormio, addor­
misco, 2 quiesco, requiesco.
To beginne to sleepe.
1 Dormisco, addormisco.
To bring asleepe. 1 Sopio, 
consopio, soporo.
To make sleepy. 1 Torporo.
To lie downe to sleepe.
1 Discubo, discumbo.
To sleepe againe. 1 Redormio.
To sleep at noone. 1 Meridio.
To sleepe often. 1 Dormito.
To sleepe vpon. 1 Indormio.
To sleepe fast, or soundly.
1 Obdormio, obdormisco.
To digest by sleepe.
1 Edormio, edormisco.
To sleepe a full sleepe: to sleepe al
night long. 1 Perdormisco.
To sleepe all night with one.
2 Pernocto.
To haue ones senses asleepe, or
benummed. 1 Torpeo, obtor­
peo, obtorpesco.
To rise from sleepe. 1 Desopio.
Laied a sleepe. 1 Sopitus, con­
sopitus, sopotatus, p. soporus.
A sleeper. 1 Dormitator, dor­
mitor, condormitor, m.

one roofe. 1 Homohypni, m.
Sleepe. 1 Somnus, m 2 quies.
A dead sleepe. 1 Sopor, m. 
cataphora, f.
A sleeping place.

thargus, veternus, m.
Sleepie. 1 Somnolentus, som­
niculosus, 3 glirius, gliricus.

nis, 3 exomnis, ad.

semisomnis, semisomnus, ad.
That maketh sleepe. 1 Somni­
ficus, somnifer, soporifer, ad.
Pertaining to sleepe.

A souldier. 1 Miles, com. g. milito

mus, tyro, tyrunculus, m. neote­

miles.
An olde worne souldier able to

A souldier of the fourth band.

Souldiers of the fist band, or legi­

Souldiers set in the rereward, &
were the strongest men.
1 Milites Triarij, 
Milites Strenui.
Souldiers which for some neces­
sitie be sodainely called out of the
field to battell. 1 Evocati, m.
Souldiers so placed in the garison
that they prevent the politike
ambushes of the enemies.
1 Prætenturæ, f.
The aray of souldiers from the
vauntgard, to the reregard, stan­
ding al along. 1 Exercitus, m.
Souldiers strongly harnessed.
1 Crupellarij, m.
A souldier that hath double sti­
pend, or wages.
1 Duplicarius Miles. 
Dupliciarius Miles.
Souldiers at commaundement
and service alwaies in warre.
1 Munificus milites.
Souldiers added to supply the
roome of those that are wanting.
1 Ascriptitij milites.
Souldiers in the garison, either
for defence of the frontires of a
land, or some other part in the
midst of the land. 1 Milites præ­
sidiarij, m.
Souldiers dimissed, that haue
their pasportes.




1 Causarij milites.

he hath leaue. 1 Emansor, m.
The fault which souldiers com­
mitte in so doing.
1 Emansio, f.
A souldier armed at all peeces: 
also a footman souldier armed
with breastplates, and curets.
1 Cataphractarius, m.
Souldiers that in war vsed two
horses, and were wont to leape
from the weary vpon the fresh.
1 Amphippi, m.
A souldier serving at the sea.
1 Incensor, ephibata, m.
A souldier which is alwaies a­
bout the magistrate to doe his
commaundement. 1 Cohortali­
nus, m.
Souldiers which defend the coun­
try.

tires of the empire against the

A Space. 
1 Spatium, n.
A space of time, or place be­
tweene. 1 Intercapedo, f.
A space of the land, or water.
2 Tractus, m.
Every space, or distance either of
time, or place.
1 Intervallum, n.
A space of ground among the
Jewes, containing 4 Italian
miles. 1 Chœmis, f.
The space of two yeares.
1 Brennium, n.
The space of 3 yeares.
1 Triennium, n. trieteris, f.
The space of 4 yeares.
1 Quadriennium, n.
The space of fiue yeares.
1 Quinquennium, n.
The space of 100, after some of
30, after other 1000 yeares.
1 Seculum, seclum, n.
Of, or belonging to such a space.
1 Secularis, ad.
The space of two daies. 1 Biduum.
The space of three daies. 1 Tridu­
um, n.
The space of 4 daies.
1 Quatriduum, n.
The space of 10 daies.
1 Decendium, n.
The space between two thinges
in an order, rew, or ranke.
1 Interordinium, n.
Space between full sentences in
writing, and printing.
1 Interductus, m.
The space over the nose between
the browes.
1 Glabra, glabella, f.
Space between games and recre­
ations.
1 Diludia, n.
The space, as of life, or of an
hower. 2 Curriculum, n.
The space between pillars.
1 Intercolumnium, n.
The space between the shoulders.
1 Interscapilium, n.
The least space of time.
1 Momentum, n.
The space of 1000 paces.
1 Milliare, milliarium, n.
A space of ground containing 12
furlonges.
1 Dolchus, m.
A space of ground containing
60 furlonges, being 7 miles and
a halfe.
1 Schœnos, schœnus, m.
The space between the knottes, or
ioints.
1 Internodium, n.
Space betweene rafters.
1 Intertignium, n.
Space between the vaines in the
earth.
1 Intervenium, n.
Space between the thighes.
1 Interfæmineum, n.
The space and distance between
the earth, and the moone.
1 Tonus, m.
Spatious, or large.
1 Spatiosus, ad.

A Spade, or shovel. 
1 Ligo, m. pala, f.
A spade, or like toole to dig with.
1 Scaphium, n.

A Spaniell, v. dogges

A Spangle, or thinne
peece of silver, or
gold.

A little spangle. 1 Bracteola, f.
Spangled.
1 Clavatus, ad.

To plaie the Spani­
ard, to murder with­
out mercy as the barbarians do. 
1 Hispanizo, barbarizo.

The Spanne from the
thumbs end, to the
fore-fingers end stretched out. 
1 Spithama, orthodoron, Li­
chas, dodrans, palmus.
A Full and perfect spanne.
1 Palmus major.
Of, or belonging to a spanne.
1 Spithameus, ad.

ro.

They spare.

pendium, n.

Sparing. 1 Parcus, compendio­
sus, ad.
Very sparing. 1 Perparcus, par­
cissimus, ad.
Sparingly. 1 Parce, continenter
anguste, adu.

To Speake. 
1 Loquor, Dico, faris, profaris
verbigero, verba fundere, 2
Narro, effero, Refero, crepo, 3
Affabulo.
To speake, or reason.
1 Peroro.
To speake, or vtter.
1 Enuncio.
To speake, or speake out.
1 Eloquor, effaris.
To beginne to speake.
1 Adordire sermonem, in ser­




monem incidere.
To speake to, or with. 1 Allo­
quor, colloquor, compello, ap­
pello, affari, 2 convenio.
To speake out, or aloude.
1 Eloquor, 2 Elatro.
To speake aloud, or terribly.
2 Tono.
To speake off.
2 Tracto, consector.
To speake of, or rehearse.
1 Memoro.
To speake eloquently.
1 Rhetoricor, 2 Eloquor.
To speake malitiously. 2 evomo
To speake faire for advantage.
1 Blandior.
To speake after other thinges, or
in the end. 2 Subtexo.
To speake often.
1 Dictito, loquacito, loquitor
To speake much. 2 Fundo, fun­
dito.
To speake, or report often.
2 Decanto.
To go, or to be about to speake.
1 Dicturio.
To speake without feare, or dissi­
mulation. 1 Edico.
To speake of before.
1 Prædico, 2 preterverto.
To speake angerly. 2 Protono
To speake before, or first.
1 Proloquor, præloquor, præ­
saris, 2 Præeo, 3 Anteloquor.
To speake against one.
2 Contravenio.
To speake softly. 1 Mutio, mus­
so, mussito.
To speake filthily. 1 turpiloquor
To speake out to the end.
1 Perloquor.
To speake fast.
2 Tolutim Loqui. 
Præcipitanter Loqui.
To speake gloriously. 2 Ebullio.
To speake out, to speake al, or to
speake as it is.
1 Eloquor.
To speake against, or contrarie.
1 Obloquor, 2 Obsisto, repug­
no, occino, murmuro, v. gaine­
saie. 
To speake in detraction.
1 Obstrigillo, obstringillo.
To speake all being to speake, or
that wee haue in our minde.
1 Proloquor.
To speake openly, frankly, and
before all the world.
1 ProFiteor.
To speake precisely. 2 Præcido.
To speake in anothers tale.
1 Interloquor.
To speake briefely & succinctly.
2 Perstringo. 
Succinctim Loqui. 
Strictim Loqui.
To speake ill of, vide to slaun­
der. 
To speake coulourably.
2 Prætexo.
To speake doubtfully.
1 Perplexe loqui, 2 Perple­
cor.
To speake at al adventure, or to
speake, or vtter foolishly all that
is in his mind. 2 Effutio.
To speake merily, or in desport, or
iest. 1 Iocor.
To speake merily: also to speake
that which hath some respect to
an other thing. 2 Alludo.
To speake no word, vide to hold
ones peace. 
To speake sharpely, or shrewdly.
1 Argutor.
To speake hastely.
2 Propero.
To speake together.
1 Colloquor, 2 convenio.
To speake troth. 1 Veridico, ve­
riloquor.
To speake with much difficultie.
3 Traulizo.
To speake ill, for ill.
1 Remaledico.
Not to be able to speake, or to
be speechles. 1 Obmutesco.
To speake much, vid  to prattle. 
They speake nothing.
1 Siletur, impers.
To be ill spoken of. 1 Male au­
dire.

1 Mithriaca, n.
The rising of the sunne.
1 Ortus solis, exortus solis.
The setting of the sunne.
1 Devexior dies. 
Occasus solis. 
2 Obitus solis.
The sunne shining. 1 Apricitas, 
f. 2 Sol, m.
The sunne sette, or place where
the sunne setteth 1 Occidens.
The stay of the sunne, when he
can go nether higher, nor lower
1 Solstitium, n.
The staie of the sunne in som­
mer, being the 24 of Iuly.
1 Solstitium Æitivum, 
Solstitium Æstivale,
The stay of the sunne in winter, 
being the 27 of December.
1 Solstitium hyemale.
The eclipse of the sunne.
1 Deliquium solis. 
Ecllipsis solis.
A sunne beame. 1 Radius, m.
Sunne and moone, a play so cal­
led, vide plaie. 
Sunne burning, or the burning
of the sunne.
1 Æstus, m.
Begotten of the sunne.
1 Siligena, com. g.
Sunnie, or open to the sunne.
1 Apricus, ad
Of, or belonging to the sunne.
1 Solaris, ad.
Of, or belonging to the time when
the sunne is at the farthest.
1 Solstitialis, ad.
Having many sunne beames.
1 Radiosus, ad.

To be Superfluous. 
1 Superabundo, superfluo, su­
persum.
To cut off that which is super­
fluous. 1 Deruncino.
It is superfluous 1 Vacat, imp.
Superfluous expending, or wa­
sting. 1 Nepotatus, m.
Superfluous flesh in the corner
of the eie, wherevnto humours
gather.
1 Anchilops, f.
A kinde of speaking, wherein
that which is added is superflu­
ous. 1 Pleonasmus, m.
Superfluity. 1 Superamentum, 
perisseuma, n. 3 Nimietas, f. v.
Excesse. 
A kind of superfluity, or rub­
bish. 1 Retrimentum, recre­
mentum, n.
Superfluous. 1 Superdans, su­
perforaneus, supervacuus, su­
pervacaneus, recrementitius
2 Immoderatus, ambitiosus, 
ad. redundans, p.
Superfluously. 1 Superflue, su­
pervacue, supervacuo, redun­
danter, luxuriose, adu.

1 Superiores, m.

phum, n.

vide Epitaph.

To Suppe, or soupe. 
1 Sorbeo, persorbeo, obsor­
beo, exorbeo, adsorbeo.
To suppe vp againe.
1 Resorbeo.
To suppe often.
1 Sorbillo.
To suppe a little, or to sippe.
1 Pitisso.
Supped cleane off.
1 Absorptus, p.
A supping, or sowping.
1 Sorbitio, f. 2 Haustus, n.
A little supping.
1 Sorbitiuncula, f.
A supping, or broth made to sup
1 Sorbillum, n.
A medicine for a sicke body, to
licke, or suppe. 1 Illinctus, m
Ecligma, vel eclegma, n.

To Suppe, or eate
ones supper. 1 Cœno.
To suppe often. 1 Cœnito.
To haue a desire to suppe.
1 Cœnaturio.
To sup againe. 1 Recœno.
To make a short supper.
1 Subcœno.
To goe supperles. 1 Incœno.
Supped. 1 Cœnatus, p.




A seeker of a Supper.
1 Cœnipeta, m.
A supper. 1 Cœna, scen­
sa, 2 vesperna, mensa, f.
A little supper. 1 Cœnula, 
3 vespertina, f.
A supper at home in a mans
owne house.
1 Domicœnium, neut.
A supping garment, or roabe.
1 Cœnatorium, n.
A supping place, or parlour.
1 Cœnaculum, n. cœnatio, 
2 cœna, f.
A supping together. 1 Syndip­
num, n. concœnatio, f.
Thinges set on the table after
supper. 1 Impomenta.
They which come late to sup­
per. 1 Trechedipni, orum.
A supper made at ones come­
ing home a welcome home.
1 Cœna viatica.
A supper of neighbours, friends, 
or fellowes when everie one
bringeth his messe.
1 Cœna collatitia. 
Cœna collecta.
Suppers among the Lacedemo­
nians, kept openly in the streets
with great temperance.
1 Phiditia, orum.
A hungrie supper, a snatch
and awaie. 1 Hecales cœna.
A reare supper, or banquet af­
ter supper. 1 Pocœnium, n. 
commessatio, f.
Supperlesse. 1 Incœnatus, 
incœnis, ad.
Belonging to a supper.
1 Cœnaticus, cœnatorius, ad

To make Sure, vide
stedfaste.
To be sure. 1 Confido.
To make sure, or put out of
danger.
1 Præstare securitatem.
It is sure, or certaine.
1 Liquet, impers.
He that maketh sure.
1 Firmator, m.
Surenesse. 1 Certitudo, 
firmitudo, stabilitas, fœm. 
firmamentum, n.
Surety, or being sure without
danger. 2 Securitas, f.
Sure holding. 1 Tenacitas, f.
Sure, stable, or stedfaste.
1 Firmus, stabilis, 2 impe­
tritus, ad.
Sure, or safe.
1 Tutus, 2 securus, ad.
Sure, or whereof one maie bee
assured. 2 Cautus, vt quo
mulieri esset res cautior.
That the thing might be sure to
the woman. 
Sure, or that holdeth sure.
1 Tenax, vt tenax memoria.
Sure, trustie, or faithfull.
1 Fidus, fidelis, 2 conjun­
ctus, ad. vt par amicitiæ con­
junctissimum, a couple of most
sure and faithfull friendes. 
Sure, or certaine.
1 Certus, ad. vide certaine. 
Surely, or indeede.
1 Videlicet, porro, atqui, a­
deo, quippe, adu.
Surelie, or fastly.
1 Tenaciter, 2 sideliter, vt fi­
deliter retinere.
Surelie, or stedfastlye.
1 Firme, perseveranter, fir­
miter, constanter, adu.
Surelie, or without all danger.
1 Tuto, adu.

A Suretie, vide
suertie.

A Surgeon. 
1 Chirurgus, vulnerarius, m.
The art of surrgerie.
1 Chirurgia, f.
A surgeons instrument, where­
with the fleshe of the gummes is
parted rounde about from the
teethe, in the toothache.
1 Pericharecter.
An instrumente of surgeons, 
called Pinsers, or made hollowe
like a little spoone, wherewith
gunshot, pellets, or such like is
pulled out. 1 Laureolum, n.
An instrumente of surgerie, 
wherewith they cut out lit­
tle bones, called also Modio­
lus. 1 Chœnicion, neut.
Of, or belonging to surgerie.
1 Chirurgicus, ad.

S ANTE W.

involvo, 3 sparganizo.

Swadling, or swathing cloutes.

crepundia, n.

to tie vp woundes.

to bind childrens knees, to make
their legges straight. 1 Fascia, f.

swage, and mitigate.

or dovoured.

A swallowing in.

or such like. 1 Gurges, masc. 
vorago, f.

A Swallowes taile
in Carpenters worke, which is a
fastning of two peeces of tim­
ber, or boardes so strongly, that
they cannot awaie.

The Sward of bacon. 
1 Cutis lardi.

puffed vp.

tumeo, coarumesco, ex­

meo, intamesco, pertu­
meo, pertumesco, turgeo, tur­
gesco, conturgeo, obturgeo, 
tubero, extubero, protubero
2 Cresco, efflor.
To swel & rise vp in levening
1 Fermentesco.
To make to swel.
1 Tumefacio.
To swel as maidens dugges doe.
1 Sororior.
Swollen 1 Turgidus, tumidus
extumidus, ad. tumefactus, 
2 Inflatus, p.
Somewhat swollen.
1 Turgidulus, ad.
A swelling.
1 Tuber, n. extuberatio, f. 
tumor, 2 Inflatus, m. inflatio
f. 3 Turgor, m.
A swelling, or a bunch.
1 Gibbus, m.
A swelling, or botch.
1 Ceramium, n.
A swelling about a sore, or
wound, very hote, called Saint
Anthonies fire.
1 Erysipelas, n.
A little swelling, or push.
1 Tuberculum, n.
A swelling in the gummes by
the vppermost cheeke teeth.
1 Eupilides.
A swelling, or push in any part
of the gummes.
1 Paralis, f.
A little swelling like a fellon.
1 Phyma, f.
A swelling in the navill.
1 Exomphalon, n.
A swelling in the legs.
1 Cruscumulus, m.
A swelling of the eie lids.
1 Emphisma, n. scleriasis, f.
A swelling of the guttes.
1 Emphisema, n.
A swelling in the fundament
proceeding of an inflammation.
1 Condyloma.
A litle swelling, hard, and red, 
rising chiefly in the crowne of
the head, the armepits, and pri­
vy partes.
1 Phygethlon.
A harde swelling within the
flesh: a kernel.
1 Scirrhas, m. scirrhum, n.
A certaine smelling vnder the
tongue, with an inflammation.
1 Batrachus, m ramela, f.
Litle swellings in the temples of
the head.
1 Dionycissi, orum, n.
Swelling in the legs with over­
much travaile.
1 Tama, f.
Swelling of the fleshe over the
naile 2 Pterygium, m.
Swelling in the eie liddes like a
barley corne.
1 Hordeolum, n.
A moist, and watrish swelling, 
thinne, and without griefe, con­
sisting of a cold intemperature, 
and flegmatike humour.
1 Oedema, n.
A swelling of maidens, or wo­
mens bellies.
1 Molucrum, n.
A swelling in the roofe of the
mouth, a disease called the vual
1 Vvula, f.

2 Fluito.

To swimme to. 1 Adno, adnato

1 Connato.

1 Supernato.
To swimme out. 1 Enato, eno
2 Emergo.
To swimme against. 1 Obnato.
To swimme often.
1 Nato, natito.
To swimme over, beyonde, or
through. 1 Trano, transno, 
transnato, 3 Tranato.
To swimme through.
1 Pernato.
To swimme backe, or againe.
1 Renato.
To swimme in. 1 Inno, innato.
To swimme like a Ducke.
1 Tetrimo.
To swimme, or to be altogether
given to swimming. 2 Fluo, 




denuo, perfiuo, v. perfiuere
voluptatibus, redundo, li­
queo, liquesco.
To be swimme over. 1 Tranor.
A swimmer. 1 Natator, m.
A swimming. 1 Natatus, m. 
natatio, fuctuatio, f.
A swimming place.
1 Natatoria, f. natatorium, 
natatile, n.
A swimming of the heade, with
a kind of moistnes. 1 Vertigo.
That swimmeth. 1 Natati­
lis, natatitius, ad.
Swimming about. 2 Circum­
fluus, ad. perfluens, p.

A Swine. 
1 Sus, com. g. porcus, m.
A little swine. 1 Porculus, 
porcellus, m.
A swine-hearde, or keeper of
swine. 1 Porcarius, suarius, 
subulcus, 3 scrosipaschus, m.
A feeder of swine.
1 Porculator, m.
A wilde swine. 3 Mallis.
Swine halfe wilde.
1 Hybridæ, f.
A swine stie, vid. stie. 
A swines belly stuffed.
1 Scrutellus, m.
Swines greace. 1 Axungia, f.
A seller of swines grease.
1 Axungarius, m.
A swine fed with graines, or o­
ther such like vile thinges.
1 Calvinarius porcus.
Swines dung, or pigges turdes.
1 Succerda, n.
Of swine, or hogges.
1 Suinus, suillus, suarius, ad.
Like a swine.
1 Suatim, adu.

or whippe.

about. 1 Roto.

swinging.

Swinged about. 1 Rotatus, p.
A swinging about.
1 Rotatio, f.

bat to beat flaxe.

vp water. 1 Tollo, tollonus, 
m. tollenon, n.

A Swible of iron, 
which turneth round about. 
1 Vertibulum, n.

Swollen, v. to swell.

Sworne, v. to swear.

1 Distringere ensem. 
Distringere gladium.
To slea with the sworde.
3 Gladio.
A sworde, 1 Ensis, gladius, 
m. machæra, 2 mucio, f. fer­
rum, telum, n.
A little sworde. 1 Gladiolus.
A short sworde. 1 Sica, fœm. 
semispathium, n.
A crooked sword that the Per­
sians vsed. 1 Acinacis, fœm. 
gladius Persicus.
A sworde hanger. 2 Scalmus.
An arming sworde.
1 Xiphomachæra, f. bellato­
rius ensis.
A two edged sworde.
1 Framea, f. gladius anceps.
A two handed, or bastard sword
1 Spatha, spathula, romphæa, 
xiphomachæra, f.
A sword like a sithe, a fauchin, 
or wood-knife.
1 Harpe, f.
A riding sworde.
1 Parazonium, n.
A sworde girdle, vide girdle. 
A sworde plaier, that fought
at the burning, or burying of
one. 1 Bustuarius, m.
A sworde plaier.
1 Gladiator, 3 condo, m.
A plaier at the long sworde.
1 Ludius, m.
A master in feates of armes, 
which teacheth to plaie at the
sworde.
1 Lanista, m.
A sworde bearer.
1 Ensifer, machæroferus, m.
The acte, or feate of fighting
with a sworde.
1 Gladiatura, f.
Pertaining to the fighting of
swordes plaiers.
1 Gladiatorius, ad.
That weareth a sworde.
1 Gladiatus, ad.

A sitting at table.

leaues. 1 Caudex, m.

priest, called Flamen, sitting

the deede. 1 Deprehendo.

To Tatle. 
1 Garrio, vide prattle. 
Tatling women. 1 Scraptæ.

To vse Taverning, or
sell as taverners doe. 
1 Cauponor.
A taverner. 1 caupo, cupo, cau­
pa, cupa, œnopola, tabernari­
us, vinarius, m.
A taverners, or vitlers craft.
1 Cauponaria, f.
A taverne.
1 OEnopolium, n. caupona, f. 
2 Meritorium, n.
A wine taverne.
1 Taberna vinaria.
A little tavern, or tipling howse
1 Cauponula, Tabernula, f.
A taverne, or vitling howse, 
where meate is eaten out of due
season. 1 Popina, f.
A taverne-haunter.
1 Attabernalis, attabernio, po­
pino, Barathro, Ganeo, m.
A haunting of taverns.
1 Popinatio, f.
Pertayning to a Taverners
crafte.
1 Cauponius, ad.
Belonging to tavernes, or tip­
ling howses.
1 Popinalis, ad.

Taught, vide teach.

To Taunt, or checke
with reproch full
woordes. 
1 Convitior, increpo, objurgo
Remaledico, bovinor, contu­
melior, 2 Carpo, mordeo pro­
scindo, sigo, defrico, vellico, 
Dicterijs accipere.
Taunted, or egerlie reproved, or
checked.
1 Increpitus, Objurgatus, pro­
scissus, p.
A Taunter.




1 Convitiator, bovinator, Re­
prehensor, 2 Carptor, m.
A writer of tauntes.

Taunting. 1 Procacitas, f.
A merry taunt, or mocke.
1 Cavilla, cavillatio, f.
Mery tauntes.
1 Dicteria, n
A reprochfull taunte.
1 Contumelia, f. convitium, n.
Tauntes. 1 Silli, orum, m.
A bitter, or biting taunt.
1 Lœdoria, f. sarcasmus, m.
Biting tauntes.
1 Aculei contumeliarum.
That taunteth.
2 Mordax, amarus, ad.
Tauntingly.
1 Procaciter, adu.

of thinne leather.

ther.
1 Alutamen, alutamentum, n.

liquid in aurem alicujus, To
tel one a thing in his eare.

To tell of by waie of admonition

nuit me errati, he told me of my

Tel on the residue.
1 Perge reliqua.
Tell me.
1 Cedo, defect.
I can tel, or I knowe.

cloude falleth, being broken.

iratus, p.

giueth from his heire his lande

A testament all written with
the testatours owne hand.

1 Tuus, a, um.
It is thine. 1 Tuum est.

A Thing. 1 Res, f.
Thinges secret, and vnknowen.
1 Abdita rerum.
A thing committed, or done.
1 Admissum, n.
Any thing. 1 Quicquam, quid­
quam, quicque, quidque.
Something. 1 Aliquid, non nihil
An vnlawfull thing.
1 Nefas, indecl.
Thinges of no value.
2 Quisquiliæ, f.

To Thinke, suppose, 
weene, deeme, or
iudge. 1 Cogito, puto, computo
supputo, deputo, reputo, arbi­
tror, opinor, suspicor, existimo
Sentio, credo, 2 Videor, vt mi­
hi videtur I thinke. duco, vid.
Deeme and suppose. 
To thinke or muse vpon.
1 Meditor, commeditor, repu­
to, commentor, lustrare animo, 
2 Rumino, evolvo, vide Consi­
der.
To thinke earnestly, or invent by
thinking on.
1 Excogito.
To thinke againe, and againe vp
on a thing.
1 Reputo, recogito, contrecta­
re mente, 2 Agito, pertracto.
To thinke, suppose, or faine to
himselfe.
1 Imaginor.
To thinke of before, or premedi­
tate. 1 Præmeditor, præco­
gito.
To thinke now one thing, now a­
nother.
2 Fluctuo.
As I thinke. 1 Vt mihi vide­
tur, vt ego quidem autumo, 
quantum ego ratione & in­
genio consequi possum, vt
mea fert opinio.
How thinke you or what is your
opinion? 1 Quid tibi videtur? 
quid tu censes?
To be thought, or iudged.
2 Colligor.
Thought vpon. 1 Cogitatus, p.
Thought vpon, or invented by
thinking on.
1 Excogitatus, p.
Not thought vpon.
1 Inexcogitatus, p.
Thought, or care. 1 Cogitatio, 
cura, f. cogitutus, m. cogitatum, 
n. 2 Mens, f. Animus, m.
He that thinketh. 1 Opinator, 
Existimator, m.
A thinking. 1 Cogitatio, existi­
mario, opinatio, opinio, f.
A diligent thinking.
1 Reputatio, f.
A thinking vpon. 1 Meditatio, 
Deliberatio, f.
A thinking on before hand.
1 Præmeditatio, f.
That may be thought vpon.
1 Cogitabilis, ad.
Not thought of, or which cannot
be comprehended by thought.
1 Incogitabilis, inopinatus.
After one hath thought, or advi­
sedly.
1 Cogitato, cogitate, consulto
cogitatim, adu.

Third,
vid. numbers. 
To doe any thing the third time. 1 Tertio.
The doing of a thing the thirde
time. 1 Tertiatio, f.
The third part of any thing di­
vided. 1 Triens, m.
Which containeth as much as an
other, and a third part more.
1 Sesquitertius, ad.
The third time, or thrise.
1 Tertio, tertium, adu.

A Thirdendell, vide
measures.

Thirteene, v. numbers.

thirst. 1 Sitio, resitio.

dus, siticulosus, ad.

Thirstilie. 1 Sitienter, adu.

To make Thongs. 
1 Corrigio.
Thonged. 2 Corrigiatus, p.
A thong of leather.
1 Corrigia, f. lorum, n.
A great thong.
1 Loramentum, n.
A thong, or loope which is tied
to a dart to throwe it.
1 Amentum, n.
A thong, or bond to tie a buckler, 
or target.
1 Insertorium, n.
A thong, or lingell, wherewith
the Oxe bow, and yoke are bound
together.
1 Cohum, n.
Thongs. 1 Flagra tauria.
A thong of a dogges skinne.
1 Corrigia canina.
Of, or belonging to a thong.
1 Loreus, ad.

to rid from Thornes.

A thorne. 1 Spina, f.
A sharpe thorne.

A white thorne.
1 Acanthaleuce, f.
A blacke thorne. 1 Spinus, m.
A wilde thorne. 1 Agricantha.
A kinde of thorne, growing in
moiste places.
1 Luma, f.
Moyst places where thornes and
briers growe. 1 Lumetum, n.
Wherewith hese thornes be cut
downe.
1 Lumarius, ad. vt lumaria falx
Sprung vp of a thorne.
1 Spinigena, com. g.
A place where thornes doe grow.
1 Spinetum, n.
Thornie, or full of thornes.
1 Spinosus, ad.
That beareth thornes. 1 spinifer
Thornie, or made of thornes.
1 spineus, ad. vt spinea corona

men do weaue in lintles, or stooles

all. 1 Acia, f. aciarium, n.

na.

sine cute et flacco.

periculum. 
Minas Proponere,

To threaten sore.

nor, eminor, minito, comminor.

tentare arma, to threaten that
they will make warre or to shake

nus in aliquem: or to threaten
with vt intentare aliquid ali­
cui. to threaten one with a 
thing.

Three nights space, or three
nights together. 1 Trinoctium, n
Three in number.

or toole. 1 Tridens, m.

Timber. 1 Durata, 2 lignum, 
n. materia, materies, f. 3 meren­
nium, n.
Any timber to build with.
2 Tignum, n. tignus, m.
any great piece of timber. 3 docus
the vpright pieces of timber in the
inner side, which of some are cal­
led foote stockes. 1 Stamina, n.
A square peece of timber, where­
on Paynims did sacrifice.
1 Molucrum, n.
A rounde peece of timber ha­
ving a leather thong aboute it, 
which turners vse in turning, or
woorking with the wheele.
1 Mamphur.
Timbred, or made of timber.
1 Materiatus, p.
A timbring or worke made of tim­
ber. 2 Materiatio, materiatura
Of, or belonging to timber.
2 Materiarius, ad.
Houses ill timbred.
1 Ædes male materiatæ.

To passe the Time. 
1 Trasigo Tempus, vel 
diem. 
Traduco  Tempus, vel 
diem.  
Traho  Tempus, vel 
diem.  
diem conficere.
To spend time vainely. 1 Fru­
stra tempus conterere.
To obserue the time to take heed
how he bestoweth his time.
1 Recte otia ponere, recte æta­
tem ducere
The time wil trie.
1 Exitus acta probabit.
the time wereth, or passeth away
1 Ætas avolat, ætas effluit. 
fluxum tempus elabitur, Ce­
dit dies.
The time is come. 1 extat tempus.
Time. 1 Tempus, n. chronos, m
dies, ætas, f. 2 ævum, n.
Shorte space of time.
2 Curriculum, n.
The time of 100 yeares, som take
it for 1000 yeares, and some for
30: also age time. 1 Se culum, n.
Time, or leasure.
2 Otium, spatium, n.
Long space of time.
1 Diuturnitas, f.
Every distance of time, or space.
1 Intervallum, n.
A seasonable time: also time.
1 Tempestas, f.
Time convenient, or due time.
1 Tempestivitas, f.
A short time. 1 Tempusculum
The time which is set, or put be­
tweene, that the yeare may agree
with the course of the sunne.
1 Intercalarium, n
The time of night when the cock
croweth wich is the fourth watch
of the night. 1 Gallicinium, n.
Time spared from other necessary
busines.
1 Succisivum Tempus. 
Subsecivum Tempus.
Vacation, or time of ceasing.
1 Vacatio, f.
That commeth in very good time
1 Opportunus, peropportunus
Doone in due, and conveniente
time. 1 Tempestivus, ad.
Pertaining to time. 1 Tempo­
ratius, temporaneus, tempora­
lis, ad.
Of one time. 1 Synchronos, ad.
Which is of one time, and age.
Coætaneus, ad.
In time, or in due season.
1 Tempori, tempore, tempe­
stive, 2 mature, maturine, per­
mature, adu.
For a time. 1 Temporarie, adu.
More timelie, or before time.
1 Temporius, adu.
Of a long time. 1 Diutine, adu.
A long time: a mans life time.
1 Ætatem, adu.
In very good time.
1 Opportune, peropportune, 
commodum, adu.
At this time, or as the worlde
gooth now. 1 Hoc ævo, hoc tem­
poris curriculo, hoc seculo, 
hoc tempore, hac hominum
ætate. 
Hac Tempestate, 
Hac ætate. 
2 Nunc, jam, jamjam, hodie.
At this time, or present.
1 Impræsentiarum, nunc, jam
inpræsens.
In times past 1 Quondam, 
olim, adu temp diebus provi­
me exactis, in diebus, seu men­
sibus prioribus. 
diebus nuperrime elapsis, 
diebus jandudum præteritis
At that time. 1 Tunc, adu.
Out of time. 1 Incommode, in­
opportundo, tempore importuno
Often times. 1 Sæpe, crebro, sæ­
penumero, frequenter, v. often
at what time. 1 quando ecquando
At any time.
1 Vnquam, nuncubi, adu

doque, nonnunquam, adu.

1 Eatenus.
Till what time. 1 Quousque.
In time to come. 1 Deinde.
Of olde time. 1 Antiquitus, ad.
After this time. 1 Dehinc, adu.
At what time soever.
1 Quandocunque, adu.
So many times as.
1 Quotiescunque, adu.
An other time. 1 Alias, adu.
To some place, or time.
1 Aliquousque, adu.

In the meane time.

rea temporis, interim, dum, o­
biter. 2 In transitu.

A Token, or signe.

A token sent. 1 Pignus, n.
A token, note, or marke.
1 Nota, f. character, m. 2 Ve­
stigia, n.
A naturall token, or marke, 
whereby a thing is knowen.
1 Macula, f.
A sure token, or iust occasion.
1 Argumentum, n.
A privie signe, or token whereby
spies, and enemies are discerned
from companions, and felowes in
armes: also a token of lead, lether
or such like.
1 Tessera, f.
Token, or billes of exchange, gi­
ven to men, by which they shall
receaue a certaine som of mony, 
or measure of corne.
1 Tesseræ Nummariæ, 
Tesseræ Frumentariæ.
A little token.
1 Tesserula, f.
A token betweene any companie
1 Intersignum, n. tesseræ, f.
A token, badge, or signe to know
one by: also a token given to one
vpon certaine covenants,
1 Symbola, f. symbolum, n. sym­
bolus, m.
A token given to souldiers when
they be ready to fight: a watch­
worde.
1 Synthenia, f.
A token given when matrimo­
nie is contracted.
2 Arrha sponsalis.
A token, or signe of some great
good, or evill chaunce to come.
1 Prodigium, n.
A token of great tempest, vide 
tempest. 
A token, or pledge of remem­
brance left with ones friend, in
rememberaunce of some thing.
1 Mnemosynum, n.

T ANTE R.

leporem.
Traced. 1 Investigatus, p.
A tracer. 1 Vestigator, m.
A trace, or track. 1 Vestigium
A trace, or course. 1 Tractus
A tracing. 1 Investigatio, 
2 Inquisitio, f.
Following the trace.
1 Indaganter, adu.

To Tracte, or pro­
long the time. 
1 Propagare tempus.
Tract of time.
1 Propagatio temporis.

The Tract of a carte
wheele made in the grounde. 
1 Orbita, f.

To make Tractable, 
or gentle. 1 Mansuefacio, 
mansuesco.
To waxe, or become tractable, or
gentle. 1 Mitesco.
To be made tractable.
1 Mansuefio.
Made tractable.
1 Mansuefactus, p.
Tractable, tame, or gentle.
1 Mitis, mansuetus, tractabi­
lis, lenis, commodus, 2 Placi­
dus, humanus, facilis, flexibi­
lis, ad.

A Trade, or manner
of bringing vp. 1 Disciplina, f.
A trade, exercise, or manner of
living. 1 Ratio, 2 Via, f. tenor
m. studium, n.

Tradition. 
 1 Traditio, f.

To Trafique, or vse
the trade of merchandise. 
1 Negotium tractare, com­
mercia, mercaturam facere.
Trafique, the course of mer­
chandice from one place to ano­
ther. 1 Negotiatio, mercatu­
ra, f. commercium, n.

To helpe to sette forwarde a
Tragedy, to make a matter
much worse then indeede it is. 
3 Paratragœdio, f.
A tragedy. 1 Tragœdia, 
2 Scena, f.
A plaier of tragedies.
1 Tragœdus, m.
A writer, or maker of tragedies
1 Tragicus, m.
Tragical, belonging to tragedies
1 Tragicus, ad.
Tragically. 1 Tragice, adu.

A Traie wherein
meat sodden, or rosted is put, or
anie hollow vessell of wood. 
1 Trulla, f. 2 alveolus, m. con­
cha, f. 3 aristophorum, n.

A Traie vsed to cary
morter in to masons. 1 Qualus.
A traie, or tub to set vnder the
tap, vide tubbe.

A Traile, or border
about a womans gowne, or such
like. 2 Segmentum, n.
Trailed, or that hath trailes, or
borders finely wrought with
many smal peeces.
1 Segmentatus, ad,

A Traine, or company of
servantes, attending vpon any
Prince, or nobleman. 
1 Cohors, f. comitatus. 
2 Strepitus, m.
The traine of a womans gowne.
1 Syrma, f.
He that bereth a noble womans
traine. 1 Syrmatophorus, m.

To Traine vp, v. in­
struct and bring vp. 
Trained vp. 1 Institutus, p.
A training vp. 1 Disciplina, f.

To play the Traitor, 
vide to betraie. 




A traitour, betraier, or he that
vseth trechery.
1 Proditor, perduellio, 2 De­
sertor, defector, 3 Fidefragus
A traitor to his father, as Ab­
solon to David, Iupitor to Sa­
turne. 1 Antipater, m.
A traitour which fleeth from
his captain in battaile, and fle­
eth to his enemies.
1 Transfuga, com. g.
Traiterous, trecherous, or full
of disloialty.
1 Perfidus, perfidiosus, infi­
dus, ad.
Pertaining to a traitour.
1 Proditorius, ad.
Traiterously, or disloially, that
doth any thing against the trust
that is put in him.
1 Perfidiose, proditorie, per­
insidias.

To Trample, vide
treade.

Tranquillitie. 
1 Tranquillitas, f.

To Transcribe, or
coppy out of one thing into ano­
ther. 1 Transcribo, describo

veigh from one place to another

jicio, transfundo.

1 Transferor, 2 Describor.
To transferre, or translate, vide
translate. 
Transferred, or caried over.
1 Translatus, traductus, 
2 Trajectus, p.

To Transfigure, vide
transforme.

To Transform, trans­
figure, or change from one form
to another. 
1 Transformo, transfiguro, 
2 Verto.
Transformed. 1 Transformis, 
ad. 2 Mutatus, p.
A transformation, transfigu­
ring, or changing out of one like­
nesse into another.
1 Transformatio, transfigu­
ratio, metamorphosis, f.

To Transgresse, or
passe beyonde neligently. 
1 Transgredior, egredior, va­
rico, & varicor.
To transgresse, or breake, as a
man doth a lawe.
1 Violo, 2 Frango, discedere
a jure. 3 Scelero.
A transgressour.
1 Transgressor, parabates, m.
A transgression.
1 Trangressio, parabasis, f.

Transitorie, that en­
dureth but a very little while. 
1 Transitorius, momentane­
us, temporarius, temporane­
us, 2 Caducus, cadivus, mobi­
lis, labilis, instabilis, occasu­
rus, fluxus, fragilis, interitu­
rus, intermoriturus, ruiturus, 
jam jam periturus.

To Translate from
one language to another: to in­
terprete. 
1 Interpretor, 2 Verto, con­
verto, vte græco in latinum
convertere, trado, traduco, 
reddo, transfundo, transfero.
To translate, or cary over, vide
transferre. 
Translated.
2 Versus, conversus, tradu­
ctus, translatus, p.
A translatour, or interpretour
1 Interpres, com. g. 
2 Translator, m.
A translation.
1 Interpretatio, f. interpreta­
mentum, n. 2 Translatio, 
versio, f.
A translation of words from
their owne proper signification
into another, as Video pro in­
telligo. 1 Metaphora, f.

A Transome, or
beame, going overthwart an
house. 1 Transtrum, transtra, 
n. catherius, m. trabes trans­
versa.

The Transomes in a
shippe, whereon the hatches bee
made. 1 Canonia, f.
A transome, or lintle over a
doore.
1 Superliminare, n.
A transome, or peece of timber
foure inches thicke.
1 Trientalis materia.

in anothers place.

Transposed.

To Trap, barbe, or
dresse horses with
trappers. 
2 Ephippio, 3 Phalero.
Trapped, barbed, or dressed with
trappers. 1 Phaleratus, 
2 Ephippiatus, p.
Trappers, trappings, or barbes
for horses.
1 Phaleræ, f. 2 Ephippia, orum
n. lorica equina.
They that haue saddles on their
horses trapped with costly har­
nesses.
1 Ephippiarij, m.
Swift horses, trapped with
purple, or scarlette.
1 Instrati ostro alipedes.
The trappers of a horse.
1 Instratum, n.

To Trappe, or take
in a trappe. 
1 Irretio.
Trapped, or taken in a ginne, or
snare.
1 Irretitus, 2 Captus, p.
A trappe, snare, or ginne.
1 Tendicula, f.
Trappes, or crafty waies to de­
ceaue: also vaine shewes, or
apparances of things.
1 Offudæ, offuciæ, offritiæ, 
offucetæ. 
3 Furra, f.




A trappe for mice, or rattes.
1 Muscipula, muristrecula.
That part of the mouse-trappe
that standeth vpright.
2 Obex, dub. g.

To Travaile earnest­
ly, or take paine. 1 Elaboro, 
operor, sudo, desudo, incum­
bo, v. to labour, and take paine. 
To travaile, or labor in vaine.
1 Frustra laborare. 
Frustra conari, inanem ope­
ram sumere, arare littus, pis­
cari in aëre, aquam cribro
haurire, asellum docere.
A travailing, or taking great
paines. 3 Operositas, f.
The travaile, or paines which
one taketh. 1 Labor, conatus, 
nisus, m. opera, industria, f. 
opus, conamen, n. 2 sudor, vt
nulli sudoris est ea res.
Which travaileth much, or ta­
keth great paines
1 Laboriosus, operosus, ad.
With great travaile, paine, &
difficultie.
1 Operose, laboriose, adu.

To Travell, or go on
a journey. 
1 Itineror, spatior.
Travailing, or wandring a­
broade. 1 Spatiatus, p.
A travailer, or one that tra­
vaileth by the way.
1 Viator, 3 hodæporus, ho­
stiator, m.
Pertaining to travailing.
1 Viaticus, ad.
Pertaining to a travailer.
1 Viatorius, ad.

To Travaile, or bee
in labour with child
or bring forth. 1 Parturio, 
enitor, connitor.
To travell before time.
1 Abortio, aborto, aborior, 
Abortivum facere. Abortum
facere. immaturum fœtum
edere.
Travelling, or being in la­
bour with childe. 1 parturiens.
That hath traveled & brought
forth. 1 Nixus, enixus, p.
A travelling with childe, or
young.
1 Paritura, f. enixus, partus, m.
A travelling before time: an
vntimely death.
1 Abortus, m. abortio, f. ab­
ortium, abortivum, n.
That causeth vntimely travel.
1 Obortivus, ad.

proculco, reculco, supercal­
co, suppedito, 2 protero, ob­
tero, pede comprimo, calci­
bus premo, 3 decalco.
To treade, or trample vpon, or
in the middest.
1 Interculco.
To treade before.
1 Præculco.
To tread, or cast vnder feete, to
make light of. 1 Pessundo.
To tread, or trample out.
1 Exculco.
To tread as a cocke doth.
2 Salio.
Trodden.
1 Exculcatus, 2 obtritus, pro­
tritus, oppressus, p.
A treader, or tracer.
1 Ichnobates.
A treading, or stamping vnder
feete. 1 Calcatio, conculca­

tus, m.
A treader of grapes.

A place where they treade, and
stampe grapes.
2 Calcatorium, n.

weavers loome.

Tribunus ærarius. 
receptor generalis.
The Lorde Treasurer.

Bilonging to treasure.

To set a place with

To growe to the bignesse of a

A tree. 1 Arbor, arbos, f. vide
Trees. 
A little tree. 1 Arbuscula, f.
A very exact planting of trees
in an orcharde by squire, so that
which waie soever one looketh, 
the trees stande one directly a­
gainst another, and of like di­
stance. 1 Quincunx, m.
shadowing of trees.
1 Opacitas, f.
Places planted with trees.
1 Arbusta, n.
Garnished with, or full of trees.
1 Arbustivus, ad.
Of, like, or serving to a tree, or
which breedeth in trees.

for feare. 1 Tremo, con­
tremo, attremo, intremo,

horreo, cohorreo, perhor­
reo, inhorreo, inhorresco, 
perhorresco, cohorresco, 2
vibror, 3 tremulo, extremu­
lo, vide feare.

1 Quasso, quatio tremefacio.
Trembling, or shaking.

pidus, tremulus, tremebun­
dus, 2 coruscus, ad. micans,

de, adu.

or trenche about. 
1 Vallo, circumvallo, obval­
lo, vallo & fossa munire, &
stringere.
Trenched, or inclosed in, as
with a trenche.
1 Circumvallatus, p.
A trenche made to defende an
armie. 1 Vallum, n. val­
lus, m. militare sepimentum, 
2 agger, m.
A trenche fortified with many
stalkes. 1 Crebrisurus, m.
A trenche, or ditche to con­
veigh water. 1 Fossa, incilla, 
fœm. incile, n. incilia, f. incil­
lis canalis.
A trenche whereby water is let
out of a ponde. 2 Comma, n.
Trenches, or ditches enclosing a
place to set out games in.
1 Eurepi.
A little trench, or ditche.
1 Fossula, f.
A trenche like a furrowe to
set vines in. 2 Sulcus, m.
A trenche, or ditche made with
handes. 1 Diorix.
Pertaining to a trenche, or bul­
warke. 1 Vallaris, ad.
