A Tribe beeing the
35 part of the people of Rome, 
because the whole number of citi­
zens was divided into thirtie
fiue Tribes, bandes, wardes, or
hundreds. It seemeth in olde
time these people were divided
into three parts, and therefore
this name Tribus did first arise. 
1 Tribus, f.
One of the same tribe.
1 Contribulus, m.
Of, or belonging to a Tribe, or
peculiar to a Tribe.
1 Tribuarius, ad.
By everie tribe, or warde.
1 Tributim, adu.




Tribulation. 
1 Afflictio, tribulatio, 2 ærununa

A Tribune, the name
of many officers among the Ro­
manes. 1 Tribunus, m.
The tribune, which was the pro­
tectour of the commons, and
maintainer of the liberties, and
benefits of the commons, against
the power of the nobles.
1 Tribunus plebis.
The tribune, which was appoin­
ted in war, to view and see that
the souldiers were well armed, 
ordered, and exercised, and to de­
fende their right: the Knight
marshall. 1 Tribunus militum
Tribunus militaris.
The tribune, which was the
common treasurer, or generall
receiver. 1 Tribunus ærarius
The tribune, which was the ma­
ster of the ordinance.
1 Tribunus armentarius.
The tribune, which was in
Rome before the Kinges were
deposed, and was chiefe of the
horsemen.
1 Tribunus celerum.
The dignity, or office of the tri­
bune. 1 Tribunatus, m.
One that standeth to be tribune
1 Candidatus tribunitius.
One that hath beene tribune.
1 Tribunitius, m.
Pertaining to the tribunes.
1 Tribunitius, ad. vt tribuni­
tia, potestas.

To sette, or putte a
Tribute. 
1 Tributum imponere, 
Tributum irrogare.
Tribute money which riseth of
the goods of the people after
their ability. 1 Tributum, n.
Tribute, tole, custome, or subsidy
1 Vectigal, stipendiarium, e­
rania pecunia, 3 Munium, n.
A tribute given to maintaine
water banks. 1 Ripatum, n.
A tribute that was exacted
for every pillar that holdeth vp
the house. 1 Columnarium, n.
They that were appointed to
receiue that tribute.
1 Columnarij, m.
A kinde of tribute, or pension.
1 Vigesima, f.
Mony received of that tribute.
1 Vigesimarium aurum, 
Vicesimarium aurum.
A certaine tribute. 1 Phollis.
He that dwelleth in a city that
paieth tribute. 1 Stipendiarius
Tributary, or that paieth tri­
bute. 1 Tributarius, vectigalis
stipendiarius, m.
That paieth no tribute.
1 Immunis, ad.

To Tricke, v. to trim

To Trickle, as teares
trickle downe ones cheekes. 
2 Mano, vt manabant illi la­
chrimæ gaudio.
Trickling downe. 2 Effusus, p. 
vt effusæ genis lachrymæ,
tears trickling downe his cheeks

To Trie, prooue, or
assay. 1 Tento, attento, pro­
bo, experior, periclitor, peri­
culum facere, 2 specto, v. assay
To trie, or assay before.
1 Prætento.
To trie, or examine out a mat­
ter: to haue sure proofe, or trial
of a thing. 1 Exploro, experi­
or, examino, exigo, cognosco
probo, comperio, 2 cerno, dis­
cepto, vt disceptare armis
de controversia, to trie the
quarel by dint of sworde. 
To trie by waight, or by the
plumbe rule. 1 Penso, perlibro.
It is tried, and proved.
1 Expertum est, copertum est.
When it is tried. 1 Comperto, 
absolute, adu.
To be tried, or prooved.
1 Experiendus, vel experiundus
Tried, or assaied. 1 Tentatus, 
Periclitatus, p.
Triying, or assaiyng.
1 Tentabundus, ad.
Tried before one meddle with it.
1 Prætentatus, p.
Expert and tried. 1 Exercitus.
Tried, found, or examined.
1 Expertus, compertus, pro­
batus, cognitus, 2 Spectatus, 
pensus, p.
Triyng, or endevouring.
1 Annisus, vel annixus, p.
A trier, or assaier. 1 Tentator
A trier, or prover.
1 Probator, 2 Spectator, m.
A trial, or assay. 1 Specimen, 
tentamen, n. tentatio, pericli­
tatio, f. tentamentum, peri­
culum, n.
A trial, or proofe. 1 Experien­
tia, exploratio, f. expertum.
A triall, proofe, or diligent ex­
amination. 1 Spectatio, f. 
spectamen, n.
That trieth, or proveth of good
experience. 1 Experiens, p. vel ad

To Trie, or fine from
dregges. 1 Defæco.
Tried, or fined. 1 Defæcatus, p
purus, putus, ad.

To Trifle, or toie. 
1 Nugor, ineptio, tricor, nu­
gas agere, denugor, 2 somnio
To trifle, or goe slowly about a
thing. 1 Maginor.
To trifle together. 3 Connugor
A trifler. 1 Nugator, nugax, 
1 Denugator, m.
A trifling. 1 Nugatio, 
1 Denugatio, f.
Ful of trifling.
3 Nugacitas f.
A trifling song.
1 Nænia, f.
A trifle.
1 Nugamentum, rhapsodema
2 Hilum, n. hecta.
A vaine trifle not like to bee
true. 2 Somnium, n.
A trifle of no valewe.
3 Buttubata.
Trifles, toies, or things of no va­
lewe 1 Nugæ, gerræ, liræ, affa­
niæ, f. abydena, n. 2 Ineptiæ, 
fabulæ, apinæ, f.
Trifles, that let necessary busi­
nes.
2 Tricæ, f.
Little trifles that smiths were
woont to haue hanges before
their shop windowes to exclude
envy. 1 Bascania.
Trifles given to children.
1 Crepundia, n.
A little trifle.
1 Nugula, f.
A trusse full of trifles.
1 Nugipera, f.
A trifling fellow.
1 Nugiparus, m.




A lover of trifles. 1 Elucus, m.
A talker of trifles. 1 Gerro, m.
A seller of trifles. 1 Nugiven­
dus, frivolarius, m.
A booke wherein no thing is
written, but trifles and fables.
1 Palæpharia papyrus.
He that carieth trifles, or vain
tales about. 1 Nugigerulus. 
3 Nugiger, ad.
Trifling, or pertaining to trifles.
1 Nugalis, nugatorius, ad.
Full of trifling songs.
3 Næniosus, ad.
Triflingly, or vainely. 1 Nuga­
torie, 3 Nuganter, adu.

To staie the carte with a
Trigger. 
1 Sufflamino.
A trigger, an instrument put
in the cart wheele least the cart
be overthrowen. 1 Sufflamen, n

To Trimme, decke, 
tricke, or dresse vp. 
1 Polio, expolio, perpolio, or­
no, adorno, exorno, excolo, 
percolo, concinno, 2 Limo, 
investio, como, perpurgo, ap­
to, apparo, compono, curo.
To trimme, or decke diversly.
1 Vario.
To trimme gallantly.
1 Redimio.
To trimme, or set a thing in or­
der, or in his place.
1 Astituo, digero, dispono.
To trimme vp a thing to make
it seeme fairer. 3 Mangonizo
Trimmed, decked, or tricked vp.
1 Politus, expolitus, perpo­
litus, vt perpolita, & ornata
oratio, Ornatus, exornatus, 
perornatus, cultus, percultus
2 Limatus, elimatus, paratus, 
apparatus, comptus, pectitus
mangonizatus, digestus, re­
dimitus, compositus, concin­
natus, excuratus, repexus, 
depexus, p.
Not trimmed 1 Inexcultus, 
2 Incomptus, p.
Trimmed againe. 1 Recultus.
Trimmed, as the heare is trim­
med. 1 Calamistratus, p.
A trimmer, decker, or polisher.
1 Concinnator, polio, politor
2 Limator, elimator, m.
A trimming, tricking, or poli­
shing. 1 Politio, polities, expo­
litio, politura, perpolitio, or­
natio, exornatio, cultura, f. 
cultus, ornatus, 2 Apparatus, 
paratus, comptus, m. 3 cura­
tura, f.
Trimnes, or elegancie.
1 Elegantia, lautitia, concin­
nitas. 3 Bellitudo, f.
Curious trimming to allure.
1 Lenocinium, n.
She that trimmeth her mistresse
1 Ornatrix, f.
A very trim woman. 1 Cultissi­
ma fæmina.
Trimme, tricke, or neate.
1 Mundus, elegans, perele­
gans, scitus, concinnus. 
2 Lautus, decorus, perdeco­
rus, ad. vide neat. 
Somewhat trimme.
1 Scitulus, mundulus, politu­
lus, ad.
The trimmest, and most excel­
lent of all Ilands.
1 Insularum ocellus.
Trimmely, or neately.
1 Scite, eleganter, concinne, 
polite, ornate, 2 lepide, deco­
re, candide, condecore, lau­
te, vide neatly.

The Trinity. 
1 Trinitas, f.

A Tripe. 
1 Omasum, n.
A tripe laide in souse.
1 Echinus conditaneus. 
Omasum conditum, 
Omasum concisum. 
intestinum maceratum.
A tripe wife, shee that selleth
tripes.
1 Omasaria, allantopolis, f.
A place where tripes be solde.
1 Allantopolium, thermopo­
lium, omasarium, n.

Triple, v. threefolde

To Trip, or stumble. 
1 Titudo, vide stumble. 
To trip with the foote.
1 Supplanto.
Tripped 1 Titubatus, offensus

A Trivet, v. trevet.

To Triumph, or re­
ioice greatly. 
1 Triumpho, triumphos age­
re, 2 Gestio, exulto.
To triumph in voice, and reioice
with noise. 2 Ovo, jubilo.
Triumphing. 1 Triumphans, 
2 Exultans, exultabundus, p.
Of whome one hath triumph, or
vanquished triumphantly.
1 Triumphatus, p.
A triumpher. 1 Trumphator
A triumphing, or reioicing.
1 Triumphalia, n. triumpha­
tus, m. 2 Exultatio, insultatio
jubilatio, ovatio, f.
A triumph, or solemne pompe, 
or shew, at the returne of a cap­
taine, for a victory that he hath
gotten. 1 Triumphus, m. tri­
umphalia, orum, n.
A triumph of a Prince, or cap­
taine, for a victory without
slaughter of men, in which hee, 
with his souldiers did sing, and
shoute forth.
1 Ovatio, f.
Of, or pertaining to a triumph.
1 Triumphalis, ovalis, ad.
Triumphantly 2 Magnifice.

To Trot, or shake, as
a horse doth. 
1 Succusso, discurso.
A trotter, or a trotting horse.

cussarius, succussio, m.
The trotting, or jogging of an
horse. 1 Succussatio, succussa­
tura, succussura, f. succussus.

A Trotte-towne, or
gadder. 
1 Ambulator, m.

disturbe, or disquiet.

bo, 2 Interpello, commoveo
moveo, cieo, convello, ob­

fundo, vt suffundere aciem
oculorum, to trouble, or con­
found the eye sight. Tento, vt
vinum tentavit caput ejus,
the wine hath troubled his head
Negotium facesso 3 Inquie­
to, lympho.
To trouble with importunate
request. 1 Lacesso.




To trouble much.
2 Fatigo, eneco, vid to vexe. 
To trouble, or disquiet with
care. 1 Ango, sollicito.
To trouble with feare.
2 Percello, exanimo.
To be troubled with.
2 Laboro, flagro.
To be troubled with feare.
1 Contremo, contremisco.
To be troubled, or dismaide.
2 Feror.
There is some trouble and busi­
nesse. 1 Turbatum est, impers.
To be greatly troubled, or letted
2 Distringor, distrineor.
Troubled. 1 Turbatus, con­
turbatus, perturbarus, inqui­
etatus, 2 concussus, commo­
tus, motus, concitus, concita­
tus, solicitus, p.
Troubled in businesse.
1 Exercitus, exercitatus, oc­
cupatus, distentus, p.
A troubler. 1 Vexator, tur­
bator, conturbator, interpel­
lator, masc.
A troublous affection of the
minde. 1 Perturbatio, f.
A troubling, disquieting, or di­
sturbing. 1 Turbatio, contur­
batio, tumultuatio, inquieta­
tio, f. turbamentum, n.
Trouble, rufling, or businesse.
1 Turba, molestia perturba­
tio, f. tumultus, 2 fluctus, m. 
malum, n.
Trouble, or anguish of minde.
1 Solicitudo, 2 angustia, an­
gustiæ, confusio, f.
Trouble or danger.
2 Difficultas, incommoditas.
A little trouble.
1 Turbella, f.
A troublous man, or a conten­
tious canvaser.
3 Comitialis homo.
With trouble, or labour.
3 Aconiti.
An interiection of a mind tro­
bled. 1 Hau.
Troublous, or troblesome.
1 Turbidus, tumultuosus, tur­
bulentus, vexabundus, 2 dif­
ficilis, intrectabilis, onerosus

Troublously.
1 Turbide, turbulente, tu­
multuose, solicite, adu.

To play the Truant. 
1 Emaneo, 2 vagor, delites­
co, 3 trutannizo.

To sound a Trumpet. 
1 Buccino clango, tubicino, 
tuba canere, 3 classico.
To sounde the alarum on the
trumpet. 1 Signum dare buc­
cina, classicum canere.
The sounde of the trumpet when
they blowe to the battle, or ala­
rum. 1 Bellicum classicum, n.
The sounde of the trumpet.
1 Clangor tubæ.
A trumpet. 1 Tuba, buccina, 
f buccinum, classicum, 3 bux­
um, n. salpinx.
A writhed, or crooked trumpet, 
like a Corneilis horne.
1 Lituus, m. 2 concha, f.
A trumpet for warre.
1 Tuba classis. 
Tuba prælialis.
There are diverse soundes of a
trumpet, 1 when it soundeth the
alarum. 1 Exorneticon.
2 When it emboldeneth the
skirmish. 1 Paraceleusticon.
3 When it soundeth the re­
traite. 1 Anacleticon.
4 When it soundeth of ceasing
from labour, & to pitche their
tentes. 1 Anapausterion.
5 When it is vsed in great so­
lemnitie. 1 Pompicon, 
pollux.
A trumpeter, he that sound­
eth the trumpet.
1 Buccinator, tubicen, liti­
cen, buccinus, æneator, clas­
siarus, 3 symphonicus, m.
A woman trumpeter.
1 Tubicina, f.
A trumpeter at funeralles.
1 Siticen, com. g.
He that with a trumpet, or drum­
slade, calleth the men together.
1 Classicus, classicen, m.
The daie wherein the trumpets
are purged with water.

To Trust, or haue a
sure confidence. 
1 Fido, confido, spero, credo, 
2 subnitor, nitor, 3 siducio.
To trust greatly, or much.
1 Præfido, 3 perfido.
To trust one with any thing, or
commit vpon trust.
1 Confido, concredo.
Men beleeue, or trust.
1 Creditur, impers.
Trusted, or beleeved.
1 Creditus, fisus, p.
Trusting, or having a sure con­
fidence to
1 Confisus, fidens, 2 subnixus, 
nixus, part.
Trusting too much to himselfe.
1 Præfidens, p.
A feoffer of trust.
1 Fidei commissarius.
A feofment of trust.
1 Fidei commissus.
Trust, or confidence. 1 Fides, 
spes, fiducia, fidentia, con­
fidentia, 3 confisio, f.
Trustinesse.
1 Fidelitas, 3 fiducialitas, f.
Trustie, sure, or faithfull.
1 Fidelis, fidus, perfidelis 2 fru­
gi, certus, 3 fiducialis, ad.
Trustily. 1 Fideliter, fide, 
fidenter, adu. v. faithfully.

To speake trueth, or
to tell trothe. 
1 Verum dicere, 3 vero.
Trueth, or verity.
1 Veritas, veracitas, alethia, 
f. verum, n. 2 fides, 3 verimonia.
A true tale, or matter that is
true. 1 Verum, veriloquium, 
3 veriverbium, n.
Likelihoode of trueth.
1 Verisimilitudo, f.
The true exposition, etimology, 
or right meaning of a word.
1 Etymologia, f. veriloquium.
A lover of the trueth.
1 Philalethes.
That speaketh, or telleth the
trueth. 1 Veridicus, verax, ve­
riloquus, veriloquax, ad.
True. 1 Verus, ior, issimus fi­
dus, 2 certus, justus, ad.
Like, or likely to bee true, or
credible. 1 Verisimilis, pro­
babilis, ad.
Verie like to be true.
1 Verisimillimus, ad.
Truely, in very deede.
1 Vere, vero, re ipsa, hercle, 
hercule, equidem, quidem, 
sane, scilicet, maxime, profe­
cto, prorsum, certe, certo, cer­
tissime, porro, haud dubio, 
revera, 2 plane, nimirum, vi­
delicet, adu.
For truelye. 1 Etenimvero, 
quippe, adu.


T ANTE V.

1 Cupa, sive cuppa, f.

for washing, or to bee bathed in.

sterium, n.
A tubbe set vnder the tappe to
receiue dripping.
1 Sinum, 2 excipulum, n.
A kneading tubbe.

A bucking tubbe.
1 Liximatorium, 2 Labrum, n.

vp. 1 Colligo.

keeping. 1 Tutelaris, ad.

To put in a Tumbe. 
1 Tumulo, contumulo.
A tumbe. 1 Tumulus, tym­
bus, m. tumba, f. bustum, n. 2
arca, f. sepulchrum, n. sar­
cophagus, m. vide graue. 
A drie tumbe, or sepulcher, 
made of stones, for Princes to be
buried in. 1 Xeroliphus, m.
A tumbe, or monument, ere­
cted in the remembrance of some
notable mannes excellent ver­
tues. 1 Heroum, n.

To Tumble, or role. 
1 Volvo, voluto.
To tumble, or role out of anie
place. 1 Evolvo.
To tumble, or role apace with
great violence.
1 Pervolvo.
To tumble, or role forth a great
thing before one.
1 Provolvo, provoluto.
To tumble, or role downe.
1 Devolvo.
To tumble, or role towards some
place. 1 Advolvo.
To tumble round together.
2 Convolvo, conglobo.
To tumble, or role vnder.
1 Subvolvo.
To tumble, role, or wallowe vp­
on. 1 Supervolvo.
To tumble, or role againe, or
backe. 1 Revolvo, 2 remolior.




To tumble vpside downe.
2 Resupino.
To tumble, role, or wallowe, 
neut. 1 Volvor, convolvor, 
subvolvor.
To be tumbled about.
1 Circumvolutor.
Tumbled, rolled, or tossed.
1 Volutus, p.
That hath tumbled, or tossed.
1 Volutatus, p.
Tumbled down, or fallen from.
1 Devolutus, p.
Tumbled away, or backe againe.
1 Revolutus, p.
Tumbled downe before.
1 Provolutus, p.
A tumbling. 1 Volumen, cy­
lisma, n volutatus, m. voluta­
tio, evolutio, 2 Iactatio, f.

cis genus.

To Turne, act.
1 Verto, converto, flecto, in­
flecto, deflecto, volvo, vt vol­
vere libros, 2 Inclino, vt in­
clinare curfum aliquo to turne
his journey to some place. diri­
go, vt direxit eam a media
linea, ad lævam.
To turne, or change.
1 Muto, converto.
To turne vpside downe.
1 Inverto, everto, perverto, 
subverto, subverso, procello, 
percello, elico.
To turne in: also to turne con­
trariwise to the right forme: al­
so to turne the inside outwarde.
1 Inverto.
To turne vp and downe.
1 Revolvo.
To turne round. 1 Circino
2 Torqueo, contorqueo.
To turne a thing from one side
to the other. 1 Detorqueo.
To turne out of the way.
1 Detorqueo.
To turne from one to another.
2 Derivo.
To turne to.
1 Adverto.
To turne about, or round.
1 Circumverto, circumflecto
offlecto, 2 Circumago.
To turne against. 1 Obverto.
To turne often against.
1 Obversor.
To turne aside. 1 Averto, 
2 Obliquo, vt equos paven­
tes obliquare.
To turne out of one hand into
another.
2 Ventilo.
To turne round like a wheele.
1 Roto.
To turne out 1 Everto.
To turne backe, or cast vp.
1 Regero.
To turne vpwarde, or vpright.
1 Resupino.
To turne from, or away.




1 Averto, 2 Dejicio, vt deji­
cere oculos.
To turne, or winde in.
1 Intorqueo.
To turne, or withdraw from.
1 Converto, 2 Deduco, tra­
duco, revoco, reflecto, abasi­
eno.
To turne about.
1 Converto.
To turne about often.
1 Converso.
To turne often.
1 Verso, volito, 3 Versito.
To turne, as to turne out of one
language into another.
2 Verto, vte; græco, vel græ­
cum in latinum vertere, red­
do, vt latinum reddere.
To turne, neut, as to turne from
one thing to another, or from
the way to some place.
1 Diverto divertor.
To turne from.
1 Digredior.
To turne from, or away.
1 Declino.
To turne backe againe.
1 Remeo, 2 Revolvor. 
3 Reverso, reversor, redorso, 
vide to returne. 
To turne, or flowe backe a­
gaine.
1 Remano, refluo.
To turne to clay.
1 Lutesco.
To turne, or wind in the forme
of a serpent. 1 Sinuor.
To turne in that sort, act.
1 Sinuo.
To turne his backe, or turne a­
way his face.
1 Aversor.
To turne his backe, or runne
away.
1 Tergiversor.
To turne into milke.
1 Lactesco.
To turne into a stone.
1 Lapidesco.
To turne out of milke into
whey.
2 Seresco.
To be turned.
1 Vertor.
To be turned awry.
1 Curvor, detorqueor, per­
vertor.
To be turned vp and downe.
1 Volvor, revolvor.
To be turned from.
2 Deducor.
Turned.
1 Versus, versatus, inflexus, 
inclinacus, tortus, flexus, p.
Turned, changed, or translated.
1 Mutatus, conversus, tran­
slatus, p.
Turned downewards.
2 Deversus, p.
Turned away, or turned on the
other side.
1 Adversus, detortus, p.
Turned from al goodnes.
1 Perversus, p.
Not turned, or bowed.
1 Indeflexus, p.
Turned out of the way.
1 Deflexus, p.
Turned backe.
1 Reflexus, reversus, replica­
tus, retrorsus. 
2 Revolutus, p.
Never turned.
1 Irrevolutus, p.
Turned in and out, turned vp­
side downe: also turned contra­
riwise, to the right forme.
1 Inversus, p.
Turned vp.
1 Supinatus, p.
Turned out of.
1 Eversus, evolutus, p.
He that turneth one out of the
right way.
1 Obvaricator, m.
Turning.
1 Volutabundus, p.
A turning.
1 Versio, versatio, versura, 
volutatio, f. volutatus, m.
A turning, or winding.
1 Inflexio, flexio, tortio, f. 
flexus, anfractus.
The turning, or winding of a ri­
ver. 3 Meander, meandrus, m.
A turning rounde, or about.
1 Circinatio, circumflexio, f.
The turning of the body round, 
which is done on the toe in dan­
cing.
1 Versus, m.
The turning of horses, or oxen, 
at the landes ende.
1 Versura, f.
A turning inside out, or vpside
downe.
1 Inversio, f.
The turning of a thing.
1 Volubilitas, f.
A turning, or deriving.
1 Derivatio, f.
A turning to the place from
whence one is come.
1 Reciprocatio, f.
A turning, or winding of a wa­
ter banke.
1 Sinus, m.
A turning path out of the high
way.
1 Diverticulum, n.
A turning, or putting away.
1 Aversio, f.
A turning to the contrarie
waie.
1 Antispasis, f.
Easie to be turned about.
1 Circumductilis, ad.
That may be turned.
1 Versilis, versatilis, versabi­
lis, ad.
That turneth it selfe, or that
turneth backe.
1 Versorius, ad.
That may be turned, or driven
about with mens hands.
1 Trusatilis, ad.
That hath many turnings, and
windings.
1 Sinuosus, tortuosus, ad.
That turneth, or whirleth
rounde
1 Versatilis, verticosus, ad.
That may be turned, and revol­
ved againe.
1 Revolubilis, ad.
Turning oft, or mutable.
1 Versutus, ad.

1 Vicis, f.

course.
1 Alternatim, alterna vi­
ce, alternis vicibus, per al­

doe. 1 Torno, detorno.

A Turret, or towre.

1 Turricula, f.
A turret, or towre made of
timber. 1 Fala, f.
A watche towre, or high hill, 
to spie thinges afarre off, and
every waie. 1 Specula, f.
Turrettes, or towres made for a
spectacle, whereat mariners, or
shipmen on the sea, or by lande
haue a token, or marke to avoid
daunger. 1 Phari, orum.
Towres of Troie.

A keeper of a towre. 1 Tur­
riarius, pyrgophylax, m.

vsed when we make
light of any thing.

nentis, vel neligentis, 2 fa­
bulæ, arum, f.

great teeth standing

ti, 3 columellus, m.

disjointe, properlie
the decked attire of women, as

ment. 2 Resono.

Twelue, v. numbers.

twale. 1 Bipennis, 2 bisa­
cuta, fœm.

A young Twigge, 
or osier. 
1 Vimen, flagellum, germen, 
neut. virga, fœm. surculus, m.
The twigge of a tree cut off.
1 Sarmentum, n.
A twigge of a vine, of the
which bunches of grapes doe
growe.
1 Racemarius, m.
A small twigge of a wine.
1 Malleolus, m.
A twigge, or young braunche, 
fit for planting,
1 Malleolaris virga.
Trees apt for to bring forth
twigges.
1 Viminalia, orum, n.
Twigges, or rods to binde vines
withall.
1 Vitilia, orum, n.
A little twigge of a pomegra­
nate, or any other fruitefull
tree, crooked, and set vpon the
crowne of the Arche-Priestes
wife, when shee did sacrifice.
1 Inarculum, n.
A place where twigges, or rods
be set to binde vines.
1 Vigetum, n.
The place where twigges doe
growe. 1 Viminetum, n.
A lime twigge.

pium, n.
Made of twigges.

mentareus, ad.
Full of twigges.
1 Sarmentosus, ad.
Of, or belonging to twigges.
1 Virgeus, sarmentitius, vi­
minalis, ad.

in the evening, or
the morning.

Twise as much.

V ANTE A.

To be VACANT, 
or emptie. 1 Vaco.
To be vacant betweene.
1 Intervaco.
To be vacant, or at leisure.
1 Ferior, 2 vaco, intervaco.
Vacant, not letted with busi­
nesse. 1 Feriatus, p. 2 vacuus.
A vacation, or ceasing from
ordinarie excercise. 1 Vacatio, 
2 intercapedo, interstitio, 
cessatio, quies, f. secessus, m.
The vacation of the terme, or
ceasing from the prosequution
of the Lawe. 1 Interstitium, n.
Vacant time. 1 Otium, neut.
Verie vacant, or emptie.
1 Obinanis, ad.

A Vaile. 
1 Velum, velamen, velamen­
tum, velarium, 2 tegimen, te­
gumen, tegmen, tegmentum, 
tegumentum, integumentum.

did wear in token of good lucke, 
and that shee shoulde never bee
devorced. 1 Flammeum, n.
Belonging to a vaile.
1 Velaris, ad.

A Vaine. 
1 Vena, f.
A sinewe like a vaine, wherein
the spirite of life doth walke, 
mixed with bloud. 1 Arteria, f.
A little vaine. 1 Venula, f.
Braunches of the vaine called
Porta, which conveieth the iuice
of the meat conconcted, from the
stomacke to the liver.
1 Mesenteriæ venæ.
The great throat vaines, which
beeing cut asunder, death pre­
sently ensueth. 1 Lisæ, f.
A vaine of silver in the top of a
mine. 1 Crudaria, f.
A little swolne vaine.
1 Varicula, f.
A crooked vaine of the thighe, 
legges, or other places, swolne
with melancholy, and corrupte
bloude. 1 Varix, m.
Hee that hath such vaines.
1 Varicus, ad.
The twelue great vaines, appea­
ring in eache side of the necke.
1 Fragitides, f.
The great carrying vain which
proceedeth out of the hollowe
part of the liver.
1 Hepatitis, f.
A greate vaine in the foot.
1 Sophena, f.
A master veine. 1 Varica, f.
Two vaines growing from the na­
vell to the matrice, beneath the
kidneies. 1 Ahertæ, f.
A vaine comming from the li­
ver, to the arme hole.
1 Axillaris vena.
The cutting of a vaine.
1 Phlebotomia, f.
A vaine in writing. 2 Vena, f.
A vaine in the earth. 2 Vena, f.
The middle space betweene the
vaines in the earth.
1 Intervenium, n.
A vaine of earth in mines, de­
claring that gould may be found
there. 1 Segullum, n.
Vaines of silver, or leadde.
1 Molybdæna, f.

Vaine speaking.

A Vermine that flieth.
1 Barbellus, vel barsellus, 
bambilius, m.
Full of vermine. 1 Vermi­
nosus, ad.

To make Verses. 
1 Versifico. 3 Poetor.
A verse maker. 1 Versifi­
cator, poeta, 3 Comaticus, 
versista, m.
A versifiyng. 1 Versificatio, f.
A verse. 1 Carmen, metrum, n. 
versus, m. poema, poematum, n. 
2 Camæna, f. numerus, mo­
dus, modulus, m.
A little verse. 1 Versiculus, m.
A kinde of verses, having the
first verse longer then the se­
conde. 1 Epodus, m.
A verse of an eleven sillables
1 Hendecasillabus, m.
A verse having three mea­
sures, which are sixe feete, Iam­
bickes, &c.
1 Trimetrum, n.
A verse of sixe feete.
1 Hexameter, m.
A verse consisting of fiue feete.
1 Pentameter, m.
A kinde of verses, made of the
foote Iambus.
1 Choliambi, m.
Verses made of Iambickes.
1 Iambicus, ad.
Verses that doe halte on the
middle foote. 1 Lagari, m.
A verse wanting sillables
at the ende.
1 Brachycatalecton.
A verse where noe sillable
wanteth, or aboundeth.
1 Acatalectos, & acatalecti­
cus versus.
Little senarie, or trimeter
verses, of sixe feete.1 Sena­
rioli versus.
When the first letters of di­
verse verses doe make a sence, 
or sentence, or expresse a name.
1 Acrostichis.
Two verses containing one
matter. 1 Distichon.
Foure verses together. 1 Te­
trastichon.
Sixe verses together. 1 Hex­
astichon.
Verses song by course. 1 Amœ­
bæum carmen, intercala­
res versus.
Verses of triumphe, or victo­
rie. 1 Epinicia, n.
The last, and vtter-most ende
of a verse.
1 Acroteleutium, n.
A foot consisting of 2 long sil­
lables, beeing also so called of
drawing the breath in divine
seruice. 1 Spondæus, m.
A foote consisting of two short
sillables: it is also so called of the
nimble moving in the Phrygi­
an dauncing, which was in ar­
mour. 1 Pyrrhychius, m.
A foote consisting of two silla­
bles, one long, the other shorte.
1 Trochæus, choreus, cho­
rius, masc.
A verse having two sillables, 
the first short the last long.
1 Iambus, m.
A foote having three long sil­
lables. 1 Molossus, 
trimacrus, m.
A foote having three short sil­
lables. 1 Tribrachus, m.
A foote of a verse having 1. 
sillable long, two shorte.
1 Dactylus, m.
A foote having three sillables, 
two short, one long.
1 Anapæstus, m.
A verse made of such feete.
1 Anapæstum, n. anapæstus
versus.
Made of such feete.
1 Anapæsticus, ad.
A foote of three sillables, the
first shorte, the two last long.
1 Bacchius, m.
A foote of two long sillabes, 
and one shorte. 1 Palimbac­
chius, antibacchius, m.
A foote consisting of three sil­
lables, the first and thirde long, 
the seconde short. 1 Amphi­
macrus, & amphimacer.
A foote having three sillables, 
the first and thirde shorte, the
second long.
1 Amphibrachus, m.
A foote consisting of four short
sillables. 1 Procele usmaticus.
A foote having four sillables, 
the first and last long, and two
in the middle short.
1 Choriambus.
A foote consisting of 4 sillables, 
one differing from the other
three. 1 Epitritus.
A foot of four sillables, the first
long, the last three short, or the
first three short, the last long.
1 Pæon.
A foote of fiue sillables, one short
2 long, a short & a long it is al
one with Bacchius, and Iambus.
1 Dochimus.

Vertue. 
1 Virtus, probitas, 2 Præstan­
tia, f. rectum, n.
Vertue, or strength. 1 Vis, facul­
tas, efficacitas, 2 Natura, f.
Vertuous. 1 Probus, studiosus, 
3 Virtuosus, ad.

A Vessell. 1 Vas. 3 vasum.




A little vessell. 1 Vasculum, n.
An oile vessel made of leather.
1 Scortia, f.
A great vessel for wine, as a
vate. 1 Orca, f.
A great and large vessel in the
bathes, wherein they vsed to
wash themselues sitting.
1 Dureta, f.
A vessell for figs, or other ser­
vice, with a great belly, and a
narrow mouth. 1 Orcula, f.
A vessell of vineger. 1 Oxys, f.
A vessel with colde water to
rinse cups in. 1 Luterium, n. 
baucasis, f.
A vessel whereinto lots were
put in elections, or judgements.
1 Cadiscus, m.
A little vessel vsed in sacrifice
1 Capeduncula, f.
Holy vessels, whereinto the bo­
wels of beasts were appoin­
ted to holy vses, and brought to
the altar.
1 Magmentaria fana.
A vessel for wine with two han­
dles. 1 Diota, f.
A kinde of vessel. 1 Lenis, f.
A certaine hanging vessell, 
wherinto men vsed to put their
fragments of meat, such as our
hearen cupboards are.
1 Cremathra, f.
A vessel to wash feete in.
1 Podoniptrum, n.
A goldsmithes vessel made like
a crabfish, and hollow, wherein
water is sodde to washe away
drosse. 1 Thermastris, f.
A vessel to put oile in.
1 Gemellar, n.
An old fashion of vessels to wash
the handes in, having a long
handle. 1 Bacrio, trulla.
A kinde of woodden and wine
vessel, like vnto Cyathus.
1 Sympinium, n.
Earthen vessels with long feet.
1 Sitropedes, vel citropedes.
Vessels containing to bushels.
1 Decimodiæ, vel decemmo­
diæ, f.
A kinde of vessel graved, and
curiously wrought. 1 Lesbium.
A vessel of brasse, or tin, made
like a cucumber. 1 Cucuma, f.
Vessels to bake, or boile in.
1 Coculum coctiatoria va­
sa, coquinatoria. 
3 Cocinatoria, n.
A great vessell of wicker, or
earth, to keepe corne in.
1 Cumera, f.
A vessel wherein liquor offered
to idols was put. 1 Choa.
A vessel vsed at wedding, wher
in the houshold stuffe of the par­
tie to be maried, was put.
1 Cumerum, n.
A little broad vessel, called also
Scitulus barbatus. 1 Nanum.
A vessell with handles, and a
wide mouth, to wash, and coole
drinking cups in the summer
time. 1 Nasiterna, f.
A vessel whereout wine was
poured in sacrifice.
1 Cuturnium, n.
A wicker vessell, wherein they
were wont to keepe figges.
1 Syriscus, m.
A vessel put vnder the tap, to
saue the droppings.
2 Excipulus, m.
A vessel, wherein beere, or ale
is set acooling. 2 Lacus, m.
A vessel having 3 lavours, out
of which water is poured.
1 Trichilum, n.
An earthen vessel.
1 Caprunculum, n.
A vessel wherein oile is kept.
1 Capsases.
Vessels that priests vsed in their
sacrifices. 1 anclabra, antlabra
A wine vessel in sacrifice, cari­
ed vpon shoulders. 1 Armillum
A certaine vessel dressed with
pitch, wherein was ointmente, 
with which Remus his arm was
annointed. 1 Persillum, n.
A certaine vessel vsed in sacri­
fice. 1 Prochites.
Vessels wherein Promulsis is
kept. 1 Promulsidaria, orum.
All maner of vessels belonging
to the table. 1 Epitrapezia, orum
A vessel of brasse vsed among
the Egyptians. 1 Ethanion, n.
Vessel of small value, as ear­
then pots. 2 Fricola, n.
A great paunched vessel.
2 Gaster, gasterium, n.
A kinde of earthen vessell, ha­
ving 2 eares: also a wine vessell
containing the eight part of a
poyson. 1 Amphora, f.
A vessel, whereinto the mother
or fome of oile is put.
1 Amurcaria dolia.
A vessell, or plate chaced, or
wrought with hammer, not
graved. 1 Anaglyphum, n.
Vessels of hard mettals, as cop­
per, or iron. 1 Ahena, n.
A vessel made of Alabaster to
keep sweet ointment in. 1 Ala­
baster, m. alabastrum, n.
A vessel of any sort to saile in.
1 Navigium, n.
Vessels in which they salt either
fish, or flesh. 1 Cadi salsamen­
tarij.
Vessels vsed in journey.
1 Viatoria vasa.
The greatnes of a vesslel contai­
ning. 1 Capedo, f.

A Vestment, ve­
sture, or garment. 
1 Vestitus, m.
A long vestment reaching down
to the ground, without plaites, 
which souldiours vsed to wear.
1 Poderis, cassiola, f. pallium
sacrum.
A kind of vesture. 1 Lopas, f.
A vestment from the belly
downward. 1 Limus, m.

A Vestry. 
1 Sacrarium, sacellum, vestia­
rium, n.
A vestry chancell of a church, 
or some such place, not common
for every one. 1 Adytum, n.

A Vetch. 
1 Vicia, f. bicion, n.
Wild vetches. 1 Orobanche, f.
A plate sowed with vetches.
1 Viciarium, n.

To Vexe, trouble, or
torment. 1 Vexo, divexo, de­
vexo, convexo, fligo, affligo, 
conflicto, crucio, discrucio, 
exerucio, ango, molesto, per­
molesto, perturbo, solicito, &
apud poetas sollicito, infesto
infenso, 2 vrgeo, vasto, pre­
mo, torqueo, conficio, mace­
ro, pango, iniquo, lacesso, 
conquasso, cieo, incieo, pro­
cieo, pello, procello, incesso, 
incendo, ago, agito, exagito, 
fatigo, protelo, vro, compungo




confundo, dilacero coquo, pe­
sequor, insector, 2 turbulento, v
afflict, trouble, torment, or dis
quiet.
To vexe, or grieue one that hath
vexed vs before. 2 Remordeo.
To vexe againe. 2 Repungo.
To vexe sorely. 1 Effligo, perex­
crucio, infesto, 2 Exuscero.
To vexe many waies.
1 Excarnifico.
To vexe often. 1 Angito, infen­
so, afflicto, conflicto.
To be vexed, or troubled. 1 Con­
flictor, discrucior, afflictor, af­
fligor, stomachor.
To be vexed in minde. 2 Æstuo.
Vexed tormented, or grieved.
1 Vexatus, afflictus, conflicta­
tus, inquietatus, 2 percitus, 
perculsus, exasperatus, appe­
titus, affectus, irrequietus, im­
pulsus, agitatus, incensus, p.
Vexed with an evill spirite.
1 Ergumenus, 3 Sparticus, ad.
Vexed with fretting of the bellie
1 Alvinus, ad.
A vexer, or troubler.
1 Vexator, 2 exagitator, m.
A vexation, griefe, or troubling
1 Vexatio, afflictio, perturba­
tio, infestatio, conflictatio, f. 2
malum, acerbitas, conquassatio
A vexation, or anguish of minde
2 Solicitudo, f. pathos, m. ago­
nia, f. vide Affliction. 
That which causeth vexation, 
or trouble. 1 Passivus, ad.

Vglie, horrible, or hi­
deous. 1 Horridus, perhorridus.


V ANTE I.

voiage. 1 Profectus, m.

A vicarage. 1 Vicaria, f.

A Vice, or jester in a
plaie, or enterlude. 1 minius, pa­
tomimus, sannio, 2 Parasitus.

A Vice, or spindle of
a presse. 2 Cochlea, f. organum.
A maker of vices. 2 organarius.
Made with vices. 2 organicus.
That goeth by a vice, that see­
meth to moue of it selfe.
1 Autumatus, ad.
With a vice. 2 Organice, adu.

To get the Victorie. 
1 Devinco.
A victor. 1 Victor, 2 superator
A victor in the games of Greece, 
which had given him a garland
of pine tree. 1 Pityonices.
He that was victor at these fiue
kinde of games, casting with the
fling, running, leaping, wrast­
ing, shooting in a long bowe.
1 Pantathlus, m.
A lover of victory 1 philonicus
Victorie. 1 Victoria, 2 palma, f. 
Trophæum, n.
A victor of the game, called  Sa­
cra certamina. 1 Hieronicus.
The reward of a victorie.
1 Palmarium, agonisma, palma
A feast made for the ioie of vi­
ctorie. 1 Epinicia, orum.
A signe or token of victorie.
1 Trophæum, tropæum, n.
Victorious. 1 Victoriosus, ad.
Belonging to victorie.
1 Victorialis, Victorius, ad.

a haunter of victualling houses

Iaceo.

Vilenes. 1 Vilitas, 2 sordes, in­
dignitas, f.

ignobilis, 2 fœdus, projectus

To growe to a Vine. 
3 Vitisco.
To pruine a vine. 1 Pampino.
To plant new vines. 1 Novello.
A vine. 1 Vinea.
A little vine. 1 Viticula, f.
He that planteth vines.
1 Vitisator, m.
He that cutteth vines. 1 Pampi­
nator, m.
A vineyard. 1 Vinea, f. vinetum.
A vineyard, wherein vines grow
vp by the trees. 1 Arbustum, n.
A place wherein young vines are
set. 1 Vitiarium, n.
He that dresseth a vineyarde, or
he that is a master of a vine.
1 Vinitor, m.
A place where male vines doe
growe. 1 Masculetum, n.
A frame whereon vines are ioi­
ned. 2 Iugum, n.
A forke to hold vp a vine.
1 Capreolus, m.
A fault common to vines when
a cobweb wrappeth the fruite, 
and consumeth it.
1 Araneum, n.
A thing set in the part of the
vinepresse, called Sucula.
1 Porculum, n.
A vine leafe. 1 Pampinus, m
The shoote of a vine: also a vine
branch.
1 Viticulum, n.
The shootes of the vine, where­
with it bindeth itselfe to some
thing.
1 Capreoli vitium.
The small topping of a vine.
1 Flagellum, n.
A branch, or twigge of the vine: 
also a dry twigge cut off.
1 Malleolus, m.
A branch of the vine that bea­
reth nothing but leaues.
1 Pampinatium, n.
The branch, budde, or wood of
the vine that is left every yeare, 
when it is cut. 1 Palmes, m.
The young budde of the vine.
2 Gemma, f.
The pruning, or cutting of a vine
1 Pampinatio, f.
The cutting of an old vine that
many young ons may be planted
thereon.
1 Propagatio, f.
Of, or belonging to a vine.
1 Viteus, vineaticus, vinearius
Belonging to a vine, or that com­
meth of a vine.
1 vitiginius, vitigineus, ad.
That beareth vines.
1 Vitifer, vinearius, ad.
Of a vine, or that beareth vines
1 Vinearius, ad.
Of, a vine, or apt, or meete for
vines. 1 Vinealis, ad.
Belonging to the keeping of a
vine, or vineyard.
1 Vinitorius, ad.
Of, or pertayning to vine leaues.
1 Pampineus, pampinarius.
Full of vine leaues.
1 Pampinosus, pampinace­
us, ad.
Like the tendrels of a vine.
1 Claviculatim, adu.

Vinum Acre. 
Vinum Acidum.




The dregges of vineger. 1 oxygion.
Wine vineger. 1 Oxymentum.
Any sharpe sauce made with
vineger. 1 Oxyporum, n.
Vineger and honie sod together.

A sirroupe made with suger and
vineger. 1 Oxysaccharum, n.
Vineger and water sodde toge­
ther. 1 Oxyeratum, n. posca.
A vessell of vineger. 1 oxys, idis
Vinegreet, or salads, or such like
thinges eaten with vineger.
1 Acetaria, orum

tio, corrumpo. 2 Violo, delibo
To violate a maide, vide to de­
flower.

Violatus, læsus, delibatus.

trappe one, or an ambushe.

That laieth wait. 1 Insidiosus.
By lying in waite. 1 Insidio­
se, insidianter, adu.

Waites, certain mu­
sicall instruments so called. 
1 Spondiales.

To waken out of sleepe.

cito, exuscito, 2 excio, ex­
cieo, excito
To be wakened.

Men wake. 1 Vigilatur, imp.
Wakened out of sleepe.

ctus, expergitus, p.
A waking. 1 Vigilatio, evi­
gilatio, pervigilatio, f.
Great waking. 1 Pervigilium, n
Wakinglie. 1 Vigilanter, adv.

Wakes, or countrie
feastes. 1 Paganalia, neut. 
vide feastes.

To Walke. 
1 Ambulo, gragior, spatior, 
incedo, 3 badizo.
To walke farre abroad.
1 Expatior.
To walke in. 1 Ingredior.
To walke about. 1 Peragro, 
circumambulo.
To walke before.
1 Præambulo.
To walke through, over and o­
ver. 1 Perambulo
To walke backe. 1 Redambulo.
To walke at noonetide.
3 Merendinor.
To walke about, or walke a­
gainst another. 1 Obambulo.
To walke forth, or abroad.
1 Deambulo, prodeambulo.
To walke vp and downe in a
place. 1 Inambulo.
A walker. 1 Ambulator, m.
A walking. 1 Ambulatio, 
inambulatio, deambulatio, 
ingressus, m. itio, f.
A little walking place.
1 Ambulatiuncula, f.
A walking place. 1 Ambu­
lacrum, deambulacrum, de­
ambulatorium, n. 2 ambulatio.
A walking place vnderprop­
ped with pillars. 1 Porticus.
An open walking place to




walke in out of the raine, or
sunne. 1 Xystus, m.
A walke, that hath no shelter
over the head.
1 Paradromis, f.
A walke about the place of
exercise
1 Peridromis, f.
A course in walking.
2 Spatium, n.
A walking vp and downe.
1 Inambulatio, f.
A walking about. 1 Obam­
bulatio, f.
A walking by night. 3 No­
ctatio, noctivagatio, f.
Walking. 1 Ambulus, ambu­
latorius, ambulatilis, ad.
That walketh farre abroade.
1 Expatiatus, p.

To Wal in, or about
1 Mœnio, 2 Circummunio, 
cingere muro.
To make walles. 3 Parieto.
Walled. 1 Muratus, muriatus, 
2 Munitus, p.
A wall. 1 Murus, paries, m.
A little wal. 1 Parietulus, m.
A wal about an house.
1 Disseptum, dissepium, n.
Walles of a towne, or a citty.
1 Mœnia, orum, n.
A bricke wall.
1 Paries testaceus. 
Paries Iateritius.
A wall of stones heaped to­
gether without morter.
1 Maceria, maceries, f.
A partition wall.
1 Paries integerimus. 
Paries communis.
A marble stone wall.
1 Paries marmoreus.
A mid wall serving for roomes
appointed to sundrie vses.
1 Paries medianus.
A wall raised out of the very
soile, or ground. 1 Stereobata, 
stereobates, f.
The vtter wal before a wall.
1 Promurale, n.
A thicke wall 1 Peribolus, m
peribolum, n.
Walles of a towne, castle, or cit­
ty. 1 Mœnia, orum, n.
Two walles made high on
both sides of a great building: al­
so the side walles of a church, 
which some cal the wings.
1 Ptera, pteromata, n.
Wals of two bricks thickenes.
1 Diplinthij parietes.
An arched wall.
1 Paries fornicatus.
A wal marked with the palm
of ones hand. 1 Paries palmatus
An vpright wall raised from
the very ground. 1 paries solidus
A mud wal. 1 Lutamentum.
A wall made of flint stone.
1 Silicatus murus.
A rough wal made of lime &
sande. 1 Paries cæmentitius.
Wals made of laths, splintes, or
studdes.
1 Parietes Arrectarij, 
1 Parietes Concretitij, 
1 Parietes Cratitij.
An olde wal broken down, or
the ruine and decay of a wall.
1 Parietina, f.
The space betweene two
walles. 1 Andronitis, an­
dron, promurium.
A place without the wals of
Rome, where the bishops of the
Gentiles made their divination
1 Prosimurium, n.
Ful of wals. 1 Parietosus, ad.
That which is vnder the wals
1 Summœnius, ad.
That which is within the
wals. 1 Intramuranus, ad.
Without the wals.
1 Extramuranus, ad.
Pertaining to a wal.
1 Muralis, ad.
That which is betweene two
wals. 1 Intermuralis, ad.

vp, as seething water.

To wamble, or wag to and fro,

To haue a wambling in the
stomacke. 2 Nauseo.
A wambling in the stomacke.

To Wander, or go a­
straie here and there. 1 Erio, ab­
erro, oberro, deerro, inerro,

tior, expatior, 2 Peregrinor, 
discuiso, lustro.

1 Convagor.
To wander with company.
1 Coerro.
To wander from the purpose.
2 Evagor.
To wander hither, and thither.
1 Divagor, dispalo, dispalor.
To wander abroade more then
needeth. 1 Supervagor.
To wander vnder, or a little.
1 Suberro.
To wander about. 1 Pervagor, 
pervago.
To wander in. 1 Inerro.
To wander over and over.
1 Pererro.
To wander out of order, with­
out a guide. 1 Palor, palo.
To wander out of the way.
1 Exorbito, 2 decedo, declino
Wandred. 1 Erratus, 
pererratus, p.
That hath wandred, or walked
abroad. 1 Pervagatus, spatiatus




A wandrer, or gadder. 1 Erro, 
vagus, profugus, spatiator,

Shee that wandreth.

A wandring. 1 Vagatio, eva­
gatio, erratio, aberratio, f. 
error. 2 discursus, m.
A wandring through.
1 Peragratio, f.
That wandreth, or straieth
much. 1 Errabundus, errati­
cus, vagabundus, palabundus.
Wandring every where.
1 Omnivagus, ad.
That wandreth on hilles.
1 Montivagus, ad.
Wandring much abroad.
1 Multivagus, ad.
Wandring in floudes, or wa­
ters. 1 Fluctivagus, ad.
Wandring all alone.
1 Solivagus, ad.
That wandreth, runneth, or go­
eth rounde about.
1 Circumvagus, ad.
Wandring abroade.
1 Pervagus, ad.
Which vseth to wander, and
leaveth it. 1 Erratitius, ad.
Not wandring. 1 Inerrans.
Wandring here & there, nowe
in one part, nowe in an other.
1 Vage, adu.

To Warre, wage, or
make war. 1 Prælior, bellige­
ro, & or, bello, & or. 3 bellifico
To be in warre, or go on war­
fare. 1 Milito.
To serue in warre for money.
2 Mereo, & or, latrocinor.
The warre is ended.
2 Bellatum est, impers.
A warriour, or man of warre
1 Bellator, m. trix, f. præliator
duellator, stratiotes, m. miles
A lover of warre.
1 Philopolemus, m.
Commissioners, to muster, and
take vp men for warre.
1 Conquisitores, m.
Certaine men of warre, whose
maner it was to haue two hor­
ses, and when the one was
weary, to leape vpon the other
1 Desultores, m.
Men of warre alwaies about
the standarde. 1 Campigeni
milites.
A man of war vpon the seas.
1 Classiarius, m.
Daies appointed for warre.
1 Dies præliares.
War. 1 Bellum, prælium, duellum
n. polemos, polemus, 2 Mars.
Warre: also the exercise of war.
1 Militia, f.
War by sea. 1 Naumachia, f. 
Classicum bellum, 
Navale bellum.
A necessary warre enterprised
for the punishment of evil.
1 Bellum expiabile.
A warre betwen the soul &
the body. 1 Psycomachia, f.
Aide in warre, as when men
of diverse countries do ioine in
war against one. 1 Symmachia.
Fellowship in warre. 1 Com­
militia, f. commilitium, n.
A setting forth towards war.
1 Expeditio, f.
An instrument of war, where
in wild fire is enclosed, to sette
timber on fire.
1 Phalarica, f.
A warlike engine made of iron
worke, full of sharpe pointed
nailes, or prickes.
1 Ericius, m.




Ordinance, or furniture for
warre. 2 Instrumentum, n.

To Waste, act spoil, 
or destroie. 1 Vasto, devasto, e­
vasto, collabefacio, dilacero, 
diripio, 2 desolo, comquasso.
To waste, spende, or consume.
1 Absumo, 2 tero, attero, 
contero, detero, corrumpo, 
deartuo, decoquo, devoro, dis­
perdo, dissipo, attenuo, lan­
cino, absorbeo, consorbeo, 
vide spende and consume. 
To waste, robbe, or spoile, as to
waste Countries. 1 Populor, 
depopulor, expopulor, pro­
populor.
To waste all over.
1 Perpopulor.
To waste, or consume riotous­
lie. 1 Prodigo, nepotor, 2
effundo, profundo, elavo.
To waste in eating & drink­
ing. 1 Abligurio.
To waste awaie, neut.
1 Tabesco, 2 deliquesco.
To be wasted. 1 Corruo, 2
delabor, morior.
Wasted rounde about.
2 Corrosus, p.
Wasted, or spoiled. 1 Vastatus, 
devastatus, populatus, la­
befactus, labefactatus, part.
Wasted, or consumed.
1 Consumptus, 2 tritus, attri­
tus, contusus, p.
Wastefully spent. 1 Decoctus, 
2 diruptus, lancinatus, part.
Wasted away. 2 Liquefactus.
Wasted riotouslye. 2 Profu­
sus, adesus, comesus, part.
A waster, or he that wasteth.
1 Consumptor, m.
A waste good, or spend all.
1 Nepos, profligator, m.
An exceeding great waster.
2 Hirudo, m.
A waster, or spoiler.
1 Vastator, populator, de­
populator, m. trix, f.
A wasting, or spoiling. 1 Va­
statio, populatio, depopula­
tio, expopulatio, excisio, f.




A wasting, or spending.
1 Consumptio, absumptio, f. 
2 Attritus, m. dissipatio, f.
Riotous, or needles wasting.
1 Nepotatus, m. prodigalitas
prodigitas, prodigentia, f. 2 pro­
fluvium, n. effusio, profusio, f.
A wasting, or consumption of
the body. 1 Tabes, 3 Tabitudo.
The waste, or losse of any thing
by wearing, and occupying.
1 Intertrimentum, n.
Wasting, or pining away.
1 Tabidus, tabitus, ad.
Wasting riotously. 2 dissolutus
That wasteth, or wastfull.
1 Prodigus, ad.
That wasteth, or spoileth.
1 Vastificus, populabundus.
That may be wasted.
1 Populabilis, ad.
That cannot be wasted.
2 Inexhaustus, ad.
Waste. 2 Desertus, vacuus.
Wastefully. 1 Prodige, pro­
digaliter, 2 sumptuose, nequiter

To Watch, wake, or
not to sleepe. 1 Vigilo, evigilo, 
invigilo, advigilo.
To watch, as in ward. 1 Excu­
bo, procubo.
To watch againe. 1 Revigilo.
To watch, and write by candle
light. 1 Elucubro, elucubror.
To watch, marke, or obserue.
1 Asservo, observo, custodio,
To watch al night. 1 Nocto, 
pernocto, pervigilo.
To watch in an high tower, or
other high place. 1 Speculor.
To watch, or tarie for.
2 Aucupor.
To watch, or espie. 1 Aucupo.
They watch, or warde.
1 Excubatur, impers.
A watch man. 1 Excubitor, m
vigil, com. g. vigilarius, vigili­
arius, m. 2 Custos, com. g.
He that kepeth watch & ward
without the camp in the night, 
when the enemies are encamped
nigh at hand. 1 Procubitor, 
excubitor, m.
A watcher, or lyer in waite to
deceaue. 1 Insidiator, m.
A scout watch. 1 Speculator.
A standing watch. 1 Statores, 
statarij excubitores
One of the watch, or warde.
1 Miles stationarius.

men, vigilamen, n.

1 Excubatio, f.

tower. 1 Speculatio, f.

like withwinde, and hath a

a gentle purger of melancholy.

bout corne: orobanke, or choke­

led ropeweede, or weedebinde.

pease, and beans, and destroieth
them.

pondero.
To weigh, or poise together.
1 Collibro, compondero
To weigh diligently.
1 Perpendo, perlibro.
To weigh downe.
1 Degravo, dependo. 
2 Opprimo, deprimo.
To weigh more on one side, then
on the other. 1 Præravo, præ­
pondero.
To weigh, or to be of weight. 
neut. 1 Pendeo.
To weigh, or consider. Metaph.
1 Æstimo, appendo, 2 Pon­
dero, compondero, meditor, 
penso, pensito, vid. consider. 
To be weighed, or considered.
1 Examinor, 2 Excutior.
Weighed, or balanced.
1 Libratus, ponderatus, tru­
tinatus, expensus, appensus, 
pensatus, pensitatus, p.
Weighed downe. 1 Degrava­
tus, 2 Depressus, p.
A weigher, or he that weigheth
1 Pensator, librator, librarius
moderator, pensitator, m.
A weigher, or he that holdeth
the ballance.
1 Libripens, m.
He that weigheth, or conside­
reth a thing diligently.
1 Logista, m.
A woman weigher of wooll, 
or flaxe. 1 Libraria, f.
A weighing. 1 Libratio, f.
A diligent weighing, and pon­
dering. 1 Pensatio, pensicatio
Any thing weighed.
1 Pensum, 2 Pondus, n.

A Weight, vi. weightes.

To make Weighty, 
or heavy. 2 Degravo, ingravo.
To make, or be more weightie.
1 Prægravo.
To waxe weighty, or heavie.
1 Gravesco.
To waxe more weighty.
1 Ingravesco.
Weightines, or heavinesse.
1 Gravitas, ponderitas, f. 
pondus, n. 3 Ponderositas, f.
A thing that is very weighty, 
and great: also the weight, &
greatnes of a thing.
1 Moles, f.
Weighty. 1 Gravis, pondero­
sus, momentosus, ad. 2 pressus
p. crassus, magnus, plumbeus.
Very waighty. 1 Pergravis, 
2 Onerosus, permagnus, ad.

Well. 
1 Bene, belle, recte, 2 Apposi­
te, scite, lepide, commode, lu­
culenter, adu.
Very well. 1 Optime, perbel­
le, 2 Præclare, graphice, sat­
satis, percommode, facile, vt
facile memini, I remembre it
very well. 
Well goe to. 1 Eja, age.
Very wel, go to, encrease, go on
forward, proced, growe more
and more. 1 Macte in sing. &
macti in plur. a mactus: quan­
quam sunt, qui sentiunt adv. 
voces adhortationem tan­
tum significantes, quibus vti­
mur, cum aliquem obrem bene­
cæptam laudamus, & ad pro­
ficiendum adhortamur.
Well done. 1 Euge.
Wel nigh, vide almost. 
As well. 1 Et, tam.
Well well. 1 Age, age.

cantatix, f.

yeeres 1 Impubes, & impubis.

To Wette, or make
wette. 1 Madido, madefacio, 
madifico, proluo, 2 roro.
To wet quite through, or al o­
ver. 1 Permadefacio.
To bee wet. 1 Madeo, dema­
deo, commadeo, madefio, hu­
meo, humesco.
To waxe wet. 1 Humesco, 
madesco, demadesco.
To be wet with dewe.
1 Roresco.
To be throughly wet.
1 Permadeo, permadesco, 2
diffluo.
To wette againe. 1 Remadeo.
Wetted, made wet, or moistned.
1 Humectatus, p.
Wetted with raine.
1 Implutus, impluviatus, 
complutus, p.
Wetnesse, or moisture.

ditas, f.
Wetnesse, or naturall moistnes
of the grounde. 1 Vligo, f.
Wette. 1 Madidus, humidus, 
madens, humens, vdus, ad.
Wet, or moistened with dewe.
1 Roscidus, 3 roridus, ad.
That is alwaies wet and moist.
1 Vliginosus, ad.
That maie be easily wetted, or
watered. 1 Riguus, ad.
Wet vnderneathe.

What. 
1 Quis, quid, ecquid.
What manner. 1 Cujusmodi.
What manner of man.
1 Qualis, quis.
What countrey man. 1 Cujas.
What number, or order, or of
what number, or order. 1 Quotus.
Whatsoever. 1 Quicquid, 
quidvis, quodcunque.
Whatsoever man he be.
1 Qualis qualis, qualiscunque.
Whatsoever thou wilt.
1 Quidvis, quodvis.
What matter, or thing.
1 Quidnam, quid.
What, or how great a matter.
1 Quanti.
What manner of. 1 Quid.
What say you of, or to this.
1 Quid.
To what place. 1 Quo.
By what place. 1 Qua.
By what place soever, or what
waie soever. 1 Quacunque.
For what cause, v. wherefore.

A Wheale, whelke, 
push, or pimple. 
1 Pustula, tubercula, f. psy­
dracium, n. 3 cutella, f. steman­
tor, masc.
A little wheale, or push, swel­
ing in the necke, or vnder the
armes. 1 Atheroma, n.
A red weale, or angry push, or
blister. 1 Papula, papulæ, f.
Plenty of such wheales.
3 Papulositas, f.
Red, and angrie weales.
1 Sudaminæ, f.
A weale, or push rising in
the skinne by night.
1 Epinyctis, epinyctides.
A little wheale, push, or rough­
nesse of the skinne in the face, 
caused by the heate of the sun.
1 Ephelis, f.
A litel round pimple, or wheal, 
rising in the bodie, but especial­
ly, in the hands and face.
1 Lenticula, f.
A pimple, wheale, or speckle in
the face, red and wanne like a 
lintle.
1 Lentigo, f.
Full of such wheales.
1 Lentiginosus, ad.
Full of pushes, or wheales.
1 Pustulosus, ad.
Full of red angry wheales.
1 Papulosus, ad.
Hee that hath wheales.




1 Pustulatus, ad.

Wheate. 
1 Triticum, n. arista, f. 2 Fru­
mentum, n.
A kinde of pure wheat, called
also Far, vsed in old time in sa­
crifice.
1 Ador, adoreum, n.
Wheat that springeth not wel
out of the hose, when it groweth
in the eare. 1 Pavera, f.
A kind of wheat. 1 Clusimum
A kind of smal, fine, & white
wheat. 1 Siligo, olyra, f.

A wheaten strawe.
2 Calamus, m
A kinde of french wheat.

Tiph wheat, or wheat of Rome: 
a certaine corne much like to
our rie. 1 Typha, f.
The fourth sort of the wheate, 
called Far 1 Alicastrum, n.
Beech wheate. 1 Fagopyrum
Sommer wheat of three mo­
nethes grouth.

Fine winter wheat.
1 Tritium, siligineum.
Turkish wheate.
1 Triticum Saracinium. 
Triticum Turcicum.
A kinde of wheate, which
hath an hundred cornes in one
eare. 1 Certigranus, m.
A wheat plum, vide plumme.

of wheate. 1 Farreus Farri­
nus, triticeus, 2 Frumentace­

wheat, or floure. 1 Siligineus.
Of, or belonging to the wheate
Ador. 1 Adoreus, ad.
Ful of wheate. 1 Triticosus.

ecquando? adu.

When thou wilt. 1 Vndelibet

Where?

Where you list, or where it li­
keth you. 1 Qualibet, qualu­
bet, vbilubet.
Euerye where 1 Passim, Vbique
Where I am. 1 Huc, adu.
No where. 1 Nullibi, adu.
Whereas 1 Quum, vbi, adu.
Whereby. 1 Vnde, ex quo, 
quo, abl.
Wheresoever. 1 Vbicunque, si­
cubi, vbiubi, vbilibet.
Wherefore not, or why not?
1 Quidni? quin?

cause? 1 Quamobrem? qua­
propter? quid autem? qua de
re? quianam? quin? quare?
cur? adu.
Do you aske why? or wherfore?

Wherefore I pray you.
1 Quamobrem.
Wherefore, or therefore.

inde, ergo, quamobrem, qua­
propter, quo, con.

To commit Whore­
dome.

Veneris, 2 Rutellus, m.

gentaria, ignis, m.

lare scortum, sexantia.

ria fæmina proseda, schænicu­

nine of the clocke, open their

Whoredome. 1 Pellicatus, con­
cubinatus, m. fornicatio, f. 
meretricium, adulterium, le­

VENTORVM
GENERA.


1 Easte.

quilo, boreas.

circius, gallicus.

Boreazephyrus.

8 West, north-west.
Corus, japyx, agrestes.

9 Weste. 
Zephyrus, favonius.

10 Weste, south-weste.
Lybs, affricus.

11 SOVTH-WEST.
Notozephyrus.

12 South, southwest.
Libonotus, caurus.

13 Sowthe. 
Auster, notus.

14 Sowth, sowth east.
Carbas.

15 SOWTH-EAST. Eurono­
tus, euroauster, notapeliotes

16 Easte, sowth-east. Vultur­
nus, altanus, græcus.

1 Philosophus, m.
wisdome, or prudence.
1 Prudentia, sapientia, sophia
phronesis, 2 sagacitas, solertia
f. sal, m.
Loue, or study of wisdome.
1 Philosophia, f.
wise, or prudent. 1 Sapiens, ior­
issimus, prudens, consydera­
tus, consultus, cordatus, do­
ctus, phronimos, scitus, persa­
piens, sophus, 2 providens, cau­
tus, circumspectus, solers, sa­
gax, issimus, salsus, callens, cal­
lidus, 3 catus, consiliosus, ad.
wise, or ready. 3 Decentarius.
very wise. 1 Persapiens, pan­
sophus, ad
Mightie in wisdome.
1 Sapientipotens, ad.
wisely. 1 Sapienter, pruden­
ter, consyderate, consulto, cor­
date. 2 Sagaciter, sobrie, soler­
ter, provide, providenter, pro­
be, perite, graviter, custodite
cailide, caute, circumspecte.
More wisely. 1 Sagacius, sapien­
tius, adu.
Better standing with wisdome.
1 Consultius, adu.
Very wisely. 1 Persapienter, sa­
gacissime, 2 persalse, adu.
Most wisely.
1 Consultissime, adu.

In no wise. 
1 Neutiquam, nequaquam, 
nullatenus, adu.
In any wise, by al meanes.
1 Quoquo modo.

To wish. 
1 Opto, volo, voveo.
To wish fervently.
1 Exopto, præopto, cupio, ave­
o, desydero.
To wish together. 1 convoveo.
To wish rather. 1 Præopto.
wished for. 1 Optatus, exopta­
tus, desyderatus, p.
A wishe. 1 Optatum, votum, de­
syderium, n.
a wishing. optatio, desyderatio
that is to be wished for or desired.
Optabilis, exoptabilis, ad.
Much wished for.
1 Ado ptatissimus, ad.
That hath been greatly wished.
1 Votivus, ad.
More wished for. 1 Optatius.
Euen as one would wish.
1 Optato, exoptato, 3 optatim

A Wispe, waze, or
wreath. 1 Peniculus, cesticil­
lus, m. peniculum, penicullum, 
n. vi. waze. 
An arse wispe. 1 Anitergium, n.

To Witch, v. to be­
witch. 
A witch, hegge, sorceresse, or en­
chauntresse. 1 Saga, venefica, 
volatica, præcantrix, præcan­
tatrix lamia, f.
A very great witch.
1 Trivenefica, f.
witches, or sorceresses wich keep
about tombs and cut of some mem­ 
bers from dead bodies, which they
abuse to there sorceries.
1 Tymbades, f.
Witch crast. 1 Magia, magice
fascinus, m. 2 Fascinum, vene­
num, n. Dardaniæ artes, vide
enchauntment. 
witchcraft done with hatchets
1 Axionomantia, f.
A kind of witchcraft. 1 goetia
witchcraft by hearbs. 1 botano­
mantia.
witching. 1 Fascinatio, effasci­
natio, f. fascinium, n.
Pertaining to witchcraft.
1 Magicus, ad.
he that vseth witchcraft. 1 magus

With. 1 Cum, 2 apud, per
in, ex, præp.
together with. 1 pariter, simul, 
vna, adu.
with much adoe. 1 Vix, adu.
Within. 1 intra, præp, & adu, in
tus adu, 2 cis, vt cis paucos di­
es. within fewe daies. 
Within, or inward.
1 Introrsus, introrium, adu.
Being within. 1 Intrarius.
within 3 daies. 1 Intra triduum
Into a place within, 1 Intro.
Without, 1 Extra.
Without, or wanting. 1 Sine, 
absque, 2 cura, vt citra codicil­
los, citra invidiam.
Without order. 2 Passim, adu.
Without punishment.




1 Impune, adu.
Without the dores. 1 Forinse­
cus, foris, vt esse foris, aforis.
From without. 1 Foris.
Without. 1 Foras, vt ire foras.
Without care. dissolutelie.
2 Dissolute, adu.
Without, or on the outside.
1 Extra, adu.
More without. 1 Exterius, adu.
Without, toward the outwarde
part. 1 Extrorsum, adu.
Without constraint.
1 Sponte, vltro, adu.
Without daunger, or perill.
1 Tuto, adu.
Without delaie. 1 Evestigio, 
mox, ilico, protinus, actutum, 
confestim, adu.
Without desert. 1 Immerito.
Without noise. 1 Tacite, adu.
Without dissimulation. 2 aperte
without doubt. 1 Proculdubio
Without booke. 1 Memoriter.
Without end. 1 In infinitum.
Without looking for.
1 Ex insperato, adu.
Without trouble. 2 Sedate.
Without pleasure, or delectati­
on. 1 Illepidus.
Without hope. 1 Expes.

To Withdraw. 
1 Subtraho, distraho, abstraho
detraho, retraho, subduco, ab­
alieno, 2 amoveo, demoveo, e­
voco, sevoco, revoco, semove­
o, traduco, abduco.
To withdrawe himselfe, to con­
veigh himselfe awaie quickly.
1 Præripio, adimo, 2 excerpo, 
conjicio.
To with drawe ones minde. vi
alienate.
to be withdrawen. 1 distrahor.
Withdrawen. 1 Detractus, 
retractus, 2 remotus, p.
That could not be withdraw­
en. 2 Irrevocatus, ad.
A withdrawing of ones minde
from. 1 Abalienatio, f.

gainesay.

To Witnesse. 
1 Testor, attestor, testificor, 3
Testimonio.
To call to witnesse. 1 Conte­
stor, 2 appello.
to be witnes to an arest, or other
like matter, in iudgment, or law
1 Audictor, m.
A witnesse, or giver of wit­
nes. 1 Testis, testificator, m. 
trix, f. martyr, m. attestans, p. 2
Arbiter, m.
Bearing witnesse. 1 Testans, 
attestans, p. conscius, ad.
Witnessed. 1 Testatus, conte­
status, testificatus, attestatus.
Proved by witnesse.
1 Attestatus, p.
Bearing witnes. 1 Attestatus.
A faithfull witnes.
1 Testis fidelis, 3 Antipas, m.
A false witnesse.
1 Pseudomartyr, m.
An eie witnesse. 1 Testis ocu­
latus.
A witnesse, or evidence.
1 Testimonium, n. testatio, f.
A witnessing, or a witnes bea­
ring. 1 Testificatio, f.
Proofe by witnes. 1 parastasis, f.
A taking of witnesse.
1 Contestatio, f.
An injunction to appeare, and
beare witnesse.
1 Denunciatio testamenti.
That by law may beare witnes.
1 Testabilis, ad.
That cannot be taken for wit­
nesse by lawe. 1 Intestabilis, ad
Which hath not bin cited, or
summoned to giue witnesse in a
ny matter before a ludge.
1 Inattestatus, ad.

To be out of ones
witte. 1 Insanio.
Witie. 1 Ingenium, n. 2 mens, 
minerva, f. acumen, n.
A smal, a prettie witte.
1 Ingeniolum, n.
Sharpenesse of witte. 1 Subtili­
tas, solertia, 2 sagacitas, acri­
monia, f. acumen, n.
Wittie sayinges. 1 Facetiæ, ar­
gutiæ, f. 2 sales, m.
A fine and wittie thing set to
adorne ons talke. 1 scitamentum, n
A wittie or wise sentence.
1 Sententia, f.
Wittie. 1 Solers, scitus, ingeni­
osus, industrius, subtilis, corda­
tus, 2 argutus, artificiosus, cau­
tus, dædalius, dædalus, salsus, 
acutus, perspicaxacer, nasutus
Well in his wittes. 1 Mentis
compos, sanæ mentis.
Without witte, or besides his
witte. 1 mentis inops, insanus.
Witlesle. 1 vecors, inconsultus
vacerra, socors, vesanus, ad.
Quicke witted, or very wittie.
1 Peringeniosus, persubtilis, 2
peracutus, perargutus, persal­
sus, perspicax, ad.
Dull witted. 1 Bardus, ad
Wittilie. 1 Ingeniose, scite, so­
lerter, industrie, cordate, 2 a­
cute, argute, salse, sagaciter, 
provide, adu.
very wittily. 1 Peringeniose, 
2 peracute, præacute, adu.

conscius, ad.

W ANTE O.

Woade for diers. 
1 Glastum, guadum, n. isatis.

woe, or sorrow. 1 dolor
Woe to. 1 Væ.

To be wofull. 1 doleo.
Wofulnes. 1 Dolor, m.
Woeful, or sorowful. 1 lamenta­
bilis, miserrimus, mœstus, tri­
stis, perluctuosus, ad.

A wolfe, 1 Lupus, m.
a female wolfe. 1 lupa, f.




A kinde of wolfe higher then the
rest, that liveth by hunting, not
hurting men, roughe in winter, 
bare in sommer. 1 Thos.
A kinde of wolues. 1 Chaus.
A little wolfe.
1 Lupulus, lupillus, m.
A hunter of wolues.
1 Luparius, m.
Wolvish, or of a wolfe.
1 Lupinus, ad.
An eating, or consuming soare, 
quicklie pearcing to the bones, &
devouring the bodie, called the
wolfe. 1 Herpes exedens.

The wombe, or mat­
trice.

matrix, locula, f.
A little wombe. 1 Vterculus, 
vtriculus, m.
That came both out of one womb
1 Vterinus, ad.

To make like a Wo­
man wanton, or nice. 
1 Effæmino, muliero
A woman. 1 Mulier, fæmina, f
A woman, or any of the female
kind. 1 Fæmina, fæmella, fæmi­
nula, f.

ripotens, ad.
A deformed woman, like a shee
ape.

A little woman.

A graue, sober, and motherly
woman.

An old woman.
1 Anus vetula, f.
A woman child with in, or vn­
der age.
1 Pupilla, f.
A woman going before a pompe, 
representing a drunken woman
her feete often tripping against
the stones.
1 Petreia, f.
A working woman.
1 Operaria, f.
An vngratious woman.
1 Nequam.
A manlie woman.
1 Virago, 3 andrago, f.
No woman. 1 Nemo, com. g.
A woman new maried.
1 Nympha, sponsa, f.
A woman full of prattles, or
wordes.
1 Lingulaca, lingulata, f.
An honest woman of her tongue
1 Eulalia, f. 2 Cygnus niger.
A woman great with child.
1 Mulier Prægnans, 
Mulier fæta. 
Mulier Gravida.
A woman hauing two twinns
at one birth.
1 Gemellipara.
A woman lying in childbirth.
 1 Puerpera, f.
A woman hired to mourne at a
buriall, to praise the life & deeds
of the dead bodye.
1 Præfica, f.
A company of women doing
any thing together.
1 Axies.
A little old woman.
1 Anicula.
Women serving Bacchus.
1 Mimallones, mimallonides.
A woman delivered of her first
childe.
1 Primipara, f.
A woman Sainte, or Goddesse.
1 Dea, diua, f.
A woman seruant.
1 Ancilla, ancillula, f.
A woman that hath brought
forth twise.
1 Bipara, f.
Womens attire.
1 Mundus, m.
A womans Bonet, cap, or hoode.
1 Calyptra, f.
A womans gowne with a
traine. 1 Cyclas.
Womanlinesse. 1 Muliebritas.
a lover of women. 1 philogynus
Companions of women, or such
as attend, and waite vpon them
3 Gynæcomites.
They that be together in a roome
with women. 1 Gynæciarij.
Of, or belonging to a women.

ebris, mulicrosus, ad.

vell 1 Miror.

To wonder greatly. 1 Emiror.
To wonder together. 1 commiror
To cause to wonder.
2 Stupefacio.
To make wonderfull, or marve­
louse. 1 Mirifico.
A wonderer. 1 Mirator, admi­
rator, 3 miro. m
He that looketh vnto, and shew
eth the meaning of wonders, and
strange sights. 1 Ostentarius, m.
A wondering. 1 Miratio, ad­
miratio, f.
Wdonderfulnes. 3 admirabilitas
A teller of wonders. 3 miridicus
A wonder, or a wonderful, or
straunge thing.

dum, 2 monstrum, portentum
prodigium, ostentum, stupen­
dum. n.
Wonders, or wonderfull things

A wonderfull thing to heare.

bilis, mirificus, mirus, 2 mon­
strosus, prodigiosus, incredibi­
lis, inenarrandus, horrendus, 
visendus, ad.
Very wonderful, or maruelouse.

Wonderful to bee heard.

That wondereth. 1 Miratus, p.

Wonderfullie. 1 Mire, mirifice, 
mirabiliter, admirabiliter, mon­
strifice, miranter, 2 singulari­

To be Wont. 




1 Soleo, persoleo, assoleo, su­
esco, consuesco, assuesco, insu­
esco.
To be wont often. 1 Solito.
It was wont. 1 Assolet, imp.
Wonted. 1 Consuetus, solitus
insuefactus, assuefactus, p.
Not wonted, or accustomed.
1 Insuetus, insolitus, p.
Wont, or custome.
1 Consuetudo, assuetudo, f.
Then is wont. 1 solito, abl. qui
nisi adv. aut comparativis
non jungitur.
After my wont, or manner.
1 Solens, solito more.
As men are wont.
1 Humanitus, ad.
Not as is wont. 1 Insolite, adu
Plus Solito. 
Minus Solito.

To make woode. 1 Furio.
To be madde, or woode.

To be woode againe.
1 Rabio, interfuro.
To be woode angrie against one
1 Obsævio.
To cease to be woode, or angrie
1 Desævio.
To be stamping, or staring woode
1 Indignor.
Woodnes, fury, rage, lacke of rea­
son. 1 Insanies, insania, rabies

petus, m.
Woode, or mad.

Wood. 1 Lignum, durata, n.

the ores do hang by a peece of lea­

1 Causima, f.
Wood that smoketh not.

A kind of bended wood, where­
with burdens are wont to be ca­
ried. 1 Amphicyrton.
A precious & odoriferous wood
brought out of India, to make
perfumes, called red stirax.

of India: some call it saunders.

A kind of wood that giueth light
1 Licinium, n.
wood of aloes, a very sweet
wood. 1 Agalocum, n.
A sweet and odoriferous wood
whereof natural balme com­
meth.

A wood, or parke.

To carrie Word a­
gaine. 1 Renuncio.
Word it brought.
1 Nunciatum est, impers.
A word.
1 Verbum, vocabulum, dictum
n dictio, locutio, lexis, vox, f. 
sermo, logos. 2 Sonus, m.
A little word. 1 Vocula, f. ver­
bulum, n.
A watch word. 1 Synthenia, f.
Wordes, or sayinges having di­
vers senses.
1 Amphibolia, amphibologia, f
wordes of one signification.
1 Synonyma, n.
A word having many significa­
tions, as Aries, an instrument
in warre, a celestiall signe, and a
ramme.
1 Æquivocum, n. amphibolia
amphibologia, f. amphibolon.
Trifling wordes.
1 Logi, m.
Wordes not perfectly pronoun­
ced for feare.
1 Tertiata verba.
Fewe wordes, or little talke, or
speach.
1 Pauciloquium, n.
The primitiue word from whence
other are derived.
2 Positio, f.
A straunge, or rare word, not
much vsed. 1 Glossema, n.
Wordes finely spoken.
Verba Byssina. 
Verba Phalerata.
Wordes franckely spoken.
1 Verba dapsilia.
Wordes called primitiues.
1 Verba primogenia.
That helpeth one with his good
word, at a time of election.
1 Suffragatorius, m.
Full of wordes.
1 Verbosus, argutus, largilo­
quus, linguax, linguaculus, ad.
That vseth faire wordes with
small effect. 1 Chrestologus, m.
Of, or belonging to a word.
1 Verbalis, ad.
In fewe wordes. 1 Breviter.
At a worde.
1 Brevi, in brevi, adu.
Vsing many wordes.
1 Verbose, adu.
Word, by worde. 1 Verbatim, 
ad verbum, adu.

To Worke, act:. or
procure. 2 Procreo, texo, struo­
conflo.
To worke newe. 2 Recudo.
To worke together. 2 Contexo.
To set hand to the worke that is
in doing: also to worke by fittes.
1 Interfacio.
To worke out. 1 Perago, vt la­
bor is pensum peragere, to
worke out his taske that he is ap­
pointed to. 
To worke cunningly.
1 Elaboro, fabrefacio.
To worke some thing.
1 Detorno.
To worke deceite. 1 StruEre do­
los, commoliri dolum.
To worke neut: or labour.
1 Operor, molior.
To worke together. 1 Commoli­
or, cooperor.
To worke by privie meanes.
2 Irrepo, vt lubenter irrepere
in opinionem gratiæ alicujus
To worke by privie meanes, that
he may be counted only to bee in
ones fauour. 
To worke by collusion.
1 Prævaricor.
To be wrought, or done: wrought.
1 Factus, p.
Wrought with the instrument
Scalprum.
1 Scalpratus, p.
Wrought, or sowed.
1 Insutus, p.
Wrought curiously. Elaboratus
p. operosus, faberrimus, ad.
Wrought by rule.
1 Amustitatus, p.
Wrought betweene.

Wormes that be in a pine apple
tree, the biting wherof is vene­
mous.
Pityocampæ, f.
A worme breeding in beames.
1 Midas.
A worme with many feete, cal­
led a palmer.
1 Campe, campa, millepeda, 
centipeda, f. oniscus, m.
A little worme breeding in
waxe.

A stinking worme, breeding in
wood, or paper.
1 Cimex, m.
A worme that breedeth in the
rootes of trees, and corrupteth, or
eateth them.
1 Rauca, f.
The silke worme.
1 Bombyx, m.
The worme where crimosin co­
lour is made.
1 Alcarnes.
A greene worme shining like
gold, and breedeth in the toppes
of ashes, oliues, and such like.
1 Cantharis, cantharida, f.
The worme breeding in wood, &
eating it.
1 Termes, termus, caries, tere­
do, cossus, cosses.
The worme, and painefull remors
and gnawing of conscience, horri­
bly tormenting the wicked men.
2 Furiæ, f.
A venemous worme, of whose
stroke, or biting, the flesh rotteth.
1 Seps.
A gloe worme.
1 Cicindela, noctiluca, nocti­
lucerna, nitedula, lampyris, f.
A worme that eateth the bodies
of the dead.
1 Letophagus, m.
A worme in a dogges tongue, 
which maketh him mad, if it bee
not taken out.
1 Lytta, f.
A little worme breeding no
where else, but where the Lion is
bred which worme when the li­
on hath once tasted and eaten, he
dieth by and by
1 Leontophonon.
A flowe worme being blind.
1 Cæcilia, f.
An heary worme, breeding in
leaues of trees, with many feete.
1 Auscaripeda, f.
A ringworme.
1 Impetigo, f.
A worme hearie, and of many
feet, eating vines.
1 Volvox, convolvolus, convol­
vulus, m. volucra, f.
An earth worme: also a long
worme in the earth, or in a mans
body.
1 Lumbricus, m.
A worme breeding in old timber, 
or wood, white, & great belliea
with a blacke head, called a can­
ker.
1 Xylophagus, m.
A worme breeding in the leaues
of a pech tree.
1 Cephalocrustes.
A gold worme.
1 Aurialis.




A worme breeding in an elme.

vines.

worme. Bombyx.

A Yeare. 
1 Annus, 2 Vertumnus, m.
The yeare of Iubile, or of relea­
sing, which happened everie fifte
yeare. 1 Iubilæus, m.
A yeare and a halfe.
1 Sesquiannus.
The daie that maketh the leape
yeare. 1 Bissextus, bisextus, m
exheresimus Dies. 
Intercalaris Dies.
That which returneth everie
fift yeare. 1 Penteris.
The leape yeare. 1 Intercalaris. 
Embolismalis Annus. 
Bissextilis Annus. 
Bisextilis Annus.
The 4 seasons of the yere.
2 Cardines temporum.
The space of an yere.
1 Anno, per annum.
The space of 2 yeres.
1 Biennium. 3 Diennium, n.
The space of 4 yeres.
1 Quadriennium, n.
The space of 5 yeres.
1 Quinquennium, lustrum, n. 
Olympias.
The space of 6 yeres.
1 Sexennium, n.
The space of 7 yeres.
1 Septennium, n.
The space of 8 yeres.
1 Octennium, n.
The space of 9 yeres.
1 Novennium, n.
The space of 10 yeres.
1 Decennium, n.
That is done yerelie, or everie
yere at a certaine time.
1 Solennis, annuus, anniversa­
rius, ad.
That is done everie 2 yere.
1 Biennalis, ad.
That is done everie 3 yere.
1 Triennalis, trietericus, ad.
That is done everie 4 yere.
1 Quadriennialis, quinquen­
nalis, sexennalis, septennalis, 
octennalis novennalis decen­
nalis.
One yeare olde.
1 Anniculus, annotinus, hornus
hornotinus, ad.
Two yeres olde.
1 Bimus, biennis, ad.
Almost two yeares olde.
1 Bimulus, ad
Of three yeres olde
1 Trimus, triennis, ad.
Of foure yeres olde.
1 Quadrimus, quadriennis, ad.
Almost foure yeares olde.
1 Quadrimulus, ad.
Of fiue yeres olde.
1 Quinquennis, & cæt sexen­
nis, septenus, septennis, oc­
tennis, novennis, decennis, bi­
lustris, vt bellum bilustre.
Of, or belonging to a yere.
1 Annalis, annarius, annualis
annuarius, ad.
Of this yeare.
1 Hornus, hornotinus, ad.
Of halfe a yeare.
 Semestris, ad.
Yerelie, or yere by yeare.
1 Quotannis, annuatim, adu.

Yeast, vide barme.

To Yeelde: acti. 1 Dedo
trado, vt se dedere, tradere, to
yeld himself, dico, as vt se alicui
in clientelam dicare, to yeelde
himselfe to ones tuition, con­
cedo, vt primas alicui in
dicendo partes concedere,




to yeeld the price of eloquence to
one. 
To yeeld, or bring forth as the
earth doeth. 1 Reddo, 2 effun­
do, fundo, suggero.
To yeeld, or pay. 1 Reddo.
To yeeld, or render vp.
1 Prodo, dedo.
to yeeld vp, or resigne. v. surrender
To yeeld an account.
1 Reddere Rationem. 
Dictare Rationem. 
Referre Rationem. 
Dare Rationem. 
2 Calculum ponere.
To yeeld, or giue over, neut.
1 Cedo, concedo, 2 pareo, suc­
cumbo.
To yeeld from. 1 Decedo.
To yeeld, or giue vp the ghost.
1 Exhalo Spiritum. 
Expiro Spiritium. 
Efflo Spiritum.
yeelded vp
1 Redditus, deditus, p.
A yeelding. 1 Cessio, deditio, f.
A yeelding againe. 1 Restitutio
That yeeldeth it selfe to another
1 Dedititius, ad.

to be yellow, or of coloure like gold
