Z ANTE E.

To haue Zeale, or
great desire to a thing. 
1 Zelo, zelor.
Zeale, or great loue. 1 zelus, m.

Zedarie, or Worme
seed. 1 zadura, f.


Z ANTE O.

the Zodiacke a circle
in heaven, wherin are the 12 signs
1 Zodiacus, signifer, m.
A Zone. 1 zona.





Certaine generall
heads of Birds, co­
lours, &c. as folow.

Birdes. 
To go a birding. 
1 Aucupor.
A birder. 1 Auceps.
A birding, or fowling.
1 Aucupium, n. aucupatio, f.
A birding place. 1 Aucipium, n
Pertaining to birding
1 Aucupatorius, ad.
a bird. 1 Avis, volucris, ales, or­
nis, ios, velithos, aliger, vo­
latile.
a little bird. Avicula, f.
A young bird, Pullus, pullulus.
Birds. 2 Volantes, plu.
The birdes gotten by fouling.
Aucupia.
Anie bird fed in the howse.
1 Boschis, vel boscis, idis.
Great birds that be fed, Alites.
young birds vnfeathered.
Implumes pulli.
Birds that cannot flie.
Involucres pulli.
Birds which liue as well by land as
by water. Amphibia.
Belonging to birds. Avitius, ad.
Birds whole footed, as all water
fowle are for the most part.
Palmipedes, solipedes.
a bird so light that it is caried eve­
rie way with the wind cepphos
A certain sea fowl, or fresh water
fowle. Phalerides.
a bird having a wing of crimsen
colour.
Phænicopterus, m.
A little bird which is at deadly
hatred with the asse.
Ægithus, m.
A bird with blacke feathers, on
the head, much like a linget, or
tittling. Atricapilla, f.
A bird that counterfeiteth the
neying of a horse, Anthus.
A great white bird of the kind of
ravens Ixon.
a bird wont to come to the altars
and carie awaie a burning coale
as a token of ill luck.
1 Spinturnix.
An vnlucky bird called also spin
turnix, the sight whereof was so
vnfortunat, that vppon that
cause onlie, they did often times
purge the cittie by sacrifice.
Incendraria, f.
a bird which breaketh the eagles
egges. Subis, f.
birds which by their flight or voice
signified than the thing purposed, 
was not to be followed. Remores
A bird which singeth sweetlie
in the morning. Lucar.
A bird drinking as though he
did bite the water, having long
red legs and bill.
Porphyrio.
A ravenous bird sometime figh­
ting with the eagle so valiantly
that in grapling together, they
fall to the ground, and be taken
of shepeheards.
Ptynx vel ptynge.
a bird in Æthiope, greater then
the eagle, having horns like a
goat. Tragoponades.
A bird that in time of treading
sweateth bloud. Erodius, m.
A bird that hath a loud voice, 
and a fair colour.
Gnaphalus, m.
A bird slow of flight.
Gradipes.
a bird whom if one do behold that
hath the yelow iaundis, imme­
diatly the man becommeth whol
& the bird dieth galgulus, icterus
A bird that hath a croked and
long bill, blacke of colour, the fe­
thers brown & full of spottes.
Helorius.
a bird about the bignes of ardeola




Himantopus, m.
A birde which in southsaying
forbade a thing to be done.
Inebræ, divina avis.
A birde which accompanieth the
Quaile, over the seas.
Cychramus, m
A birde which in his flight fetch­
eth a compasse. Circania, f.
A bird making her neste with
Cinamon.
Cinnamologus, m.
A bird breeding of the Alcions
nest. Ceyx, vcis.
A certaine vnluckie birde.
Parra, f.
A birde that by his voice, signifi­
eth somewhat to come: also any
singing birde.
Oscinis, vel oscen, com. g.
A birde of the bignes of a cul­
ver, which Gaza translateth Vi­
nago. Oenas.
A birde that hath no spleene.
Agocephalus, m.
A birde whose dung cureth the
dimnes of the eies. Caladrus, m.



Proper names of birdes
placed alphabetically. 


A.

An arsefoote, a little diver, or a
didapper. Mergulus, m.


B.

A barnacle. Chelonolopex, 
Chelonalops.

A bat, reremouse, or flitter
mouse. Vespertilo nyctrix, f.

A blacke birde, vide Ousell.

A birgander, a bird of the kinde
of geese chenalopex, f. vulpanser

a bittour. Butio, ardeastellaris

A brambline. Montifringilla, f.

A bull finche. Rubicilla, f.

A Bunting, or little larke. Ter­
raneola, rubetra, alaudula, f.

A bustard, or bistard. Bistardus
tetrao, otis vel odos, erythro­
taton, tarda, f. asio, onis.

A buzzard. Buteo, m.

A bald buzzard. Percnos, m. 
planga, f.

A butwyne. Capella, f.


C.

A Canarie bird. Vireo, chloris.

A Castrell, or kestrell. Tinuncu­
lus, vel tintinnunculus, m.

A chaffinch, spinke, or sheld apple: 
a birde singing in colde wether.
1 Fringilla vel frigilla, f.

A chough Graculus, m. mone­
dula, f. Frigulat graculus.

A cornish chough. Pyrocorax, m

A colemouse, or gnat snapper.
Ficedula, f.

A Cocke. Gallus, gallinaceus, 
m. cucurit gallus.

A cormorant, or sea crowe. Pha­
lacrocorax, corvus marinus, 
mergus.

A Cowte, or sea crowe.
Corvus aquaticus.

A crane. Grus, palamedia avis

A young crane. Vipio, m.

A crowe. Corvus, cornix, sati­
ria, plebeius ales.

A little crowe. Cornicula, f.

Of a crow. coracinus, corvinus

A night crowe, or raven.
Nycticorax, nyctuavene, cicu­
ma, cicina, f.

A cuckoe. Cocyx cuculus, cucul­
lus, cuculat cuculus.

A Culver. vide dooue. 

A curlewe. Curlinus, m.


D.

A Daker henne. Crex.

A dawe, or iacke dawe.
Monedula, f. vide choughe.
 
A Didapper, diver, or dipchicke.
Vrinatrix, Columbris, vrinucu­
la, mergulus, m.

A doue, pigeon, or culver.
Columbus, columba, peristera

A Turtle doue. Turtur, dilecta.

The chast turtle doue.
Castus turtur.

The young dooue, or pigeon.
Pullus columbaceus, pipio, 
onis.

Wilde pigeons, or doues which
Soothsaiers were wont to obserue
Titi.

A ring doue, or wood culver.
Palumbes, palumbus, torqua­
tus palumbus.

A stocke doue. Livia, vinago.

A ducke, or drake Anas.

A tame ducke. Anas cicur.

A wilde ducke. Anas fera, vel
silvestris.

A little ducke. Anaticula. 



E.

An Eagle. Aquila, ales Iovis.

Fierce Eagles. Aquilæ feroces.

An Eagle supposed to be a faul­
con of the second kinde.
Pygargus.

An Eagle that hath so strong a
beake, that she breaketh bones.
Ossifraga, ossifragus, sanqua­
lis, f.

A kinde of Eagles living chiefly
about pooles, and lakes.
Morphuus, peronopterus.

The right Eagle, of meane bignes
of colour tawnie. Gnesium, n.

A Bird saith Festus, of the kind
of Eagles, the southsaiers, saieth
Plinie, take it diverslie, some for
the chicke of a vulture, some for
a young Eagle, before his taile be
white: this bird alwaies gaue sig­
nification of good lucke.
lmmussulus, vel, vt alij scribunt, 
immusulus, vel immustulus.

An Eate Bee, vide woodpecker. 

An Egret. Asterias.


F.

A Feasant. Phasianus, itis, or­
nix.

A Feasant hen Phasiana, f.

A Flaxflince. Linipha, f.

A Flittermowse, vide batte.

A Fenducke, vide Morehen.

A Fieldfare. Collurio, glaucium.


G.

A Ganet. Penelope.

A Glow birde that shineth by
night. Lampyris, m.

A Godwitte, a bird of delicate
meate. Attagen, attagena.

ellus, m. carduelis, miliaria, au­
rimitris, chrysomitris, acan­
this.

A gleade, vide kyte.

onis.

phus, vultur, m.

Vulturinus, ad.

on grapes and figges. Ficedula, f

Gavia cineracea.

M.

feete to goe, but onely stumpes.

clawes, which hunteth after

Luscinia, Philomela.

Molliceps.

Sitta.

Noctua aurita, otis, idis.

thers on every side of her heade
like eares. Asio, onis.

kind of hawkes, flying by night
Hybris.

Merula, misippa, turdus.

fra avis, apud Horatium.

P.

can, vel pelecanus, m.

duck. Boscha, f. vel potius bos­
cas, adis.

A Pie. Picus, m. pica, citta, f.

A chattering pie. Picaloquax.

A Pigeon, vide doue.
 
A kind of Pigeons called, an eate
corne, or eate wheate.
Pyralis, frugipeta, f.

A Pinnock, titling, or hedge spa­
rowe: a bird which breedeth vp
the Cuckoes egges in steede of her
owne. Curruca, f. epialis, græc.

A Popiniaie, or parrat.
Psittacus, psittace, es, f.

Garrulus Psittacus.

A Plover. Pardalus, pluviarius

A Plungeon: a kinde of water
fowle with a long reddish bill.
Phalacrocorax.

Phaleris, dis, f.

A night Raven, vide crowe.

A Redshanke. Hæmatopodus, 
odls, Hæmathoes

buteo.

cilla.

A Swallowe. 1 Hirundo, 
chelido, f.

culicilega, f. cinclus, m.

Swallowes which want the
vse of their feete. Apodes.

A sea swallow. Drepanis.

nus, olor, m.

A wild Swanne braying like
an asse. Onocrotalus, m.

Certaine ravenous birds like to
Swannes, having beneth their
mouth a little gorge, into which
they swallow their meat gree­
dily. Oenocratali.

A Stare, or starling. Sturnus.

A place where Thrushes are
kept asatting. Turdarium, n.

vel fringillago, f. parus major

Nun. Parus minor.

eat bee Apiaster, apiastra, me­
rops, mellisuga, picus, & pi­
cunnus.

A sea woodcocke, because it
hath a long bill, not vnlike a
woodcocke. Trochilos, vel
trochilus.

vel trochilus.

A kinde of birds called of some

Immusculi, m.

A little wrenne alwaies at
jarre with the Eagle.
Regaliolus, m.

Wry necke. Iynx, torquilla.

A yelamber. Luteus, vel lutea.






Voces inarticulatæ
volatilium quorun­
dam, secundum Sido­
nium, Ovi. & Iulium
Pollucem.

la clangit: Accipiter pipat:

culat: Perdix cacabat: Anser
gratitat, glacitat: Cygnus
drensat: Turtur, atque Co­
lumba gemunt: Palumbes
plausitat: Ciconia gloterat: 
Gallus cucurit; Gallina gra­
cillat, glocit, glocidat: Pavo
pupillat: Grus gruit: Vultur
pulpat: Graculus frigulat: 
Milvus lipit jugit: Anas tetri­

pisitat: Turdus trutilat: Acre­
dula mitilat: Coturnix grylis­
sat: galgulus glocitat: Merula
stridet, vel modulatur: Vpu­
pa popissat: Meleagris cac­
cissat: Vespertilio stritlet: Pi­
ca picatur, vel modulatur: 
Cuculus cuculat: Pubo bu­
bulat: Noctua cucubat: Vlu­
la vlulat: Butio bubit
Regulus zinzilulat.

Apes bombilat: Parus tinni­
nat.

pedum animalium.

pus vlulat: Aper frendet:

ger glocitat: Taurus mugit:

Ovis balat: Sus grunnit: Ca­

Grillus grillat: Sorex disticat
Serpens, & Anguis sibilant: 
Rana coaxat.




Colours.

A Colour. 1 Color, tinctus, 
m. tinctura, f.

Of one colour. Vnicolor, mo­
nochramateus, monochro­
matos, & monochramatus.

Of 2 colours. Bicolor, ad.

Of 3 colours. Tricolor, ad.

Of sundry, or diverse colors. Dis­
color, varicolor, multicolor.

That is of changeable colours.
Versicolor, ad.

Ill coloured. Decolor, ad.

A perfect, full, and deep colour
Color satur, color plenus.

A good, liuely, durable, and la­
sting colour. Color pertinax.

A vading, decaying, or a deade
colour Color evanidus.

A liuelie, braue, trimme, and
gallant colour. Color floridus.

A darke, duskish, or sad colour.
Color surdus, color austerus.

A weak and vnperfect colour
Color dilutus, color remissus

Painters colours. Pigmenta, n.

A colour made of Ceruse, and
ruddle burned together, called of
some Patise, red or arsenicke.
Sandix.




The middle colour betwixte
blacke and white. Elbum, n.

Of that colour. Elbidus, ad.

Of the colour of a Iasper stone.
Iaspideus color.

Colour in graine, or twise dyed
Dibaphus, m.


A.

Arsenicke colour
Sandix, sandaracha, f.




Ash colour. Cinereus, cinera­
ceus, leucophæus, ad.

Azure colour. Cæuleus.


B.

Bay Colour. Badius, balius, ad

Black of colour. Niger, ater, 
pullus, ad.

Cole black. Anthracinus, fur­
uus, melaneus, melaneetes.

Black like pitch. Piceus, ad.

A bright black, like the fethers
of a Crow. Coracinus, ad.

Somewhat black. Nigellus, ad.

Black and bléw, mixed with
the color of led. lividus plumbeus.

Bleak, or pale of colour. Pallidus.

Blew like azure. Cæruleus, 
cærulus, 3 Blavus, ad.

Blew. Lividus, ad.

Blew like the sea waues. Thalas­
sicus, thalassinus, cymatilis.

A bright blew color. Cyaneus.

Somewhat blew. Subcærulus, 
lividulus, ad.

Blow with specks of gray.
Cæsius color.

A light, or Venice blew.
Venetus color.

Blewish, drawing to the colour
of purple. Indicus, ad.

Brown, swart, or dark of color. Pullus, fuscus, subniger, suba­
ter, bœticus, hiberus, ferrugi­
neus, spanus, nativus color.

A browne, or natural colour.
Pulligo, f.

A brown colour, that which is
mingled with black and red.
Ferrugo, f.

Brown blew. Luridus, ad.

Blunket colour, or light watchet
Scyricum, n.

lvus, tussus, ad.

corne. Orobitis.

like the flowres of mallowes.
Molochinus, m.

twise died. Dibapha, vel di­

To be, or waxe red. Irrubeo.

Red. Ruber, rubrus, rubeus, 
rubidus, rufatus, minius, ad.

dulus, ad.

Red, or strong of colour. Robus

That is red of colour. Robus, m

Very red of colour.
Rubicundus, sandarachinus.

A sad red colour Rufus color.

A bright red, or a clear shining
red, or fierie red colour. Rutilus, 
rutileus, igneus color.

A bloud red colour, v. sanguine

Tempered with red arsenick.
Sandarachatus, ad.

Of red arsenick. Sandarachinus

Fiery red like the eies of a Lion
glaucus, glaucinus, ad.

To wax somewhat ruddie.
Rutilesco.

A colour somewhat ruddy, or
bloud red, like the vine leafes in
harvest. Xerampelinus color,

A liuely ruddie color, wher with
harlots vse to color their faces.
Purpurissum, n. rubriceta, f.

A deep red colour. Burrhum, n

He that hath a swart red colour
Burrhus, ad.

Marked with red, as sheepe.
Rubricatus, ad

pon. Impluviatus, ad.

White, like Alabaster.

yellow. Aureus, aureolus, ruti­
lus, rutileus, rutilatus, ad.

A deepe, ful, and sad yellow co­
lour. Ruber, ad.

Bright yellow like a womannes
haire. Flavus.

A darke yellowe, like the colour
of honey. Mellinus, melleus.

Yellow like waxe.
Cereus, cerinus, ad.

Yellow like the yolke of an egge.
Luteus, ad.

A weake, or vnperfect yellow
like boxe. Buxeus, ad.

Yellowe colour, like rawe silke
yearne. Byslinus, ad

Yellow colour like saffron.
Croceus, crocinus, ad.

Yellow like mettall. Æneus, ad

Somewhat yellowish. Subftavus
ruteolus, pallidus, ad.

Having colour of the yeallow
Electrum, Chryselectrus.






Canes.

A Dog, or bitch. canis, m. v. f

A dog. Canis masculus.

A bitch, or brach. Canis
fœmina.

A little dog, or whelp. Catulus
& catellus, m.

A young dog, not yet well trai­
ned. Tyruncula canis.

A little bitch. Canicula, f.

A fierce dog. Canis acer.

A swift dog. Citus canis. 
Celer canis.

That hath A shril mouth. argutus.

That hath a coller on his neck
Armillatus.

An olde dog past the best.
Canis emeritus.

A mad dog. Canis rabidus, 
Canis rabiosus.

A spaniell, hound, or other dog
that hunteth by sent.
Canis generosus, 
Canis sagax, 
Canis odorus, 
Canis odorisequus.

A spaniell Hispaniolus, m.

A water spaniel.
Hispaniolus aquaticus, 
Hispaniolus villosus.

A land spaniell.
Hispaniolus agrarius, 
Hispaniolus capestris

A hound. Venaticus, m.

A drawing hound, or bloud
hound Investigarius, plaudus
canis scoticus.

A gase hound Agasæus, m.

A gray hound. Leporarius, 
gallicus.

A terrare. Terrarius, m.

A tumbler. Vertagus, m.

A mastife, or band dog.
Molossus.

A curre Canis gregarius, 
Canis degener.

A sheepheards, or heardmans dog
Canis pecuarius, 
Canis pastoralis, aggrega­
rius, m. pœmenis, pernix.

A farmers cur to keep the hous
Canis villaticus.

A little pretie dog, which wo­
men vse to plaie with: a fisting
hound. Mæliteus canis.

A mongrell. Hybris, hybrida.

A mongrell ingendred of a wolf
and a dog. lycisca, lyciscus, cra­
cuta, alopecida, alopecidos.

To barke like a dog. Latro.

To howle. 1 Vlulo, exululo, bau­
bor.

To go asaut as bitches do.
1 Catulio.

To set dogges on.
1 Immittere canes.

To hunt. Venot, sector, in
dago.

To draw, or follow by the foote.
Investigo.

To quest, or open as spaniels, or
hounds do when they haue the
sent, or sight of their game.
Nicto, is.

To cheere the hounds.
Hortari.

To crie like a young whelpe.
Glaucito.

Doggish, or currish.
Caninus, ad.

Of, or pertaining to a dogge.
Caninus, canarius, ad.

Pisces.

A fishe. Piscis, mas.

A freshe water-fishe, or river-­
fishe.
Piscis fluvialis, vel fluviatilis.

A fishe of the lake, ponde, or
mote Piscis lacustris.

A sea fishe.
Piscis marinus vel pelagius.

A little fishe. Pisciculus, m.

Salt fishe. Salsamenta, orum. 
pisces muria durati, vel con­
diti.

The Gilles of fishe. Branchiæ:

The Finnes, Pinnæ:

 the Backe
bone, Spina:

the Scale. Squa­
ma:

the Milt, Lactes:

It is pro­
perly the signe of a Male fishe: 
the Frie, or spawne, Ovum
Piscis:

a peece, or paring of fish,
Tomus:

The parting, or divi­
ding, Segmentum:

The Clees, or
clawes of a fishe, bending like
hookes, as in a Crabbe. Aceta­
bula, flagella, brachia, chelæ, 
forcipes denticulatæ, forci­
pata brachia cancrorum.

Things like hairs about Oisters: 
hornes of the Crabbe; Snaile, or
such like, whereby they feele, 
or grope their waie. Cirri, Bar­
be

 Shel fishes, testacei pisces.

A kinde of shel fishe in the sea.
Bosphorus, mya, f.

A certaine shelfishe, which be­
ing boiled through, yeeldeth a
most comfortable liquor, Sole­
nes:

They which take that fish
Solenistæ.

A shelfish of the Sea, that hath
a leader, whom they followe
as their king. Strombus.

A
shell fishe having an ill savour, 
like a goate, Tragos.

A kind of
shelfishe, wherein pearles doe
breede, Berberion, vel berbe­
ri, barbal, n.

A shell fishe.
Concha, f.

Fishes covered with a softe
smoth shell. Crustati pisces, 
molli testa aperculati.

Gristlie fishes, as Ray, or Scate
Cartilaginei pisces.

Greate fishes as whales, or such
like Cetacei pisces.

A place where great fishes bee
salted and solde. Cetaria, f.

Belonging to great fishes of the
sea, as whales. Cetarius, ad.

The intrales of great fishes, or




whales. 
Cetosa viscera.

A fish in the river Ganges, ha­
ving a snout like a Dolphin, but
much bigger. Platanista, f.

Certaine fishes seeking after
shadowie places, and much de­
lighted with the moist, and cold
Element. 
Psycotrophi.

A fishe, which alone is thought
to chewe his meate. 
Escarus, m.

A fish called Adonis. 
Exocœtus

A certaine craftie fish, which
biteth away the bait, & med­
leth not with the hook. 
Glanis, vel glanus.

A certaine fishe, which hurteth
much with his teeth. 
Dentex.

A greate fishe, enemy to the
Whale. Orca, f.

A certaine sea fishe, keeping
by the shore, not much vnlike
Pagrus Orthragoriscus, m.

A fishe onely in Nilus, which
the Ægyptians worshipped for a 
God. Oxyrrhincus, m.

A kinde of fish that swimmeth
on her side. 
Plagusia, f.

A fishe to vs vnknowen, which
is of a most delicate taste. 
Helops.

A fishe, of whose skinne water-­
glewe is made. 
Ichthyocolla, f.

A certaine fishe in the Ægyp­
tian sea. Sargus, m.

A fish that casteth out all his
bowels, vntil the hooke where­
with he is taketh bee out, which
being done, he sucketh them vp
againe. Scolopendra, fœm.
Centipes, dis.

A fishe having a pretious stone
in the braine. 
Synodus untis.

A fishe fensed with a long bone
standing out, having no heart. 
Tenthis, dis.

A certaine fish having but one
eie in his heade. 
Vranoscopos, vel vranosco­
pus.

A certaine fishe with a wide
yawning mouth, some take it
for that fishe called Lupus. 
Labrax.

A kinde of fishe delighting in
her taile. 
Labrus, m.

A fish that hath so great a iaw
and is so ravenous, that it can,
and did devoure an armed man 
Lamia, f.

A fishe with teeth standing out
of his lippes. 
Charax, m.

A fishe that is poison to man,
and man to him. 
Lepus, m.

A fishe that maketh a nest in
the water 
Chromis, f.

A fishe foure square. 
Cybium, n.

A kind of small fish, & differ­
ing from a Calamary only in
Face. Zolius, m.

A kind of fish in the Ocean sea
of Mauritania, which coming
in a scull, is able to overthrowe
a shippe. 
Lulligo, f.

A fish that killeth a Tunie to
haue the vaine in his iawes. 
Clupea, f.

A fishe, which sometime flieth
aboue the water, and that is a
signe that tempests will cease 
Milago, f.

A fish that hath his scales tur­
ned towards his head, and swim­
meth against the water. 
Acipenser, vel aquipenser.

A fish, whose gall healeth scars
of wounds and superfluous flesh
in the eies 
Callyonimus, m.

A kind of fish which being a­
fraide, hideth only his head, &
thinketh then that his whole bo­
die is hidde. 
Cephalus, m.

A certaine little fish which
swimmeth very softly. 
Narica, f.

A fish that killeth a Tuny, to
haue the veine in his iawes. 
Alosa, clupea.

A fish that is guid to the whale
that hee runne not vpon rocks. 
Musculus.

A certaine sea fish, not much
vnlike Pagrus, keeping alwaies
by the sea shore side. 
Orphus.

A river fish, that eateth flesh,
and hath lice breeding vnder
the armes. 
Aerica.

A fish which is a devourer of
mannes flesh. 
Anthias.

A sea fishe, which perceiving
the hooke fastned in him, biteth
off the line about the tackling,
and so scapeth. 
Alopex marina.

The young fish comming of the
spaune of Thunie. 
Auxuma.

A certaine fish in the river
Padus, it weigheth sometimes
a thowsand poundes. 
Attilus.

Fishes in the river Boristenes,
like Dolphines, without sinews. 
Antacæi.

A fish having his skinne like
vnto tanned lether. 
Alutarius piscis.

A fish that cleaveth to the keel
of a ship, and staieth it. 
Remeligo.


A.

Apuæ, a fishe so called. 
Encrasicoli.

latus.

cause it maketh the eaters laxa­
tiue. 
Mœna, f.

Loliguncula, f.

Capriscus, a fish having most
sharp and strong teeth. Apriscus

burbatus, m.

proper to Winander meere in
Lancashire. Aurisequa, f.

A Chevine. Laccia, f.

A cockle fish. Concha, f.

A kind of wrethen cockle, or
shell fish, wrinkled like the na­
vill, and thereof hath his name
Vmbilicus, m.

A codfish. Asellus, capito, m.

A conger. Congrus, conger.

A fish like a conger. Ophidium

A crab. Cancer, m.

A cramp fish, that hath the na­
ture, to make the hands of them
that touch it, to bee astonied, 
though they doe it with a long
pole. Torpedo, f.

A creafish. Gammarus, vel
cammarus, cancer, testudi­
nes fluviatiles.

A sea creafish, or a kind of yel­
low crab. 2 Leo.

A kind of creafishes. Hippiæ.

A cuttle fish. Sepia, nauplius.

A little cuttle fish. Sepiola, f.

A curre fish. Cuculus, m.

boundance of raine, and being

Alphya, latine apua dicitur.

ken in the winter, because that
it hideth it selfe in holow places
by reason of the extremitie of
colde. Hippurus, m.

A kind of Lobster. Garus.

Lamprey.

Hawkes.

To Hawke. 
Aucupor, alites accipitre ve­
nari.

Let vs first Hawke this ershe, 
for here lieth a covie. 
Hanc primo lustremus stipu­
lam, nam hic latet agnen.

A falconer. Accipitrarius fal­
conarius, m.

A chiefe falconer. Protofalco­
nerius, protohieracarius, m.

A hawke. Accipiter

The male of a hawke.
Accipiter mas.

A short winged hawke.
Micropterus, m.

An Eagle.
Aquila, f.

An Iron the
male of an ea­
gle. Aquila
mas.

An ospraie.
Haliæetus, m
aquila mari­
na.

The male of
an ospraie.
Haliæetus
mas.

Hierax, me­
lanæetus, m.

The male of a
Saker. Hierax
vel malanæ­
etus masculus

Phasianopho­
nus, m.

a Goshawke.
Mas phasia­
nophoni.

hawke. Meru­
larius accipi­
ter, humipeta

Fringillari­
us, humipe­
ta masculus.

Ardearius, 
masc.

a Gerfalcon, 
called a Ier­

nis, sexennis, Septennis, o­
ctennis, novennis, decennis




An Eyiesse. Apotrophus.

A brancher.
Eutrophus.

Although she be an eyies yet she
is somewhat coy.
Licet domi sit alumnus, ma­
net tamen aliquanto aver­
sior.

Ful summed, or firmed.
Integer pennatus, 
Integre alatus.

To reclaime a hawke.
Mansuefacio.

To ensaime a hawke.
Repurgo, macero.

She plumeth. Deplumat.

She tireth. Exantlat.

She feedeth. Ingerit, vescitur.

She puketh, or putteth over.
Degerit alvum, 
Demittit in alvum.

She disgorgeth, or casteth her
gorge. Regerit, revomit.

She endeweth Digerit.

She muteth. Egerit.

She hath cast. Eructavit, pur­
gamentum remisit.

She suiteth, or sueth her beake.
Rostrum tergit, 
Rostrum exacuit.

She batheth.
Proluit se, immergit se.

She proineth.
Plumas comit, 
Plumas concinnat.

She rowseth. Coruscat.

She mantleth. Dispennat, pan­
diculatur.

She towreth.
Insurgit.

She frilleth. Orrhotinassat.

She collieth. Collineat, an­
nuit.

She baiteth. Volaturit, con­
tendit.

She baited at a black bird.
Ad merulam contendebat.

If my hawke once baite, she wil
not rebate.
Cum semel devolarit, non re­
petet pugnum.

To rebate a hawke.
Relicere, retractare.

She is enterpenned.
Pennulas impedivit. 
Pennulas intricavit.

To vnenterpenne.
Expedire, extricare.

She commeth. Advolat.

She commeth wel.
Incunctanter revolat, 
Ad nutum revolat.

She checketh.
Ludificatur.

She soreth. Subvolat.

She flew it to the marke.
In perfugium coegit, resi­
dentem observavit.

She giveth it over.
Tergiversatur, deficit.

She Jouketh.
Consopitur, obdormit.

A hood. Capitium, n.

The gesses. Lemniscus, m.

The lines. Tænia, f.

A Creiance.
Funiculus, m.

A hawkes bell.
Tintinnabulum, n.

A button to tye the bel.
Offendix, f.

Tiring. Osseum, n.

Casting. Purgamentum.

A Mute. Fimus, m. fimum, n.

A perch. Ames.

A mue. Cavea, caveola, tran­
senna, f.







Herbarum genera.

AN hearb. 1 Herba, f. 2 gra­
men, n.

An hearb growing
of it owne accord: a weed. Her­
ba voluntaria.

The stalke. Caulis,

The stocke, 
or stemme. Scapus thyrsus.

The knot, or ioint. Geniculum, 
n. articulus, m.

The quil, cane, 
or space betweene two ioints.
Internodium.

The pit, or hole
wherout the branches sprout &
shoote. Sinus, alarum cavum.

The round tuft of any hearb, 
wherin the seed lieth. Vmbella, 
muscarium, n.

the flowre, bloom, 
or blossome. Flos, flosculus, m.

The budde of a flowre. Calyx.

The chieue, or little threeds of
flowres. Apex, m. stamen, n.

The cup of the flowre by little
& litle opening, & gapening it
selfe. Nympha, f.

The downe of
flowres, which the wind blow­
eth about. Pappus.

Red plume, 
or cats taile. Phoba, panicula
f.

The blade. Capillamentum, 
n.

The huske, hull, or pill in clo­
sing the seed. Pericarpium, n. 
folliculus, m. siquila, f.

The se­
veral places wherin the seeds do
ly. Loculamentum, n.

The
nerue of a leafe, as in plantain.
Nervus.

The iagges, or notches
about the edges of leaues.
Crenæ.

Herbs to be eaten: pothearbs.
Holus, vel olus.

Smal hearbs good to eat.
Olusculum, n.

A kind of pot hearbs sweet in
smell, and sharpe in taste.
Ligurium, n.

Of or like pot hearbs.
Oleraceus, ad.

Hearbs sodden, or chopt.
Olus coctivum, vel conci­
sum, n.

An handful, or gripe of hearbs.
Fasciculus manualis.

An hearb having leaues like
oliues. Chamælea, f.

An hearb of two sorts, the one
white, and the other black.
Chamæleon, onis, f.

A certaine hearb full of milke.
Lactoris, f.

An hearb, wherof Ladanum is
made. Lada, f.

A wild pot hearb growing a­
mong corne. Lampsana, f.

An hearb that the king of Per­
sia gaue to the Embassadours, ha­
ving in it this belief, that while
it was about them, they should ne­
ver want necessary foode.
Latace, f.

An herb of the kind of Spurge.
1 Lathyris, f.

An herbe which some think to
be Gnaphalium,

some Quin­
quefolium. Chamezeleon.

An herbe, whereof Geese bee a­
fraide. Chenomycon, n.

An herbe like vnto a Goose
foote.
Chenopus, m.

The wild vine, or brionte.
Chironia vitis.

An herbe called Scortona.
Chibis.

An hearb called Achillea, &
militaris herba. Chiliophillon

An hearb called also Polemo­
nia. Chiliodynamis.




An hearb called Aizoum mi­
nus. Chimerine.

An herb with white leaues like
succory, and stalks like rushes.
Chondrilla, f.

The hearb Parthenium.
Chrysocalis.

An hearb, or kind of pulse.
Cicilindrum, cilindrum, n.

An hearb much like to our
hemlocke, but having small
leaues: some vse it for hemlocke.
Cicuta, f.

An herb growing in stone wals
with small leaues, somwhat like
Ivy. Cimbalaris, f.

An hearb which some haue
counted to be veratrum, ni­
grum. Lemonium, five li­
monium, protion, melanor­
rhizon.

An hearb, whose flowers are lik
to a Lions mouth, when he ga­
peth. Leonina, f.

An hearb good for those that
spit bloud. Leucographis, f.

An hearb called also Trago­
narum. Lychnis agrestis.

An hearb wherewith hunters
doe poison their arrowes.
Limeum, ei, n.

An hearb called also Centau­
rium minus. Limnesium, n.

A kind of hearb, called Ane­
mone. Limonia, f.

An hearb, with leaues like vn­
to leeks, but broder and ruddie, 
having black flowres. lonchitis

An hearb growing in fenny, &
watry places, called also Corne­
ola, or Lysmachium. Lutea, f.

An herb fit to die yellow with
all. Lutum, n.

An hearb like to line, or flax.
Lychnis agria.

An hearb called also Taxus
barbatus. Lychnitis, itidis, f.

An herb that preserveth harts
from poisoning. Cinnara.

An hearb like night shade.
Circæ, f.

An hearb, the iuice whereof be­
ing sodden in water, taketh a­
way the stinging of serpentes.
Corinthas, adis.

An hearb by touching wherof, 
the spider Phalangium dieth 
Crocis.

An hearb like the thistle, called
Camelion niger. Crocodilium.

An hearb, wherof ther be three
sorts, Cunila capitata, our sa­
vorie, Cunila gallinacea, ma­
soran with a small leafe, the third
is pennie roiall with the broad
leafe. Cunila.

An hearb that groweth in mud
walles, with a leafe in fashion
like Ivy, but much lesse, and
having a little purple flower.
Cimbalaris.

An hearb in Ethiopia, wannish
and dangerous to looke on, being
dronke it doth terrifie the mind
with a sight of dreadful serpents, 
that condemned persons, for fear
thereof, do kill themselues.
Ophiusta.

An herb like iagged coleworts, 
which maketh the hair black.
Ophrys.

An hearb that being put in pot­
tage, killeth dogs. Cynomazon

An hearb that killeth mice.
Mycophonos.

A kind of hearb, which being
put into wine, driveth away sad­
nes. Nepenthes, n.

An hearb having a leafe like
carrets, a white flour, a big stalk
and like an orange, a great root, 
with many round heads.
Oenanthe, f.

Of that hearb oenanthe.
Oenanthinus, ad.

An hearb that helpeth manie
diseases. Omnimorbia, f.

An hearb like a tongue, medici­
able for the flowers in women.
Onobletum, n.

An hearb growing by wels.
Onobrychis, f.

A rough and sharp hearb, whol­
some against poison.
Ophiglosson, n.

An hearb growing halfe a cu­
bit high, and having a tuft like
elder at the top.
Drabe, f.

An hearb having leaues full of
holes. Othonne.

An hearb in the hill Canarie, 
wherewith they die cloth.
Oricola, f.

A garden hearb in Egipt, fit to
make garlands of. Persoluta, 
vel persolyton.

An hearb that beareth burres
Persolata, f.

An hearb that cureth the bi­
ting, or stinging of the vene­
mous spider. Phalangites.

A kind of the hearb Lappago
like to Anagallis, but that it
hath more leaues.
Mollugo, g.

An hearb growing among corn, 
having leaues like Rue, and in
vertue it is like Poppy. Hype­
coon, vel hypopheon, n.

An hearb like to Intubus, but
lesser, it is good being dronk, to
heal wounds. Hyosiris, f.

An hearb comming out of the
earth, like millet, or hirse, ha­
ving sharp leaues and mossie, it
is good to stanch bloud.
Ischæmon.

A kind of wild radish. 1 Ischas.

An hearb growing in water, ha­
ving a hard roote necessarie for
smithe. Sari.

An hearb vsed of the Druides
for all eie sores. Selago.

An hearb that purgeth melan­
choly. Sesamoides, f.

An herb growing in vineyards
Sicelion, n.

An hearb having a thin stalk
4. fingers high, a red flowre, and
leaues like coriander, it gro­
weth by rivers, and meeres, &
healeth all cuts & gashes what­
soever. Siderion, heraclium.

An hearb whereof the gumme
called Beniamin doth come.
Silphium, n.

An hearb having leaues like to Gladiolus, but narrower, and
bending more to the earth, ha­
ving about the top of the stalk, 
seed inclosed in certaine heads.
Sparganion, n.

An hearb having stalks and
leaues prickled, and groweth in
waterie grounds. Stœbe, f.

An hearb wherewith beg­
gers vse to make their flesh raw.
Strumea, amedendo stru­
mæ, f.

An hearb wherewith woolle is
commonlie washt. Strutius, m.

An hearb which maketh men
mad that eat of it.
Strychnus, vel strychnis.

A certain hearb dissolving im­
posthumes. Reseda, f.

An hearb which hath a stalke




like knots, and ioints, a leafe like
a nettle, and white in the mid­
dle. Rhodora, f.

An hearb like germander, some
take it for pempernell.
Teucrion, vel Trucrium, n.

An hearb like fennell, with a
yellow flowre, a flat round seed, 
with a iuice as white as milke,
Thapsia, f.

An hearb gowing only in Can­
dy, having boughes, leaues, and
seeds like Iuniper.
Tragium, n.

An hearb, the root whereof is
thought to be Turbit, vsed of the
phisitians to purge fleigme.
Tripolium, n.

An hearb which hath flowres
thrise in a yeare. Trithales.

An hearb growing on walles, 
wherwith vessel being scoured, 
is made wonderfull bright.
Vitreolum, n.

An hearb like rosemary, that
draweth gold vnto it. Vlex, icis

An hearb that in time of bat­
tle (as enchaunters teach) being
cast into an army, wil cause the
souldiers to be in feare.
Achimenis, idis, f.

A vemenous herb, wherof there
be 2 kinds (as Turner saith) the
one may be called Libardine, 
the other wolfe wort.
Aconitum, n.

An hearb like vnto chervill, 
that it cannot be distinguished
from it, but by the thinne and
sweeter leaues.
Anthriscus, m Anthriscum, n

An hearb like grounswell.
Anticyricon.

Hearbs, whose stalks in the win­
ter seem dead, but towards som­
mer, new spring out of the root.
Anvicallia, vel Anvifera.

An hearb like the wild poppie, 
and healeth a disease in the eye, 
called Argema. 
Argemone, Argemonia, f.

A small hearb, having a root of
the bignes of an oliue.
Arisaron, Aris.

An hearb, which being dronke, 
ingendreth men children.
Arsenogogon, n.

An hearb having long boughes, 
leaues like Juy, and many roots
Asclepias, adis.

The iuice of balme hearb.
Balsamelæon, n.

An hearb of the length, and big­
nes of a Lily, with a leaf like rue
growing only in Egipt, or India
Balsamita, f.

An hearb called death to oxen, 
because that if they eat thereof, 
they dye of the squince.
Buphonum, n.

An hearb growing without so­
wing, or setting, with a top like
dill, Bupleurus.

A white hearb in Ponius, of
whose flower the bees do gather
a bitter kind of honey.
Aegolethros.

An herb which enchanters vse, 
by force wherof, rivers are dried
and locks are opened.
Aethiopis, idis, f.

An hearb having a leafe like a
lisander. Agtion nardum.

An hearb growing much about
the river Mella

in France, the
flower whereof is called Amel­
lum. Amella, f.

An hearb having the leafe of
Organum Ammi, ios, vel Am­
mium, n.

An hearb without savour, or
fruit, having a flower like orga­
ment. Amomis, idis.

An hearb in Sicilie, wherewith
they make bands to tye vines.
Ampelodesmos.

An hearb the touching wherof, 
restoreth loue between man, &
man. Anacampseros, otis, f.

An herb very fair to see to, but
having a stincking savour.
Anagyris, f.

An hearb very plentifull in the
sea coast of syria, white without
leaues, having green husks in the
tufts, and seed in the husks.
Androsaces.

An hearb like to linne, having
a seed like to a calfes head, with
the nostrels open.
Anthirrinum, vel Antirrhinum

An hearb holsome against the
pinne and the web, in the eye.
Phormion, n.

A kind of pricking hearbs.
Phyllanthes.

An hearb vsed to dye purple.
Phyllanthion, n.

A certaine rough hearb with
pricking leaues. Polycanthus.

An hearb having leaues like
Lawrell, long and thinne, good
against serpents. Polygnoides.

A certaine vnknowen hearb, 
wholesome to loose the belly.
Pycnocomon, n.

An hearb like vnto Scammoni­
um. Echite.

An hearb having nine long
leaues. Enneaphillon.

An hearb like a horse mane.
Equiselis.

An hearb against the pains in
the eare, or purging the head by
the eares. Erinum.

An hearbe causing loue.
Erogenneton.

An hearb about Boristhenes, 
which being dronk with wine &
mirrh, causeth laughing,
Gelotophyllus.

An herb like to smallage, grow­
ing in watery grounds, & hath
but one leafe.
Heleoselinum.

An herb wherof be two kinds, 
the one called lingwort, the root
wherof, is neesing pouder, the o­
ther bears foot, terwort or set­
wort. Helleborum, n. helle­
borus, m.

An hearb smelling more in the
night time, than in the day.
Hesperis, idis, f.

A kind of the hearb Gerauni­
um, Herobrynchas.

An hearb, which being born in a
mans mouth, keepeth from hun­
ger and thirst.
Hippice.
The hearb whereof there be two
kinds, the one perwincke the o­
ther lesseron.
Clematis daphnoides.	

An hearb wholesome to breake
the stone. Phellandrius, m.

A certaine hearbe called also
Stoet, or Stæbes. Phleos, ei. f.

An hearb that women vse to
make ley with Phlum.

An hearb like vnto lettice, cal­
led also Fucus marinus. 
Phycos thalassium.

An hearb of the kinde of spur­
ges. Pityusa, f.

A certaine herb named of Ga­
len Neuras, good for the sinews. Poterium, n.




An hearb like to Organet.
Pseudanchusa, f.

An hearbe called commonlye Pabulum cervi, and of the A­
pothecaries Gartia Dei. Some
take it for Sage.
Elaphoboscum.

The hearb called Epicactis.  
Elleborine.

An hearb, which being vsed in
medicines, cureth the disease, but
engendreth barrennes. Clinemos

The hearb Polygonion. 
Cnopodion.

An hearb that buds twise in
the yeer, his flowre is called Co­
dion, also it is taken to be a kind
of lettice. Codiaminon, codion.

An hearb called, Hermoda­
ctylus, & bulbus agrestis, Col­
chicum.

An hearb good to provoke v­
rine. Fulviana, f.

A kinde of the hearb Laserpi­
tium. Magudaris, sive magy­
daris, f.

An hearb which Dioscorides calleth Lychnis coronaria, 
Maloion.

An hearb like to Orgament.
Halus, m.

A kinde of the hearb Strichi­
nis. called also. DorychinonManicon.

An hearbe like Maioram, but
of stronger savoure. Marum, n.

The leafe, or after some the
stalke of Laserpitium. Mas­
petum, n.

An herbe called Flos paradisi: the Frenchmen call it Oculus
Dei. Alisti.

An hearbe like to a foxe taile, 
ful of mossinesse. Alopecurus.

An hearbe called Lotus. 
Anacacabea, f.

The fruit of that. Anacacabos.

That is, of Lotus.



An hearb called Gladiolus, 
Anactorion.

An hearbe like to Lentle.
Anthillion.

An hearbe called Trifolium
odoratum Medion.

An hearb having long leaues
like haires. Barba senis, barba
petræ.

An hearb called Ramunculus, 
wherof there be foure kinds: The 
one called Pes corvi, crow foot, 
and beareth yeallowe flowers: 
The second Apium risus: The
third, Wilde Persly: The fourth, 
Senicle. Batrachium, n.

An hearbe that stoppeth bloud.
Sanguinaria, f.

An hearb, of some thought to
be spinache. Blitum, blitus, 
blætum.

An hearbe called Pes Galli. 
 Brion.

An hearb called of some Ve­
nerea, or Lanceola. Medusa, f

An hearb, called also helxine, 
& vitis nigra. Melampelos.

An hearbe very like to Camo­
mill, it is also called Partheni­
um. Melabathrum, n.

An hearb called also Caltha. 
 Calendula, f.

A kind of the hearb called, Hel­
loborus niger. Melampodium.

An hearbe whereby water doth
freese. Callicia, f.

An hearbe full of branches, ha­
ving a seede like fengrecke.
Melampyrum, n.

An hearbe growing among
corne, with a white flowre.
Melandryum, n.

An hearb, called also Aristolo­
chia longa. Melocurpos.

The hearb Polium.  Melosmus

A certaine hearb, or shrub, cal­
led Vitis alba. Melothrum, n.

An hearb not much vnlike to
annise. Meon.

The hearb called Smilax aspe­
ra. Mergina, f.

An hearb called Tripolium. 
 Meris.

A leafe of the Indian spiknard.
Mesophærum, n.

An hearbe given to cattle a­
gainst the rot. Cytisus.

The leafe of spikenard.
Microsphæron.

An hearb called also Volubilis 
Combretum, n.

An hearb that in August bea­
reth a red flowre, and taketh a­
way a disease, called the kinges
evill. Condurdon.

An hearbe like hemlocke.
Conion, latine cicuta.

An hearb called also Cunila­
go. Conyza, f.

An hearb called Polygonion, 
it groweth much on stones, and
wals, and is alwaies greene.
Osteocollon.

An hearb called also Cynoce­
phalia, because it is like a dogs
leg. Osirites.

The hearbe, or iuice Chelidonie.
Othomia.

An hearb called Spartum. 
 Iberica.

An hearb called Ruscus. 
 Myacintha.

A certaine hearb, with a stalke
like fenell, and leaues like ma­
dir. Myagros.

An hearb that killeth mice.
Mycophonos.

A kind of the herb Artemisia. 
 Monoclonus.

An hearb having a sweet root
and is called also Eringium. 
 Myrocanthon.

A kind of fenel giant. narthex

An hearb called Poterion. 
 Neuras, adis.

An hearb which is called Ru­
bus caninus. Neurospaston.

An hearbe called Nyctegretum, 
because it shineth afarre in the
night tyme. Nyctilops.

The hearb called Vitis nigra. 
 Oblamenia, f.

An hearb which Theadore doth
translate sometime Cicram, sometime Erviliam.  Ochros, 
ocharon.

The name of an hearbe like to
the leafe of an almond tree.
Oenathara, f.

An hearb that some thinke to
be called Myle, or moly. 
Oloconitis.

The hearb Apocynon. 
Onystis.

A kind of the hearb Anchusa,  
Onochelus.

An hearb called Elaphobos­
cus, which harts vsed to eat, to
strengthen themselues against
serpents. Ophioctonon, vel
ophiogenium.

The herbe called Solanum som­
niserum. Dircæon.

An hearb, as big as a leeke, or
scallion, having the qualities of
a leeke, or onion.
Scorodoprasson.

An hearb called of the Apothe­
caries, Siler montanum. Seselis.




An hearb called Secelis, with
the root, or seed wherof, they wer
wont to season the wine which
they drunk before noone. Sile.

An hearb called Polyum. 
 Teuthrion.

An hearb, the roote whereof
doth kill Scorpions. Thelypho­
nom. Aconitum primum.

The hearb Saxifraga, growing
in stony places, it is good against
the stone. Saxifragia, vel saxi­
fraga, & saxifragum, vel saxi­
fragium, n.

An hearb called Cunilago. 
Cunizamis, dis.

An hearb called of the Egipti­
ans Osirtis, verie divine, and
effectuall against all poison.
Gynocephalea.

An hearb called Centimor­
bia, Numalaria, f.

An hearb, some think it to be 
Germander, Chamærops.

The hearb called Semper vi­
vum. Chrysospernon.

The hearb called Helxine. 
Cissamethos.

riæ. Cissanthemus, m.

An hearb called Hiberis. A­
griocardamum, n.

An hearb like to wild savory.
Polioneumon.

merimnon.

tercæ. if it be three sorts, one is
commonly called Herb-Iuie, the
2. small Cipresse, set in pots, the
third is thought to bee Saint
Iohns wort. Chamæpytis, yos.

ny. Betonica, psychotrophum

hight. Zygis.

Helxine, cessampelos, vitealis

ing in hils. Oreon.

alba.

C.

Cabage. Brassica, f.

Cole cabage. Brassica capitata

Piperitis.

Camock, a weed growing among
corne, which letteth the plough, 
and therefore is called resthar­
row: in Cambrige shire, a whine
Ononis, anonis.

mælum, leucanthemis, leu­
canthemum, anthemis.

A kind of camomill, having
purple flowers. Eranthemum.

led. Campanula, f.

A caret, the root whereof is
vsed to be sod with meat. Caros
Caron, careum.

astaphylinos.

White carets, yellow persnips, 
or skirwort. Siser, vel sisarum

Caros, caron, careum.

Acesis.

Calues snout, an hearb so called
Lychnis silvestris.

centaurium, centaurea, orum.

ches.

limnesium, centauria, minor
fel terræ.

vel heliochrysum, n.

The common cicory.
Ambubeia, ambugia, f.

Cicory hearb, whose flower will
open at the rising of the sun, &
close at the going downe.
Heliotropium.

fed grasse. Quinque folium, 
pentaphyllis.

Ciues, a kind of onions. Cepina
cepula, cepa palatina.

Coleworts. Brassica, corambe, 
& coramba.

A kind of coleworts, crisp, and
delicate to eat. Halmiris.

Wild coleworts, so called of the
Arabians. Lapsana, f.

Coleworts, or cole cabages.
Lea, f. brassica capitata.

like gold knaps. Chrysanthe­

leaues, and sharp taste.
Myrsenium.

The hearbe called winterchery.
Halicacabus, m.

A winter greene. Pyrola, f. limo­
nium, n.

With-winde. Cassutha, con­
volvolus vel convolvulus, lili­
astrum, vitealis.

The hearbe woodroofe. Rubia sil­
vestris, erithrodanum, n.

Wood sorrel Alleluya, trifolium
acerosum.

Woolblade, or lingwort.
Verbascum, n.

Woodbine. Periclymenos vel
periclymenon, volucrum majus

Wormewood. Absynthium.

Sea wormewood, or worme seede.
Seriphium, n. 
Absynthium Ceriphium, 
Absynthium Marinum.

Worme seede. Lunbricorum se­
men.

Small woortes, or herbes.
Heluellæ, f.

Wortes. Lachanum, olus.


Y.

Yarrowe, or nosebleed wherewith
Achilles is sayd to kill Telaphus
Achillæa, millifolia, millefo­
lium.






Numbers.

1.

One. Vnus, a. um.

The first. Primus, a. um.

Once. Semel.


2.

Two, or
twaine. Duo,
æ, o.
Bini, æ, a.

The second. Secundus, a. um.

Of, or containing 2. Binarius, ad

Twise Bis.


3.

Three. Tres. 
Terni. 
Trini, æ, a.

The third. Tertius, a. um.

Of, or con. 3 Ternarius, a, um.

Thrise, or three times. Ter.


4.

Foure. Quatuor. 
Quaterni, æ. a. 
Quadrini.

The fourth. Quartus, a, um.

Of, or con. 4. Quaternarius.

Foure times. Quater.


5.

Fiue Quinque.

Fiue Quini, æ, a.

The Fifte. Quintus, a, um.

Of, or con. Quinarius.

Fiue times. Quinquies.


6.

Sixe. Sex. 
Seni, æ, a.

The sixte: Sextus, a, um.

Of, or con. 6. Senarius.

Sixetimes. Sexies.


7.

Seaven. Septem. 
Septeni, æ, a.

The seaventh. Septimus, a. um.

Of, or con. 7. Septenarius, a um.

Seaven times. Septies.


8.

Eight. Octo. 
Octeni, vel
Octoni, æ, a.

The eighth. Octavus, a, um.

Of, or con. 8. Octonarius.

Eight times. Octies.

Nine. Novem. 
Noveni, æ, a.

The ninth. Nonus, a um.

Of, or con. 9. Novenarius, no­
narius.

Nine times. Novies.







Tenne, vi: the last article, in the
next Columne.

1000.

A thou­
sand. Mille.
Milleni, æ, a.

The thousandth Millesimus, a, um

Of, or contayning. 1000. Millena­
rius, a, um.

A thousand times. Millies.

Two thou­
sand. Duo millia,
Bis mille.

Three thou­
sand. Tria millia
Ter mille.

Fiue thousand times. Quinquies
Millies.

Nine
thou­
sand. Novem Millia.
Novena Millia.
Novies mille.

Fourtie
thou­
sand Quadraginta
Quadragena Mil­
lia.

Two hundred thousand.
Ducenta Millia. 
Ducena Millia.

Ten hundred
thousand. Decies cente­
na millia.


Where note that Decies, or any
adverbe of like termination, ad­
ded to an other number, signifi­
eth but it selfe, as in the last ex­
ample, but standing without an
other number, is multiplied by
an hundred thousand, as decies
coronatorum ten hundred thou­
sand crownes, Vicies talentûm
Twentie hundred thousand ta­
lents.

Vnde: & Duode: being set be­
fore viginti, vigesimus,  or any
kind of greater article, the one sig­
nifieth the number wherwith it
is ioyned, saue one the other saue
two, as vndetriginta thirtie
saue one, duodequadragesimus
The eight and thirtieth, or forti­
eth saue two, vndequinquagies
nine and forty times.





Ordinall Adverbs.

First Primo.

Secondly. Secundo.

Thirdlie. Tertio, &c.

The ablatiue of the ordinall, ma­
king the adverb.





Numeralia in plex.

single, simple, of on sort. simplex

Double, two fold, or of two sorts
Duplex.

Triple, three fold, or of three sorts
Triplex.

Foure fold, of foure sorts.
Quadruplex.

Fiue fold, or of fiue sortes.
Quintuplex.

Sixe fold, or sixe sorts.
Sextuplex.

Seven fold, or of seven sorts.
Septemplex, septuplex.

Eight fold, or of eight sorts.
Octuplex.

Ninefold, or of nine sorts. 
Noncuplex.

Ten fold, or of ten sorts.
Decuplex, &c.

Fowre score and ten fold.
Nonagecuplex, eadem est re­
liquorum ratio.

Adverbs of the same sort.
Simpliciter, dupliciter, tripli­
citer, quadrupliciter, bifariam, 
trifariam, quadrifariam, & sic
in cæteris. 
Numeralia, in plus.

Single, iust so much, or the same
quantity. Simplus.

Twise so much. Duplus.

Thrise so much. Triplus.

Foure times so much.
Quadruplus.

Fiue times so much.
Quintuplus.

Sixe times so much. Sextuplus.

Seaven times so much.
Septuplus.

Eight times so much. Octuplus.

Nine times so much.
Noncuplus.

Ten times so much.
Decuplus, &c.

Fourescore and ten times so much
Nonagecuplus.

Two hundred times so much.
Ducentuplus.

Fiue hundred times so much.
Quingentuplus, &c.

Adverbs of the same sort.
Simplo, duplo, triplo quadru­
plo, &c.





Stones.

A stone. Lapis.

A great stone: also a naturall
stone, or rock. Saxum, n.

A little stone. Lapillus, m.

A stone that serveth to worke
withal. Lapis, operarius.

A square stone.
Lapis quadratus.

a stone wherout runneth a spring.
Lapis manalis.

A stone that one may gripe, or
handle in his hand.
Saxum manuale.

A little stone gotten into ones
shoe, and troubling him in trave­
ling.
Scrupus, m.

Spels, or broken peeces of stones, 
coming of hewing, or grauing.
Assulæ, micæ, arum, segmina, 
secamenta, orum.

A stone that may easily be rub­
bed into crums.
Tophus, porus, m.

A stone pecked in, as a milstone
or grindestone.
Insus, & incusus, lapis.

Stony, or ful of stones.
Calculosus, confragosus.

A square stone laid vppon a
tombe.
Mensa, f.

A stone hurled, or throwen.
Missile, n.

A stone that is azure blew.
lapis cyaneus, cæruleus lapis.

A great square stone, broad be­
neath, and waxing smaller and
smaller towards the top.
Obeliscus, m.

A stone in the vpper part resem­
bling the colour of a mans naile
Sardonychus, & sardonyx, m.

Having apparel garnished with
a stone of that colour.
Sardonychatus, ad.

A stone found in the bellie of
a greene lizard.
Saurites, m.

a dusky stone which having oile
put to it, waxeth bright.
Savinus lapis.

A stone of saffron colour easy to
be cleft into very thin plates,
Schistus, vel schistos.

A stone of the colour of a scorpi­
on. Scorpites.

A stone wherein is a white, that
decreaseth and in creaseth, as the
moone doeth. Selenitis, m.

A stone made of water, light &
ful of holes, and fit for arch rofes
or vaults. Sfungia, f.

A stone like iron, having power
to cause variance amongest men
Siderites, m. & it is also a kind




of diamond stone.

A stone of nature soft, but being
beat in oyle, it waxeth hard.
Sipnius, m.

Little round stones of marble, v­
sed in paving. Scutullæ, f.

A stone greene, and not shining
through, which printeth perfect­
ly. Sphragis, vel sphragide, f.

A stone fownd in a spunge.
Spongites.

A white stone fownd in silver
mines, good for the eies.
Stibium, n.

A stone in shape altogether like.
Strombus Strombites.

A stone whereby, as magicians
say, ghostes be called vp.
Synochites.

A stone taken out of the braine
of the fish Synedus.
Synodonities.

A stone round in the blader of a
wolfe. Syrites.

A stone having the figure of the
new moone. Tephitis.

A stone called the stone of India
good for the collick and the stone
Tecolithus.

A stone like a pecock.
Taos.

A stone of a contrary nature to
the load stone.
1 Theamedes.

A kind of hard ston wherof mor­
ters were made. Thytes.

a stone which being whole  swim­
meth, but when it is broken, eve­
ry part thereof sinketh.
Tirrhenus lapis.

A gravell, or sand stone, that
may easilie bee rubbed to crum­
mes.
Tophus, vel tosus.

Hard as the stone Tophus:of, 
or belonging to that stone.
Tophaceus, & tophinus, ad.

A stone which sheweth 3 sortes
of colours, at the roote black, the
midle sanguine, the top white.
Tricus, m.

a ston of the colour of the mullet
fish. Triglites.

A stone having the figure of 3
eies. Triophthalmus, m.

A stone which leapeth, & brea­
keth asunder with the fire.
Tuscanicus lapis.

A kind of Cadmia stone, having
certain lines in it like girdles.
Zonitis, f.

A kind, of burning and shining
stone. Lignis, is, f.

A stone of ashe colour, and good
against serpents.
1 Limensis, tephoria.

A certaine stone good for pain­
ting. 1 Colaticus lapis.

A stone called catte silver.
Magnetis.

A stone of a darke colour.
1 Malanchites.

A stone which yealdeth a iuice
like hony.
Melanes.

A stone sometime blacke, some
time yellow. Melichros.

A little stone of the coloure of
leekes, which sweateth liquour
like to milke.
Meroctes.

A stone with golden raies.
Coraloachates.

A stone which being broken, is
like to a beane.
Cyamea, f.

Certain stones growing in spon­
ges, good for the disease in the bla­
der.
Cystiolithi.

A stone of the rose colour, but a­
gainst the sun, chaungeable.
Mithrax.

A stone in Ægipt, called galax­
inus, which the linen drapers
vse to make their cloth white.
Morochthus, m.

A stone of divers colours cleere as
christall, having spotts of purple
and white.
Murrha, f.

Made of that stone.
Murrhinus, ad.

A stone having in it a figure of
an emmet, or pismier.
Myrmecites.

A stone of sanguine colour with
little black veynes.
Nasamonites.

A stone which some called notia, 
and falleth with lightning and
thunder.
I Ombria, f.

A stone like berill.
Diadochos.

A stone like a shell, vsed to smoth
the skinne insteed of a pumish, or
steele stone.
Ostracites.

The stones of hogges when they be
gelded. Polimenta, orum.

A stone of the colour of leekes.
Prasoides.

A certain round stone smooth &
white. Enhydros.

A certain stone which being bro­
ken, is like the cullions of a man.
Enorchis.

A faire white stone, wherewith
goldsmithes polish gold.
Exhebenus, m.

A stone of milke coloure, and
full of bloody veines
Galaxias.

A stone having earth within it
holownes, and being laid to the
eare, it maketh a sownde.
Geodes.

A stone in Creta of an Iron co­
loure, like a mans thumbe.
Ideus dactylus.

A stone of violet coloure.
Ion.

The stone of an oliue.
Sampsa, f.

A kind of burning stone, called
Garamantites.
Sandastro.

A stone of a carnation coloure.
Sarcion.

A soft stone, but of an excellent
savour.
Baptes.

A stone wherof they make whet
stones.
Balsamites.

A stone in colour and shape
like to a greene frogge.
Batrachites.

A stone wherein blacknes is mix­
ed with red, and white spottes.
Boryptes.

A stone having blew speckes a­
bout it. Cadmites.

A stone having the print of a
blacke flie, called a beetle.
Cantharias.

A little stone and small of va­
lew. Carchedonius, m.

A stone comming from the dra­
gons braine. Cardisce, f.

Stones lying gap aboue other.
Cephedines.

A stone like to haile, and so cold, 
that no fire can heat it,
Chalazias, æ, m.




A stone of brasse colour.
Chalcites.

A blacke, stone sownding like
brasse. Chalcophonos.

Little stons fownd in the maw of
a swallow. Cheledonij.

a stone like to the eie of an Indi­
an snake. Chelonia, f.

All manner of stons like to Ivo­
ry. Chernites.

A green stone mixed with a gol­
den brightnes. Chrysoprasus.

A stone sound in the brain of the
fish. Cinædus, Cinædia, f.

A stone like roch allum, or stone
allum, wherof matches are made, 
which being once kindled, never
go out, so long as the oile lasteth.
Amiantus, m.

A stone in the maw, or gizard of
a cocke, in colour like christall.
Alectoria, f.

A red stone mixt with blew, pro­
voking to bleed.
Alabandina.

A blacke stone Ambrum, n.

A stone which being once fired
cannot be quenched. Asbestus.

A kind of black stone not shining
through. Antipates.

A stone found in the bladder of a
woolfe. Syrtities.

A stone that by no fire will da­
mage, or deface. A pyrotos.


A.

The Agath stone. Gagates

A kind of agath of a blody colour
Hæmachates.

An adamant stone. Cenchron.

An amethist, a stone of violet
colour. Amechistus, m.

Antimony, a stone found in silver
mines. Platyophthalmus, m.

The azure, or lazul stone. Lazuli
Cyaneus lapis.


B.

The bever stone. Castorea, orum


C.

A carbuncle stone, which is in
colour like hot burning coales. 
Carbunculus, pyropus, m.

Carbuncle stons which are not ve­
ry cleere. Libycontes.

A kind of carbuncle shining wan­
ly and faintly. Lithizontes.

A christall. Chrystallus, m. 
Chrystallum, n.

A kind of christall having with
in it golden droppes shining like
fire. Sandastricus.

A christall stone, shining like gold
Chrysoberyllus, m.

Corall, a red stone so called.
Coralium, n.


D.

A diamond stone. Adamas, 
Anachites.

Of a diamond. Adamantinus


E.

An emerald: a stone that glasiers
vse to cut their glasse. 
Smiris, Smaragdus, m.

Belonging to an emeralde.
Smaragdinus, ad.


F.

A flint stone, hard stone, or mar­
ble. Silex. m, et f.

A flint stone, of a marvelous na­
ture, being steeped in water, it bur­
neth, and sprinkled with oile, 
it is quenched.
Thracias, vel Thracius lapis

A flint stone, or marchasit, out of
the which fire is stroken. Chalix
pyrites, igniarius lapis marcha­
sita, lapis ærarius.

Made with flint. Silicatus, ad.

Of flint. Siliceus, silicus, ad.


G.

A gem, vide
precious stones. 

A grindstone.
Aquaria Cos. 
Rotaria Cos. 
Gyratilis Cos.


I.

A iacinct stone. Hyacinthus, m

A kind of iacinct stone having
a white vein mingled with the co­
lour of gold. Leucochrysus, m.

A iasper being of a green colour
Iaspis.

A Iasper stone like the aire.
Aerizusa, f.

A kind of iasper with white
strakes, or lines overthwart.
Iaspis grammatias.

A kind of iasper stone.
Borea f. Capnias, Chrysolithus

A ieat stone. Gagates.


L.

The loade stone. Magnes.

Belonging to the load stone.
Magneticus, ad.


M.

A marble stone. Marmor, m

A kind of marble of ashe colour
Tephria, f.

A little marble stone.
Marmoriolum, n.

A kind of white marble cut out
of the quarries by candle light: al­
so a kind of gem whose liuely, 
clerenes is stirred vp by candle
light, and is red like scarlet.
Lychnites.

A kind of marble. corralliticus

A kind of excellent marble, cal­
led of Papinian Libicus silex. 
Numidicus lapis.

A kind of marble having spots
like a serpent. Ophites.

A red marble. Porphyrites.

A kind of marble. Onyxes.

Of red marble. porphyreticus.

A kind of marble in Ægipt, 
ruddy and full of white spottes.
Purpurites.

A kind of marble wherof the
Ægiptians made Obeliscos, 
which they dedicated to the sun.
Pyrrhopæcilus, m.

A white marble. Leucostictis.

A kind of marble about Thebes, 
wherwith kings made beames.
Sicnites.

A margarite. margarita, mar­
garites, f.

A marchasite, or fire stone.
Pyrites.

A milstone. Lapis molaris.


O.

An onix stone. Onyx.

Onix, a stone resembling the co­
lour of a mans naile onychium.

A kind of onixe of a blacke co­
lour, called a corneole.
Sardius lapis.

Made of the onix stone, or of the
colour, of an onixe, or Cornalin
stone. Onychinus, ad.


P.

A pearle. Margarita, bacca, e­
rythræus lapillus.

A long pearle, like an egge in fa­
shion. Cylindrus, elenchus, m.

Bell pearle, which is round here, 




and flat there. Tympanum, n.

A peeble stone. Calculus, m.

A round peeble stone. Glarea, f.

A pumeise stone. Pumex, m. & f


R.

A ruddle stone, vide Sinoper.

The printer supplied this entry (and all others for the letters R, T, and W, 
at the end of the dictionary (sig. pp4v) under the 
following note: "Certaine Stones, which were omitted in the generall title of Stones aboue, Col. 1776. after the letter P."



A sanguinarie, or cinoper: a soft
and red stone, found in mines.
Cinnabaris indica, sive Cinna­
beri, & Cinnaberin.

at the end of the dictionary (sig. pp4v) under the 
following note: "Certaine Stones, which were omitted in the generall title of Stones aboue, Col. 1776. after the letter P."

Hæmatites.

at the end of the dictionary (sig. pp4v) under the 
following note: "Certaine Stones, which were omitted in the generall title of Stones aboue, Col. 1776. after the letter P."



A Saphire stone. Sapphirus, m. 
cyanus, m.
The printer supplied this entry (and all others for the letters R, T, and W, 
at the end of the dictionary (sig. pp4v) under the 
following note: "Certaine Stones, which were omitted in the generall title of Stones aboue, Col. 1776. after the letter P."



A darke blewe Saphire.
Cyanus mas.
The printer supplied this entry (and all others for the letters R, T, and W, 
at the end of the dictionary (sig. pp4v) under the 
following note: "Certaine Stones, which were omitted in the generall title of Stones aboue, Col. 1776. after the letter P."

Precious stones.

A precious stone, or gem. 
Gemma, f. lapillus, m.

A precious stone having the co­
lour of Scarus. Scarites, m.

A precious stone like to tallowe
Steatites.

A precious stone in colour like
a figge. Sycites.

A pretious stone of rose colour.
Rhodites.

A pretious stone of the colour of
a hart. Telicardios.

A precious stone called a To­
pace. Topazius, m. & topazium.

A certaine precious stone like
to amber. Xanthenes, vel
zathene.

A precious stone of bright yellow
colour. Xanthos.

a certain precious stone brought
from the Indias. Xistius, m.

A precious stone which the ma­
gicians do vse. zaronysios.

A precious stone called Smarag­
sus. Limoniates, f.

A precious stone which bee­
ing perfumed calleth out all
beastes. Liparis.

A pretious stone of 4 diverse co­
loures. Lycophthalmus.

A precious stone ingendred of the
congealed vrine of the beast lynx
Lyncurium, n.

A pretious stone. Circos.

A precious stone like an Ivie
leafe. Cistites.

A precious stone like to poppie
Mechonites.

A precious stone black, and Ha­
ving veines like the aire: it yel­
deth a sweat like saffron, and a
taste like wine Media, f.

A precious stone which shineth
as it were through pure gold.
Melectris.

A precious stone white on one
side, and like honey on the other
side. Melichoros.

A precious stone of the colour of
an orenge.
Melites.

A precious stone black, having a
white strake in the middle.
Mesoleucus.

A precious stone having a black
veine parting every coloure by
the middest. Mesomelas.

A precious stone very hard by na­
ture. Craterites.

A precious stone like a cherrie.
Crocallis, m.

A precious stone of the colour of
saffron Crocias.

A precious stone, which is called
turquois. Cyanos.

A kind of pretious stones, having
a thick greenishnes, in colour like
to mallowes. Molochites, f.

A precious stone having the co­
loure of a hart.
Mucula, f.

A precious stone having little
knottes like warts.
Myrmecias.

A stone having in it a figure of
an emmot, or pismire.
Myrmecites.

A precious stone, having the co­
lour of myrrhe, and the smell of
ointments. Myrrhites.

A precious stone dedicated to
Liber. Nebrites.

A precious stone falling downe
with showers.
Notia, f.

A precious stone called Iaspo­
nix, white of colour, with red
strakes Onychipuncta, f.

A precious stone having the pro­
pertie of diverse stones.
Opalum, n. opalus, m.

A precious stone of black co­
lour, devided with 2 white lines.
Ophicardulus, m.

a precious stone wholsome against
falling sicknes. Daphnia, f.

A precious stone like a shrub, or
an Ivie bush. Dendrachates.

a precious stone which being put
vnder a tree, maketh that the
axe in cutting it, should not bee
dulled Dendritis, f.

A precious stone, having red
spottes. Dionysias.

A precious stone of 2 sorts, white
and blacke, male and female.
Diphris.

A preciouse stone comming out
of the head of a dragon. draconi­
tes, sive draconitias, m.

A kind of precious stone, called
of some Siderites, Orites, m.

A certaine pretious stone
brickle like a shell, and resem­
bling the Agath. Ostracias, m.

A pretious stone hauing likenes
of frozen water.
Pæantides.

A pretious stone called Opalus,
wherein appeareth the fierie
brightnes of the Carbunckle, the
shining purple colour of the A­
mathist, the greene shewe of the
Emerald, al shining together with
an vnbeleeueable mixture.
Pæderos.

a pretious stone taking away
barennes. Pansebastos.

A pretious stone having divers
spottes like a Panther.
Pardalius, m.

a pretious stone in whitenes next
to the Margaret.
Pedorus, m.

A certain pretious stone, having
a white threed goeing downe
from the mouth even to the roote
Perileucus, m.

A pretious stone wherein a appea­
reth as it were a flame of fier.
Phlegontis, f.

A pretious stone having the co­
lour of Alga. Phycites.

A pretious stone called a Sma­
rage.
Polygrammos.

A pretious stone with many cir­
cles. Polysonus, m.

a pretious stone of darkish green
colour, and somewhat like a vi­
per. Echites.

A pretious stone having in it
the figure of an heart.
Encardia.

A pretious stone having some­
what a blacke colour over it.
Epimelas.

A pretious stone like a flint.
Erotylus.

A pretious stone of foure colours
Eupelatos.

A pretious stone of a fierie colour
Eupetales.

A pretious stone like an Oliue
berrie, called Iudaicus lapis. 
Eureos.

A pretious stone found in an E­
gles nest, which being shaken, see­
meth to haue an other in it.
Gagites.

A pretious stone of white




colour.
1 Galactites.

A pretious stone, having the fi­
gure of two handes chlinched to­
gether.
Gemites, m.

A pretious stone, good to helpe
in travaile.
Gemonides.

A pretious stone like the spawn
of a fishe.
Hammites.

One of the most precious, & sa­
cred stones in Ethiopia, of the co­
lour of gold Hammonis cornu.

A pretious stone procuring pu­
nishment to a mans enemie.
Genianes, f.

A pretious stone of the figure of
the Liver.
Hepatites.

A pretious stone of a fierie red
colour, having the nature of a
looking glasse.
Hephæsites.

a pretious stone of a bright fierie
shining colour.
Hermelion.

A little pretious stone having
divers corners.
Hexecontalithus, m.

A pretious stone of fierie colour.
Hormesion.

A pretious stone having a circle
about it, of the colour of golde.
Horminodes.

A pretious stone of the colour of
a Iacinct.
Sacodios.

A Pretious stone called a Sa­
phire. Sapphirus, m.

Of, or belonging to a Saphire.
Sapphirinus, ad.

A precious stone in Corsica.
Catochites.

A Pretious stone in Cappado­
cia. Catopyrites.

A pretious stone having in it
Mill seede. Cenchrites, æ, etcen­
chrus, m.

A pretious stone, cleare like
Christall. Cepionides.

A pretious stone, full of white
strakes.
Cepites sive cecopacites.

A precious stone of the coloure
of Tile.
Ceramites.

A white pretious stone.
Ceraunia, æ, vel ceraunius la­
pis, qui a fulmine distringitur

A pretious stone, in colour like
to waxe.
Cerites.

A pretious stone like vnto the
torteyse shell.
Chelonitis.

A pretious stone green like gras
Chlorites.

A pretious stone firie by night, 
and pale by day.
Chrysolampis, f.

A pretious stone, like to a Lions
skinne.
Leontius, m.

A pretious stone like the scale of
a fishe.
Lepidotes, m.

A pretious stone all white.
Leucogæa, et leucographia.

A white pretious stone with
strakes of golde.
Leucopetalos.

A pretious stone like a white eye
Leucophthalmos.

A pretious stone like to franken­
cense.
Libanochrus, m.

Pretious stones of a greene co­
lour. Balamites, gemma sub­
viridis.

A certaine pretious stone called
Berill, in fashion sixe square, in
colour like oyle, or water in the
sea. Berullus, m.

A Pretious stone like a clodde.
Bolenia, f.

A pretious stone like to womens
haire.
Bostrychites.

A pretious stone like a Saphire.
Calais, f.

A certaine pretious stone, of the
colour of a Crabbe fishe.
Carcinias, æ, m.

A pretious stone found in an E­
gles nest.
Ætides, Ætites.

Pretious stones, which are light
and haue no points.
Acenteta, acentra.

A pretious stone like glasse.
Acopis.

A pretious stone shining like sil­
ver, being 3 fingers broade.
Atizoes.

A pretious stone called a goates
eye. Aegophthalmus.

A pretious stone, shining like gold
representing the shape of a Rams
horne, and is said to cause true
dreames.
Ammonis cornu.

A pretious stone of the colour of
golde, square, and of the same
nature of the load stone, but that
it is said to drawe golde vnto it
selfe.
Amphitane.

A pretious stone, hard and hea­
vie, bright like silver, & in forme
of divers little squares, it put­
teth away furie of an anger, & rage
of lechery.
Androdomas, antis.

A pretious stone savouring like
Myrrhe.
Antachate.

A pretious stone, wherein see­
meth as it were sparkes of fire.
Anthracites.

A pretious stone and weightie, 
pointed with red veines, and be­
ing once heated in the fier, conti­
nueth hot seven daies.
Apistos, apsictos.

A pretious stone like silver.
Aspilates.




Trees.

A Tree Arbor, m.

A fruitfull tree. Arbor fœlix.

A barren tree.
Arbor infœlix.

A tree bearing fruite twise in
one yeere. Arbor bisera.

A little tree. Arbuscula, f.

A plant of a tree.
Planta, f. plantarium, n.

To cut a tree in long wise, as it
were in planckes.
Arborem in pulpam cædere.

To plant trees in checker wise.
Arbores in quincuncem dige­
rere, vel dirigere.

An arbour, trees wrethed over
head archwise.
Arbuscula topiaria.

The roote of a tree, or herbe
Stirps.

Water shootes  shootes that grow
out of the rootes, or sides of the




stocke, and proue not.
Stolones, soboles.

A shrub, or that which groweth
vp of a young shoote, and riseth
not to the iust bignes of a tree.
Frutex.

Plants, or young setts being remo­
ved after they be set.
Semina, plantæ.

A shoote, young twigge, or sprig
Surculus, m. germen, n. Turio.

A graffe, or science.
Surculus, m. insitum, n. cala­
mus, m.

A graffe cut on both sides to bee
set in the earth. Talea.

To put, or set young plants in
the earth.
Taleas inhumare.

The stem, or main body of a tree.
Caudex, stipes.

The stocke, or stumpe of a tree
without boughes. Truncus, m.

The maine bough, or branch of a 
tree. Ramus, brachium arboris.

A seared, or dead bough cut off, 
and lopt from the tree.
Ramale, n.

A bough, or branch broken, or
pluct away with fruit thervpon
Termes.

The branch of a date tree pulled
from the tree with fruit therupon
Spadix.

A twigge, or rod.
Virga, f. vimen, n.

The barke, or outward rinde of
a tree. Cortex.

The inner pill, or rinde.
Liber, m.

The pith, sappe, or life of the tree.
Medulla arboris, fructus, vel
matrix.

To rid, or cleare a tree of mosse.
Arborem emuscare.

A tree whereof commeth the
gumme called Bdellium. 
Malachra, f.

A tree bringing forth most plea­
sant fruit. Melia.

a great tree called Lotos, & Fa­
ba Syriaca: it bringeth forth a
fruit good to be eaten, bigger then
pepper, and sweet in taste.
Mella, f.

A tree in Africke wherof com­
meth the iuice called Ammoni­
acum. Melosos.

A tree having fruite like A­
drachne, called Pappus.
Corrigria, f.

A tree in Arcadia wherof they
make them garmentes. Cyna, f.

A bush, or tree much like to that
wee cal privet.
Cypus, f.

The bunch of a tree called Acer.
Molluscum, n.

A tree having leaues like Lau­
rel but greater and weaker.
Mustace, f.

An hollow tree, like a ship, which
is vsed in the gathering of grapes
Navia, f.

A tree, or shrub with leaues like
an almond, which some cal Olian­
der, some rosagaine, some roselau­
rel. Nerium, n.

Certain trees like to figge trees.
Ochi.

A tree in Syria out of the bodie
wherof, issueth an oile as thick as
honey, and of a sweet taste.
Oleomella, f.

A tree that beareth the fruit cal­
led Tamarindie.
Oxyphænix.

A great tree like a figge tree
whose fruit commeth not out at
the toppes of the boughes, as figs
do, but out of the middest of the
boughes, and is sweet like a wild
figge it is never ripe, vnlesse it
be scraped with an iron tocle.
Sycomorus, f.

The fruit of the same tree.
Sycomorum, n.

A tree where masticke runneth
out. Schinos.

A tree like white thorne, which
never rotteth. Setim.

A kind of tree growing in Pale­
stine. Sicinnina, vel Sicimina

A certaine tree called of the
Greekes Creatonia. Siliqua, f.

A kind of tree resembling the
date, or palme tree.
Spatha, vel spathe, f.

A tree beyond the Alpes, white, 
bearing siliquas, and therein the
kernell of an hazell nut. Staphy­
lodendros.

A tree whereof perfumes were
made mixed, with the wine of
dates. Strobus.

A kind of tree, where out is ta­
ken the strongest, and best swim­
ming corke. Suberies, f.

Trees growing on the bankes of
rivers, or in the rivers.
Retæ, f.

a kind of tree, the leaues wherof
curriers occupie to thicken lea­
ther. Terginus, vel tergorarius
rhus coriarius.

A tree in Ægipt, called Palma
Christi, which hath a seed like an
onion. Ricinus.

A tree like firre, bearing berries
that are poison.
Taxus.

A tree bearing fruit good for the
stomacke, and to eate.
Persia, f.

A tree first found by king Juba, &
called by the name of his phisiti­
an.
Euphorbia, f. euphorbium, n.

The tree that beareth cotten.
Gossipium, n.

The tree whereof masticke com­
meth. Granomastix, f.

A tree having bitter fruit, that
no beast wil touch it.
Haliphlæus.

A kind of ivie bearing no berries
Helix, f.

A kind of trees bearing mast.
Hemeris, f.

A tree so called, because it was
given to cattel in steed of hearbs
when pasture failed.
Herbitum, n.

a kind of medlar tree, the fruit
whereof hath 3 stones. Epimelis

A tree bearing mast, which no­
thing will eate but swine.
Salsicortex.

A tree bearing mast greater then
al other mast, next the oke, and
hath leaues greater then the oke
Æsculus.

Of that tree. Æsculeus, ad.

The place where it groweth.
Æsculetum, n.

A tree in India, the fruit wher
of is like the hart of a little bird
and hath a iuice red like bloude, 
out of the fruit wherof procedeth
honey. Anacardion, n

A tree in Afrik called Lotes, the
fruit is called Laba. Celtis.

A tree that never beareth fruit
Alaternus, f.

A kind of tree that beareth mast
Cerrus, f.




Of that tree.
Cerrinus, cerreus, ad.

a tree having leaues like the pine
tree, the timber being apt for
building: it will not perish either
by rotting, or eating of worm, nor
burn by flame, nether be brought
to coales, but by long space con­
sume. Larix, f.

A straunge tree, the blossome
whereof bees will not touch.
Alpina, f.

A tree which is taken of some
for the bush, whereof they make
brushes, called ruskines.
Chamæmyrsine, f.

A tree in Arabia, black, of the
bignes of an Oliue tree.
Bdellium, n.

A tree in Ægipt, called Papyrus
the barke whereof made paper, 
and the wood hippes.
Biblos.

A certain tree like to Cypres.
Bruta, f.

A tree of a kinde of gum called
Dragant. Tragacantha.

A tree whereof the wood is good
against the French pockes.
Guajacum.

a kind of ashe medicinable against
