A kinde of Ivie.
Erythranon, chrysocarpum.

A Juniper tree. Iuniperus, f.


L.

Laurell of Alexandria, or tonge
Laurell. Hippoglottion.

A Laurell tree, vi. Bay tree.
 
A Lemon tree. Citrea, f.

A Lentiske, or mastike tree.
Lentiscus, f.

A Lynden, or teyle tree, bearing
fruite like a bean, round & seedes
like to that tree. Tilia, f.

Of, or belonging to that tree.
Tiliaceus, ad.


M.

A Maple tree. Acer, n.

Of a Maple tree. Acernus, ad.

A Mastike tree, v: lentiske tree.
 
Of, or belonging to Masticke.
Lentiscinus, ad.

A Medler tree. Mespilus, f. 
Mespilum, n. Æschisus, f.

A mirre tree. Myrrhus, f.

A Mirtell tree. Myrtus, f. of
which Cato maketh three kindes.
Myrtus Candida, 
Myrtus Nigra, 
Myrtus Conjugalis.

A place where Myrtell is set,
Myrtetum, n.

Tempered with Myrtle.
Myrtatus, ad.

Like Myrtle. Myrtosus, ad.

Of Myrtle. Myrtinus, myrteus.


N.

A Nut tree. Nuclarius, nucus
Nux, f.

A place where Nut trees growe.
Nuclearium, nucetum, n.


O.

An Oake. Quercus, ilix, robur

The place where Oakes growe.
Quercetum, querquetum, n.

Pertaining to an Oake.
Querceus, reboreus, roburne­
us, robusteus, querculanus.

An Oliue tree. Olea, Oliva, Pal­
ladia arbor.

A wilde Oliue tree. Oleaster.

A kinde of Oliue tree.
Piturum, n.

A little wilde Oliue tree.
Oleastellus, f.

The place where Oliues growe.
Olivetum, n.

Of an oliue tree, or of the colour of
an Oliue. Oleagineus, oliva­
ceus, ad.

An Orenge tree.
Malus Medica, 
Malus Citrea.

An Osier, or twig. Vimen, vinci­
men, viburnum, n.

The place where Osiers, and
twigges are set, to binde vines.
Virgetum, n.

Gathering of Osiers. Virginde­
mia, f.

Of Osiers. Viminalis, vimineus
virgeus, ad.


P.

A Peach tree. Malus Persica.

A Peare tree. Pyrus, f.

A Pepper tree. Piperis, f.

A Pine apple, or pine tree. Pi­
nus, pinea, coccalus, strobilus.

The wilde pine, or pine aple
tree.
Pinaster.

The place where pine aple trees
growe. Pinetum, n.

Belonging to a pine tree.
Pineus, ad.

A Pitch tree. Picea, abor pi­
caria, apinus, f.

The wild pitch tree. piceastrum.

The plane tree. Platanus, f.

The place where Plane trees
growe. Platanetum, n.

Of a Plane tree. Plataninus, ad.

A plumme tree. Prunus, f.

A wilde plumme tree.
Spinus, f.

A place set about with plum
trees Prunetum, n.

A little shrub, like the young
shootes, springing out of the plum
tree. Chamæcerasus, f.

A Pomegranate tree.
Malus Punica.

A Poplar tree. Populus, f. 
Farfarum, n.

The white poplar tree.
Farfugium, n. leuce, f.

A place where Poplars growe.
Populetum, n.

Of a poplar tree. Populeus, po­
pulnus, populneus, ad.

Full of Popplars. Populosus, ad.

A Privet, or prune prime tree.
Ligustrum, n.


Q.

A Quince tree. Cydonia, f.

A Quince. Cotoneum, n.

A Quince peare. Cydonium, n.

A yellow quince. chrysomelum


S.

 
A sallowe tree. Salix, f.

A groue of sallowes. Salictum, n

A sabine tree. Sabina, f.

A little tree called Sene Colu­
tea, f.

The fruite of the tree Sene.
Coluteum, n.

A service tree. Sorbus, ois, f.

a place, where Service trees do
growe. Sorbetum, n.

A sloe tree. Prunus silvestris
pruncolus, spinus.

A spindle tree, or pricke timber.
Evonimus, f.


T.

A tamariske tree. Murica, f.

A thorne tree. Spina, f.

A blacke thorne. Spina nigra.

A wilde thorne. Agricantha, f.

The Trifolie tree. Colutea, f.





V.

 
A Vine tree. Vitis, vinea, f.

A little vine. Viticula, f.

A new growen vine.
Malleolus, m. Novelletum, n.

Vines when grapes fall from the
clusters. Cittosis.

A vine running on a frame.
Pergulanus, pergulana vitis.

A wilde vine. Labrusca, f. la­
bruscum, n. taminia vua.

A vine graffed on an Oliue, &
bearing the fruit of both the trees
Eleostaphilos.

Vines that are stayed vp with
trees. Anadendrades.

A vine that is digged.
Bipastinaria, f.

A vine when it is cut Sarpa, f.

A kinde of wilde vines with a
blacke stemme, and a green fruit, 
having, a kernell three cornered.
Scaphis, f.

Vines having long braunches vp
on trayles. Brachiatæ vineæ.

A kinde of vine called Ampe­
loleuce. Archezostis, f.

A vine climing vp, or growing
against trees Vitis arbustiva

An olde vine cut downe, and set
to bring plantes againe.
Propago, f.

A kinde of vines made round, 
like garlands. Stephanitæ vites

A vine called the blacke vine, 
whereof the best wine is made.
Inerticula, f.

A vine growing long and broad
in manner of an orchard gallery.
Vitis compluviata.

A vine layde on poles, which
runne gratewise on forkes.
Vitis Iugata, 
Vitis Cantheriata.

A vine vnderpropped with poles
Vitis Statuminata, 
Vitis Pedata.

A vine planted in order, and set
checkerwise. Vitis ordinaria.

A ranke vine growing wilde.
Vitis luxurians.

a dropping vine. vitis lachrimans

A blasted vine. vitis siderata.

A vine planted with a roote.
Viveradix.

The mother of the vine.
Vinaceus, m. vinacea, f.


W.

A wall-nut tree. 
Iuglans, avellanus, f.

A place where wall nutte trees
growe.
Avellarium, avellanarium, n.

A warden tree. Volemus, f.

A wilding, or crabbe tree.
Arbutus, f.

Of a wilding. Arbuteus, ad.

A willowe tree, called parke
leaues. Agnos, agnus castus, sa­
lix, vitex equina, amerina.

Of willowe. Salignus, saligneus

A place where willowes growe.
Salicetum, salictum, n.

A withie, or osier tree. Siler, n.

A witche tree Opulus, f.


Y.

An Yewe tree. Taxus, smilax, f.

Of Yewe. Taxeus, ad.





Weightes.

Weight, or poise. Momentum, 
pondus, n.

The weight of burdens. Pressus
ponderum.

A little, or small weight.
Pondusculum, n.

A weight of ledde, that leapers, 
vauters, or dauncers on cordes do
holde in their handes, to counter­
poise their owne weight, for the
more certaintie of their exercise
Halter, m.

Standing weight, or even weight
Libramen, libramentum, æ­
quilibrium, æquamentum, æ­
quipondium, n.

Of like weight. Æquilibris, ad.

That is put in the ballaunce to
make even weight. Sacoma.

A little more then weight.
Momentum.

Overweight, or that which is
aboue, or beside weight. Super­
pondium, additamentum, corol­
larium, n. mantissa, accessio, f. 
auctarium, n.

He that is cunning in the know­
ledge of weightes and measures.
Oedastinus, m.

A thing that is very weightie: 
also the weight and greatnes of a
thing. Moles, f.

A paire of weights. Trutina, li­
bra, statera, f.

Gold weights, or ballaunces.
Simbella. 
Trutina Momentanea, 
Trutina Monetaria.

Troy weightes or ballaunces: also
Troy weight. Trutina campana.

The beame of the weights, or bal­
launces. Iugum, n.

The handle of the weights. Ansa.

The tongue, or needle of the
weightes. Examen, n.

The scale of the weights. Lanx.

The box wherin the gold weights
be put. Trytodoche.

A weight, or that whereby any
thing is weighed. Pondus, n.


Ponderum varietas.

A graine the 506, part of an
ounce. Granum, n.

A weight of 2 graines. chalchus

A weight of foure graines. Sili­
qua, siliquus.

A weight of 6 graines. Semio­
bolus, Cerates.

a weight of 8. graines. bissiliqua

A weight of 11. graines, the sixt
parte of Drachma. Obolus.

a weight of 4. graines, being the
third part of a dramme. scrupulus
scrupulum, scripulum, scriptulum.

Pertaining to that weight.
Scrupularis, ad.

A weight being the 8 part of
an ounce, containing 32. graines.
Tremissis.

A weight being the 2. part of a
dram, and containing 36. grains
Lupines. Semidrachma.

A weight which is the 2. parte
of an ounce, and containeth 48
grains. semisextula, faba syriaca

A weight called a dramme, being
the 8. part of an ounce, contai­
ning 72. graines Drachma.

A weight being the 6. part of an
ounce, and containing 96. drams
Sextula, f.

A weight being the 4. part of
an ounce, & containeth 2. drams
Sicilicus, sicilicum, siclus.

A weight being the 3. part of an
ounce, and containeth 2. drams, 
and two third parts of a dramme
that is 2. scruples. Duella.

A weight being halfe an ounce, 
and containeth 4. drammes.
Semuncia, assarion, assarius.

A weight called an ounce, which
is by Troie weight, the twelfth




part of a pound, by haber de poise
weight, the 16. and it contai­
neth of drams, 8. of scruples, 24. 
of graines 576. Vncia, f.

Belonging to that weight.
Vncialis, vnciarius, ad.

A little ownce. Vnciola, f.

An ounce, and a halfe.
Sesquiuncia, sescunx.

Belonging to that weight.
Sesquiuncialis.

Two ounces Sextans.

Of, or belonging to that weight, 
or weighing so much.
Sextantarius, ad.

Three ounces. Quadrans, triunx

A thing that weigheth three
ounces. Triuncium, n.

Weighing three ounces: of, or be­
longing to three ounces.
Triuncis, teruncius, ad.

Four ounces. Triens.

A weight of four ounces among
the Jewes. Schilchi.

Weighing, or belonging to
that weight. Triental, trientalis

Fiue ounces. Quincunx, ad.

Of, or weighing that weight, or
belonging therunto.
Quincuncialis, ad.

Six ounces, or halfe a pound, ac­
cording to the Troy weight.
Semissis selibra, simbella, f.

Of, or weighing that weight, or
belonging therunto. Semissalis

Seven ounces. Septunx.

Of, or weighing that weight, 
or belonging thereunto.
Septuncialis, ad.

Eight ounces. ves, vel bessis, m

Of, or weighing that weight, or
belonging thereunto. Bessalis.

Nine ounces. Dodrans, m.

A thing that weigheth nine
ounces.
Nonuncium, n.

Of, or weighing that weight, or
belonging thereunto.
Dodrantalis, ad.

Ten ounces. Dextans.

Of, or weighing that weight, or
belonging thereunto.
Dextantalis, ad.

Eleven ounces. Deunx.

Of, or weighing so much, or be­
longing thereunto. Deuncius.

Twelue ounces, being by Troy
weight a pound. Libra, f. as, vel
assis, m. Assipondium, n. pon­
do, indecl.

Of, or belonging to that weight, 
or that weigheth so much.
Libralis.

A weight of twelue ounces and
a halfe, being more than the Ro­
mone pound, by foure drames.
Mina, vel nona, f.

A weight containing 16 ounces, 
which is by haber de pou weight
a pound, which commonly all
merchants and occupiers do vse
Zvgostatica libra.

A pound and a halfe weight.
Sesquilibra, xesta, f.

A two pound weight, or the
weight of two pound. Dipondi­
us, dupondius, m. dipondi­
um, n. bilibra, f.

Of that weight, or belonging
thereunto.
Dipondiarius, bilibris, ad.

Three pound weight.
Tripondium, n. trilibra, tressis.

Of, or weighing that weight, or
belonging thereunto. Trilibrsi, 
tripondiarius, ad.

Four pound weight.
Quadrussis.

Weighing 4 pound: or of, or belon­
ging thereunto. Quadrilibris.

Fiue pound weight. Quintussis

Sixe pound weight. Sextussis.

Seven pound weight. Septussis.

Eight pound weight. Octussis.

Nine pound weight.
Nonussis, vel non assis.

Ten pound weight. Decussis.

Twenty pound weight. Vicessis.

Thirty pound weight. Tricessis

Forty pound weight.
Quadricussis.

Fifty pound weight, or halfe an
hundreth. Semicentussis.

Weighting that weight.
Quingentilibralis.

An hundred pound weight.
Centussis.

Weighing fiue hundred pound
weight. Quingenarius.

A thousand pound weight.
Millepondium, n.




Calendarium Romanum nostro collatum Tyronibus Rhetoricu vtilissimum.

Mensis quisque dividitur in Caleudas, Nonas, & ldus: primus mensis, dies vocatur Calendæ, sed ea­
rum ordo continuatur in diebus mensis præcedentis, vt prima dies Februarij, calendæ Februarij di­
cuntur, vltima Ianuarij, pridie Calendas Februarij, tricesima Ianuarij, tertio Calendas Februarij, &
fic numeratim ordine retrogrado, vsque ad diem decimam tertiam, in qua initium habent Idus Ia­
nuarij post primam mensis diem, seu Calendas, sequuntur Nonæ singulis mensibus quaternæ, exceptis
quatuor, Martio, lulio, & Octobri, qui habent sex: subsequuntur Idus, vbique octonæ: reliqui om­
nes dies sunt Calendæ, sed mensis sequentis, à quo denominantur. 

Dies cujuslibet Mensis.

Aprili, Iunio, Septemque, Novemque triginta
Plus alijs vno, viginti Februar Octo. 
Bis binæ reliquis Nonæ, sex Mar. Ma, Iul, Octo. 
Octonæ cunctis anni sunt Mensibus Idus. 
Bis octo. Februar, plus vno Mar, Ma. Iul, Octo. 
Octodecim Aprili, Iunio, septemque, Novemque. 
Plus vno tribus his Ianu. August, atque Decembri. 

Nonæ.
Idus.
Calendæ.

Sed hic Calendæ Mensi ascribuntur, non à quo nomen, sed in quo locum obtinent.

Hos versiculos, si memoria teneas, facile erit quemvis Mensis diem per Calendas, Nonas, & Idus ex­
primere: quæ voces ab authoribus, cum tempus, quo quid factum fuerit, designent, in auferendi casu
vsurpantur, vt Calendis, Nonis, Idibus Ianuarij; pridie Calendas, id est priori die ante Calendas: tertio
Nonas, id est tertio die ante Nonas: quinto Idus, id est, die quinto ante Idus: decimo octavo Calen­
das, id est die decimo octavo ante Calendas.
